title: Newest face of long-term unemployed in US? The college educated
summary:
“Such an increase is unprecedented outside of recessions,” said an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, alluding to a steady worsening of the long-term unemployment rate.
But just as surprising as the rise in long-term unemployment is the subset of workers who are increasingly driving it: the college educated.
The fraction of long-term unemployed people with a college degree has grown from about one-fifth a decade ago to about one-third today, according to government data compiled by Professor Matthew Notowidigdo and Mr Jingzhou Huang of the University of Chicago.
There are simply more college graduates today than there were 10 years ago, and the job market for people without college degrees has improved, reducing their share of long-term unemployed.
“The data is signalling that there’s some restructuring going on,” said Professor Andreas Mueller, an expert on long-term unemployment at the University of Zurich.

title: Elon Musk buys $1.3 billion worth of Tesla shares, sending stock up for 2025
summary:
– Mr Elon Musk responded to an unprecedented pay proposal from Tesla’s board by buying about US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion) worth of shares, sending the carmaker’s stock soaring into positive territory for 2025.
Mr Musk, 54, last bought Tesla stock in the open market in February 2020, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Tesla shares currently trade at about 186 times forward 12-month earnings, compared with the S&P 500’s average of 23 times.
The following day, Mr Musk made a remote appearance at a London march organised by the far-right agitator known as Tommy Robinson.
Mr Musk is the world’s richest person, with a net worth of about US$419 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

title: China says Nvidia broke anti-monopoly laws, straining trade talks
summary:
– China ruled that Nvidia violated anti-monopoly laws with a high-profile 2020 deal, ratcheting up the pressure on Washington during sensitive trade negotiations.
The Chinese agency did not specify what remedies it would seek from Nvidia, adding that it will investigate the company further.
Beijing gave approval for the US$7 billion (S$9 billion) acquisition deal four years ago, on the condition that Nvidia not discriminate against Chinese companies.
The US government then implemented regulations that banned Nvidia from selling its most advanced AI chips to Chinese companies, including the H100, because of what it called national security concerns.
Nvidia redesigned its chips at least twice, so they would comply with US regulations and could be sold in the country.

title: Thailand said to weigh tax on gold trades to slow baht rally
summary:
Thai authorities are considering a tax on physical gold trading to slow a rally in the nation’s currency that has threatened exports and tourism.
– The Thai authorities are considering a tax on physical gold trading to slow a rally in the nation’s currency that has threatened exports and tourism.
The Bank of Thailand (BOT) and the Finance Ministry are discussing ways to tax gold bought and sold through various online channels and settled in baht, according to people familiar with the matter.
He also pledged to act on any irregularities in the recent surge in gold exports, including shipments to Cambodia.
A stronger baht is hurting Thai exports and tourism, which together account for 70 per cent of the nation’s gross domestic product.

title: US stocks close higher ahead of Fed meeting; Tesla and Alphabet rally
summary:

Tesla shares climbed 3.6 per cent after regulatory filings revealed CEO Elon Musk had acquired nearly US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion) worth of the electric vehicle maker’s stock on Sept 12.
And Google parent Alphabet hit a record high and raced past US$3 trillion in market capitalisation.
Tesla’s gains boosted the S&P 500 consumer discretionary sector 1.1 per cent to its highest level in nearly nine months.
The S&P 500 posted 23 new 52-week highs and 11 new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 117 new highs and 66 new lows.

title: EDB, food science, nutrition, health, food technology
summary:

Mr Lindeboom declined to state the cost of the laboratory, but said the Singapore facility is its single biggest investment.
Singapore has been the organisation’s regional base and its only development centre outside the Netherlands since 2011.
The 33-year-old Singaporean, who is trained in food science and technology, said her goal now is to successfully commercialise concepts born out of the laboratory within the next two years.

title: STI edges down 0.1%, going against regional trend; Hongkong Land is top gainer
summary:
SINGAPORE - The Straits Times Index (STI) inched lower on Sept 15, going against regional indexes.
The STI closed down 0.1 per cent or 5.82 points to 4,338.42.
Hongkong Land was the top gainer on the STI, closing up 3 per cent or 19 US cents at US$6.61.
DBS Bank closed down 0.8 per cent at $51.40, UOB dropped 0.1 per cent to $35.26, while OCBC Bank closed 0.2 per cent lower at $16.82.
The rate cut is largely anticipated and discounted, and should not come as a surprise to the markets.

title: ST Engineering raises capacity for aircraft engine maintenance and repairs in aerospace hub boost
summary:
SINGAPORE - ST Engineering has opened a new facility for aircraft engine maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) services, as Singapore looks to strengthen its position as an aerospace hub.
ST Engineering says the expansion will progressively double the company’s capacity for maintenance of CFM56 and Leap engines to over 300 engines annually by 2027.
Together with its engine MRO facility in Xiamen, China, its capacity will increase to over 400 engines a year.
Its portfolio has expanded over the last few decades and today, its engine MRO business serves about 50 airlines.
According to management consulting firm Oliver Wyman, the global MRO business is expected to reach US$119 billion (S$152.6 billion) in 2025 , and projected to hit US$156 billion by 2035.

title: Citi names Lee Lung-Nien as Singapore country head; first local to hold role in 50 years
summary:
SINGAPORE - Citi has appointed Mr Lee Lung-Nien as its Singapore country officer and banking head – its most senior position in the city state.
A banking veteran, Mr Lee has been with Citi for 35 years.
Upon stepping into the new role, Mr Lee will oversee all Citi businesses and operations in Singapore, the bank said.
Mr Lee will report to Mr Amol Gupte, Citi’s head of Asia South cluster.
Throughout his career, Mr Lee has taken on leadership roles, such as that of chief executive of Citibank in Malaysia, Citi said.

title: PSA Singapore inks Tuas Port warehousing and logistics deal with shipping giant Cosco
summary:
SINGAPORE – PSA Singapore and Chinese shipping line Cosco have agreed to collaborate on warehousing and logistics at a new facility in Singapore’s new mega port in Tuas.
The PSA Supply Chain Hub @ Tuas (PSCH), located within Tuas Port and the adjacent Tuas Free Trade Zone, is slated to start operations in 2027, said PSA, which operates the world’s largest container transshipment hub in Singapore.
A memorandum of understanding was signed on Sept 15 between Goldlead Supply Chain Development (Southeast Asia), a joint venture between Cosco Shipping Holdings and Cosco Shipping International (Singapore), and PSA.
PSA said the tie-up with Cosco builds on their long partnership and takes it beyond container port operations into full supply chain services.
In 2024, Singapore’s port terminals handled a record 622.67 million tonnes of cargo and 40.9 million TEUs , with bunker sales reaching a record 54.92 million tonnes.

title: Investors must take greater responsibility for their investment decisions: SGX chairman
summary:
We can be bold in entrepreneurship, not just in our start-ups but (also) in our policy thinking,” Mr Koh said.
Being the first mover is crucial in capital markets, Mr Koh said.
Trade sales alone will not fulfil this role.”The SGX Group is well placed to meet their needs, so long as it is supported by an enabling policy framework.
Said Mr Koh: “A few may list on the largest global exchanges, while the rest will require a different venue and solution.
A healthy, vibrant capital market must serve not only the exceptional few but (also) the promising many.

title: SGX chief Loh Boon Chye’s annual pay rose 3.3% to $7.8 million
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe bulk of Mr Loh Boon Chye's pay package came from a cash bonus and long-term incentives, totalling $6.5 million.
SINGAPORE – Singapore Exchange (SGX) chief executive Loh Boon Chye’s total gross remuneration grew to $7.82 million for financial year (FY) 2025 on the back of the bourse’s strong financial results.
This was about 3.3 per cent higher than the $7.57 million he received in FY2024, according to SGX’s annual report released on Sept 15.
But he also received a cash bonus of $3.27 million and $3.27 million in long-term incentives such as performance shares that were aligned with the company’s long-term results.
SGX shares closed 2.9 per cent higher, or 48 cents, to $17.05 on Sept 15.

title: BYD’s $58 billion stock wipeout raises doubts over China outlook
summary:
- BYD faces pressure to restore investor confidence after a US$45 billion (S$58 billion) stock sell-off, with growing concerns over its ability to fend off competition amid a destructive price war in China.
BYD now expects to deliver 4.6 million vehicles in 2025, a steep drop from its earlier target of 5.5 million.
The unveiling of new models in the first quarter of 2026 will be a key stock catalyst for BYD, market watchers say.
Despite its domestic challenges, BYD has been making strong inroads abroad, thanks to more product launches and increased localised production.
All eyes will be on the company’s upcoming domestic product launches, with features in focus as well as pricing strategy.

title: Fading Labubu frenzy wipes $16.7 billion from Pop Mart shares
summary:
– The cooling frenzy over Labubu dolls has brought one of the world’s biggest stock rallies to a halt, erasing billions of dollars from the value of Pop Mart International Group.
The Wall Street bank’s downgrade comes amid signs that the hype surrounding Pop Mart’s designer toys is fading.
Pop Mart’s stock too is witnessing a sharp draw-down, having lost almost US$13 billion (S$16.7 billion) – or roughly a quarter of its value – since reaching a record on Aug 26.
Pop Mart’s shares are trading at nearly 23 times their 12-month forward earnings estimate.
Pop Mart is planning to release animation and a new version of Labubu before Christmas and is also seeking to launch interactive toys, JPMorgan analysts noted.

title: China’s economy posts another sharp slowdown as investment slumps
summary:
China’s economic activity slowed more than expected across the board in August with a sharp slump in investment.
Industrial output and consumption had their worst month yet in 2025 after a sharp slowdown in July.
The data “confirms a sharp slowdown in the second half of 2025, especially on the investment side,” said Mr Carlos Casanova, senior Asia economist at Union Bancaire Privee in Hong Kong.
China’s investment in August contracted sharply in a number of industries, such as the manufacturing of pharmaceuticals, machinery and raw chemicals, as well as in education and healthcare.
Another source of pressure for the economy is the government’s “anti-involution” campaign that aims to ease overcapacity and excessive competition among firms.

title: Jardine C&C units to acquire Indonesian gold mining company for $693 million
summary:
Both DTN and EPN are wholly owned subsidiaries of construction machinery and mining company United Tractors, which is listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX).
Jardine C&C said the proposed acquisition aims to expand United Tractors’ business in the mineral sector.
It is intended to be a gold mining company and holds a mining business for the 4,000ha Doup mining block in the province of North Sulawesi, Indonesia.
Its sole asset is the licence for the block, which is a brownfield site to be developed by United Tractors.
DTN acts as a holding company for United Tractors’ mineral business and is currently focused on expanding its business in gold and nickel.

title: Fed expected to cut rates this week as divisions grow amid heavy Trump pressure
summary:
A cut this week, however, will not necessarily set the Fed on a smooth glide path to lower rates.
Divisions among Fed officials over what to do next could result in multiple dissents, with some favouring no rate cut and others calling for a larger move.
Mr Trump, who has been putting pressure for months on Fed chair Jerome Powell to cut rates and repeatedly called on him to resign, predicted a “big cut” this week.
“I think you have a big cut,” Mr Trump told reporters on Sept 14 on his way back to Washington.
A rate cut this week would nonetheless pull policymakers off the sidelines, where they have been all year.

title: Australia’s ANZ bank hit with record $205m fine over ‘widespread misconduct’
summary:
SYDNEY – Australia’s ANZ has agreed to pay a record fine of A$240 million (S$204.7 million) over “widespread misconduct”, the financial regulator said Sept 15.
The fine is the largest ever announced by the regulator against a single entity, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) said.
“Time and time again ANZ betrayed the trust of Australians,” Mr Joe Longo, chair of the ASIC, said.
“In the bond trading case, ANZ was in a trusted position and its conduct had the potential to reduce the amount of funding available to the government.
Beyond bond trading, the violations revealed widespread customer service failures.

title: Apple delays release of new iPhone Air in mainland China
summary:

The company’s website has also added that other carriers like China Mobile and China Telecom would eventually support the iPhone Air and eSIM.
Apple’s other new iPhones – the iPhone 17, 17 Pro and 17 Pro Max – launched as planned in the region and include physical SIM cards locally.
New orders now arriving later include the 17 Pro Max in both silver and orange in all storage capacities, as well as some blue iPhone 17 Pro Max configurations.
The iPhone Air, the smaller 17 Pro and the standard iPhone 17 did not show any substantial US delays hours after pre-orders opened, though the cloud white Air model is now arriving between the end of September and early October.

title: Aerospace advancements create jobs that ‘Singaporeans will want to take up’: EDB vice-president
summary:
SINGAPORE – Technological progress in aerospace is creating attractive jobs, but also increasing the need for upskilling, said panellists in a Sept 3 roundtable organised by The Business Times and presented by aircraft engine manufacturer and system provider GE Aerospace.
Singapore’s aerospace industry has seen strong employment growth, with nearly 3,000 jobs created between 2021 and 2023, and some 2,500 more expected in the next three to five years.
The industry is a leading adopter of technologies, said Economic Development Board (EDB) vice-president of mobility and industrial solutions Zheng Jingxin.
Such new technologies not only help companies become more competitive, but also “create jobs that Singaporeans will want to take up”, he said at the roundtable, themed Advancing MRO for a Resilient Aerospace Industry in Asia-Pacific.
GE Aerospace also has its own talent development efforts, he added.

title: Apac aviation boom presents ‘tremendous opportunity’ for maintenance, repair and overhaul
summary:

SINGAPORE – The strong growth of the Asia-Pacific’s (Apac) aviation sector “presents tremendous opportunity” for the region’s maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) industry, said Mr Nakul Gupta, GE Aerospace vice-president of sales and general manager for the Asia-Pacific.
“All this growth in Apac presents tremendous opportunity, but also a great responsibility for all of us in the industry to ensure aviation remains safe, efficient, reliable, and advances the industry’s sustainability goals,” Mr Gupta said.
The MRO industry helps to ensure the safety, efficiency and reliability of flights.
Driving innovation and collaborationGE Aerospace’s engines power three out of every four flights in the world, said Mr Gupta.

title: SGX climbs as efforts continue to strengthen stock market; DBS flirts with $53 mark

Shares of SGX, a component stock of the STI, rose 1.2 per cent through the week, closing Sept 12 at a high of $16.57.
Shares of Singapore’s largest bank rose to a high of $52.90 on Sept 11 , falling just shy of the $53 mark.
Some 249 million shares will be offered to institutional investors under a placement tranche, while 13.2 million shares will be offered to the Singapore public.
The company’s placement of 30 million shares, priced at 20 cents each , was fully subscribed, raising $6 million.

US investment firm KKR & Co is expected to complete a $6.4 billion acquisition of the company in the coming weeks.
More deals of this size are expected, particularly in the digital infrastructure, banking and renewable energy spaces, for the rest of 2025 and in 2026, experts said.
Consolidation of healthcare services in hospitals and specialist care is already gaining traction, with growing interest in both domestic and outbound deals.
Experts also expect more M&A deals by Singapore companies acquiring overseas infrastructure and green energy assets, with sovereign funds set to play an increasingly active role.

title: Brookfield in talks to buy Yes! Communities from Singapore’s GIC in $12.8 billion deal: FT report

Communities from Singapore’s GIC in a deal valued at more than US$10 billion (S$12.8 billion), the Financial Times (FT) reported on Sept 14.

was exploring an initial public offering that could raise US$1 billion or more in 2025.

title: SingPost launches new parcel service to US to comply with tariff changes on postal shipments
summary:
Starting on Sept 15, the new service comes following changes on Aug 29 to US tariffs, which removed the “de minimis” exemption for postal shipments to the US worth less than US$800 (S$1,026).
SingPost said it suspended standard postal services for commercial items to the US on Aug 25 to protect customers from potential delays or parcel seizure.
It added that the traditional post system is not equipped to handle the changes, which subject all commercial items to duties, taxes and enhanced scrutiny.
The change has caused turmoil among postal services around the world.
More than 30 countries suspended shipments to the US in August before gradually resuming them with a “postal delivery duties paid” service – which postal services have typically not done before.

title: They had money problems. They turned to ChatGPT for solutions

Each day, within the same chat, she asked ChatGPT for a new task to help her raise money, and she did each one.
Budgeting for milestonesPeople looking for financial advice feel most comfortable asking chatbots about budgeting and tracking expenses, according to a survey by Empower, a financial services company.

title: Eyeing overseas job exposure? How to set yourself up to thrive abroad
summary:
SINGAPORE – Once regarded as a luxury, overseas exposure for local talent is fast becoming a key way to hedge and thrive in a tough job market, in an upended global trade regime.
There are signs that young Singapore workers are keen to rise to the challenge.
Not everyone sets out wanting a pathway to overseas stints, whether long-term postings or work travel based out of Singapore.
Still, you can start by basing your job search on some simple principles, if you feel inclined to work abroad.
Ambitious local small and medium-sized enterprises in sectors like chemicals, energy and manufacturing are starting to ramp up their overseas job offerings too.

title: US stocks mixed as investors look forward to Fed meeting

The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 per cent to 45,834.22, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index was flat at 6,584.29.
“It really is all about the Fed” next week, said Mr Christopher Low, of FHN Financial.

title: Should Tesla’s shareholders green-light Elon Musk’s US$1 trillion performance package?

title: Commercial property owners will get to vote on joining scheme to rejuvenate districts in S’pore
summary:
SINGAPORE – Commercial property owners in some areas will get the chance to vote on whether to join a scheme to liven up their districts.
Under the pilot BID programme, commercial property owners and businesses take collective ownership of the precincts they operate in by pooling funds for marketing, hospitality and events.
The plan is for commercial property owners to propose a suitable BID boundary and fee arrangement with stakeholders before taking it to a vote.
Singapore River One (SRO), which organised the Singapore River Festival, is the URA’s first pilot BID.
Businesses in the Boat Quay and Clarke Quay area can also apply for extension of liquor licences till 4am on Thursdays and Fridays.

title: Singapore stocks fall amid regional gains; STI down 0.3%

The Nikkei 225 rose 0.9 per cent, the Hang Seng Index 1.2 per cent, the Kospi Composite Index 1.5 per cent, and the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI 1.1 per cent.

title: UK economy stalls in July as headwinds grow
summary:
Gross domestic product (GDP) was unchanged over the month, a slowdown from the 0.4 per cent growth in June, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Sept 12.
Private-sector economists expect a more pedestrian growth rate in the second half, though Britain is nonetheless expected to grow faster than its major European peers.
GDP increased 0.2 per cent in the three months through July, suggesting that momentum in the economy has eased.
“Growth in the economy as a whole continued to slow over the last three months,” said Ms Liz McKeown, ONS director of economic statistics.
The economy still faces multiple headwinds, including sticky inflation, elevated interest rates and deep caution among households.

title: China gives Mexico stiff warning over tariffs seen appeasing US
summary:

Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum, who is preparing for talks on North America’s free trade deal, later insisted she does not seek conflict with China but instead wants to protect domestic industry.
China’s exports to Mexico have nearly doubled since 2016, the year before Mr Trump started his first term in office, in part because Chinese companies moved operations there to avoid tariffs.
The biggest producer of copper in Mexico is US-based Southern Copper, a part of Mexican billionaire German Larrea’s Grupo Mexico.

title: Wealth, jobs sparked local anger in US state before raid on Hyundai plant

title: OpenAI, Nvidia CEOs set to announce UK data centre investments in the billions of dollars
summary:
San Francisco – The leaders of OpenAI and Nvidia plan to pledge support for billions of dollars in UK data centre investments when they head to the country next week at the same time as US President Donald Trump, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
The two companies are teaming up with London-based data centre business Nscale Global Holdings on the project, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the deliberations are private.

title: CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit’s public offer in China IPO is 535 times subscribed

title: Microsoft, OpenAI reach non-binding deal to allow ChatGPT maker to restructure
summary:
