As at Aug 8, Keppel shares have climbed 25.4 per cent to date in 2025, outpacing the 11.9 per cent rise in the Straits Times Index, LSEG data showed.

title: Palantir’s 2,500% stock rally has bulls scrambling to justify valuation
summary:
Trading at 245 times forward earnings, it is the most richly valued company in the S&P 500 Index.
By comparison, chipmaker Nvidia, another big gainer, trades at just 35 times forward earnings.
Valuation is also a sticking point for Mr Gil Luria, managing director and head of technology research at DA Davidson.
Mr Luria praised Palantir’s quarterly results and called it “the best story in all of software” in a recent note.
Online streamer Netflix, for instance, traded north of 280 times forward earnings at a 2015 peak, and now stands at a forward price-to-earnings of 40.

title: Former EDB chairman Philip Yeo to join new corporate governance body
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMr Philip Yeo’s role at a new corporate governance body, currently being set up by NUS accounting professor Mak Yuen Teen, has not been decided yet.
SINGAPORE – The former chairman of the Economic Development Board (EDB), Mr Philip Yeo, will be joining a new corporate governance body that is in the midst of being set up by corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen, who is also an accounting professor at the NUS Business School.
Besides Mr Yeo, Professor Mak has roped in former Bursa Malaysia chairwoman Shireen Muhiudeen and First Resources independent director Mary Yeo.
Focus on governance, directorshipProf Mak first made known that he was setting up a new corporate governance body in a LinkedIn post on Aug 1, and called for “directors, aspiring directors and governance professionals who are sick of double standards and not walking the talk” to be part of the new body that “will uphold high corporate governance standards”.
He said the new body will focus on governance and directorship, and added that he has already developed a draft Constitution and is working on establishing a code of conduct and a corporate governance policy.

title: Nvidia, AMD to pay 15% of China chip sale revenues to US in unusual move
summary:
AMD will deliver the same share from MI308 chip revenues, the person added, asking for anonymity to discuss internal deliberations.
It also said it had been unable to take in US$2.5 billion of H20 China revenue in that period because of the new rules.
That implies it would have got more than US$7 billion in H20 sales to China during the period.
AMD could generate US$3 billion to US$5 billion of 2025 revenue if restrictions were lifted, Morgan Stanley estimated.
“But the complication is China’s accusations about H20 chips containing backdoors, which could be a negotiation tactic to highlight that the country is not ‘hard up’ for US chips.” BLOOMBERG

title: Singapore can deliver and thrive in a fragmented global economy: Morgan Stanley analysts
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe analysts say Singapore has a proven track record of adapting to a changing global economic environment.
He believes that Singapore has a proven track record of making policies needed to adapt to a changing global economic environment.
Singapore is also the world’s third-largest foreign exchange (FX) trading hub after London and New York, and the biggest in the Asia-Pacific.
The Morgan Stanley analysts do recognise the risks that can hinder Singapore’s progress on these initiatives, but they believe its proactive policymaking will keep it a step ahead of others.
On Aug 4, it launched an Economic Strategy Review (ESR) to help ensure Singapore thrives in the new global economic landscape.

title: DBS shares hit $50 record after 1% rise in Q2 profit; some analysts think stock could hit $57
summary:
The stock hit an all-time high of $50.98 on Aug 8 before closing at $50.74, up 6.7 per cent through the week.
UOB declared an interim dividend of 85 cents a share for the half-year, down from 88 cents a year ago.
Shares of UOB closed on Aug 8 at $35.70, down by more than 1 per cent through the week.
The other STI company to report strong results last week was the Singapore Exchange (SGX).
Despite the strong results and firmer outlook, SGX shares closed the week flat at $16.02.

title: China’s consumer inflation unchanged amid anti-price war campaign
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox– China’s consumer prices held steady in July as deflationary pressures eased on the back of a government pledge to contain excessive competition.
The consumer price index was unchanged from a year earlier, said the National Bureau of Statistics on Aug 9.
Factory deflation persisted into a 34th month, with the producer price index falling 3.6 per cent, matching June’s decline.
Price wars are intensifying deflationary pressures in China, where consumer demand remains fragile.
The government has launched a campaign to curb the cut-throat competition among businesses that has eroded profits and driven down wages in the world’s second-biggest economy .

title: Traders flee stocks feared to be under threat from AI
summary:
The trio are part of a basket of 26 companies Bank of America strategists identified as most at risk from AI.
But with tech giants like Microsoft and Meta Platforms pouring hundreds of billions into AI, investors have started to get more defensive.
To many tech- industry watchers, the time is nearing when AI becomes so pervasive that companies start going out of business.
The stock has roughly doubled over the past year – but concerns linger that the next generation of AI will be a threat.
Much of that is funding the build-out of AI infrastructure, which is benefiting companies like Nvidia , whose chips dominate the market for AI computing .

title: Bessent leads broad search for US Fed chair that includes Bullard, Sumerlin
summary:
Mr Trump has pressured Mr Powell all year to cut interest rates, building on his past comments critical of the Fed chief that emerged during his first term as president shortly after he elevated Mr Powell to the Fed chair role.
Critics have said the President should let Mr Powell complete his term as chairman without interference.
Mr Hassett, Mr Warsh and Mr Waller have all signalled support for lower rates, which Mr Trump had indicated would be a requirement for the job.
Mr Bullard, who left the St Louis Fed in 2024 to be dean of Purdue University’s business school, was Mr Waller’s boss before Mr Trump plucked the regional Fed’s research director from under Mr Bullard to serve on the Fed Board.
Mr Trump has indicated that a search continues for someone who could fill the Fed Board role for a 14-year term beginning on Feb 1, 2026.

title: Are you set to retire comfortably in Singapore?
summary:
A comprehensive insurance plan covering critical illness and long-term care is crucial, says Mr Harpreet Bindra, chief executive of HSBC Life Singapore.
For others, it could simply mean covering essential financial needs without worry,” says Mr Bindra.
Buying life insurance in your 50s may not be the best choice if you have no dependants or debt, says Ms Hadikusuma.
If these payments are likely to strain your retirement income, consider adjusting the coverage amount, which may lower the premium payments, Ms Hadikusuma says.
For both protection and health insurance, the critical consideration is premium sustainability – ensuring you can afford the premiums comfortably during retirement.

title: Trump’s US Fed pick wanted to upend its protection from politics
summary:
Dr Stephen Miran - nominated to the Board of Governors of the US Fed by President Trump - would like to radically overhaul the institution.
Instead of a system insulated from politics it would be a system fully infused with it, but in a form of “monetary federalism” Dr Miran argues would increase accountability.
To Dr Miran, the current set-up at the Fed has merely excused what he regards as poor performance.
The most fundamental changes Dr Miran proposed would take an act of Congress, and are considered unlikely.
But all of that stops short of what Dr Miran envisions, including stripping the Fed of its autonomous budget authority and making that part of the congressional appropriations process.

title: Nasdaq ends at record high as US stocks post solid weekly gains
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in New York City.
NEW YORK - The Nasdaq posted a second straight record on Aug 8 as US equities concluded a winning week on an upbeat note amid optimism over artificial intelligence and less uncertainty over trade policy.
All three major indices finished solidly higher, with the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index up 1 per cent at 21,450.02, its second all-time closing high in a row.
Apple, which pledged increased US investment at a White House meeting this week, rose significantly for the third straight day with 4.2 per cent gain.
Among other names, Expedia rose 4.1 per cent as the travel company lifted its annual earnings and revenue projections.

title: Trump fires IRS commissioner, Treasury Secretary Bessent named acting head
summary:
A gregarious and colourful personality, Mr Long had tried to cultivate a connection with the depleted and demoralised IRS workforce.
That way you’ll be rested for my 70th birthday on Monday!” Mr Long wrote to staff on Aug 7, a Thursday.
Mr Long wrote on social media that he would be nominated to become the next US ambassador to Iceland.
Others added that the Trump administration officials had been considering moving Mr Long to a new position for several weeks.
Before he left, Mr Long amplified a post on social media about the need to “purge” the agency’s workforce.

title: IPO for Centurion’s new Reit at ‘very advanced’ stage; launch likely in September
summary:
At the group’s results briefing on Aug 8, Mr Kong said the upcoming IPO was at a “very advanced stage”, though the group has yet to receive its eligibility-to-list letter from the Singapore Exchange.
He added that Centurion was “quite committed” to the trust, named Centurion Accommodation Reit, and will have “quite a high stake” in it.
That is not to say Centurion will be divesting more assets; instead, the aim is to expand its portfolio and assets under management, noted Mr Kong.
Mr Kong said Centurion’s Malaysia assets will not be included in the Reit, given the emerging market risk, but that the listco will continue expanding its portfolio in the country.
“We are pretty confident that this is only short-term headwinds.”In terms of asset class, Mr Kong said the Reit will lean heavily towards PBWA assets.

title: Extraordinary climb for DBS with flurry of upgrades after share price hit $50
summary:
SINGAPORE – DBS Bank shares continued their bull run on Aug 8 to close at a record high on the back of a flurry of analyst upgrades sparked by the bank’s stellar latest earnings.
The board declared an ordinary dividend of 60 cents a share for the quarter and a capital return dividend of 15 cents a share.
Goldman Sachs is keeping its buy call on DBS, and has revised the 12-month target price from $54.50 to $57.20.
Citi is raising its target price on DBS from $48.85 to $56.50, despite the latter trading at a significantly higher price-to-book multiple compared with rivals OCBC Bank and UOB.
Mr Thilan Wickramasinghe, head of research at Maybank Securities, has upgraded his call on DBS from a hold to a buy and raised the target price from $45.26 to $56.15.

title: Singapore stocks end in the red amid geopolitical uncertainties; STI down 0.4%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe wary mood sent the Straits Times Index down 0.4 per cent or 18.32 points to 4,239.83.
SINGAPORE – The local share rally went slightly off the rails on Aug 8 as investors took stock of geopolitical uncertainties and looked ahead to corporate results.
Earnings reports took centre stage over broader themes such as tariffs and interest rates, said Singapore Exchange market strategist Geoff Howie.
He noted that most of this week’s top contributors were tech or internet stocks, suggesting that markets remain driven by artificial intelligence trends.
This may be reflected in the US market as well, given some of the robust earnings growth of US tech giants.

title: Singapore’s digital banks trim deposit rates, mirroring moves by incumbent players
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDigital banks said that they are adjusting their deposit rates according to market conditions.
SINGAPORE – Digital banks serving retail customers here have been trimming deposit interest rates in line with traditional lenders.
Fintech industry analyst Zennon Kapron said digital banks must ensure customers are happy with the user experience in the face of declining deposit rates.
Mr Tamma Febrian, director of the financial institutions group at Fitch Ratings Singapore, said digital banks can offer appealing options.
GXS has rolled out a digital investment platform for account holders looking to extract more yield on their spare cash.

title: Gold prices jump after US said to add surprise gold bar tariffs in blow to Switzerland
summary:
– The US has put tariffs on imports of 1kg gold bars, according to the Financial Times, threatening more turmoil in the global bullion market and dealing another trade blow to Switzerland.
US gold futures hit a record high after the FT report.
Spot gold edged up 0.1 per cent to US$3,400 an ounce, while gold futures rose as much as 2.3 per cent to an all-time peak of US$3,477.
Contracts for December delivery in New York jumped to a premium of more than US$100 an ounce above the global benchmark for spot prices in London.
One-kilogram gold bars are the most common form traded on Comex, the world’s largest gold futures market, and comprise the bulk of Switzerland’s bullion exports to the US, the FT said.

title: SoftBank shares surge to record on AI-fuelled profit recovery
summary:
– SoftBank Group’s shares surged to a record after it swung to a quarterly profit, an affirmation for Mr Masayoshi Son’s bets on artificial intelligence (AI) players such as Nvidia.
It reported net income of 421.82 billion yen (S$3.7 billion) in its fiscal first quarter, more than double the average of analyst estimates.
The Vision Fund logged a 451.39 billion yen profit, helped by a recovery in tech valuations and gains on holdings such as Coupang, Auto1 Group and Symbotic.
That Stargate push has been somewhat delayed, chief financial officer Yoshimitsu Goto said, conceding for the first time that the US$500 billion AI tie-up with OpenAI was behind schedule.
The company has been selling off assets ahead of such mega-projects and deals, as the fair value of the Vision Fund portfolio rose US$4.8 billion from the prior quarter.

title: Indebted HK developer New World in talks with CapitaLand, Blackstone for asset sales: Sources
summary:
Blackstone has been in discussions with New World to buy some of its assets.
Singapore property company CapitaLand also engaged with New World for exploratory discussions in recent weeks, the people added.
Controlled by Hong Kong’s Cheng family, New World carries the heaviest debt burden among major developers in the city, amid a prolonged real estate downturn in the financial hub and China.
New World said on Aug 7 that no share offers were given to the company by anyone, including the controlling shareholder of New World and Blackstone.
The Cheng family also owns a stake in Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group, led by Mr Adrian Cheng’s sister Sonia.

title: Sembcorp first-half profit dips 1%; shares tumble nearly 14%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Sembcorp Energy Storage System site in Banyan on Jurong Island.
SINGAPORE – Sembcorp Industries posted a net profit of $536 million for the half-year ended June 30, down 1 per cent from the same period a year ago, on lower gas contributions.
Sembcorp shares closed at $6.72, down 13.9 per cent or $1.08, on Aug 8.
Sembcorp booked a $95 million DPN forex loss for the half-year, compared with a $46 million gain for the same period in 2024.
Sembcorp group chief executive Wong Kim Yin said the company delivered resilient results for the half-year despite macroeconomic uncertainties.

title: Latest Astrea bonds over 3 times subscribed, draw more than $3.4 billion in demand
summary:
SINGAPORE – Investor demand has surged for the latest Astrea private equity (PE) bonds, with total subscriptions surpassing $3.4 billion across all three classes – 3.4 times the US$780 million (S$1 billion) issued under the public and placement tranches.
Public offers for Class A-1 and Class A-2 bonds alone drew more than $1.5 billion in valid applications – 3.5 times the combined $380 million and US$50 million offered.
To meet growing demand from individual investors, Azalea increased the retail tranche for Astrea 9 by 37 per cent compared with the previous issuance, Astrea 8.
For the Singapore dollar-denominated Class A-1 bonds, Azalea received $1.2 billion in valid applications from 34,969 applicants, with more than 82 per cent of the bonds allocated to those who applied for $50,000 or less.
More retail engagement is planned through its annual Astrea Investor Day.

title: Inaugural Singapore Retail Festival from Sept 26 to Oct 12 aims to boost local shopping scene
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe festival will focus on experiential retail cencepts, meaningful consumer engagements, and innovation.
SINGAPORE - The inaugural Singapore Retail Festival (SRF) will be held in September and October, coinciding with the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix, to showcase the Republic as a shopping destination to the world.
The festival, which will take place annually, will be held across the island, from Sept 26 to Oct 12, said the Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) in a statement on Aug 5.
Mr Sing said the festival will focus on “value beyond price and emphasising experiential retail, meaningful consumer engagements, and innovation”.
It is widely acknowledged that the retail industry has been experiencing a challenging time, clouded by economic uncertainties and shifts in consumer behaviour, said Mr Sing.

title: SGX says over 30 companies in its IPO pipeline, eyes more acquisitions
summary:
SINGAPORE – The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has more than 30 companies in its pipeline of initial public offerings (IPOs) that have already hired advisers and started preparatory listing work.
More are still contemplating going public in Singapore, SGX head of global sales and origination Pol de Win disclosed at a results briefing on Aug 8.
SGX did not specify the timeline for its IPO pipeline.
SGX will also invest in product innovation, sales capabilities and technology infrastructure to improve client services and expand its market reach.
The regulator’s equity markets review group announced in July that it will set aside $50 million for the Grant for Equity Market Singapore scheme.

title: It’s only a matter of time until Americans pay for Trump’s tariffs
summary:
Interestingly, almost the same thing happened during Mr Trump’s first (much more modest) round of tariffs in 2017: Import prices stayed largely the same.
He points to research he and his team did during Mr Trump’s 2017 tariffs.
Data shows pricing has already started rising (an average of 3 per cent) in response to Mr Trump’s tariffs.
After Mr Trump’s first round of tariffs in 2017, imports from China dropped by roughly 10 per cent over the next couple of years.
The 50 per cent tariffs on steel and aluminium will touch products all across the economy: toys, electronics, cars, housewares and... even lawn chairs.

title: Who loses the most from Trump’s tariffs? Who wins?
summary:
A truce in the US trade war with China has the US imposing 30 per cent tariffs on Chinese goods.
But there is little question that Mr Trump’s tariff regime will leave few winners and plenty of losers.
Who are the biggest losers from Trump’s tariffs?
Is anyone winning from Trump’s tariffs?
Mr Trump’s project to remake the global economy is proceeding apace for now.

title: Trump nominates his top economic adviser for vacant US Fed seat
summary:
As a governor, Dr Miran would have the ability to vote on interest rates as well as a range of other policy decisions.
Mr Trump has had a highly contentious relationship with the central bank since returning to the White House.
The source of their tension stems from the Fed’s reluctance to cut interest rates in 2025 , after it lowered borrowing costs by a percentage point in 2024.
Mr Trump has called for interest rates to be 3 percentage points lower, arguing that the Fed is not only preventing the economy from booming, but also making interest payments on the federal debt expensive.
On Aug 6, Dr Miran acknowledged on CNBC that recent economic indicators – including downbeat reports on jobs and manufacturing – had not been “up to snuff”.

title: Germany’s factory output falls to lowest since 2020 pandemic
summary:
Factory output fell 1.9 per cent month on month, federal statistics agency Destatis said, steeper than a drop of 0.5 per cent forecast by analysts polled by financial data firm FactSet.
There were particularly heavy falls in the machinery and pharmaceutical sectors, helping to drag overall output down to levels last seen in May 2020 during the Covid-19 pandemic.
German business morale rose to its highest level in July after seven straight increases, while think-tanks, including the respected DIW institute, have revised growth forecasts up for 2025 and 2026.
Experts say better data early in the year was the temporary effect of US “front-loading” as American customers rushed to get orders in before Mr Trump’s tariffs took effect.
“Don’t forget that tariffs were usually between 0 per cent and about 2 per cent at the most beforehand,” she said.

title: Nasdaq ends at record, Dow falls as tariff hikes take effect
summary:
NEW YORK - The Dow fell while the Nasdaq finished at a fresh record on Aug 7 as markets grappled with worries over lofty equity valuations in light of President Donald Trump’s aggressive trade policies.
The mixed session reflected lingering unease as new US tariff increases took effect.
“There’s concerns about the market acting a little bit too complacent around these tariffs.”The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.5 per cent at 43,968.64.
The broad-based S&P 500 dipped 0.1 per cent to 6,340.00, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.4 per cent to 21,242.70, a new all-time high.
But some market watchers expect a pullback in light of valuations that are priced for meaningful earnings growth.

title: Genting Singapore H1 profit falls 34% on weaker gaming, room revenue
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGenting Singapore reported a 12 per cent drop in gaming revenue for the first half of 2025.
SINGAPORE – Resort and casino operator Genting Singapore reported a 34 per cent drop in profit for the first half of 2025 to $234.7 million.
Revenue declined by 10 per cent to $1.2 billion, from $1.4 billion in the previous corresponding period, Genting said in a regulatory filing on Aug 7.
According to its financial statement, the revenue decline was partly driven by a 12 per cent drop in gaming revenue to $839.4 million, and a 19 per cent fall in room revenue to $98.4 million.
Earnings per share stood at 1.94 cents for the first six months, down 1.02 cents from the previous year.

title: Bank of England cuts rates to 4% after narrow 5-4 vote
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBank of England Governor Andrew Bailey and four colleagues backed lowering bank rate to 4 per cent from 4.25 per cent.
Chief economist Huw Pill also voted to keep bank rate at 4.25 per cent.
“The restrictiveness of monetary policy had fallen as bank rate had been reduced,” it said.
It has cut borrowing costs eight times since June of last year, three more reductions than those of the BOE.
Longer-term growth forecasts were little changed from its report in May, with annual growth of just over 1 per cent expected in the coming years.

title: STI up 0.7% in line with regional gains despite US tariff kick-off
summary:
The regional advances followed a positive session on Wall Street overnight, where an Apple rally helped push the Nasdaq up 1.2 per cent to a near-record.
The S&P 500 added 0.7 per cent while the Dow industrials gained 0.2 per cent.
The gains came despite the higher tariff rates imposed by US President Donald Trump taking effect on dozens of trading partners.
The stock rocketed up around 11 per cent in early trade to hit $2.92, its highest level since February.
UOB led the STI decliners, falling 1.8 per cent to $35.81, after reporting a 6 per cent year-on-year drop in second-quarter earnings that fell below analyst estimates.

title: Dive into AI’s impact on young people’s work lives at ST’s Headstart panel session on Sept 6
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxParticipants can hear from a panel of experts on how AI is reshaping the future of work for graduating students and young professionals.
SINGAPORE - With many entry-level roles being automated and skills demands evolving fast, how can you stay ahead and stand out?
Join The Straits Times’ Headstart session on Sept 6 and hear from a panel of experts on how artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping the future of work for graduating students and young professionals – and what you can do about it.
One of the panel speakers is Mr Brandon Lee, assistant chief executive of WSG’s transformation support group.
The discussion will explore what young job seekers should know about how AI is changing work processes, and not just roles.

title: Private credit fuels ‘buy now, pay later’ lending boom in Asia
summary:
A friend suggested she get a “buy now, pay later” (BNPL) loan from Billease, an online lender.
In the United States, merchants typically pay any fees, so customers get no-interest loans as long as they keep current.
In Jakarta, ads for the BNPL companies are almost inescapable both online and on billboards, city buses and commuter trains.
One for Kredivo encourages customers to use BNPL loans for smaller daily purchases, even for train fares and items at convenience stores.
BNPL lenders say they obey debt collection rules and the rates they charge reflect the risks of the population they are serving.

title: S’pore firm looks to buy SMEs lacking successors, launches CEO training programme to foster renewal
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTimah Partners CEO Dennis Chua (right) with Mr Kelvin Ho, the inaugural candidate of the firm's CEO succession programme.
Mr Chua said the CSP aims to close this gap with a structured succession training programme.
The services sector, which includes businesses from landscaping to pest control and waste management, is also not widely seen as an attractive career destination, said Mr Chua.
Mr Chua, a Harvard Business School graduate, described the programme as akin to an MBA programme with a practical corporate attachment.
As the programme’s first candidate, Mr Ho will also be instrumental to designing the programme, said Mr Chua.

title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares surge 8% on record first-half earnings
summary:
SINGAPORE – Shares of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding soared on Aug 7, after the mainboard-listed company posted a record net profit for the first half of 2025.
Yangzijiang saw a 36.7 per cent jump in net profit to 4.18 billion yuan (S$747.2 million) for the six months ended June 30, from 3.06 billion yuan in the year-ago period.
This was despite a 1.3 per cent dip in first-half revenue to 12.88 billion yuan, the company reported before the market opened on Aug 7.
Revenue from the shipping segment fell 15.4 per cent year on year to 511.4 million yuan, following a drop in charter rates.
Contributions from Yangzijiang’s associated companies and joint ventures rose 79 per cent year on year to 481.4 million yuan.

title: How Apple is using a familiar strategy to avoid Trump’s tariffs
summary:
Vance, Mr Cook announced that Apple will increase its US investment commitment to US$600 billion (S$770 billion) over four years – up from the US$500 billion pledged after Mr Trump’s second-term victory.
Though Apple has touted the US roots of iPhone glass before, a portion of that glass was previously made overseas.
Corning has supplied Apple since the first iPhone in 2007 and Mr Cook has long promoted the iPhone’s American-made glass.
Mr Cook even seized on Mr Trump’s famous love of gold.
This is not the first time that Apple has used US manufacturing announcements to promote Mr Trump’s priorities.

title: South Korea says Samsung, SK Hynix will not face 100% US chip tariffs; Taiwan says TSMC ‘exempt’
summary:
SEOUL – South Korea’s top trade envoy Yeo Han-koo said on Aug 7 that Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix will not be subject to 100 per cent US tariffs on chips.
Meanwhile, Taiwan on Aug 7 said Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) “is exempt” from the 100 per cent chip tariff.
Some Taiwanese chipmakers “will be affected” by the 100 per cent tariff, but their competitors will also face the same levy, Mr Liu said.
“While both Samsung and SK Hynix have made US investments, there are doubts about whether SK Hynix’s packaging plant alone will fully qualify for tariff exemptions,” said Yuanta Securities analyst Baik Gil-hyun.
Shares in Samsung Electronics climbed 2.6 per cent, while shares in SK Hynix were trading up 0.6 per cent in line with the broader market.

title: Jewellery retailer Claire’s with 2,750 stores files for second bankruptcy after tariffs
summary:
– US retailer Claire’s filed for its second Chapter 11 bankruptcy in seven years, months after President Donald Trump’s tariff plans created uncertainty over how the retailer’s global supply chain will be affected.
It currently has 2,750 stores across 17 countries as well as 190 sister-brand Icing stores in North America, according to its website.
It operated more than 4,500 stores at the time of its first bankruptcy filing.
The retailer listed liabilities and assets of US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion) to US$10 billion each in its Chapter 11 petition.
The company elected to skip rent payments on some stores in June and July, Bloomberg previously reported.

title: DBS shares hit $50 after Q2 profit beats forecast on strong wealth fees, trading income
summary:
Ms Tan explained that the bank projected net interest income in 2025 to exceed 2024 levels despite declining interest rates as higher volumes can drive net interest income growth.
“Focus on net interest income.
Don’t focus on net interest margin, because it will go down with the markets, but net interest income can go up with volumes and that’s how you mitigate that.
DBS chief executive officer Tan Su Shan said the bank projected net interest income in 2025 to exceed 2024 levels despite falling interest rates.
Net interest income in the first half fell 1 per cent to $7.34 billion from $7.42 billion, weighed by lower interest rates.

title: UOB lowers outlook on tariff impact after 6% drop in Q2 profit; shares fall 1.8%
summary:
UOB shares closed down 1.8 per cent, or 64 cents, at $35.81 on Aug 7, after its results announcement.
UOB declared an interim dividend of 85 cents a share for the half-year, down from 88 cents a year ago.
Operating profit for the half-year rose 3 per cent to $4 billion, underpinned by broad-based double-digit growth in fee income.
It forecast a NIM growth of 1.85 per cent to 1.9 per cent, with low single-digit loan growth and high single-digit fee growth.
This is lower than its original 2025 estimation at its fourth-quarter results briefing in February, where it forecast high single-digit loan growth and double-digit fee growth.

title: China’s property slump to last longer than expected, UBS says
summary:
“The sales momentum has become tepid in recent months,” Mr Lam said in an interview.
Global banks are divided on the outlook for China real estate, which has been a drag on the economy for more than four years.
China’s total housing inventory has continued to fall since the end of March, according to Mr Lam.
A Reit listing of a developer’s malls will likely provide a stock catalyst for the builder itself, Mr Lam said.
“China’s real estate financing may undergo a major structural change in the next three to five years,” Mr Lam said.

title: Singapore’s Carro targets US IPO with over $3.8 billion valuation, sources say
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxIf successful, Carro’s listing would be the largest South-east Asian IPO in the US since Shopee parent Sea’s listing in 2017.
The company is aiming for a valuation of more than US$3 billion , according to the sources, who could not be named discussing confidential information.
If successful, Carro’s listing would be the largest South-east Asian IPO in the United States since Shopee parent Sea’s US$989.3 million listing in 2017 and the third-biggest South-east Asian high-tech IPO in the US, according to LSEG.
The IPO size is still under discussion and may change depending on market conditions, the sources added.
A successful listing could pave the way for other regional unicorns, such as Carsome, Traveloka and Xendit, to follow suit.

title: US stocks rise as Apple surges
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks rose on Aug 6 with Apple and most other large tech companies rallying as markets largely shrugged off US President Donald Trump’s latest tariff hikes.
Apple piled on more than 5 per cent after White House officials said the tech giant plans an additional US$100 billion (S$129 billion) in capital spending in the United States.
Mr Trump ordered an additional 25 per cent tariff on Indian goods.
A new wave of Trump tariffs is due to take effect on Aug 7 on dozens of other economies.
But McDonald’s jumped 3 per cent as it reported an 11 per cent rise in profits to US$2.3 billion.

title: Investors seek court-ordered judicial management of Tokenize Xchange operator amid police probe
summary:
SINGAPORE – Seven cryptocurrency investors have applied to the High Court to place AmazingTech – the operator of embattled cryptocurrency platform Tokenize Xchange – under interim judicial management to protect their investments.
The Straits Times understands the seven customers have not been able to withdraw their deposits amounting to more than $4 million that are held by Tokenize Xchange.
The seven investors are represented by lawyers Alfred Lim, Jaime Lye and Rasveen Kaur of law firm Meritus.
The timeline for a judicial manager to be appointed by the High Court may take up to a few months.
On July 20, Tokenize Xchange said it would shut down the business following MAS’ decision not to grant it a licence to offer digital payment token services here.

title: Fintech platform iFast among 5 S’pore companies on Forbes Asia’s Best Under A Billion list
summary:
SINGAPORE – Home-grown fintech platform iFast has made it to the latest Forbes Asia’s Best Under A Billion list, buoyed by growing wealth in the region.
The others are local bourse SGX itself, accommodation provider Centurion, luxury yacht builder Grand Banks Yachts, and credit and risk information provider Credit Bureau Asia (CBA).
Leading the pack on the Forbes list are China, with 30 companies, and India, with 29.
The Singapore company on the Forbes list that boasts the largest market capitalisation at $17.4 billion is SGX itself.
Grand Banks Yachts manufactures luxury yachts under the brands of Grand Banks, Eastbay and Palm Beach out of its yard in Pasir Gudang, Johor.

title: Air India to tap Singapore Airlines to bolster fleet upkeep after June crash: Sources
summary:
– Air India plans to lean on shareholder Singapore Airlines (SIA) to move some aircraft maintenance services in-house instead of outsourcing them to a state-owned company, according to people familiar with the matter.
SIA, which owns 25.1 per cent of Air India, will help in the transition of those maintenance tasks to the airline’s staff, the people said.
“As a significant minority shareholder in Air India, Singapore Airlines has been working closely” to support Air India’s transformation plan, an SIA spokesperson said in an e-mail.
The Air India plane crash also brought sharp scrutiny in the sector on issues like the maintenance of aircraft.
Air India has a fleet of 191 aircraft while its low-cost subsidiary – Air India Express – operates 115 planes, according to flight tracking website Flightradar24.

title: Singapore stocks rise for third straight day on strong sentiment; STI up 0.5%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE – Local stocks enjoyed a third straight day of gains on Aug 6 despite mixed regional markets and declines on Wall Street over concerns about the US’ faltering jobs market.
The buoyant mood here lifted the Straits Times Index (STI) 0.5 per cent, or 19.12 points, to 4,227.70 with gainers besting losers 309 to 217 on solid trade of 1.5 billion securities worth $1.4 billion.
Australia’s ASX 200 was the standout performer, rising 0.8 per cent to a record close.
A downbeat Wall Street overnight failed to inspire as tariff uncertainty continues to unnerve markets, particularly in the area of pharmaceuticals, which may be hit with huge levies.
The S&P 500 fell 0.5 per cent and the Nasdaq dropped 0.65 per cent but both remain at near record highs.

title: Cathay Pacific buys 14 planes in its first Boeing deal in more than a decade
summary:
– Cathay Pacific Airways said it would place a US$8.1 billion (S$10.4 billion) order for 14 more Boeing 777-9 jets in its first deal with the US planemaker in 12 years.
Cathay’s latest order makes it one of the largest buyers of the 777X, behind Gulf carriers Emirates Airline and Qatar Airways.
Cathay’s last Boeing order was in 2013.
Cathay Pacific, whose major shareholders include Swire Pacific and Air China, operates a fleet of 236 aircraft: 73 Boeing planes and 163 Airbus jets.
Airbus has previously scooped up consecutive orders with Cathay for passenger widebody, single-aisle and freighter jets.

title: Hong Kong asks insurers to return investing roles from Singapore: Source
summary:
The push, led by the Hong Kong Insurance Authority (HKIA), started in early 2024 and is focusing on companies including AIA Group, the people said.
The Hong Kong insurance regulator is able to track the decision-making process when insurers notify them about their outsourcing decisions.
AIA has since been moving assets in private equity and global stock strategies from Hong Kong to Singapore, according to the people.
With 198 staff, Singapore-based AIA Investment Management (AIAIM) managed US$139 billion (S$179 billion) as of end 2024.
The number of companies with regional headquarters in Hong Kong dropped from 1,457 in 2021 to 1,410 in 2024, according to government data.

title: Asian container liners set for profit drop as tariff truce ends
summary:
Trans-Pacific trade picked up during the US-China tariff truce, with freight prices up sharply in June.
US-China trade talks are progressing, with US President Donald Trump set to make the final call on maintaining a tariff truce with China.
“For China, it is too early to say how adverse the impact of revised tariffs will be on container lines,” he added .
Since March, China-Asean export volumes have been double those of China-US, traditionally the most important route in container shipping.
“We expect that container lines will cancel many more sailings, increase demolitions of ships and take other measures to manage oversupply in the second half of this year,” he said.

title: China firms set for record US listings, undeterred by geopolitics
summary:
Waiting to list on the Nasdaq are more than 40 Chinese companies, including a mobile advertising service provider and a traditional Chinese medicine maker, Chinese disclosure showed.
The increased Chinese interest, however, has caught the attention of US lawmakers, who called for the delisting of Chinese companies from US exchanges as recently as May, citing national security concerns.
In China, a company needs to exceed a certain size or be profitable to qualify for a mainboard listing.
Alternatively, to list on tech boards, companies need to align with government self-sufficiency goals or achieve set levels of productivity.
The lengthy approval process and high listing thresholds mean that for start-ups, “listing in China becomes mission impossible”, said deal adviser Ronald Shuang of investment company Balloch Holding.

title: AMD’s China concerns overshadow upbeat sales forecast for AI
summary:
– Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), the second-largest maker of artificial intelligence (AI) processors, warned that its return to the crucial China market remains a work in progress, overshadowing a generally upbeat forecast for its AI business.
China is the largest market for semiconductors, and the restrictions have threatened to erase billions of dollars in total revenue from both companies.
Third-quarter sales will be about US$8.7 billion, the company said, topping the average analyst estimate of US$8.37 billion.
AMD’s second-quarter sales rose 32 per cent to US$7.7 billion, compared with a US$7.43 billion average estimate.
AMD is the second-biggest provider of graphics chips, which form the basis for the AI accelerators that run in data centres.

title: Easy to lose, hard to restore: With Trump firing, US data trust now on the line
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUS President Donald Trump’s firing of US Bureau of Labour Statistics head Erika McEntarfer has put trust in US data reporting on the line.
“That’s a whole other level of problems.”Policymakers, businesses and investors are scrambling to understand how Mr Trump’s attempt to upend the global trade system will affect prices, employment and household wealth.
Central banks, which once tried to guide market bets on rate moves months down the line, now say decisions are “data-dependent”.
The key lesson from past examples of loss of data confidence is that it can take years for trust to be restored.
It also prompted European governments to grant the Eurostat statistics arm of the European Union powers to check suspect national statistics reported to it.

title: US trade deficit hits nearly 2-year low in June; China gap plunges as tariffs bite
summary:
Days after reporting that the goods trade deficit tumbled 10.8 per cent to its lowest since September 2023, the government said the full deficit, including services, was also its narrowest since then.
US and China trade negotiators met last week in Sweden in the latest round of engagement over the trade war that has intensified since Mr Trump’s return.
The trade deficit with Germany also slid, coming in at US$3.8 billion and the lowest in five years.
Services sector softeningThe tariff effects showed signs in July of spilling over into the domestic services sector, which accounts for roughly two-thirds of total US economic activity.
A reading above 50 indicates growth in the services sector, which accounts for more than two-thirds of the economy.

title: US stocks fall as as investors consider tariff impact on results, economy
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks ended lower on Aug 5 as investors weighed the impact of tariffs after Yum Brands and other companies cited trade duties in their results or outlooks.
“The impact of tariffs remains a work in progress.
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit a string of record highs recently, and the S&P 500 remains up 7.1 per cent for the year so far.
While the earnings period is winding down, investors look forward to more key results on Aug 6, with both Walt Disney and McDonald’s due to report.
On the Nasdaq, 2,216 stocks rose and 2,365 fell as declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 1.07-to-1 ratio.

title: Dezign Format targets $6.5m IPO on Catalist, eyes Malaysia expansion
summary:
Dezign Format specialises in installations for meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (Mice) events, as well as fit-outs for retail and commercial spaces.
Regional expansion is also a priority for the company, which currently employs 166 staff in its Singapore office.
Dezign Format is gearing up for expansion in Malaysia, its first overseas market, in the fourth quarter of 2025.
Dezign Format was established in 1988 by Mr Chong and his elder brother Chong Nen Sing, and has been a family-owned firm since.
Another local firm, semiconductor optics company MetaOptics, lodged its preliminary prospectus for a listing on Catalist on July 30.

title: Women on corporate boards give firms a competitive advantage, says Australian Governor-General
summary:
SINGAPORE – The case for including women on boards should go beyond representation, as doing so is a competitive advantage for companies looking to navigate risks and secure new investments, Australian Governor-General Sam Mostyn said on Aug 5.
Ms Mostyn held leadership roles in the public and private sectors before being appointed Australia’s 28th governor-general in July 2024.
Ms Mostyn said her appointment drew criticism, because she was seen to have benefited from a “quota appointment” reserved for women.
The number of women on the boards of companies listed on Australia’s ASX 300 index has nearly doubled over the last decade.
According to a report by the Council for Board Diversity, women directors made up more than 25 per cent of the boards of Singapore’s top companies in 2024.

title: Singapore retail sales up by 2.3%, driven by sales of motor vehicles
summary:
SINGAPORE - Retail sales grew 2.3 per cent year on year in June, driven by the sales of motor vehicles, according to data from the Department of Statistics released on Aug 5.
Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales increased 0.4 per cent in June, compared with the flat growth in May 2025.
Of this, an estimated 13.6 per cent were from online retail sales, higher than the 12.3 per cent recorded in the previous month.
Excluding motor vehicles, the total retail sales value was about $3.3 billion, of which 16.2 per cent were from online retail sales.
A muted outlook for Singapore’s retail sales is anticipated over the coming months, said DBS Bank senior economist Chua Han Teng.

title: Singapore shares up again, lifted by retail sales growth; STI rises 0.3%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE - The Straits Times Index (STI) settled higher on Aug 5 for the second consecutive session, supported by stronger-than-expected retail sales figures for June.
Retail sales rose 2.3 per cent year on year that month, indicated data released by the Department of Statistics.
The growth was broad-based across industries and exceeded the median estimate of 2 per cent by private sector economists polled by Bloomberg.
The biggest gainer on the index was Thai Beverage, rising 2.2 per cent or one cent to 47 cen ts.
OCBC chief economist Selena Ling noted that the recently released retail sales figure fell short of her forecasted 2.7 per cent growth.

title: Astrea bonds open up private market for S’pore retail investors, but note the risks, say observers
summary:
The private markets had been traditionally out of the reach of retail investors until 2018, when the Astrea IV series of PE bonds was launched.
By buying this Astrea 9 PE bond, a retail investor is essentially lending money to the bond issuer.
Senior lab technician Dallas Goh, 34, has been buying the PE bonds since Astrea IV , when these investments were first made available to retail investors .
M r Chue En Yaw, chief executive and chief investment officer of Azalea Investment Management, clarified that Astrea PE bonds are “not guaranteed by anybody, including Temasek”.
According to Azalea, the PE bonds issued by Astrea III, Astrea IV and Astrea V have been fully redeemed, and retail investors have been returned their principal.

title: OCBC Q2 profit drops 7% as interest rates fall; CEO flags tariff headwinds
summary:
SINGAPORE - OCBC Bank posted a 7 per cent fall in earnings for the second quarter, as declining interest rates weighed on net interest income.
OCBC expects its 2025 net interest income to be lower by a mid-single-digit percentage.
It maintained most of its 2025 financial targets, including mid-single-digit loan growth and credit costs in the range of 20 to 25 basis points.
Net interest income for the quarter fell 6 per cent year on year to $2.28 billion, as net interest margins dropped to 1.92 per cent from 2.2 per cent.
Total income dipped 1 per cent, as a fall in net interest income from the peak level a year ago was mostly compensated by robust fee and trading income growth.

title: Apple results blow past forecasts, surprising investors worried iPhone maker had lost its touch
summary:
– The tech industry has spent much of the past week boasting about how artificial intelligence is boosting sales.
Wall Street analysts had predicted quarterly sales of US$89.34 billion and profit of US$21.43 billion.
The purchases helped lift iPhone sales in the most recent quarter by more than 13 per cent to US$44.58 billion.
The company said it expected to increase its revenue in the current quarter by 4 per cent to 9 per cent.
Apple said US tariffs of 30 per cent on Chinese imports had added US$800 million in costs in the quarter.

title: Amazon cloud computing results fail to impress; shares dive
summary:
Amazon said they were 32.9 per cent in the second quarter, down from 39.5 per cent in 2025 ’s first quarter and 35.5 per cent a year ago.
AWS reported a 17.5 per cent increase in revenue to US$30.9 billion (S$40.1 billion), edging past expectations of US$30.77 billion.
By comparison, sales for Microsoft’s Azure rose 39 per cent and Google Cloud gained 32 per cent.
Amazon forecast between US$15.5 billion and US$20.5 billion, compared with expectations of US$19.45 billion.
Amazon has said it was pushing suppliers to pull forward inventories to ensure supply and keep prices as low as possible.

title: US stocks end lower after strong start as rally fades
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks finished lower on July 31, shrugging off strong gains by Microsoft and Meta as traders await key US employment data and a White House tariff deadline.
Facebook parent Meta surged 11.3 per cent and Microsoft jumped 4 per cent after both companies reported strong quarterly results that underscored their strength in artificial intelligence.
Microsoft’s valuation topped US$4 trillion (S$5.2 trillion) for part of the day before retreating.
After initially greeting trade deals, investors are also reevaluating Mr Trump’s trade agreements, most recently with South Korea, the latest to set a 15 per cent tariff on goods.
Health was the weakest sector in the S&P 500, with pharmaceutical companies selling off after Mr Trump threatened using “every tool in our arsenal” if the sector doesn’t lower prices.

title: Singapore shares dragged by Singtel, Seatrium declines; STI down 1.1%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxLosers outpaced gainers 388 to 204 on bumper trade of 1.6 billion securities worth $1.9 billion.
SINGAPORE – Local shares took yet another hit on July 31 after investors bailed out of index heavyweights Singtel and Seatrium.
In the broader market, losers outpaced gainers 388 to 204 on bumper trade of 1.6 billion securities worth $1.9 billion.
Seatrium was the STI’s biggest decliner, slumping 5.4 per cent to $2.27 with 42 million shares done.
Singtel was another notable decliner, dropping 3 per cent to $3.88 after trading in the stock went ex-dividend.

title: Firms in S’pore’s services, manufacturing sectors are cautiously optimistic about outlook ahead
summary:
The rest expect conditions to remain the same.
Water transport firms, including freight shipping companies as well as tugboat and barge operators, are particularly cautious about the geopolitical uncertainties.
Air and land transport firms, however, are more positive about their outlook.
Banks remain cautious, although payment processing firms expect a rise in transaction volumes and revenue driven by the e-commerce market’s continual expansion.
A weighted 10 per cent of them expect business conditions to improve, while a weighted 5 per cent foresee a weaker outlook.

title: Singapore gold investment soars 37% to 2.2 tonnes in Q2 while jewellery demand wanes
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore investors’ appetite for gold remained strong in the second quarter of 2025 with 2.2 tonnes of gold bars and coins purchased, according to the World Gold Council’s latest report released on July 31.
However, demand for gold jewellery in Singapore dropped 8 per cent to 1.5 tonnes, as record gold prices curbed spending power and global jewellery buying slumped to pandemic-era lows.
In South-east Asia, gold investment demand in the second quarter continued to grow across Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, with double-digit year-on-year increases.
Overall, total gold demand reached 1,249 tonnes, including over-the-counter transactions.
In particular, jewellery demand in China dropped 20 per cent to 69.2 tonnes, and Indian demand fell 17 per cent to 88.8 tonnes.

title: Deepening Singapore-Latin America ties a matter of urgency amid global trade uncertainty: Alvin Tan
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore is strengthening ties with Latin America, with such efforts taking on greater importance and urgency amid the global trade uncertainty, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.
“Our strengthening trade architecture at the institution level will continue to promote and support these flows,” Mr Tan added.
Depa establishes key rules on digital trade and economic collaborations on issues such as digital identities, cross-border data flows and artificial intelligence to help businesses, especially smaller ones, engage in digital trade and electronic commerce.
Meanwhile, venture capital investment in Latin America rose by 26 per cent in 2024, driven largely by activity in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.
Mr Tan also said Latin America is known as the world’s “next global breadbasket” and is the largest net food-exporting region in the world .

title: US-listed Chinese stock loses 90% in minutes after pump-and-dump warning
summary:

The stock closed trading on July 28 at US$30.96 and opened on July 29 at US$31.25.
When trading resumed 90 minutes later, the stock’s plunge reached 89 per cent before trading was halted again.
Pheton is just the latest example of wild trading moves seen in Chinese companies that trade on Nasdaq.

title: Keppel shares jump on strong first-half profit rise, $500m share buyback
summary:
Keppel shares rallied as much as 6.8 per cent, before closing up 3.6 per cent, or 29 cents, at $8.47 on July 31.
The company introduced a new reporting metric – it dubbed “New Keppel” – which excludes non-core portfolio assets held for divestment.
Keppel’s real estate business rebounded, swinging to a net profit of $98 million from a net loss of $24 million in the year-ago period.
However, its infrastructure business saw a 5 per cent dip in earnings to $346 million, due to lower asset management net profit and power business earnings.
The connectivity business also saw a decline in net profit by 19 per cent to $57 million.

title: Grab swings to $25.9 million profit in Q2 as revenue beats estimates
summary:

– Grab Holdings beat Wall Street expectations for second-quarter revenue on July 30, as consumers boosted spending on its ride-hailing and food delivery platform despite global economic uncertainty.
This drove it to a profit of US$20 million ($25.9 million) for the quarter, compared with a US$68 million loss in the same period a year earlier.
The company has been attempting to lure price-sensitive consumers to its ride-hailing platform while increasing the number of drivers to keep pace with a growing user base.
Grab reported revenue of US$819 million for the six months to June 30, above analysts’ expectations of US$811.3 million, according to LSEG data.

title: China factory activity unexpectedly worsens as exports stumble
summary:
– China’s factory activity unexpectedly deteriorated in July to a six-month low despite a tariff truce with the US, as early signs emerge that exports are slowing and weak domestic demand persists.
The official manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) was 49.3, versus 49.7 in June, said the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) on July 31.
The non-manufacturing measure of activity in construction and services fell to 50.1 from 50.5 in June , according to the statistics office.
The PMI figures are the first official data available each month to provide a snapshot of the health of the Chinese economy.
Cargo throughput at the nation’s ports last week was the lowest in almost three months and dropped nearly 7 per cent from the previous seven days, a sign trade may be starting to slow.

title: Samsung says tariff agreement reduces uncertainty, expects Tesla deal to boost orders
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSamsung forecast a gradual second-half recovery after its chip profit plunged 94 per cent in the second quarter.
SEOUL – Samsung Electronics said a trade deal that will see the United States charge 15 per cent tariffs on imports from South Korea reduces uncertainty, as it forecast more major chip orders after signing a US$16.5 billion (S$21.4 billion) deal with Elon Musk’s Tesla.
“Building on this milestone, we anticipate securing additional orders from large customers,” Samsung vice president Noh Mi-jung said of its struggling contract chipmaking business during an earnings conference call.
Last October, Samsung said it was making progress on a major deal to supply HBM3E chips to an unidentified customer that analysts said was Nvidia.
Meta Platforms and Microsoft on July 30y pointed to strong AI chip demand and major investments in data centres in their earnings announcements.

title: Microsoft and Meta fuel $648 billion rally in AI stocks as investments pay off
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBoth tech giants raised capital spending after their quarterly results showed their massive investments in AI were paying off.
NEW YORK - Tech giants Microsoft and Meta Platforms fuelled a US$500 million (S$648 billion) rally in AI stocks on July 30 after their quarterly results showed massive investments in artificial intelligence were paying off.
In extended trade, Microsoft jumped 8 per cent and Meta surged 9 per cent, with the two Magnificent Seven companies increasing their market values by US$288 billion and US$152 billion, respectively.
Meta raised the lower end of its annual capital expenditures forecast by US$2 billion, driven by its high-stakes push for “superintelligence” in the heated AI race.
In its just-ended fiscal fourth quarter, capital spending rose 27 per cent to US$24.2 billion.

title: Seatrium first-half profit soars 301% to $144 million on strong order book but shares fall
summary:
But underlying net profit, which excludes legal and corporate claims, rose 16 per cent to $133 million from $115 million.
As at the end of June, Seatrium’s net order book stood at $18.6 billion, of which $6.3 billion is for renewables and cleaner or green solutions.
Revenue for the first half grew 34 per cent, reflecting the strong execution of its robust order book, it added.
Mr Ong also said that Seatrium’s order book is diversified across geographies and segments, which helps to buffer the impact of short-term market volatility and strengthen its revenue visibility.
“Offshore wind continues to be in demand in Europe and the Asia-Pacific, as nations advance energy transition goals,” Seatrium said.

title: US stocks mostly fall as Fed avoids dovish shift
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks finished mostly lower July 31 after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates flat and refrained from signaling it will soon cut interest rates.
The Fed, as expected, held interest rates steady, despite relentless pressure from US President Donald Trump for an interest rate cut.
In a press conference, Fed chairman Jerome Powell emphasised future monetary policy decisions would depend on economic data.
Futures markets lowered their odds for a September interest rate cut following the press conference and statement, which included no major tweaks that would have implied an imminent interest rate cut.
“It’s been a very dynamic time for these trade negotiations,” he told reporters at a press conference.

title: Trump shocks markets with scaled-back copper tariff; US prices plunge
summary:
“Markets are now busily repricing refined copper much lower after Trump’s epic backflip on his own import tariff policy,” said Mr Tom Price, an analyst at London brokerage Panmure Liberum.
The tariff details sparked a “massive market surprise”, said Ms Natalie Scott-Gray, senior metals analyst at consultancy group StoneX, adding that she expects US copper prices to fall further.
More possibleThe measure came after a US investigation under Section 232, which Mr Trump ordered in February.
Mr Trump said he may still impose further tariffs, and has asked Mr Lutnick to provide an update on the domestic copper market by June 2026.
At that point, the President will evaluate whether to impose a phased universal import duty on refined copper of 15 per cent starting in 2027, and of 30 per cent starting in 2028, he said.

title: US Fed holds rates steady despite Trump’s pressure, with two governors dissenting
summary:
“You have to think of this as still quite early days,” Mr Powell said at a press conference after the release of the Fed’s latest policy statement.
Along with Mr Powell’s comments, the Fed’s new policy statement also gave little hint that rates were likely to fall soon.
Mr Powell was careful to keep his options open on monetary policy.
The Fed’s regional bank presidents are hired by local boards of directors who oversee the Fed’s 12 regional institutions.
Dissenting members of the FOMC often release statements explaining their vote on the Friday following Fed meetings.

title: Temasek cashes out of Indian joint venture with Schneider Electric for $8.18b
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s investment company Temasek will sell its 35 per cent stake in an Indian joint venture to its French majority owner for €5.5 billion (S$8.18 billion).
The Indian unit is a joint venture with Indian conglomerate Larsen and Toubro, which has operations in heavy industry, energy and construction.
Schneider said on July 30 that the unit had posted statutory revenues of €1.8 billion in 2024 and noted that the joint venture performed strongly in the Indian market, with double-digit growth in 2023 and 2024.
Schneider chief executive Olivier Blum said India will be one of the key focus markets of Schneider Electric.
In December 2024, Temasek and Swedish private equity firm EQT Infrastructure sold their Indian renewable energy platform O2 Power for US$1.5 billion (S$1.93 billion).

title: Singapore shares down for 4th straight session; STI dips 0.2%
summary:

Total employment rose by 8,400, based on advance figures released by the Ministry of Manpower on July 30.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2 per cent or 10 points to end at 4,219.41.
Singapore Airlines was the biggest decliner on the STI, falling almost 2 per cent or 14 cents to $6.90.
The local bank counters saw DBS drop 0.7 per cent or 34 cents to $48.26, while OCBC was flat at $17.04.

title: Nvidia-partner Foxconn forms pact with Taiwan’s Teco for AI push
summary:
TAIPEI - Hon Hai Precision Industry formed a strategic alliance with Teco Electric and Machinery, a pact that should help the iPhone-assembler advance its push into artificial intelligence hardware.
The companies said the pact will focus on areas such as AI servers and other AI data-centre hardware.
Hon Hai, for years the largest manufacturer of electronics for iconic global brands, has tried to offset the impact of stalling smartphone sales.
The Taiwanese company is also relying on the AI boom to propel growth, and has been adding investments in the US to build AI servers.
Shares of the company commonly known as Foxconn, as well as those of Teco, were suspended from trading ahead of the disclosure.

title: S’pore’s economic resilience will face headwinds in second half of 2025 from tariffs, trade conflicts: MAS
summary:
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) added that both the global and local economies remain subject to significant uncertainty for the rest of 2025 and 2026 .
“Against this backdrop, Singapore’s growth is expected to moderate over the rest of the year,” MAS said in its quarterly Macroeconomic Review report on July 30.
Year on year, the economy grew 4.3 per cent, extending the 4.1 per cent growth in the first quarter.
However, the uncertainty facing the Singapore economy is likely to persist and affect companies’ investment decisions.
The central bank said labour market conditions in Singapore could also moderate further in the second half of 2025, amid uncertain economic growth prospects.

title: HSBC first-half profit slumps 26% as China losses mount
summary:
HONG KONG – HSBC Holdings reported a 26 per cent slide in first-half pre-tax profit on July 30, missing analyst estimates, as impairments from its investment in Bank of Communications and exposure to Hong Kong real estate weighed.
Europe’s largest bank posted a pre-tax profit of US$15.8 billion (S$20.3 billion) for the first six months of 2025 , versus US$21.6 billion a year earlier.
The lender took a further US$2.1 billion hit from its stake in Bank of Communications, following a US$3 billion impairment it took in February 2024 amid mounting bad loans in China.
A sluggish property market in Hong Kong could continue to weigh on asset quality of banks operating in Hong Kong, according to Citi’s analysts.
The lender, with a market value of US$225 billion, announced a new share buyback worth up to US$3 billion, on top of a US$3 billion buyback programme announced earlier in 2025.

title: Adidas says tariffs will add $297 million to second-half costs
summary:

Vietnam and Indonesia, Adidas’ two biggest sourcing countries, made up for 27 per cent and 19 per cent of the company’s products respectively as at 2024.
Adidas posted an operating profit of €546 million in the quarter, exceeding the €503 million average of analyst estimates.
Adidas said it still expects to generate operating profit of between €1.7 billion and €1.8 billion in 2025.
“We do also not know what the indirect impact on consumer demand will be should all these tariffs cause major inflation.” REUTERS, BLOOMBERG

Asap & Co’s business development manager, Ms Mariam Moni, noted: “The (SME Centre) toolkit has helped us a lot.

title: Seatrium to pay $168m to Brazilian authorities, $73m to Singapore authorities to settle corruption case
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWith this announcement, Seatrium said that the Singapore authorities have concluded their joint investigations into potential offences.
SINGAPORE – Singapore-listed Seatrium will pay financial penalties to the Brazilian and Singapore authorities totalling $241.7 million to settle a long-drawn corruption probe in Brazil.
It was also required to pay a penalty of US$110 million (S$141.5 million) to the Singapore authorities, under a deferred prosecution agreement entered with the Attorney-General’s Chambers (AGC) in Singapore.
As such, the amount payable by Seatrium under the deferred prosecution agreement will be US$57 million (S$73.3 million) .
The deferred prosecution agreement, signed on July 30 with the Singapore authorities, is subject to approval by the Singapore High Court.

title: S’pore’s Q2 total employment rises but infocomm, professional services see more job cuts
summary:
The growth in the second quarter is, however, lower than the 11,300 jobs added in the same period in 2024.
Uneven hiring momentumResident employment continued to increase in sectors like financial services and health and social services, said MOM.
The rise was also seen in sectors like administrative and support services, and health and social services.
For every 1,000 employees, 1.4 people were retrenched in the second quarter, slightly lower than 1.5 in the preceding quarter.
Declines in wage expectations were observed in outward-oriented sectors such as financial and insurance services, professional services, and transportation and storage.

title: Trump tariff angst distanced Vietnam from China – but that did not last
summary:
In Vietnam’s northern manufacturing belt, tariff angst is not stopping the flow of Chinese money.
HANOI – In Vietnam’s northern manufacturing belt, tariff angst is not stopping the flow of Chinese money.
Mr Trump’s trade adviser Peter Navarro took to Fox News in April and described Vietnam as “essentially a colony of communist China”.
Neighbours in South-east Asia are getting tariffs of about 20 per cent, while China faces a duty of about 55 per cent, leaving Vietnam relatively secure.
In the second quarter, after Mr Trump announced his tariffs, they increased 24 per cent from a year ago.

title: S’pore car-sharing firm GetGo launches ZipZap no-deposit car leasing, starting at six months
summary:
SINGAPORE – The team behind car-sharing company GetGo has introduced a long-term car rental service with no deposit required and a minimum period of six months – shorter than other long-term rental services.
Launched on July 29 under the name ZipZap, the service aims to bridge the gap between short-term and long-term car rentals.
In contrast to ZipZap, GetGo’s eponymous car-sharing platform offers short-term rentals from a minimum of an hour to a maximum of five days.
ZipZap users pay a monthly fee that covers all major costs – such as road tax, insurance and maintenance – except for fuel.
When the leased car is sent for servicing or repairs, ZipZap users will be able to use a “courtesy car” in the meanwhile.

title: Cathay Cineplexes ropes in restructuring specialist as more payment demands pile up
summary:
