It will also oversee the next phase of work, including the onboarding of other core national payment infrastructure participants as company members, and the transition of the payment schemes from their current administrators to Span.
Such schemes are currently administered and governed by MAS, ABS, the Singapore Clearing House Association and the Infocomm Media Development Authority.
This development comes after MAS and ABS announced on Feb 12 plans to consolidate Singapore’s national payment schemes under a single entity.
In his speech, Mr Gan noted that Singapore’s banking sector has been the cornerstone of the city-state’s position as a global financial centre.

title: Work-life balance most important factor for Gen Z, millennials and Gen X: Randstad survey
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE – Getting their work-life balance right is the most highly valued employment factor for workers in Singapore, no matter what the age, noted a new survey.
It found that just over 50 per cent of employees here rated “work-life balance” and “salary and benefits” positively when evaluating their current employers.
While work-life balance and attractive salary and benefits remain the top two priorities for Gen Z (aged 13 to 28) and millennials (29 to 44), Gen X (45 to 60) place slightly more emphasis on compensation.
Other findings noted that while Gen Z prioritised strong training and development opportunities, Gen X looked for a financially healthy company.
Impact of artificial intelligenceThe use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the workplace has steadily increased year on year, with more frequent users among Gen Z and Gen X.

title: Singapore shares rise, tracking regional gains; STI up 0.6%
summary:
SINGAPORE – The stability of the ceasefire between Israel and Iran has drawn plenty of sceptics, but there were enough true believers across major regional markets to drive shares higher on June 25.
Wall Street set the direction of travel overnight, where stocks put on gains after the ceasefire seemed to hold firm.
Oil prices went the other way, falling 6 per cent, and are now below the level when fighting began earlier in June .
Mr Nigel Green, chief executive of global financial advisory company deVere Group, noted that global markets were “dangerously relaxed” over the wider global risk of the Israel-Iran conflict.
For instance, equity markets are not showing the “defensive rotation” expected of investors when there are many risk indicators.

title: More than a third of retail investors in S’pore face problems exercising their rights: Survey
summary:
SINGAPORE - More than a third of retail investors, or 37 per cent, experienced difficulties in exercising their rights, according to a new survey out on June 25.
The survey, which was commissioned in 2024 by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or Sias, included the responses of 197 people in a bid to track the progress of investors’ rights in Singapore and see what more needs to be done.
Sias is the main investor-led organisation dedicated to investor education and the advocacy of retail investors’ rights.
The opportunity for reform has also cropped up, with the ongoing review by the Equities Market Review Group, which was set up in 2024 to boost Singapore’s equities market.
“This journey reflects our unwavering belief that protecting investor rights is fundamental to building trust and resilience in our capital markets.”

title: SIA CEO’s annual pay down 13.5% to $7m even as airline posts record earnings
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSIA CEO Goh Choon Phong's pay package in the FY2023/2024 was $8.1 million.
SINGAPORE - Singapore Airlines (SIA) chief executive Goh Choon Phong saw his pay fall by 13.5 per cent to $7.01 million in the financial year ended March 31 , when the flag carrier’s earnings reached a record high.
This came as SIA posted a record net profit of $2.8 billion in FY2024-2025, up slightly from the $2.7 billion in the year before.
SIA and its budget airline Scoot also carried a record 39.4 million passengers, up 8.1 per cent, it said.
Passenger traffic growth, which stood at 6.4 per cent, also lagged behind its capacity expansion of 8.2 per cent.

title: China seizes moment to globalise renminbi as dollar doubts mount
summary:
Beijing’s hope is that a more internationalised renminbi may reshape trade and global finance and challenge the dollar’s dominance in reserve portfolios.
Role in monetary systemIn a speech last week, Chinese central bank governor Pan Gongsheng envisioned a new global currency order with a reduced role for the dollar.
To push that vision, the People’s Bank of China plans to establish an international operation centre for the digital renminbi in Shanghai.
In Hong Kong, a fast payment system was launched over the past weekend.
China’s own payment system, the Cross-Border Interbank Payment System (CIPS), is also gaining traction.

title: Singapore’s long-term wealth creation set to boost local stocks, says Morgan Stanley
summary:
SINGAPORE - As Singapore reaches its 60th birthday, investment bank Morgan Stanley believes the city-state is “primed for wealth creation”, which could unlock real gains for investors.
Morgan Stanley identifies three key pillars set to underpin Singapore’s wealth creation.
It ranks among the top 10 global AI markets and is now positioning itself as a regional AI inference hub.
Below are some stocks that Morgan Stanley earmarked as potential beneficiaries.
Morgan Stanley Research projects revenue and Ebitda CAGR of over 20 per cent and 40 per cent, respectively, from 2024 to 2027.

title: Chinese firms boost exports to UK as Trump tariffs shift trade
summary:
Official data from both nations point to a pick-up in the value of Chinese exports to Britain after the US President imposed hefty duties on products from the world’s second-largest economy before recently reducing them.
Exports of small parcels and electronics have jumped, in a sign of possible rerouting to avoid the US tariffs.
The figures add to evidence that as Mr Trump’s trade barriers reduce the US’ reliance on Chinese production, demand for those exports often shifts elsewhere rather than disappears.
Chinese exporters of low-value items in small packages directly to consumers have been saying they will shift to other markets once the US imposed tariffs.
London School of Economics and Political Science associate professor Thomas Sampson said: “The data shows tentative signs of Chinese exports diverting to the UK… The increases to date are relatively small, and monthly trade data can be quite volatile.

title: New Zealand fintech Xero to buy Melio Payments in US$2.5 billion deal
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxXero has agreed to buy Melio Payments for US$2.5 billion in the New Zealand-based company’s biggest ever acquisition.
“Xero and Melio are highly complementary,” Xero chief executive Sukhinder Singh Cassidy said in the statement.
In 2024, though, it was valued at US$2 billion in a US$150 million funding round led by Fiserv, according to a statement.
The company’s shares have gained 15 per cent in 2025, giving the company a market value of about A$30 billion (S$24.9 billion).
Xero is New Zealand’s biggest company by market value, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

title: FedEx guidance disappoints with tariffs weighing on demand
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAnalysts had already reduced their 2026 profit estimates for FedEx in recent months.
FedEx forecast a worse than expected profit for the current quarter, in a sign that soft parcel demand and uncertainty over global trade are unlikely to abate in the near term.
Adjusted earnings in the fiscal first quarter will be US$3.40 to US$4 a share, the company said in a statement on June 24.
Although it typically provides a full-year forecast, FedEx said it would share its outlook only for the current quarter due to the “uncertain global demand environment”.
The forecast assumes no further negative developments in the global trade environment, the company said.

title: Iran-Israel ceasefire lifts US stocks
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in New York City.
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks jumped on June 24 as an Iran-Israel ceasefire appeared to hold through its first day and oil prices continued their retreat.
The broad-based S&P 500 advanced 1.1 per cent to 6,092.18, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.4 per cent to 19,912.53.
But Mr Powell “didn’t close the door” to a potential rate cut, Mr Hogan said.
Defence-related stocks were lower with the improving conditions in the Middle East.

title: Powell repeats rate cuts can wait as Fed studies tariff impacts
summary:
Mr Trump, who appointed Mr Powell as chair in his first term but is expected to replace him when his term ends next spring, has repeatedly called for steep rate cuts.
Mr Powell has built strong alliances in Congress over his three terms as Fed chair, often getting plaudits from Republicans and Democrats for his oversight of the Fed.
In his prepared testimony, Mr Powell said the economy remains in a “solid position”, with low unemployment and inflation far below its pandemic-era peak.
The outcome of that policy shift will be critical for the Fed to understand, Mr Powell said.
“Policy changes continue to evolve, and their effects on the economy remain uncertain,” Mr Powell said.

title: ‘We just want our money’: Income Insurance shareholders disappointed at failed Allianz deal
summary:
Income has 15,510 individual shareholders who hold 27.4 million Income shares, according to its 2024 annual report.
The couple said they have held on to Income shares as they have enjoyed healthy dividends in the past.
Ms Tan was elected to the board of NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative as an independent non-executive director on May 26, 2017.
NE holds about 78 million Income shares, representing close to 73 per cent of Income.
“As a shareholder of Income Insurance, you are now participating in the company’s economic interest and its growth and will be able to participate in any liquidity event involving the shares of Income Insurance,” Mr Ong said.

title: Tech services firm Kyndryl opens Asean AI lab in S’pore, to fill AI jobs with local workers
summary:
SINGAPORE – About 50 jobs in artificial intelligence (AI) are being created at technology services firm Kyndryl, and they are open only to Singapore citizens and permanent residents.
The New York City-based company announced on June 24 its intention to base its Asean AI Innovation Lab in Singapore, following two similar hubs it opened in the UK and France, and will hire data scientists, data engineers and AI full-stack developers.
The programme, called AI Cloud Takeoff, is part of the Government’s $150 million Enterprise Compute Initiative to speed up the adoption of AI and cloud technologies among local businesses.
Mr Philbert Gomez, senior vice-president at DISG, said Kyndryl’s new lab will bolster Singapore’s ambition to be the centre of AI innovation by tying industry, academia and government in collaboration.
Candidates would preferably have AI consulting experience and knowledge of gen AI technologies, including large language models from major cloud providers.

title: Singapore shares rise on Israel-Iran ceasefire and Wall St rally; STI up 0.7%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index gained 0.7 per cent or 25.04 points to 3,904.3.
SINGAPORE - Local shares ended higher on June 24, tracking a rally on Wall Street after the US brokered a ceasefire in the conflict between Israel and Iran.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.7 per cent, or 25.04 points, to 3,904.3.
The Hang Seng Index rose 2.1 per cent, the Nikkei 225 gained 1.1 per cent and the Kospi was up 3 per cent.
On the STI, Jardine Matheson Holdings was the top gainer, rising 2.3 per cent to US$46.35.

title: ST Explains: How do volatile oil prices affect Singapore consumers?
summary:
Analysts also feared that oil prices would shoot past US$100 a barrel.
Still, it is clear that oil prices are likely to be more volatile moving forward, especially as the situation in the Middle East remains uncertain.
Singapore Airlines also uses a fuel-hedging policy to manage the volatility of oil prices.
“Should oil prices continue to rise, this could lead to higher costs of electricity generation and in turn higher electricity prices.
When it comes to shipping and freight services, oil prices will also have an impact on costs .

title: Construction player Lum Chang’s interior design firm files to list in Catalist IPO
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe move comes after its spin-off from mainboard-listed Lum Chang Holdings was completed, following an internal restructuring exercise on June 19.
– Interior fit-out firm Lum Chang Creations has filed a preliminary prospectus for a listing on the Singapore Exchange’s (SGX) Catalist board, the second firm in a week to have lodged documents for a listing on the local bourse.
Lum Chang Creations specialises in urban revitalisation projects, with a focus on conservation, restoration, interior fit-out and addition and alteration works.
Shares of Lum Chang Holdings closed up 7.35 per cent at 36 cents on June 24.
If its IPO is successful, Lum Chang Creations would be the second company to list on Catalist in 2025 .

title: ThaiBev billionaire leaves his ownership of company to his five children
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe move stopped short of handing over full control of Thai Beverage, the drinks giant and maker of Chang beer.
SINGAPORE - Thailand’s richest man Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi distributed stakes in holding firms which control about 66 per cent of Singapore-listed Thai Beverage to his five children, though he stopped short of handing over full control of the drinks giant.
A cornerstone of that is ThaiBev, the maker of Chang beer, which also operates distilleries across Scotland.
The share transfer is part of a longer-term shift in the holdings of the patriarch and his late wife Khunying Wanna Sirivadhanabhakdi as succession beckons.
Shares of ThaiBev rose 1.1 per cent, or 0.5 cent, to 46 cents on June 24.

title: Oil tanker rates soar to highest since 2023 on Middle East conflict
summary:
SINGAPORE – Tanker rates extended gains as tensions in the Middle East ratchet higher, with ship owners demanding bigger fees to call at ports in the Persian Gulf after the US launched strikes on Iran over the weekend.
Navies have cautioned about an elevated risk to shipping in the region, though for now flows appear largely unaffected.
Forward-freight agreements – a derivative of shipping rates – for the key route for supertankers carrying crude from the Middle East to East Asia rose in the week’s opening session.
On June 23, the Joint Maritime Information Centre (JMIC), which liaises between navies and merchant ships, said it assesses an elevated threat risk for shipping.
“JMIC recommends the shipping industry remain vigilant to the changing security environment and have threat and risk mitigation plans at the ready.” BLOOMBERG

title: Amazon to invest $69.5 billion in the UK over next three years
summary:
- Online retail giant Amazon will invest £40 billion (S$69.5 billion) in the UK over the next three years, the government said on June 24, a boost for Prime Minister Keir Starmer as he struggles to kick-start the economy.
He announced in February that Amazon would invest more than US$100 billion (S$128 billion) in 2025, primarily to boost its cloud and AI capabilities.
In June, Amazon also announced major investments in North Carolina (US$10 billion) and Pennsylvania (US$20 billion), again for data centres and AI projects.
Amazon is currently under investigation by the UK Food Regulator, suspected of late payments to food suppliers.
If found guilty, Amazon could be fined up to 1 per cent of its annual UK turnover.

title: Second Fed official signals support for faster rate cuts in latest sign of division at US central bank
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe comments by US Federal Reserve's vice-chair for supervision Michelle Bowman is the latest sign of division among Fed policymakers about interest rates.
Mr Powell hinted that he was more focused on the risk of inflation right now, partly because the labour market has so far remained solid.
Ms Bowman and Mr Waller were appointed to their positions by Mr Trump, and Mr Waller, in particular, is often spoken about as a potential candidate to succeed Mr Powell when his term as chair ends in 2026r.
Ms Bowman and Mr Waller joined Mr Powell and other officials in voting to hold interest rates steady at last week’s Fed meeting.
But, Ms Bowman said, she is concerned that cracks are beginning to show in the labour market.

title: A $5 billion Hong Kong family office makes first crypto foray
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWealth managers are taking steps to accommodate rising crypto adoption among their clients.
- A money manager to some of Hong Kong’s richest individuals will start investing in crypto, as more favourable regulations attract a wider array of investors to the digital-asset sector.
The decision is part of recent moves by VMS to diversify into more liquid investments, Mr Cheung said.
Mr Cheung declined to identify VMS’ clients.
VMS opted to to make its crypto foray through Re7 rather than investing directly in tokens like Bitcoin to limit volatility, Mr Cheung said.

title: Attempted misuse of work pass for foreign students or trainees ongoing for years: Industry insiders
summary:
SINGAPORE – Errant employers and agents have for years attempted to illegally bring in foreign workers for rank-and-file roles such as dishwashers under a pass intended for foreigners to undergo short-term professional training here, said industry insiders.
The ministry has stepped up enforcement efforts against employers who misuse the TEP scheme to circumvent the work pass framework, said the spokesperson.
The TEP allows foreign students or trainees from a company’s overseas office or subsidiary to undergo practical training for professional, managerial, executive or specialist jobs here for up to three months.
However, this is subject to a levy, and still counts towards an employer’s quota for work permit holders.
The short duration of a TEP limits the types of roles that errant employers can practicably assign TEP holders.

title: US stocks close higher as rate-cut hopes offset Iran war fears
summary:
“The rally is a bit surprising,” said Mr Jay Hatfield, CEO and portfolio manager at InfraCap in New York.
Fiserv’s shares rose 4.4 per cent following its announcement that it would launch a new digital asset platform.
AI-server-maker Super Micro Computer dropped 9.8 per cent after it announced a private offering of US$2 billion (S$2.6 billion) five-year convertible bonds.
On the Nasdaq, 2,591 stocks rose and 1,875 fell as advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 1.38-to-1 ratio.
Volume on US exchanges was 18.60 billion shares, compared with the 18.16 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.

title: Hong Kong’s smaller developers become $28 billion risk for banks
summary:
Banks are tightening the screws on mid-sized developers that have at least HK$173 billion (S$28 billion) in debt.
The shift underscores growing caution in a sector long regarded as a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s economy.
The pressure threatens to erode bank margins, weigh on the local job sector, and send ripples through overseas markets where Hong Kong developers have long been active players.
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and banks are handling developers’ financing needs on a case-by-case basis, Hong Kong Financial Secretary Paul Chan said in an interview with local media on June 23.
“The deterioration in Hong Kong smaller developers’ financial health can fuel a domino effect on the economy,” said Natixis senior economist Gary Ng.

title: MAS sets on record its regulatory oversight in Allianz’s offer for Income Insurance
summary:
SINGAPORE - The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on June 23 set on record matters related to its regulatory oversight during German insurer Allianz’s planned offer to buy a majority stake in home-grown Income Insurance in 2024.
It was later revealed that Allianz had a capital reduction plan where Income would return $1.85 billion in cash to shareholders within three years.
“The proposed transaction was subject to further regulatory approval from MAS for Allianz to obtain effective control and become a substantial shareholder of Income,” said MAS.
“ There was no application to MAS to approve the capital reduction plan, neither did MAS give any such approval.
Any capital reduction would need separate and specific MAS approval,” said the regulator.

title: Oil prices plunge as Trump announces ceasefire in the Middle East
summary:
SINGAPORE – Oil prices fell sharply on June 24 as US President Donald Trump said a ceasefire had been agreed on between Iran and Israel, alleviating worries of supply disruptions in the Middle East – a major oil-producing region.
Mr Trump announced on June 23 that Israel and Iran fully agreed to a ceasefire, adding that Iran would begin the ceasefire immediately, followed by Israel after 12 hours.
“Moving forward, the extent to which Israel and Iran adhere to the recently announced ceasefire conditions will play a significant role in determining oil prices,” Ms Sachdeva said.
On June 23, he demanded that energy producers push down crude prices following US military strikes on Iran, while also urging the US Energy Department to boost drilling.
Lower oil prices may help to quell global inflationary pressures, easing the challenge facing central bankers and potentially aiding the case for interest rate reductions.

title: ‘No intention’ to convert Great Eastern Class C non-voting shares to ordinary ones in 5 years: OCBC
summary:
SINGAPORE – OCBC Bank said it has “no intention” to convert its Class C non-voting shares in Great Eastern to ordinary shares when they come up for conversion in five years.
“OCBC is electing for the Class C non-voting shares at Great Eastern’s request to help Great Eastern to meet the free-float requirement and the resumption of trading,” it said.
The statement was made in response to media reports about how OCBC can still propose the privatisation and delisting of Great Eastern by converting these non-voting shares to ordinary voting shares.
This includes a one-for-one bonus issue comprising new ordinary shares and newly created Class C non-voting shares.
All shareholders will receive the bonus shares unless they elect to receive the Class C non-voting shares; OCBC said it intends to opt to receive the Class C non-voting shares.

title: Wilmar expands in Nigeria as nation’s currency crisis ebbs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWilmar last week announced a plan to acquire all the shares in a palm oil venture with PZ Cussons for $90 million.
– Wilmar International, the Singapore-listed agribusiness, plans to boost its palm oil business in Nigeria, wooed by policies that have helped stabilise the naira and bolstered the availability of US dollars in Africa’s most populous nation.
The company, led by billionaire Kuok Khoon Hong, last week announced a plan to acquire all the shares in a palm oil venture with PZ Cussons for US$70 million (S$90.5 million).
Still, Nigeria has struggled to boost output while rivals like Thailand and Colombia have seen production jump.
“A significant portion of Nigeria’s palm oil production still comes from small-holder farmers,” Mr Pillai said.

title: STI down amid mixed regional trading after US strikes on Iran
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAcross the broader market, losers beat gainers 269 to 217, after 1.16 billion securities worth $1.28 billion changed hands.
SINGAPORE – Local stocks ended lower on June 23 amid a mixed trading session in the region, after the US launched strikes on three of Iran’s nuclear facilities over the weekend.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1 per cent or 4.17 points to 3,879.26.
Across the broader market, losers beat gainers 269 to 217, after 1.16 billion securities worth $1.28 billion changed hands.
“What’s going for markets is a lot of idle liquidity on the sidelines that could provide market support, should there be sharp pullbacks,” he said.

title: Singapore core inflation dips in May but analysts say may pick up on escalating Middle East conflict
summary:
The drop-back in core inflation in May was driven mainly by lower food inflation, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said in their joint report on June 23.
Core inflation excludes private transport and accommodation costs to better reflect the expenses of households here.
DBS Bank senior economist Chua Han Teng said the rising global crude oil prices could translate into higher energy import prices for Singapore.
All these, he said, meant any potential disruption and loss of crude oil supply from Iran can in theory be absorbed.
They added that while global crude oil prices have risen in recent weeks, oil prices remain close to the average in 2024.

title: Analysts weigh impact of possible oil shock on Singapore economy after US strikes on Iran
summary:
Global oil benchmark Brent, after surging as much as 5.7 per cent to US$81.40, was also little changed at US$77.05 a barrel at 5.06pm .
However, oil prices are far from 2025’s low of US$60.23 a barrel on May 5.
World Bank estimates suggest that a 10 per cent increase in oil prices raises overall inflation by 0.4 percentage point in a median economy.
StanChart placed Singapore sixth in a global ranking of economies sensitive to rising oil prices.
Singapore, which has a significant refining capacity and is a major oil trading hub, imports more crude oil and petroleum products than it exports.

title: Tesla starts long-awaited robotaxi service with low-key roll-out
summary:
– Tesla launched its long-awaited robotaxi service on the streets of Austin on June 22 following almost a decade of hype from Mr Elon Musk, kicking off a precarious new era for the carmaker.
The low-key roll-out has nonetheless been highly anticipated by investors, who are counting on the new business line to revive a company battered by flagging sales and a consumer backlash against Mr Musk.
Austin has become a hot spot for autonomous vehicle operations.
In Texas, Tesla faces few restrictions to operate autonomous vehicles.
At the federal level, the authorities are taking steps to ease the deployment of autonomous vehicles without driver controls like steering wheels or pedals.

title: Air India crash risks fuelling up to 30% jump in airline insurance premiums
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxInsurance claims for the June 12 Air India crash are expected in the realm of US$475 million (S$613.2 million).
– Indian insurance policy sellers expect the cost of coverage for airlines to spike as much as 30 per cent after the deadliest aviation crash in more than a decade.
Premium hikes of that scale would be larger than for previous crashes, given the enormity of the Air India accident, the brokers said.
The insurance premium increase would be for all airlines, said people familiar with the matter, who asked not to be identified discussing private matters.
The premium increase is expected to be large, and further loss of aircraft could drive premiums to a record, the people said.

title: Two oil supertankers make U-turns in Strait of Hormuz after US strikes
summary:
– Two supertankers, both capable of hauling about two million barrels of crude, made U-turns in the Strait of Hormuz after US air strikes on Iran raised the risk of a response that will ensnare commercial shipping in the region.
Together, the tankers offer the first signs of a re-routing of oil ships following the US strikes.
Oil tanker owners and traders are closely watching for signs that the escalation in the Middle East will affect vessel movements and flows.
The shipping companies said they are closely monitoring the situation and sharing updates with ships operating in the region.
On a per-day basis, chartering costs were near US$46,000 (S$59,000) on June 17 , according to data from the Baltic Exchange .

title: FedEx founder Fred Smith, who transformed parcel delivery, dead at 80
summary:
FedEx was conceived in a paper that Mr Smith wrote as a Yale University undergraduate in 1965.
Mr Smith was celebrated as one of the great business minds and executives of his time.
Mr Smith got a personal meeting with then President Bill Clinton in the Oval Office.
Mr Smith was widely reported to be in the running to serve as Mr Bush’s secretary of defence before withdrawing from consideration.
After Mr Smith’s death, Mr Bush released a statement hailing Mr Smith, “my Yale fraternity brother”, as “one of the finest Americans of our generation”.

title: Central banks in Asia becoming wary of currency intervention
summary:
SINGAPORE – Some of Asia’s biggest central banks in emerging markets look to be dialling back their interventions in the currency market.
The central banks of India and Malaysia have reduced the size of some derivatives positions they use to weaken their currencies.
Best betsTraders are now trying to game out which currencies have the most to gain from a period of reduced intervention.
Bank Indonesia pushed back against volatility on June 19 as Middle East tensions hit emerging market currencies.
But for some of emerging Asia’s most interventionist central banks, the calculus appears to have shifted in favour of a less hands-on approach.

title: Honda supplier rethinks China relationship as trade war bites
summary:
– As the US-China trade war expands into the auto, steel and rare earths sectors, few companies are feeling the pressure more than top Japanese car parts supplier Daido Steel.
But rare earths are proving to be a particular sticking point in trade negotiations.
Success has been limited though: Japan depends on China for 60 per cent of its rare earths supply, down from 80 per cent to 90 per cent.
As well as seeking alternative supplies, Daido Steel focused on new technology to use fewer rare earths.
Daido Steel also supplies magnets indirectly to automakers by way of Aisin Corp and Denso Corp – two of Japan’s biggest suppliers.

title: Oil prices surge as Trump’s attack on Iran ramps up risks to supplies

The Middle East accounts for about a third of global crude output, and higher, sustained prices will boost inflationary pressures.

title: Digital token service providers relocating should not be surprised at new licensing rule: MAS
summary:
Digital payment tokens include cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, while tokenised capital market products are digital representations of securities such as stocks or bonds.
Still, the Republic could also risk losing talent and support structures that help the digital asset industry mature, depending on how broadly the rules are applied.
For example, the central bank launched Project Orchid in 2021 to examine the infrastructure needed to develop a digital Singapore dollar.
Mr Gerald Goh, chief executive of digital asset banking group Sygnum Singapore, said MAS’ latest regulatory move is likely to strengthen Singapore’s position as Asia’s premier hub for institutional digital asset adoption.

title: Wilmar slips in S’pore after anti-graft action in Indonesia; Singtel falls
