title: Pharmaceutical stocks tumble on Trump’s plan to cut US drug prices
summary:
Although the feasibility of Mr Trump’s plan is “questionable”, his announcement is negative for the pharmaceutical sector, Mr Hidemaru Yamaguchi, a healthcare sector analyst at Citigroup Global Markets Japan, wrote in a note.
Mr Trump cited the industry’s argument, but said it meant “the ‘suckers’ of America” ended up bearing those costs “for no reason whatsoever”.
His plan seems similar to one proposed during his first term aimed at capping Medicare drug prices, Mr Stephen Barker, an equities analyst at Jefferies Japan, wrote in a note.
Still, a renewed push to lower drug prices may have an “enormous” impact on the sector’s revenues, Mr Barker said.
Mr Trump’s plan likely affects only the drugs up for price negotiations under the IRA, said Mr Evan Seigerman, head of healthcare research at BMO Capital Markets.

title: Toyota faces biggest hit from Trump tariffs among automakers
summary:
- Toyota Motor is the biggest carmaker in the world – and also the auto industry’s biggest loser when it comes to projected losses from US President Donald Trump’s trade war.
But that rate of loss is not too far off the mark from the US$1.2 billion hit Toyota is projecting based on 730 hours per month.
Japan production pledgeToyota has already invested heavily to build out its US operations – including spending US$13.9 billion on a new battery plant in North Carolina.
Chairman Akio Toyoda has repeatedly pledged to keep making at least three million vehicles a year in Japan.
Toyota also said it has increased direct manufacturing employment in the US to 31,000 workers, up from 25,000 in 2016.

title: Private credit firm Zagga sees growing interest from Singapore and Asean for Australia real estate
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore and Asean investors keen to jump into Australia’s housing market have typically favoured bricks-and-mortar investment properties – but private real estate credit funds are gaining traction as an alternative avenue.
PHOTO: ZAGGAPrivate real estate credit comprises loans provided by non-bank lenders, like Zagga, to property developers.
Zagga recently launched a new Singapore variable capital company (VCC) – the Zagga Real Estate Credit Fund (ZRECF) – and has obtained A$20 million in commitments.
PHOTO: ZAGGAZRECF will invest directly in prime commercial real estate across Australia’s east coast, where the markets are “most liquid”.
Real estate private credit in Australia is delivering “decent returns” of around 8.5 per cent in Singapore dollars versus the dismal savings rates offered by banks, he said.

title: China stocks rally, renminbi gains after US-China reach trade deal
summary:
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index extended the gains to over 3 per cent after the news, while the Hang Seng Tech Index rallied more than 5 per cent.
The renminbi strengthened to 7.2001 against the US dollar to reach a six-month high, while its offshore counterpart rose more than 0.5 per cent.
China’s blue-chip CSI 300 Index closed up 1.2 per cent and the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.8 per cent before the details came out.
The Hong Kong benchmark Hang Seng has been down 0.3 per cent since April 2.
Leading gains on May 12, the CSI Defence Index surged 5 per cent and the info-tech sub-sector index jumped 0.9 per cent.

title: Nissan job cuts double to 20,000 in huge overhaul, NHK says
summary:
Nissan will cut around 15 per cent of its workforce, both in Japan and overseas.
TOKYO – Nissan Motor will eliminate 11,000 more jobs than previously planned, NHK reported on May 12, as part of a plan to restructure its flailing business.
Now those job cuts will be closer to 20,000, or around 15 per cent of the entire workforce, according to Japan’s national broadcaster.
The alliance was formally ended in February , and Nissan has been sliding further into its worst position in some 26 years.
He will be expected to shed light on speculation over job cuts and potential plant closures when Nissan announces fiscal results on May 13.

title: US dollar surges after US and China agree to reduce tariffs
summary:
– The US dollar soared and government bonds sold off as markets reacted to a de-escalation in the trade war between China and America , which agreed to temporarily lower some tariffs for 90 days .
A gauge of dollar strength rose as much as 0.9 per cent and the yen, a traditional haven, plunged as progress in talks stoked risk appetite across asset classes.
He targeted China with particularly punitive tariffs, sparking a trade war and fears of a recession.
In the US, Nasdaq 100 futures surged as much as 3.9 per cent while S&P 500 futures rose 3.1 per cent.
Still, the move towards de-escalation of trade tariffs spurred some big sector-level moves in Europe, with shipping stocks including Danish container giant A.P.

title: Chinese EV battery giant CATL aims to raise $5.2b in Hong Kong IPO
summary:
– Chinese EV battery giant CATL aims to raise US$4 billion (S$5.2 billion) in its Hong Kong listing scheduled for May 20, said a statement filed to the bourse on May 12, making it the largest initial public offering (IPO) expected in the city so far in 2025 .
The company is already listed in Shenzhen, and its plan for a secondary listing in Hong Kong was announced in a filing in December with the stock exchange.
Founded in 2011 in the eastern Chinese city of Ningde, CATL was initially propelled to success by rapid growth in the domestic market.
CATL is also planning to limit the types of US investors that can participate in its Hong Kong listing, an indication that US-China tensions may be spilling into the IPO market, Bloomberg reported on May 11.
It is unusual for such a large share offering in Hong Kong not to be available to onshore US investors.

title: UOB, DBS, OCBC expect more earnings volatility as tariffs hit home
summary:
UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong noted that macroeconomic uncertainties from US tariffs had triggered significant market volatility and disruptions in global trade.
Consequently, the bank will pause its 2025 earnings guidance until the macroeconomic situation stabilises.
He had last bought shares in UOB on Feb 20, scooping up 200,000 shares at $38.65 apiece or $7.7 million in total.
The bank is already expecting net profit for 2025 to come in below 2024’s, owing mainly to the global minimum tax.
Shares of the three banks closed flat for the week, with UOB last trading at $34.83, DBS at $43.71 and OCBC at $16.23.

title: Brunei’s economic diversification draws Singapore investments
summary:
Costs came in at 60 per cent of a similar set-up in Singapore, thanks to lower rent and wage costs.
Ms Lim Jing Jun, director for South-east Asia at Enterprise Singapore, listed opportunities in renewable energy, the digital economy and food supply chain resilience for Singapore businesses.
Enterprise Singapore has supported several Singapore firms in entering Brunei, such as Rotary Engineering and halal food company Pondok Abang.
In November 2024, Pondok Abang tied up with Bruneian government-linked company PDS Abattoir to distribute and market PDS Abattoir’s products in Singapore.
Since March, CyberSafe’s teams have been working in sync with augmented reality glasses across its offices in Singapore, Brunei and the Philippines.

title: Delta, Korean Air buy 25% of WestJet in $714 million deal
summary:
SINGAPORE – Delta Air Lines and Korean Air Lines will spend US$550 million (S$714 million) acquiring a stake in Canadian carrier WestJet, adding to the broader consolidation among airlines globally.
The Onex group will continue to own and control Calgary, Alberta-based WestJet.
As part of the deal, Delta will buy a 15 per cent minority interest for US$330 million, while Korean Air will pay US$220 million for a 10 per cent stake.
WestJet will “ultimately one day” be “reintroduced to the public markets”, co-head of Onex Partners Tawfiq Popatia said on the same call.
Deutsche Lufthansa recently took control of Italian carrier ITA, Alaska Airlines snapped up Hawaiian Airlines, while Korean Air itself finalised approval for its merger with Asiana Airlines.

title: US stocks end on a quiet note with focus on US-China talks
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks ended the week on a quiet note on May 9 after oscillating between slight gains and declines, as investors gauged President Donald Trump’s comments on Chinese tariffs ahead of weekend trade talks between the two countries.
For the week, the S&P 500 fell 0.47 per cent, the Nasdaq declined 0.27 per cent, and the Dow fell 0.16 per cent.
Of the 450 S&P 500 companies that reported earnings through May 9 morning, about 76 per cent topped analyst expectations.
Days after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, Fed policymakers on May 9 pointed to increasing economic risks from Mr Trump’s tariffs, echoing comments from Chair Jerome Powell at the meeting earlier this week.
The S&P 500 posted six new 52-week highs and three new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 53 new highs and 97 new lows.

title: Singapore stocks rise on US-UK trade deal; STI up 0.7%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Straits Times Index went up 0.7 per cent or 27.94 points to 3,876.16 with gainers outstripping losers 272 to 206.
SINGAPORE – News that the US has struck a trade deal with Britain – the first since President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs worldwide – gave local investors a welcome boost on May 9.
The optimistic response to the deal sent the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.7 per cent or 27.94 points to 3,876.16, with gainers outstripping losers 272 to 206 on lacklustre trade of 810.1 million securities worth $1.1 billion.
Those gains were underpinned by a positive session on Wall Street overnight on the back of the trade deal that Mr Trump dubbed “full and comprehensive”.
ST Engineering was the STI’s top gainer, rising 1.6 per cent to $7.63, while Jardine Matheson Holdings led the losers, falling 1.6 per cent to US$46.49.

title: CDL fails in bid to buy out New Zealand hotel unit
summary:
SINGAPORE – City Developments Limited (CDL) has failed in a bid to buy out its listed New Zealand hotel unit, in another setback for the embattled Singapore developer.
The company controlled by Singapore’s richest family had sought to take Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand (MCK) private.
CDL had offered to buy the 24 per cent of ordinary shares it did not own.
CDL already controls the firm and managed to increase its stake to nearly 84 per cent after the latest proposal.
When it made the latest offer, CDL said it will continue to generate profit through hotel assets rather than winding up the portfolio.

title: China’s exports to US slump 21% in April but soar to South-east Asia in rush to beat tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina's total exports rose 8.1 per cent but shipments to the US fell 21 per cent after the imposition of tariffs in early April.
– China’s exports rose more than forecast, even as shipments to the US slumped sharply in the first month after US President Donald Trump hit its goods with tariffs of 145 per cent.
China’s tariffs on American goods meant that imports from the US fell almost 14 per cent.
Their production is highly reliant on China’s exports in raw materials and industrial inputs, so China’s exports got support,” said Dr Dan Wang, China director at Eurasia Group.
China’s trade surplus with the US dropped to US$20.5 billion (S$26.6 billion) in April from US$27.6 billion in March, a win for Mr Trump, who has repeatedly said he wants to narrow the gap.

title: Apple, GM among US firms facing billions in tariff costs
summary:
Among US companies that have disclosed financial projections so far, GM sees a US$5 billion (S$6.5 billion) hit in 2025 , while Apple expects US$900 million in higher costs in the current quarter.
Combined with unrelated costs associated with customer returns, the move lowered its profitability during the first quarter by roughly US$1 billion.
Procter & Gamble estimated current and proposed levies could add US$1 billion to US$1.5 billion to its annual costs.
Medical instrument specialist Thermo Fisher Scientific and Johnson & Johnson each said they expect to lose US$400 million to tariffs in 2025.
Hershey said it sees US$15 million to US$20 million of tariff-driven costs in the second quarter.

title: F&N first-half profit up 0.3% on higher sales of beer, soft drinks and milk
summary:
SINGAPORE – Beverage company Fraser and Neave (F&N) saw profit grow 0.3 per cent for the first half of its fiscal year ended March 31, on the back of stronger sales of its beer, soft drinks and milk.
“F&N has delivered a resilient performance despite the challenging market environment,” said Mr Hui Choon Kit, its chief executive.
In particular, the beer and soft drinks segment saw a 28 per cent rise in revenue, driven by higher sales volumes from Chinese New Year campaigns, the introduction of new products and better pricing, F&N said.
The dairies segment, which is the largest contributor to group earnings, recorded an 8 per cent increase in revenue.
This was supported by strong domestic canned milk sales in key markets, along with increased volumes in Laos and Cambodia.

title: Foreign investors ramp up Singapore logistics bets amid shifting global trade flows
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe 143,000 sq m Sunview Logistics & Container Hub will be one of the largest multi-storey warehouses and automated container depots here once completed in 2027.
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s links to Eastern and Western markets and moves by shippers to reconfigure supply chains amid trade and geopolitical risks are prompting foreign investors to pour funds into logistics facilities here.
The opening of DP World’s Singapore warehouse also comes after the company moved its regional headquarters here from Sydney and Hong Kong in 2021.
The 143,000 sq m Sunview Logistics & Container Hub will be one of the largest such facilities in Singapore when completed in 2027, said ESR.
“The Japanese investors have shown strong confidence in the growth of the Asia-Pacific region and Singapore’s logistics sector,” ESR said.

title: Hong Kong works on image overhaul to attract overseas visitors
summary:
It was the biggest year-on-year quarterly growth in tourists since travel resumed in Hong Kong after the Covid-19 pandemic.
Hong Kong’s image as a tourist-friendly destination has suffered from years of turmoil, including pro-democracy protests, strict Covid-19 measures and Beijing’s clampdown on freedoms in the special administrative region.
But economic uncertainty in the mainland is leading Chinese travellers to pull back on luxury shopping, a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s tourism sector, spurring the city’s efforts to diversify overseas arrivals.
The plan hopes to attract visitors through sports and cultural events programmes that could help re-establish Hong Kong as a regional events hub.
We are telling people that they are all welcome to come to Hong Kong.” BLOOMBERG

title: Asia’s super rich rapidly scale back US exposure on Trump’s trade war
summary:
Singapore – Some of Asia’s richest families are cutting exposure to US assets, saying President Donald Trump’s tariffs have made the world’s largest economy much less predictable.
They are allocating more to Asia, primarily China and Hong Kong, where valuations are more attractive.
The moves by private individuals echo a broader, emerging shift away from the world’s largest financial market as the Trump administration’s policies undermine its appeal.
For many of the affluent in Asia, the world’s largest economy has also been a favoured choice to send their children to college.
Mr Trump could dial back tariffs as quickly as he started them.

title: OCBC keeps 2025 earnings guidance amid uncertainties; Q1 profit falls 5% but beats forecast
summary:
SINGAPORE – OCBC Bank has maintained its 2025 earnings guidance despite warning of a challenging economic environment and posting a 5 per cent decline in first-quarter earnings.
Net profit for the three months to March 31 came in at $1.88 billion, down from $1.98 billion a year earlier, mainly on lower net interest income.
“If the economic situation is going down, (which means) economic growth is lower, loan growth will be lower as well,” she said.
Ms Wong noted in an earlier statement that the bank continued to see deposit inflows and loan growth despite the more volatile environment.
While DBS and OCBC broadly maintained their 2025 earnings guidances and met analyst forecasts, UOB suspended its earnings outlook, citing tariff uncertainties, as it reported earnings below estimates.

title: Toyota expects $1.6 billion profit hit in two months from tariffs
summary:
– Toyota Motor said US President Donald Trump’s tariffs will result in a 180 billion yen (S$1.6 billion) hit to operating income in just two months, with the Japanese carmaker joining a growing list of companies grappling with the fallout of trade turmoil.
The carmaker said its latest annual operating profit was 4.8 trillion yen, well below the record 5.35 trillion yen for the 2024 fiscal year – a record for any Japanese company.
The manufacturer ended the fiscal year with profit rising 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter to 1.1 trillion yen.
Separately, on May 8, Mitsubishi Motors said it could suffer a 40 billion yen hit from tariffs.
That was reflected in its forecast for 100 billion yen in full-year operating income, which fell short of analyst expectations.

title: ST Engineering posts 8% rise in Q1 revenue to $2.9 billion as contract wins surge
summary:
SINGAPORE – ST Engineering’s revenue rose 8 per cent to $2.9 billion for the first quarter ended March, from $2.7 billion in the corresponding year-ago period, on the back of broad-based growth across all segments.
The group reported contract wins amounting to $4.4 billion for the first quarter, bringing its order book to $29.8 billion as at March 31.
Its defence and public security unit secured $2.7 billion of jobs in the quarter.
Meanwhile, ST Engineering said it is seeing “strong order momentum” as well as demand for “higher-value solutions” for smart mobility.
On the ongoing tariff war, ST Engineering said it sees “immaterial financial impact” for the group, but continues to monitor the “evolving situation”.

title: US stocks rise after Trump announces UK trade deal
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWall Street stocks climbed early on May 8, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4 per cent about 20 minutes into trading.
NEW YORK – US stocks finished firmly in the green on May 8 after President Donald Trump unveiled a “breakthrough” trade agreement with the United Kingdom.
The deal reduces tariffs on British cars, steel and aluminum, while in return Britain will open up its markets to US beef and other agricultural products.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.6 per cent at 41,368.45, as did the broad-based S&P 500, which closed at 5,663.94.
The enthusiasm in financial markets spread to cryptocurrencies, with bitcoin rallying on the news to trade above US$101,500 for the first time since early February.

title: Bank of England cuts interest rate as US tariffs hit economy
summary:
LONDON - The Bank of England on May 8 cut its key interest rate by a quarter point to 4.25 per cent as the threat of US tariffs starts to weigh on economic growth.
Britain is facing 10-per cent tariffs on most of its goods exported to the United States, its second-largest trading partner after the European Union.
With the latest rate cut priced in by markets, investors were looking for any shift in language by the BoE’s Monetary Policy Committee that hinted at further reductions in 2025.
Also May 8, the central banks of Norway and Sweden kept their key interest rates unchanged while signalling future cuts were possible amid economic uncertainty.
The European Central Bank cut eurozone borrowing costs in April.

title: Singapore stocks retreat as investors keep eye on tariff negotiations; STI dips 0.4%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThere was a modest fall in the Straits Times Index, which fell 0.4 per cent or 17.15 points to 3,848.22.
SINGAPORE – Local investors kept their powder dry on May 8 as global markets awaited news of the trade deal between Britain and the US.
The upshot was a modest retreat in the Straits Times Index, which fell 0.4 per cent, or 17.15 points, to 3,848.22.
The S&P 500 added 0.4 per cent, the Dow Industrials advanced 0.7 per cent and the tech-focused Nasdaq gained 0.3 per cent.
It was much the same elsewhere: Japan’s Nikkei and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng added 0.4 per cent, while Seoul’s Kospi and Australian shares both gained 0.2 per cent.

title: Shopee parent Sea opens new financial services HQ in S’pore, rebrands SeaMoney as Monee
summary:
SINGAPORE – Gaming and e-commerce firm Sea opened its global headquarters for its digital financial services business in Singapore on May 8.
The firm also announced that the business, called SeaMoney, has been rebranded as Monee.
Sea has since grown into a regional technology powerhouse with three core businesses – digital entertainment, e-commerce and digital payments and financial services.
Monee has become one of South-east Asia’s largest digital financial platforms since its launch in 2014 and now serves users across Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan, Vietnam and Brazil.
Correction note: An earlier version of the story said that gaming and e-commerce firm Sea Group opened its global headquarters for its digital financial services business in Singapore on May 8.

title: US stocks end mostly up, rebounding from bad GDP report
summary:
NEW YORK – Wall Street stocks finished mostly higher on April 30 after digesting a poor US gross domestic product reading that was offset by solid consumer spending data.
But equity markets moved gradually higher throughout the day, rising after mid-morning data showed personal spending in March actually topped earlier estimates.
Part of the contraction in GDP was due to a surge in imports from businesses seeking to get ahead of Mr Trump’s myriad tariffs.
Besides the GDP data, payroll firm ADP reported that private sector employment grew by 62,000 in April, a sharp slowdown from a revised 147,000 in March.
But travel tech company Booking Holdings rose 3.9 per cent as it reported higher quarterly revenues even as it pointed to “uncertainty around the near-term geopolitical and macroeconomic environment.” AFP

title: US economy contracts in first quarter; Trump says ‘be patient’, blames Biden
summary:
In response, Mr Trump blamed his predecessor, Mr Joe Biden.
The figures were published on the 101st day since Mr Trump’s return to office on Jan 20.
Not surprisingThe report reinforced Americans’ growing disapproval of Mr Trump’s handling of the economy so far.
Mr Trump on April 29 softened the blow of his auto tariffs through an executive order mixing credits with relief from other tariffs on parts and materials.
Mr Trump sees tariffs as a tool to raise revenue to offset his promised tax cuts and to revive a long-declining US industrial base.

title: Labour movement has made good strides helping workers earn a better living, live a better life: NTUC
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxNTUC said it will continue to work with the Government and employers to support workers, overcome challenges and seize new opportunities.
SINGAPORE – The labour movement and its affiliated unions have made good strides in advancing its mission to help workers earn a better living and live a better life, said NTUC president K. Thanaletchimi and its secretary-general Ng Chee Meng.
This funding will support caregivers of children with special needs and single caregivers with young children and elderly dependants.
On the support for youth, NTUC introduced the NTUC Starter Awards in 2024 , offering bond-free scholarships and leadership programmes for students in institutes of higher learning.
Also cited was how NTUC synergised its Company Training Committee initiative with SkillsFuture Singapore’s SkillsFuture Queen Bee programme in a “first-of-its-kind tripartite partnership”, enabling workers to take on higher-value jobs.

title: Singapore stocks rise on April 30, snapping four-day losing streak; STI up 0.7%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index gained 0.7 per cent or 27.33 points to 3,832.51.
SINGAPORE – Equities on the Singapore bourse rose on April 30, as four sessions of losses drew some bargain hunting.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.7 per cent or 27.33 points to 3,832.51.
The top gainer was property developer Hongkong Land, which rose 4 per cent or 1 9 US cents to US$4.89.
OCBC Bank closed 1.1 per cent or 17 cents higher at $16.15.

title: Singapore investors buy 2.5 tonnes of gold bullion in Q1, the most since 2010
summary:
Their demand for gold bars and coins rose 35 per cent year on year to 2.5 tonnes, the highest since records began by World Gold Council (WGC) in 2010.
The gold investment demand in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand also grew steadily at double-digit year-on-year rates, according to the first quarter gold demand report released by WGC on April 30.
Gold jewellery demand declined across the Asean countries, aligning with the global trend amid record-high gold prices.
Singapore , in particular, saw the demand fall 20 per cent on the year, at 1.7 tonnes of gold jewellery purchased.
In particular, the Monetary Authority of Singapore sold three tonnes of gold in the quarter, maintaining its total gold holdings at about 220 tonnes.

title: Chinese sovereign fund CIC to sell $1.3 billion of US private equity investments, sources say
summary:
– Chinese sovereign investor China Investment Corporation (CIC) is selling about US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion) of its private equity (PE) investment portfolio in the secondary market, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
The US has been the Chinese sovereign fund’s biggest investment destination, according to its past public disclosures.
CIC is an active investor in US PE funds.
Potential buyers for the CIC investment portfolio include other sovereign funds, secondary-focused asset managers, and private investors such as family offices, said the people, declining to give details.
US stocks made up 60.29 per cent of CIC’s overseas public market equities as of the end of 2023, the annual report shows.

title: CDL Hospitality Trusts Q1 net property income slides 14.2% to $30 million on lower revenue
summary:
SINGAPORE - Net property income (NPI) for CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) fell 14.2 per cent to $30 million for the first quarter of its fiscal year ended March, from $34.9 million in the year-ago period.
Revenue stood at $63.4 million, down 2.8 per cent from $65.3 million previously.
Its Singapore, New Zealand, Maldives and Italy markets logged declines while its Australia, Japan, UK and Germany markets experienced growth.
The group’s core Singapore market posted declines for NPI of 19.6 per cent, at $17.7 million from $22.1 million in Q1 of FY2024.
Occupancy for its Singapore hotels was down to 75 per cent for the quarter, from 82.1 per cent previously.

title: Samsung chips profit hurt by export controls and falling prices
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSamsung Electronics’ chip business reported a roughly 40 per cent drop in profit after US export controls dented sales of its high-end chips.
SEOUL – Samsung Electronics’ chip business reported a roughly 40 per cent drop in profit after US export controls dented sales of its high-end chips even as it seeks to catch up in the lucrative artificial intelligence (AI) memory arena.
March-quarter operating profit at Samsung’s chip segment tumbled to 1.1 trillion won (S$1 billion) on erosion in average selling price as well as a drop in sales of its key high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips due to export controls, according to a company statement.
It spent 9 trillion won in research and development in its fiscal first quarter, up 16 per cent from a year ago.
That helped boost net income to 8.03 trillion won, above estimates.

title: Singapore's Wilmar posts higher first-quarter profit, flags tariff uncertainty
summary:
Bengaluru - Singapore-listed agribusiness giant Wilmar International reported a 4 per cent rise in first-quarter profit on April 29, and flagged increased market volatility from US tariffs for the rest of 2025.
Wilmar said its core net profit for the three months ended March 31 was US$343 million (S$449 million), up from US$328.4 million in the year-ago period.
The company, one of the world’s largest food producers, posted a higher core net profit on better performance from both its food products and plantation and sugar milling segments.
Wilmar’s first-quarter profit was also boosted by higher earnings from its investments in China, India and South-east Asia, it said.
Weaker contributions from the feed and industrial products segment offset some of the higher profit, the company added.

title: Grab raises full-year profit forecast as Q1 revenue beats estimates on ride demand
summary:
The company saw an 18 per cent rise in revenue to US$773 million for the first quarter, surpassing the average analyst estimate of US$766 million.
Grab narrowed its operating loss to US$21 million from US$75 million.
Net profit came to US$24 million, reversing from a US$104 million loss in the year-ago period, driven by the improved operating loss and higher net finance income, including foreign exchange gains.
Grab, the largest of South-east Asia’s ride-hailing and delivery firms, is trying to prove its cost-cutting drive is yielding results.
GoTo on April 29 reported its third straight quarterly profit on an adjusted basis, helped by cost cuts.

title: China’s factory activity sees worst contraction since 2023 as US tariffs hit
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina’s factory activity slipped back into contraction in April, revealing early damage from the trade war with the United States.
– China’s factory activity slipped into the worst contraction since December 2023, revealing early damage to the world’s second-biggest economy from the trade war with the US.
April’s official manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) fell more than expected to 49 from 50.5 in March, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) said on April 30.
It shows tariffs started to bite,” Mr Robin Xing, chief China economist at Morgan Stanley, said on Bloomberg Television.
Foreign Minister Wang Yi warned countries against caving in to US tariffs threats, saying that appeasement will only embolden the “bully”.

title: UPS to cut 20,000 jobs on slashed Amazon deliveries as US tariffs weigh
summary:
UPS also said a big percentage of the volume reduction from Amazon is money-losing work moving goods from fulfilment centres.
If Mr Trump’s hefty China tariffs stick, fully replacing trade with China will take years.
Mr Trump’s current China tariffs could further slow already sluggish shipments between businesses.
If US consumers buy fewer goods from Amazon because tariffs make prices too high, UPS would suffer.
In the best-case scenario, the US and China will soon come to an agreement that normalises trade, UPS executives said.

title: Apple retains top spot among Singapore’s best employers, with Asia Pacific Breweries at No. 2
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTech giant Apple has retained its ranking as Singapore’s best employer.
SINGAPORE – Tech giant Apple has retained its ranking as Singapore’s best employer in an annual league table compiled by The Straits Times and global research company Statista.
Rounding up the top five are Asia Pacific Breweries Singapore (Heineken Asia Pacific), BMW Group Asia, The Lego Group and GSK .
Singapore’s Best Employers 2025 ranks the top 250 firms among companies and institutions that have at least 200 employees here.
BMW Group Asia, a new entrant to the list of best employers, came in at No.

title: US stocks rally as Trump tempers auto tariffs
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks rose on April 29 as markets digested mixed earnings while applauding a move by President Donald Trump to ease tariffs on automakers.
Investors are “encouraged by the Trump decision to be a little more flexible (...) with the autos,” said Mr Sam Stovall, of CFRA Research.
The broad-based S&P 500 advanced 0.6 per cent to 5,560.83, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6 per cent to 17,461.32.
Mr Stovall predicted stocks could go higher.
Among automakers General Motors fell 0.6 per cent, Ford rose 1.3 per cent and Stellantis gained 2.5 per cent.

title: Electronic Arts lays off hundreds, cancels Titanfall game
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe cancelled project, code-named R7, was an extraction shooter set in the Titanfall universe, according to people familiar with its development.
NEW YORK - Electronic Arts is laying off hundreds of workers and cancelling a Titanfall game that was in development at its Respawn Entertainment subsidiary.
Between 300 and 400 positions were eliminated, including around 100 at Respawn, according to a person familiar with the cuts.
The cancelled project, code-named R7, was an extraction shooter set in the Titanfall universe, according to people familiar with its development.
Earlier in 2025, EA reduced its bookings estimate for the fiscal year following the miss of its latest soccer game, EA Sports FC 25.

title: Sheng Siong Q1 net profit up 6.1% to $38.5m on stronger sales
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe improved performance came despite operating costs rising 12.4 per cent to $81.6 million.
SINGAPORE – Supermarket operator Sheng Siong recorded a 6.1 per cent increase in net profit to $38.5 million for the first quarter ended March 31, from $36.3 million the year before.
Revenue grew 7.1 per cent to $403 million, from $376.2 million in the corresponding period in 2024.
Gross profit rose to $122 million in Q1, a 10.2 per cent increase from the $110.7 million posted in the year prior.
The improved performance came despite operating costs rising 12.4 per cent to $81.6 million.

title: Singapore stocks end lower amid mixed showing in regional markets
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE – Stocks on the local bourse closed slightly lower on April 29 amid a mixed showing among regional markets.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.2 per cent, or 6.6 points, lower at 3,805.18.
The trio of local banks ended mixed.
Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.9 per cent, the Kospi was up 0.7 per cent and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index increased 0.2 per cent.
“Whereas Beijing may quite rightly assess that rushing to acquiesce the aggressor (on tariffs) inadvertently, but damningly, concedes the upper hand to Washington – a strategic error that Beijing will avoid,” added Mr Varathan.

title: Former top civil servant to join asset manager Seviora
summary:
SINGAPORE - Temasek’s joint head of corporate strategy Gabriel Lim will join Seviora Holdings, an asset management firm backed by the investment company, as chief executive officer-designate on May 1 .
He is set to take over as chief executive on Sept 1, succeeding Mr Jimmy Phoon, who is retiring on Aug 31.
Headquartered in Singapore, Seviora Group is an independent asset manager wholly owned by Temasek.
Seviora Holdings chairman Goh Yew Lin said Mr Lim “brings a wealth of experience and a fresh perspective” to the company.
“His extensive experience in strategy development and stakeholder engagement will be an asset to the firm,” he added.

title: S’pore working to tap potential of senior workers in supporting an ageing workforce: SNEF
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSingapore has been working on ways to formulate policies that expand job opportunities for senior workers while enhancing workforce flexibility and productivity.
SINGAPORE – An ageing workforce will be a key challenge over the next decade, but “Singapore can prove to be the exception”, said Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) president Tan Hee Teck.
Singapore has been working on ways to formulate policies that expand job opportunities for senior workers while enhancing workforce flexibility and productivity.
He reiterated SNEF’s commitment in being the voice for employers, supporting them in building more progressive workplaces and ensuring workplace fairness in Singapore.
Developing the Workforce Fairness Legislation – Singapore’s first workplace fairness legislation – was another joint effort with MOM and NTUC.

title: Some Chinese exporters hasten US dollar conversion amid trade war
summary:
– Some Chinese exporters are speeding up conversion of their US dollar income into renminbi on bets that the worst of the tariff-led loss in the local currency may be over.
The renminbi fluctuating around 7.25 to 7.35 per dollar is beneficial for the company’s cross-border trade, he added.
The onshore renminbi has clawed back some of its losses in April as doubts over US exceptionalism pummelled the dollar.
Still, the renminbi remains the third worst-performing currency in Asia in 2025, behind the Indonesian rupiah and the Hong Kong dollar.
Renminbi weakness is providing an opportunity for exporters that were holding out on converting their dollar proceeds to finally act.

title: HSBC Q1 profit drops 25%; launches $3.9 billion share buyback
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe bank reported US$900 million in expected credit losses for the quarter.
HONG KONG - HSBC launched a US$3 billion (S$3.9 billion) share buyback after reporting a 25 per cent fall in first-quarter profit on April 29 and warned of heightened business uncertainty in the face of U.
The London-based bank reported profit before tax of US$9.5 billion in the first quarter.
That compared with US$12.7 billion a year earlier and US$7.8 billion average of analyst estimates compiled by the bank.
HSBC said it is looking to redeploy up to US$1.5 billion of costs from non-core businesses into more strategic activities including wholesale transaction banking and an expansion of its Asian wealth business.

title: Sony weighs chip unit spin-off as it plans to focus on entertainment: Sources
summary:
Sony’s semiconductor business also faces declining margins, higher costs and new competition from Chinese chipmakers who are catching up.
Sony Group Corp is considering spinning off its semiconductor unit, according to people familiar with the matter, marking the PlayStation maker’s latest effort to streamline its business and focus on entertainment.
The spin-off and listing of Sony Semiconductor Solutions Corp may occur as soon as this year, the people said, asking not to be named discussing a private matter.
“This article is based on speculation and there are no concrete plans,” representatives for Sony and the chip unit said in an e-mail.
Sony’s semiconductor business also faces declining margins, higher costs and new competition from Chinese chipmakers who are catching up.

title: Gold declines as trade war concerns ease
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSpot gold fell 0.4 per cent to US$3,329.12 an ounce as at 0211 GMT.
US gold futures lost 0.2 per cent to US$3,342.40.
– Gold fell on April 29 as softening trade tensions between the United States and its trading partners dulled the metal’s safe-haven appeal, while investors awaited US economic data to assess the Federal Reserve’s policy path.
Spot gold fell 0.4 per cent to US$3,329.12 an ounce as at 0211 GMT.
China’s recent moves to exempt certain US goods from its retaliatory tariffs showed a willingness to de-escalate trade tensions, he added.

title: Amara shares surge 27% on privatisation offer
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe S$0.895 offer represents a 33 per cent premium over Amara’s net asset value per share as at end-December 2024.
SINGAPORE – Shares of hotel group Amara soared shortly after the market opened on April 29, a day after news broke that it had received a voluntary conditional general offer at 89.5 cents apiece.
By 9.47am, it had eased to 88.5 cents – still up from April 28’s close by 18 cents or 25.5 per cent – with some 209,400 shares transacted.
On April 28, Amara received a privatisation offer from a consortium led by property company Hwa Hong, which was formerly listed on the Singapore Exchange.
The 89.5 cent offer represents a 33 per cent premium over Amara’s net asset value per share as at end-December 2024.

title: Spotify has paid over US$100m to podcasters to take on competitors
summary:
Spotify has paid more than US$100 million (S$131 million) to podcast publishers and creators since January, the company told The New York Times’ DealBook.
Compared with YouTube, Spotify has become a podcast underdog, with about 170 million monthly podcast listeners among its total audience of 675 million.
Spotify previously paid creators only by sharing advertising revenue with them, much like YouTube.
David Coles, host of the horror fiction podcast, Just Creepy: Scary Stories, said he was re-evaluating his “home platform” after his Spotify revenue recently surpassed his YouTube revenue.
While declining to share exact figures, YMH Studios said its quarterly Spotify revenue more than tripled after joining the partner programme.

title: Explainer: Why cheap oil relieves some, worries other countries
summary:
By early April, oil prices had fallen to a four-year low, and ticked up only slightly later in the month.
Why are oil prices falling?
Lower oil prices are good for importers, typically reducing fuel bills and lowering pump prices for drivers.
Additionally, wind and solar industries are only marginally affected by oil prices: their real competition comes from natural gas and, in some parts of the world, coal.
The transition to electric vehicles will be more directly affected by lower oil prices: prices at the pump influence what kind of car consumers buy.

title: Alibaba rolls out latest flagship AI model in post-DeepSeek race
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAlibaba unveiled its Qwen3 series of models, which it said rivals DeepSeek’s performance on several fronts, including maths and coding.
Alibaba Group Holding took the wraps off a new version of its flagship Qwen artificial intelligence (AI) model, sustaining the breakneck pace of development that has characterised China’s AI sphere in the wake of DeepSeek.
The tech giant on April 29 unveiled its Qwen3 series of models, which it said rivals DeepSeek’s performance on several fronts, including maths and coding.
It unveiled a new version of its AI assistant Quark app in March.
Alibaba said on April 29 that all its Qwen3 models are open source, and the company is building its AI endeavours around Qwen.

title: Boeing removed from credit watch by S&P in turnaround boost
summary:
The ratings agency’s statement on April 28 is the latest sign of progress in Boeing’s turnaround after a brutal 2024.
S&P said it is no longer actively considering cutting Boeing’s ratings, which are one step above junk status, at BBB-.
Boeing is in the lowest tier of investment grade with all three major rating agencies, including Moody’s Ratings and Fitch Ratings.
Moody’s affirmed that rating in January and removed the company from review for a downgrade, while Fitch never placed Boeing under review after the strike started.
Even with the shift this week, S&P is keeping a negative outlook on Boeing’s ratings, which means it still sees a risk of a downgrade in the medium term.

title: Nvidia, Eli Lilly bosses among CEOs to tout US investments with Trump
summary:
Economists questioned whether all the pledged spending – which often came with a White House press conference and to great acclaim from Mr Trump – will come to fruition.
The event billed as “Invest in America” comes as major retailers and Wall Street leaders are warning of price increases and fallout from Mr Trump’s trade war.
Last week, Mr Trump met executives from Walmart, Home Depot and Target to discuss trade and tariffs.
In his second day in office, Mr Trump announced a joint venture between SoftBank, OpenAI and Oracle to fund artificial intelligence infrastructure.
Eli Lilly previously pledged to invest US$27 billion to build four new manufacturing plants, and Johnson & Johnson offered US$55 billion in new investments.

title: IBM plans to invest US$150 billion domestically in latest tech sector pledge
summary:
IBM said it would invest US$150 billion in the US, including US$30 billion to support production of its mainframe and quantum computers.
The software company, headquartered in Armonk, New York, said that it would invest US$150 billion (S$196 billion) in the US over the next five years, including US$30 billion to support production of its mainframe and quantum computers.
But whether pledges from IBM and other tech giants fully come to fruition remains to be seen.
A US$10 billion project announced in Wisconsin by the electronics manufacturer Foxconn in 2018 – hailed by Mr Trump as the “eighth wonder of the world” – fell far short of expectations.
Even so, it has spared smartphones, computers, semiconductors and other electronics from tariffs which Mr Trump imposed on Chinese goods as part of his trade war.

title: ‘We are making real progress for workers’: Tan See Leng in May Day message
summary:
SINGAPORE - Workers in Singapore have made progress and this has come about through the close partnership between the Government, unions and employers that is the bedrock of Singapore’s economic progress, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.
“We are making real progress for workers – especially those with lower incomes,” he said in his May Day message on April 29.
On workplace safety, he said Singapore’s workplace fatality rate in the last five years averaged around 1.1 per 100,000 workers, “putting us amongst the best in class”.
Dr Tan said that as “pressures from respective constituencies” grow, sustaining tripartism – the three-way relationship between employers, unions and the Government – will get harder.
Noting that tripartism is the bedrock of Singapore’s economic progress, he stressed that this “foundation matters more than ever”.

title: S&P 500 ekes out slight gain with data, megacap earnings eyed
summary:
In all, 180 S&P 500 components are set to report earnings this week, and investors are likely to closely monitor how US President Donald Trump’s new tariffs could affect future profits.
The slight gain for the S&P 500 marked its fifth straight daily advance, its longest streak of gains since early November.
Trading was choppy after stocks opened firmer, with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq briefly touching their highest levels since April 2, prior to Mr Trump’s tariff announcement.
The S&P 500 remains about 10 per cent below its February record high as investors look for clues on the extent of any tariff damage.
The S&P 500 posted three new 52-week highs and two new lows, while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 47 new highs and 53 new lows.

title: Resort living reimagined: Waterfront homes in JB’s Special Economic Zone minutes from Singapore
summary:
Located 5km from the Malaysia-Singapore Second Link, about a 15-minute drive, Forest City blends luxury residences with a full suite of resort-style amenities.
A gateway to the region’s growth corridorStrategically located within the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JSSEZ), Forest City sits at the heart of an emerging cross-border economic corridor.
Buyers of these villas will also receive the Forest City Golf Resort Premier Card, granting them privileged access to elite golfing facilities and resort services.
Children of Forest City property owners are also eligible for tuition discounts if they enrol in the Forest City International School.
For prospective buyers, Forest City has introduced a special gift package for site visits.

title: Trump’s trade war puts Singapore’s economic growth, jobs and wages at risk, says MAS
summary:
“Conversely, trade tensions may de-escalate over time, which could boost sentiments and export activity.”Mr Chua Han Teng, a senior economist at DBS Bank, said there are considerable downside risks to Singapore’s growth outlook.
He believes that Singapore’s economy will still grow by 2.1 per cent in 2025, slightly above the Ministry of Trade and Industry’s zero per cent to 2 per cent growth forecast.
“Global growth could slip further if the US broadens and intensifies the tariffs to include other specific products such as semiconductors and pharmaceuticals,” MAS said.
MAS said the US is Singapore’s second-largest market, accounting for 11 per cent of its domestic exports in 2024.
MAS said trade conflicts hurt global growth as economies that levy duties on imports suffer an increase in costs, which in turn weigh on business and consumer spending.

title: Hotel group Amara Holdings receives $514.6m privatisation offer from its bosses, other developers
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAmara Holdings is the hotel and property group that runs Amara Singapore in Tanjong Pagar.
SINGAPORE - Amara Holdings, the hotel and property group that runs Amara Singapore in Tanjong Pagar, has received a $514.6 million takeover offer from a consortium involving its bosses and Singapore property developers Wing Tai and Hwa Hong Corp .
It is the second time Amara Holdings’ chairman and chief executive Albert Teo is attempting to take the company private.
It added that Amara Holdings has not needed to raise funds from the equity market since going public in 1997, making it less beneficial for the company to continue staying listed.
Amethyst Assets, which has a 76.2 per cent stake in Amara Holdings, is backed by Mr Teo and his family.

title: Trump’s trade war puts Singapore’s economic growth, jobs and wages at risk, says MAS
summary:
“Conversely, trade tensions may de-escalate over time, which could boost sentiments and export activity.”Mr Chua Han Teng, a senior economist at DBS Bank, said there are considerable downside risks to Singapore’s growth outlook.
He believes that Singapore’s economy will still grow by 2.1 per cent in 2025, slightly above the Ministry of Trade and Industry’s zero per cent to 2 per cent growth forecast.
“Global growth could slip further if the US broadens and intensifies the tariffs to include other specific products such as semiconductors and pharmaceuticals,” MAS said.
MAS said the US is Singapore’s second-largest market, accounting for 11 per cent of its domestic exports in 2024.

title: Singapore stocks close lower amid caution over economy’s outlook
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark STI fell 0.3 per cent or 11.98 points to 3,811.80.
SINGAPORE – Shares on the Singapore market ended lower on April 28, after the city state’s central bank sounded a cautious note about the economy’s growth outlook.
The Republic’s latest employment report also cast more pessimism, with the Government forecasting further softening in the labour market.
Singapore’s other local banks also fell on April 28, with DBS Bank slipping 0.1 per cent or five cents to $42.30, and OCBC Bank ending 0.4 per cent or seven cents lower at $15.83.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 closed 0.4 per cent higher, along with South Korea’s Kospi, which gained 0.1 per cent.

title: Singapore’s Q1 unemployment up slightly; employment growth slows amid trade war uncertainty
summary:
SINGAPORE – The unemployment rate in Singapore ticked up slightly in the first quarter of 2025, with employment growth slowing as escalating global trade tensions put a dent on business sentiment.
Meanwhile, the resident unemployment rate came in at 2.9 per cent between January and March.
MOM publishes unemployment rate figures monthly.
Although the unemployment rate of Singaporeans held steady at 3.1 per cent in March compared with February, it was higher than the 2.9 per cent recorded in December 2024.
Overall, the unemployment rate from 2015 to 2019 ranged from 1.8 per cent to 2.3 per cent.

title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust gross profit rises 4% in Q1
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGross profit from new properties, such as ibis Styles Tokyo Ginza, replaced the drop in gross profit from divestments in 2024.
SINGAPORE - CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (Clas) managers said in a business update on April 28 that the trust’s gross profit rose 4 per cent year on year in the first quarter of 2025.
Gross profit from new properties in the quarter replaced the drop in gross profit from divestments in 2024, the managers said, driven by stronger performance from properties the trust renovated last year.
Excluding acquisitions and divestments, Clas’ gross profit was 1 per cent higher on a same-store basis, said the managers.
Even so, the trust’s diversified portfolio and its stable income sources, which comprise 60 per cent to 70 per cent of gross profit, could mitigate this effect, they said.

title: Moleskine notebook a bestseller in the region, with maker expanding in Singapore
summary:
The forecast by research and advisory firm Mordor Intelligence also pointed to the Asia-Pacific as set to be the fastest-growing market.
Italian notebook brand Moleskine, which opened a small boutique store at basement one of Takashimaya Shopping Centre earlier in April, is well-poised to capture the growing market in the region, particularly in Asia.
In an e-mail interview with The Straits Times, Moleskine’s chief executive officer Christophe Archaimbault said the Moleskine classic notebook has consistently been the top seller in the region.
It has also earned its fair share of complaints in its overall paper quality.
“We continuously monitor feedback and refine our production to uphold the quality, consistency, and craftsmanship that the Moleskine name represents,” he said.

title: Revived corporate bond deals in Japan underline need for funding
summary:
– Japanese corporate issuers are rekindling some shelved yen bond deals in a sign of pressing funding needs even as investors seek fatter premiums.
Another beverage group, Asahi Group Holdings, sold yen bonds on April 25 in an offering that was postponed at the start of the month.
Companies paid about 60 basis points more than Japanese sovereign debt on average in April for new issuance, data compiled by Bloomberg showed.
As well as the pulled deals, borrowers failed to sell out bonds in the usually stable local government debt market.
They are up from 54 basis points in March, according to the data which includes financial issuance.

title: Gold’s bullish sentiment seen easing as record rally stumbles
summary:
As bullion hit a record on April 21, the trading of options on the SPDR Gold Shares ETF surpassed 1.3 million contracts, a level never reached before.
Gold has already lost more than 5 per cent from its intraday peak last week on signs some trade tensions may be easing.
And to him, both assets could rally further as their implied volatility and skew remain within the long-term historical ranges.
With Barclays’s proprietary indicator showing that sentiment is still bullish on gold, the strategists recommend selling June calls to buy puts for a zero-cost risk reversal.
“Obviously, the trade is mostly directional, so for this trade to really work gold has to come down,” said Mr Pascale.

title: UK growth outlook slashed to 0.8% as US tariffs hit investment
summary:
– The British economy will grow half as quickly as previously expected in 2026 as US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs hit business investment, according to EY Item Club.
The influential forecaster warned of shrinking exports and more subdued household spending that will snuff out the strong pickup in growth previously projected.
Business investment is expected to be particularly badly hit, barely expanding this year.
EY Item Club cut its forecast for household spending growth in 2025 to 0.9 per cent from 1.6 per cent.
Business investment, previously forecast to grow 2 per cent, will now expand just 0.3 per cent.

title: Toyota chairman proposes record buyout of its supplier at over $55b valuation
summary:
It is not clear whether a successful buyout of Toyota Industries would change Mr Toyoda’s participation on the carmaker’s board.
Toyota Industries, the company founded by Mr Toyoda’s great-grandfather Sakichi that ultimately birthed the world’s No.
In a statement, Toyota Motor said it was considering various possibilities, including a partial investment in Toyota Industries, but nothing has been decided.
Seven & i PrecedentThe Toyota Industries buyout proposal comes months after the collapse of a similar bid to take Japanese retailer Seven & i Holdings private.
It is not clear whether a successful buyout of Toyota Industries would change Mr Toyoda’s participation on the carmaker’s board.

title: Treasury market’s ‘new world order’ brings fear of the long bond
summary:
By one measure, that added cushion, which traders dub the term premium, is around the highest since 2014.
The US$2 trillion bond manager currently favours maturities from five to 10 years.
Although they have since receded, they remain higher than when Mr Trump announced his plan for sweeping tariffs on April 2.
With Republicans debating how to pay for their tax cut Bill, the fiscal story is the next chapter for the term premium.
“Once greater clarity is given and agreements are reached, I’d expect term premium to abate,” said the firm’s head of fixed income.

title: Trump, China ramp up Panama Canal pressure with Li Ka-Shing deal in limbo
summary:
The US and China have been embroiled in an escalating war of words over the Panama Canal.
It is piling further political pressure on Mr Li as he tries to sell the two Panama ports, putting him in the crosshairs of tensions between the US and China.
The escalating pressure from both sides highlights the increasingly tricky business environment that CK Hutchison and other major global companies have to navigate as trade tensions between the world’s two biggest economies ramp back up.
If finalised, the transaction would net CK Hutchison US$19 billion (S$24.9 billion) in cash proceeds.
The Wall Street Journal reported in April that there are discussions around separating the two Panama ports from the US$22.8 billion deal to buy dozens of ports from CK Hutchison.

title: Property stocks rise: Hongkong Land surges on $1.1b asset sale; CDL up despite board tensions
summary:

SINGAPORE - Hongkong Land was the biggest gainer on the Singapore stock market index last week, leaping almost 13 per cent to close April 25 at US$4.64.
CDL rises despite board tensionCity Developments Limited (CDL) shares also rose last week, closing just under $5 on April 25, up 6.4 per cent, despite ongoing tensions among its board of directors at the property developer’s 2024 annual general meeting on April 23.
Mr Yeo was also disappointed that the decision to appoint Ms Young and Ms Wong was not unanimous and disregarded the chairman’s position on the board.
According to data provided by the exchange, retail investors bought a net $1.16 billion worth of Singapore stocks from April 1 to April 23.

title: Yangzijiang Financial looking to spin off maritime investments business and list it on SGX
summary:
SINGAPORE - Investment management company Yangzijiang Financial is exploring spinning off its maritime investments business into a new incorporated company that will be listed separately on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX), it announced on April 27.
The firm, previously the financial arm of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, said the move will help it to unlock its full growth potential.
The proposed transaction involves transferring the group’s maritime investments assets to a new group, which will function as a dedicated maritime investment platform.
The spin-off will focus on unlocking value across the maritime value chain and capturing high-growth opportunities in the maritime industry, Yangzijiang Financial said in a media statement.
“Operationally, each company group will benefit from greater agility, streamlined decision-making and clearer governance.

title: China has an army of robots on its side in the tariff war
summary:
– China’s secret weapon in the trade war is an army of factory robots, powered by artificial intelligence (AI), that have revolutionised manufacturing.
China has more factory robots for every 10,000 manufacturing workers than any other country except South Korea or Singapore, according to the International Federation of Robotics.
China’s automation drive has been guided by government directives and backed with huge investment.
And as robots replace workers, automation positions China to continue to dominate mass production even as its labour force ages and becomes less willing to take industrial jobs.
Car factories in the United States also use automation, but much of the equipment comes from China.

title: US stocks finish higher again, extending rebound
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the US in April.
NEW YORK – Wall Street stocks finished higher on April 25, extending a rebound following a tonal shift from US President Donald Trump on tariffs and the US Federal Reserve.
Reports next week on the labour market and other key indicators will show if “we are truly weakening or not”, Ms Fernandez said.
The broad-based S&P 500 climbed 0.7 per cent to 5,525.21, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.3 per cent to 17,382.94.
Beijing has said there are no active negotiations with the US, while Mr Trump claimed to have spoken with Chinese leader Xi Jinping.

title: 170 jobs in logistics to be created with Sankyu Singapore’s new warehouse facility in 2026
summary:
SINGAPORE - Around 170 new jobs will be created by the Singapore subsidiary of Japanese logistics company Sankyu with the construction of a built-to-suit, fully air-conditioned warehouse facility in Tuas with about 57,000 storage pallets.
Priority for employment will be given to Singaporeans, said Sankyu Singapore.
Called Tuas Distribution Hub (TDH), it offers storage facilities equipped with temperature control, security protocols, and inventory management systems compliant with industry standards.
Sankyu Singapore, which was established in 1971, offers services such as logistics, supply chain management, and consulting services.
Sankyu Singapore owns other warehouse facilities, including its Clementi Distribution Centre and Tuas Logistics Hub.

title: BYD’s quarterly profit surges at fastest pace in nearly two years
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBYD's first-quarter net profit totalled 9.2 billion yuan (S$1.66 billion), compared with its earlier estimate of 8.5 billion yuan to 10 billion yuan.
- BYD’s first-quarter profit leapt 100.4 per cent from a year earlier, the fastest pace in nearly two years, as the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) giant extends its lead in a competitive home market after launching a smart EV price war.
Net profit totalled 9.2 billion yuan (S$1.66 billion), a stock filing showed on April 25, compared with the company’s earlier estimate of 8.5 billion yuan to 10 billion yuan.
Revenue came in at 170.4 billion yuan in the quarter, up 36.4 per cent year on year, versus a 52.7 per cent rise in the previous quarter.
Outside of its home market, which makes up about 90 per cent of its total sales, BYD is targeting exports of 800,000 vehicles in 2025.

title: Some Singapore retailers feel the pinch as US tariffs take effect
summary:
SINGAPORE – Local collectibles company Mighty Jaxx felt the immediate impact of the tariffs on its shipments currently on the way to the US.
On April 2, US President Donald Trump imposed sweeping tariffs on many countries before announcing a 90-day halt on reciprocal tariffs about a week later.

Dr Leong said Singapore retailers who double down on e-commerce, localised manufacturing and regional diversification will be the ones most resilient in the face of these global trade shocks.
He said: “Singapore retailers must now move beyond reactive tactics and embrace long-term strategic shifts.

title: May Day Awards: SM Lee among 180 awardees feted for championing workers
summary:
National Trades Union Congress president K. Thanaletchimi presented the Distinguished Comrade of Labour award to SM Lee at the yearly May Day awards ceremony held at Marina Bay Sands Expo and Convention Centre.
SM Lee “led the nation to take difficult but necessary measures, such as cutting Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions to cut costs and preserve jobs”, said NTUC.
In a March 20 interview with NTUC, SM Lee recounted the Government’s decision to cut CPF contribution rates in 1985.
SM Lee also mentioned seeing other founding PAP members Fong Swee Suan, Samad Ismail and Lim Chin Siong in his childhood years.
“I hope more migrant domestic workers will step forward and join CDE as volunteers.”

title: Singapore shares end down on April 25; STI slides 0.2%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2 per cent or 8.14 points to 3,823.78.
SINGAPORE - Stocks on the Singapore market ended lower on April 25, as a smaller-than-expected gain in the Republic’s manufacturing output outweighed the improvement in sentiment amid the broadly more positive tone around trade discussions.
Factory output rose 5.8 per cent year on year in March, strengthening from February’s upwardly revised growth of 0.9 per cent.
The benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2 per cent or 8.14 points to 3,823.78.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 gained 1.9 per cent and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index rose 0.3 per cent.

title: Singapore factory output up 5.8% in March but misses analysts’ forecasts as tariffs loom
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore’s manufacturing production rose for the ninth straight month year on year but fell short of analysts’ expectations.
Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output grew 4.9 per cent, according to data from the Economic Development Board on April 25.
Indicating the slowing momentum though, on a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, manufacturing output dropped 3.6 per cent in March.
Meanwhile, the marine and offshore engineering segment increased by 8.1 per cent, while the land segment jumped by 5.4 per cent.
Ms Ling noted that the March industrial output implies a potential downward revision in Singapore’s manufacturing growth estimates.

title: Nissan sees record $6.9 billion loss as restructuring charges mount
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWith an ageing line-up, Nissan has been discounting its cars in order to avoid building up inventory, eroding profits.
TOKYO – Nissan Motor warned it will post a net loss of as much as 750 billion yen (S$6.9 billion) for the fiscal year that ended in March – a record annual deficit – as restructuring charges weigh on the struggling Japanese carmaker.
With an ageing line-up, Nissan has been discounting its cars in order to avoid building up inventory, eroding profits.
Analysts on average were projecting a loss of 112 billion yen, which itself was worse than Nissan’s prior outlook for a deficit of 80 billion yen.
While Nissan slightly raised its sales forecast late on April 24, the company warned that its net loss could be 700 billion to 750 billion yen.

title: IMF cuts its Singapore 2025 growth forecast as Trump tariffs, US-China trade war bite
summary:
SINGAPORE – The International Monetary Fund (IMF) slashed its 2025 growth forecast for Singapore, along with those of its Asean neighbours, saying the outlook has dimmed amid US President Donald Trump’s global tariffs and his escalating trade war with China.
IMF lowered its growth forecast for the Asean region to 4.1 per cent for 2025, down from 4.8 per cent achieved in 2024 and 0.6 percentage point lower than its forecast in October 2024.
IMF slashed its 2025 US growth forecast to 1.8 per cent from 2.7 per cent.
However, Mr Srinivasan said Asean in particular can soften the blow from the trade war by furthering diversification of export markets and regional integration.
“Singapore is among the most digitally competitive economies, and South Korea and India lead in digital government services,” said Mr Srinivasan.

title: Hongkong Land to sell space in One Exchange Square for $1.1b, launch share buyback programme
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxProceeds from the sale of space in One Exchange Square in Hong Kong will finance a US$200 million share buyback programme.
SINGAPORE - Singapore-listed Hongkong Land will sell 147,025 sq ft of One Exchange Square to Hong Kong’s stock exchange operator for HK$6.3 billion (S$1.1 billion) and launch a share buyback programme.
Shares of Hongkong Land jumped almost 10 per cent to close at US$4.64 on April 25.
This, together with its acquisition of space in One Exchange Square, raises its total footprint in Exchange Square.
The purchase price of the property was determined after negotiations between parties involved, said Hongkong Land.

title: Meta lays off more than 100 employees across Reality Labs unit
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe latest job cuts impacted Reality Labs staff working on VR experiences for Meta’s Quest headsets, as well as employees working on hardware.
San Francisco – Meta Platforms is laying off more than 100 people across its Reality Labs division focused on creating virtual reality and wearable devices, according to a person familiar with the matter.
The latest round of job cuts impacted Reality Labs staff focused on creating VR experiences for Meta’s Quest headsets, as well as operations-focused employees working on hardware, said the person.
Meta leadership hopes to streamline similar work being done across two different teams within Reality Labs, the person said.
Impacted staff are eligible to apply for new roles at the company.

title: Southwest CEO says US airline industry already in recession
summary:
Noting demand for domestic leisure travel has dropped more than he’s ever seen outside of the Covid-19 pandemic, Mr Bob Jordan said on April 24 that an economic contraction is in full swing, at least in the US airline industry.
The CEO said his company expects second-quarter revenue to fall by six percentage points, following a three-point decline in the first three months.
“I don’t care if you call it a recession or not, in this industry that’s a recession,” Mr Jordan said in an interview.
Southwest is more dependent on domestic leisure travelers for revenue than US peers with more extensive international operations and corporate business clients.
Domestic leisure travel remains weak, but international and business travel remain on track, he said.

title: China’s investments in South-east Asia snarl US plans on supply chains

“Much of US import diversification through Asean export hubs has been supported by Chinese firms,” they wrote, adding Chinese and foreign multinationals often relocate to Asean in tandem.
Chinese investment has helped contribute to a soaring US trade deficit with the region.
Indonesia was one of the largest recipients of Chinese investment into renewable energy equipment in 2022-2024, according to the Rhodium data.

title: US stocks rise for 3rd straight day

Meanwhile, President Donald Trump blasted China after Boeing said Chinese companies had refused plane deliveries due to the trade dispute.
But stocks looked past these developments – or lack thereof – and the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.2 per cent at 40,093.40.
On April 22, Mr Trump said he had no intention to fire Mr Powell.

“Our existing policy is that our hybrid employees should spend approximately three days per week on site,” Mr Tan said.
“We must balance our reductions with the need to retain and recruit key talent,” Mr Tan said in the memo.
Intel is focused on improving its balance sheet and is cutting the budget for new plants and equipment by a further US$2 billion, Mr Zinsner said.

title: Singapore stocks finish flat amid mixed showing in region
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index closed almost flat, down 0.4 points at 3,831.92.
SINGAPORE – Local stocks ended April 24 muted, amid a mixed showing by other Asian markets after China signalled its openness to trade talks and US President Donald Trump suggested potential tariff cuts on Beijing.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed almost flat, down 0.4 points at 3,831.92.
Its manager also warned that trade tensions could weigh on performance.

title: Marina Bay Sands Q1 revenue holds steady at $1.58b amid strong operating environment
summary:
SINGAPORE - Net revenue for Marina Bay Sands (MBS) edged up to about US$1.2 billion (S$1.58 billion) for the first quarter as it improved service offerings and introduced new suite products.
MBS also entered into a new facility agreement on Feb 21, which provides an approximate $3.8 billion term loan, $750 million revolving credit facility and $7.5 billion delayed draw term loan facility.
As for the revolving credit facility, it may be drawn for general corporate purposes, including payment of dividends.
The statement also noted that future proceeds from the delayed draw term loan facility may be used to finance development and construction costs, expenses, fees and other payments related to the MBS Expansion Project.
The commitments under the 2012 Singapore Credit Facility were terminated, with the entrance into the new facility agreement.

title: Komoco chairman’s Old Holland Road GCB sold after auction closes via private treaty
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe bidding process lasted for over half an hour, before being taken into private treaty with two interested parties behind closed doors.
SINGAPORE - A good class bungalow (GCB) along Old Holland Road, belonging to automotive group Komoco Holdings executive chairman Teo Hock Seng, has been sold via private treaty, after being withdrawn from auction.
The bidding process lasted for over half an hour, before being taken into private treaty with two interested parties behind closed doors.
The Hengs built the 12,000 sq ft GCB in 1994.
One was a King Albert Park GCB with an opening price of $26.8 million, or $1,649 psf, on a site area of 16,250 sq ft.

title: Keppel Q1 profit up over 25%; firm expects limited direct impact from US tariffs
summary:
The earnings exclude legacy offshore and marine assets such as shares of Seatrium and legacy rigs remaining from the company’s divestment of its offshore and marine business in 2024.
He also noted that the company is involved in meeting demand for alternative real assets that are supported by macrotrends, including energy transition, digitalisation and artificial intelligence.
In its connectivity business segment, Keppel reported progress on the Bifrost subsea cable, reaching 92 per cent completion as at March.
It also expects the joint investment in subsea cable solutions provider Global Marine Group by Keppel Infrastructure Trust and Keppel Infrastructure Fund to enhance its connectivity business and digital infrastructure strategy.
As for the legacy offshore and marine assets, Keppel is looking at how it can put more rigs to work, amid the drop in oil prices in recent months.

title: US officials mull over easing tariffs targeting auto industry
summary:
The Trump administration is considering whether to reduce certain tariffs targeting the auto industry that carmaker executives have warned would deal a severe blow to profits and jobs.
Mexico City – The Trump administration is considering whether to reduce certain tariffs targeting the auto industry that carmaker executives have warned would deal a severe blow to profits and jobs.
Another option being studied would fully exempt auto parts that comply with the US-Mexico-Canada trade pact, known as the USMCA, some of the people said.
But the discussions offer a signal that the administration is considering ways to narrow the scope of levies affecting the auto industry.
Mr Trump plans to travel to Michigan next week.

title: TSMC shows off new tech for stitching together bigger, faster chips
summary:
TSMC said it plans to build two factories to carry out the work near its chip plants in Arizona, with plans for a total of six chip factories, two packaging factories, and a research and development centre at the site.
Intel, which is working to build out a contract manufacturing business to compete with TSMC, is due to announce new manufacturing technologies next week.
In 2024, it claimed it would overtake TSMC in making the world’s fastest chips.
Demand for massive AI chips that are packaged together has shifted the battleground between the two firms from simply making fast chips to integrating them - a complex task that requires working closely with customers.
You’re not going to pick one over the other because they have the technological lead,” said Mr Dan Hutcheson, vice-chair at analyst firm TechInsights.

title: Malaysia’s Zus Coffee to add 200 outlets in South-east Asia, including six in Singapore
summary:
Zus overtook Starbucks as Malaysia’s largest-coffee chain in early 2024.
It has 743 outlets in the country, while Starbucks operates 320 stores.
The coffee chain also operates in Brunei under a franchise model.
The jump in profit comes amid strong investor interest in Malaysia’s mass consumer sector.
Then you have premium mass coffee selling at RM11 and above.

title: Hackers manipulate stocks in $920 million illicit trading spree
summary:
– Criminals are hijacking online brokerage accounts in Japan and using them to drive up penny stocks around the world.
Eight of Japan’s biggest brokers, including Rakuten Securities and SBI Securities, have reported unauthorised trading on their platforms.
The Japan Securities Dealers Association, the umbrella group for the country’s securities firms, is also pushing its members to upgrade their systems to make multifactor authentication mandatory.
The attack typically begins by luring users to a fake site via a phishing e-mail or malicious ad.
The fake site then redirects users to the legitimate site, where his login credentials are intercepted.

title: You’ll die faster if you stay: Chinese exporters retreat from US as 145% tariffs crush profitability
summary:
Fearful Chinese exporters are making permanent plans to withdraw from the US market and turn to other regions like the Middle East for sales instead.
- For an increasing number of Chinese exporters, many of whom battled through the trade war in US President Donald Trump’s first term and who have invested years to capture the spending power of American shoppers, it may be closing time in the US.
Exporters are now trying to “survive” the current crisis, said Ms Wang Xin, head of the Shenzhen Cross-Border E-Commerce Association, which represents some 3,000 exporters.
The plight of Chinese exporters means US consumers could face rising prices and shortages of crucial goods in the coming months.
