“But when it was raised to 125 per cent and then 145 per cent, people decided to quit because you’ll die faster if you insist on staying in the US.” BLOOMBERG

title: South Korea’s economy shrinks as tariffs darken global outlook
summary:
South Korea, a key US ally, was hit with a 25 per cent across-the-board tariff that has been temporarily reduced to 10 per cent for 90 days.
– South Korea’s economy contracted in the first quarter, underscoring the fragile state of business activity even before exporters absorbed the full force of US President Donald Trump’s punitive import duties, and raising fears over the potential for further damage in the region.
South Korea’s disappointing numbers follow the International Monetary Fund’s downgrade of its 2025 global growth forecast to 2.8 per cent, down from the 3.3 per cent predicted in January.
Early trade data for South Korea released this week showed shipments to the US fell 14.3 per cent i n the first 20 days of April.
As with other nations, it also faces a 25 per cent tariff on shipments of cars, steel and aluminium.

title: Nvidia supplier SK Hynix sees limited tariff impact on AI chips after bumper Q1
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSK Hynix said quarterly profit more than doubled and demand for AI chips was so robust that it expects only limited impact from potential US tariffs.
- SK Hynix, a key supplier of high-bandwidth memory (HBM) processors to Nvidia, said quarterly profit more than doubled and demand for AI chips was so robust that it expects only limited impact on those products from potential US tariffs.
In smartphones, the advancement of AI features in new models is expected to drive replacement demand, boosting sales of high-performance mobile Dram chips, it added.
SK Hynix has been leading a global race to meet explosive demand for HBM chips, a crucial component of chipsets made by the likes of Nvidia that help process vast amounts of data to train AI models.
It is the main HBM chip supplier to Nvidia as cross-town rival Samsung Electronics has struggled to keep up.

title: US stocks rise again on more benign Trump tone on China
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks posted solid gains for a second straight session on April 23 as markets continued to cheer the Trump administration’s more conciliatory tone on trade negotiations with China.
The broad-based S&P 500 rose 1.7 per cent to 5,375.85, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.5 per cent to 16,708.05.
But markets are rallying on “any headline that’s less negative on trade,” said Mr Art Hogan, of B. Riley Wealth Management.
“We’ve moved into a slightly more positive position but we still don’t know what the endgame will be on trade,” Mr Hogan said.
Amazon rose 4.3 per cent, Facebook parent Meta won 4 per cent and Microsoft climbed 2.1 per cent.

title: Dispute over CDL directors’ appointment casts shadow over property group at AGM
summary:
Mr Sherman Kwek has denied any attempt to oust the chairman.
I want to register my unhappiness,” Mr Yeo said, to another round of applause.
The company currently has 11 board members, including Mr Kwek Leng Beng and Mr Sherman Kwek.
Speaking to The Straits Times after the results were announced, Mr Yeo said he still has concerns.
“Yes, there is still a fundamental problem.”Mr Kwek Leng Beng told ST he was “very happy” with the outcome.

title: Singapore shares close higher on possible easing of trade tensions; STI up 1%
summary:
The upbeat sentiment here was further boosted by data showing that core inflation slowed more than expected in March.
Mr Eli Lee, Bank of Singapore’s chief investment strategist, noted that weakness in US shares, Treasuries and the greenback will exert “significant pressure” on Mr Trump to de-escalate.
Mr Lee warned that a recession could materialise if Mr Trump’s proposed reciprocal tariffs are implemented alongside existing US-China levies.
Wall Street set the mood, with US shares rising on the Trump turnaround.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq both added 2.7 per cent, while the S&P 500 put on 2.5 per cent.

title: Chinese online shopping sites to end refund-without-returns amid weak economy, sources say
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe government met operators including Temu owner PDD Holdings and concluded the practice must end by July, sources say.
The government met operators including Temu owner PDD Holdings and concluded the practice must end by July, from which point only merchants will be able to initiate a refund, the people said, without specifying dates.
In July 2024 , hundreds of people gathered at a Temu office in southern China to protest against its refund policy.
The authorities including the market regulator and Commerce Ministry subsequently ordered PDD to revise the policy.
This year, government bodies including the market regulator and the National Development and Reform Commission have increased criticism of what they dub “involution-style” competition.

title: Frasers Hospitality Trust undertaking strategy review
summary:
SINGAPORE - The managers of Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) are conducting a review of its business strategy, though there is currently no certainty of any change.
It urged investors to exercise caution and refrain from taking action with respect to their FHT stapled securities that may be prejudicial to their interests.
FHT is a stapled group comprising Frasers Hospitality Reit and Frasers Hospitality Business Trust.
It attained favourable votes representing 74.88 per cent of units, from around 70.91 per cent of stapled security holders.
Frasers Property Hospitality Trust, a wholly owned subsidiary of FHT’s sponsor Frasers Property, proposed to acquire all FHT stapled securities apart from those held by itself, its subsidiaries and TCC Group Investments for 70 cents apiece in cash.

title: Singapore core inflation drops to 4-year low of 0.5% in March; analysts see more downward pressure
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore’s core inflation dropped for a sixth consecutive month with weaker global demand from trade uncertainty and US tariffs seen putting more downward pressure on consumer prices.
Core inflation, which excludes private transport and accommodation costs to better reflect the expenses of households here, eased to 0.5 per cent year on year, from 0.6 per cent in February.
Overall – or headline – inflation remained unchanged at 0.9 per cent year on year in March, due to higher private transport inflation which offset the fall in core inflation.
“An open and trade-reliant economy like Singapore will be affected by weak underlying global demand, which will keep core inflation here muted,” she said.
“On balance, we expect headline inflation to average 0.7 per cent this year from 2.4 per cent last year and for core inflation to average 0.6 per cent from 2.6 per cent.

title: Keppel Reit Q1 distributable income falls 3.5% to $48.4 million
summary:
SINGAPORE - Keppel Reit reported on April 23 that its distributable income from operations in the first quarter of 2025 fell 3.5 per cent year on year to $48.4 million from $50.2 million previously.
Including an annual $20 million anniversary distribution, distributable income fell 3.2 per cent year on year to $53.4 million, from $55.2 million.
Despite this, net property income (NPI) grew 13.3 per cent year on year to $54.6 million in Q1 from $48.2 million.
Property income rose 12.1 per cent to $68.7 million, from $61.3 million.
The Reit’s portfolio occupancy was 96 per cent, while weighted average lease expiry stood at 4.7 years.

title: CEOs haven't been this gloomy about the US economy since the global financial crisis
summary:
US chief executives are struggling to gauge the impact of the White House’s rapidly shifting policies on their businesses.
NEW YORK – Not since the global financial crisis has Corporate America been so downbeat about the state of the economy in earnings calls, an ominous sign for investors trying to figure out how much more pain Mr Donald Trump’s trade war will inflict on the stock market.
That’s especially true for firms with profits more closely tied to vagaries of the economy, like carmakers.
That’s further pressuring US stocks that threatened to sink back towards a bear market in recent days on the heightened risk of a recession and a resurgence in inflation from Mr Trump’s levies.
Delta Air Lines withdrew its full-year financial guidance on the uncertainty surrounding global trade, while Kimberly-Clark has lowered profit expectations for the year, citing questions on the impact of the trade war on its costs.

title: US stocks soar on White House optimism on China trade deal, Dow up 2.7%
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks jumped on April 22, rebounding from the prior day’s rout, after upbeat comments from Trump administration officials about US-China trade talks.
US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told a closed-door event in Washington that the tit-for-tat tariff war would de-escalate soon.
But the International Monetary Fund slashed its forecast for global growth this year, citing the effect of US President Donald Trump’s new tariff policies.
Mr Stovall said the market is very uncomfortable with Mr Trump’s pressure on Mr Powell.
The threat of Mr Trump firing Mr Powell “is enough to push the market down 3 per cent,” Mr Stovall said.

title: Intel to announce plans this week to cut more than 20% of staff
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe layoffs would be the first major restructuring under new CEO Tan Lip-Bu, who took the helm in March.
– Intel is poised to announce plans this week to cut more than 20 per cent of its staff, aiming to eliminate bureaucracy at the struggling chipmaker, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
It would be the first major restructuring under new chief executive officer Tan Lip-Bu , who took the helm in March.
Mr Tan is aiming to turn around the iconic chipmaker after years of Intel ceding ground to rivals.
Intel needs to replace the engineering talent it has lost, improve its balance sheet and better attune manufacturing processes to the needs of potential customers, Mr Tan said in March at the Intel Vision conference.

title: Tesla earnings plunge 71% as EV maker warns of tariff pain ahead
summary:
Tariffs, an ageing vehicle line-up and the backlash against chief executive officer Elon Musk are having an impact on the electric-vehicle maker.
Mr Musk oversees five companies: Tesla, SpaceX, XAI, Neuralink and The Boring Co. Tesla is the only publicly traded company in his empire, and it has borne the brunt of public protests against him.
The EV maker’s dimmer outlook for the year follows a tough 2024, when it missed its annual sales growth target for the first time in more than a decade.
Tesla reported earlier in April that first-quarter vehicle sales slid 13 per cent.
Tesla Takedown, a decentralised movement that accuses Mr Musk of harming democracies around the world, is encouraging people to sell their Tesla vehicles and the company’s stock while condemning violence and vandalism.

title: IMF slashes global growth forecast, says downside risks dominate as Trump tariffs spark trade war
summary:
– The International Monetary Fund (IMF) sharply lowered its forecasts for world growth for 2025 and 2026, warning the outlook could deteriorate further as US President Donald Trump’s tariffs spark a global trade war .
The IMF cut its projection for global output growth in 2025 to 2.8 per cent in its updated World Economic Outlook released on April 22.
The IMF increased its forecast for US inflation in 2025 by roughly 1 percentage point to 3 per cent.
The Washington-based fund cut its forecast for global trade growth in 2025 by 1.5 percentage points and sees only a slight recovery in 2026.
“However much the IMF may downgrade the growth forecasts to start, history suggests the ultimate blow will be worse.” BLOOMBERG, AFP

title: Paragon Reit unit holders give nod to privatisation offer
summary:
Paragon Reit unit holders will receive the scheme consideration of $0.98 a share in cash on or around June 4.
SINGAPORE - Unit holders of Paragon Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) on April 22 approved the scheme resolution proposed by Cuscaden Peak’s Times Properties to take the trust private.
During the scheme meeting, 1,000 unit holders, or around 82.8 per cent of those present and voting, agreed to the privatisation offer.
Paragon Reit unit holders will receive the scheme consideration of $0.98 a share in cash on or around June 4.
Its cash offer of $0.98 per unit values the Reit at $2.8 billion.

title: Singapore stocks rise as they continue to rally
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAcross the region, major indexes ended mixed following a weak start on Wall Street and the US dollar falling to a three-year low.
SINGAPORE - Singapore stocks ended higher on April 22, even as other Asian markets delivered a mixed performance amid trade uncertainty.
The counter rose 4.3 per cent or eight cents to $1.96.
OCBC Bank rose 0.8 per cent or 13 cents to $16.38, and UOB increased 0.7 per cent or 24 cents to $35.54.
Across the region, major indexes ended mixed following a weak start on Wall Street and the US dollar falling to a three-year low .

title: Gold hits new high of US$3,500 as Trump’s attack on Fed sparks flight to haven
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBullion gained as much as 2.2 per cent on April 22, following a 2.9 per cent jump the previous day.
Bullion gained as much as 2.2 per cent on April 22, following a 2.9 per cent jump the previous day.
“The ‘Trump Trade’ narrative has evolved into a ‘sell America’ narrative,” she said.
Gold for immediate delivery traded 1.8 per cent higher at US$3,484.19 an ounce at 2.27pm in Singapore, after easing back from its new all-time high.
The Bloomberg Dollar Index dropped again following a 0.7 per cent decline on April 21.

title: Singapore, EU have common grounds to forge deeper links, says Tan See Leng
summary:
The groundwork is there, with talks for the EU-Singapore Digital Trade Agreement having concluded in 2024.
In a fireside chat with Mr Rubbert, who asked how Singapore plans to keep itself attractive to European investments, Dr Tan said Singapore offers consistency through a stable political environment.
It also attracts global talent via schemes such as the Overseas Networks and Expertise Pass, with about 3,000 passes issued in 2024.
In his closing remarks, Dr Tan said Singapore remains a credible, consistent and committed partner, with clear, transparent and predictable rules.
Correction note: In an earlier version of the story, we said the EU-Singapore Digital Trade Agreement was signed in 2024.

title: Roche to invest $65 billion in US over next five years
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDrug makers are announcing investments to counter tariffs by the Trump administration.
ZURICH - Roche on April 22 said it will invest US$50 billion (S$65 billion) in the United States over the next five years, in one of the biggest inward investment moves by companies dealing with US President Donald Trump’s tariffs policy.
Roche said its investment will include new research and development sites as well as expanded manufacturing facilities in Indiana, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and California.
Roche chief executive Thomas Schinecker said the investment underscored the company’s commitment to the United States.
“Our investments of US$50 billion over the next five years will lay the foundation for our next era of innovation and growth, benefiting patients in the US and around the world,” he said in a statement.

title: Singapore’s Syfe clinches nod to buy Australia-listed Selfwealth for $54.5m in cash
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe acquisition will make Syfe one of the largest digital wealth platforms in the Asia-Pacific., said CEO Dhruv Arora.
SINGAPORE - After six gruelling months of preparation, Singapore-based investment platform Syfe has emerged the winner in a three-cornered fight to buy Selfwealth, one of Australia’s largest digital investing platforms.
On April 22, Selfwealth shareholders overwhelmingly voted in favour of Syfe’s all-cash A$65 million (S$54.5 million) offer.
The acquisition will make Syfe one of the largest digital wealth platforms in the Asia-Pacific, said founder and chief executive Dhruv Arora.
Selfwealth will then be delisted from the Australian Securities Exchange, and operate as Selfwealth by Syfe.

title: US slaps tariffs as high as 3,521% on solar imports from South-east Asia
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe US probe found that solar manufacturers in Cambodia, Vietnam, Malaysia and Thailand were unfairly benefiting from government subsidies.
– The US set new duties as high as 3,521 per cent on solar imports from four South-east Asian countries, delivering a win for domestic manufacturers while intensifying headwinds already threatening the country’s renewable power development.
The investigation was sought by domestic solar manufacturers and initiated under former president Joe Biden.
The findings confirm “what we’ve long known – that Chinese-headquartered solar companies have been cheating the system, undercutting US companies and costing American workers their livelihoods”, he said.
The US initiated a probe that was triggered by an April petition from the American Alliance for Solar Manufacturing Trade Committee.

title: ‘For our country’: China’s retail investors join ‘national team’ to defend stock market
summary:
The home designer from China’s southern Guangdong province changed his mind after April 2, when the US President announced “reciprocal tariffs”, intensifying a trade war with his country.
He said he opened trading accounts after the higher tariffs hit Chinese stocks.
In this trade war, “every individual should stand by the country until the end”.
Like Mr Cao, many retail investors are joining the state-backed “national team” to defend the stock market – another battlefield in the broadening US-China trade war, say traders and brokers.
The data does not show how much of those inflows were from retail investors, versus the “national team”.

title: Walmart-backed Flipkart to shift base back to India from Singapore
summary:
- Flipkart will shift its holding company from Singapore to India, the e-commerce company said on April 22, as its parent Walmart aims to take the 17-year-old company public.
Flipkart started in 2007 by selling books online and expanded into a behemoth that competes with Amazon in India.
It moved its holding company to Singapore in 2011.
Walmart bought a controlling stake in Flipkart in 2018, which also gave it ownership of PhonePe, a digital payments company owned by Flipkart at the time.
In 2022, PhonePe separated from Flipkart and shifted its headquarters from Singapore to India, a move that left Walmart with a tax bill of nearly US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion).

title: LG Energy pulls out of $11 billion EV battery project with Indonesia
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxLG Energy's withdrawal is a blow to Indonesia's ambitions to become a major hub for the technology.
– LG Energy Solution withdrew from a 142 trillion rupiah (S$11 billion) partnership with Indonesia to build a full electric vehicle battery supply chain, in a blow to the country’s ambitions to become a major hub for the technology.
LG’s withdrawal is a setback for Indonesia, which has tried to leverage its large reserves of battery metal nickel to draw investment from foreign firms.
LG Energy Solution said it would continue to explore areas of collaboration with the Indonesian government.
In 2024, the firm opened the country’s first battery cell plant with Hyundai Motor Group.

title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 27.7% rise in Q1 distributable income of $65 million
summary:
SINGAPORE - Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) on April 22 reported a jump in distributable income of 27.7 per cent to $65 million for the first quarter of 2025, from $50.9 million in the year-ago period.
KIT is set to acquire an approximate 46.7 per cent stake in GMG from its trustee-manager, Keppel Infrastructure Fund.
It previously held a 100 per cent interest in GMG since acquiring it in early March .
Post-acquisition, the remaining 53.3 per cent interest will be held by KIF and its co-investor.
Contribution from Ixom, KIT’s infrastructure business in Australia and New Zealand, however, was down 2.2 per cent to $14.7 million on higher capex and interest expenses.

title: Tariff confusion leaves US advertisers ‘paralysed’ and ‘sombre’
summary:
How do social media companies account for the potential disappearance of Chinese companies that have spent billions of dollars promoting their wares?
How does an automaker pitch vehicles that may cost consumers thousands of dollars more than they did a year ago?
Now, those advertisers feel “paralysed”, said Mr Jay Pattisall, a principal analyst at Forrester, a research firm.
A home goods merchant in Minneapolis offered discounts on vintage Chinese items “in *celebration* of the tariff tirade”.
Caution will reign for now, said Mr Martin Sorrell, the founder of S4 Capital and a former head of WPP, one of the world’s largest ad companies.

title: Japan’s Nomura to buy Macquarie’s US, European asset management units for $2.3 billion
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe transaction is expected to close by the end of 2025.
Bengaluru - Japanese investment bank Nomura will acquire Macquarie Group’s public asset management operations in the United States and Europe for A$2.8 billion ($2.3 billion), the companies said on April 22.
Japan’s largest brokerage and investment bank will acquire all of Macquarie Asset Management’s US and European public assets, investment teams and operating platforms, and will retain the existing management team.
The Australian financial conglomerate said that as part of the deal, it would collaborate with Nomura on product and distribution.
Upon the deal’s completion, Nomura’s total assets under management within its investment management franchise are expected to increase to around US$770 billion (S$1 trillion) from approximately US$590 billion currently, Nomura said.

title: US stocks suffer steep losses following Trump’s anti-Powell tirade
summary:
All three major indexes tumbled more than 2 per cent, with big losses in the “Magnificent Seven” group of megacap growth stocks weighing heaviest on the tech-laden Nasdaq.
The S&P 500 closed 16 per cent below its Feb 19 record closing high.
All 11 major sectors in the S&P 500 ended in negative territory, with consumer discretionary and tech suffering the biggest percentage losses.
On the Nasdaq, 1,205 stocks rose and 3,174 fell as declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 2.63-to-1 ratio.
The S&P 500 posted one new 52-week high and nine new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 28 new highs and 184 new lows.

title: I thought I was an ethical shopper – until I was forced to cut up a new pair of shoes
summary:
The writer was asked to cut up the shoes in order to get a refund.
It was, I reasoned, high time I invested in a pair of flats that would last – and I knew just the pair.
“In order to process your refund, we will need to receive a picture of the TONGUES OF YOUR SHOES.
Please carefully cut both tongues (or the part of the shoes where the item number is stated),” the brand’s reply read.
I bought them off the brand’s Singapore website and did not question if it had a physical store here (it did not).

title: I thought I was an ethical shopper – until I was forced to cut up a new pair of shoes
summary:
The writer was asked to cut up the shoes in order to get a refund.
It was, I reasoned, high time I invested in a pair of flats that would last – and I knew just the pair.
“In order to process your refund, we will need to receive a picture of the TONGUES OF YOUR SHOES.
Please carefully cut both tongues (or the part of the shoes where the item number is stated),” the brand’s reply read.
I bought them off the brand’s Singapore website and did not question if it had a physical store here (it did not).

title: Singapore stocks rise on April 21 as STI extends rally amid mixed regional markets
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe STI closed up 1.1 per cent or 38.89 points at 3,759.22.
SINGAPORE - The Straits Times Index (STI) continued to rally on April 21 as Asian indexes closed mixed amid traders tracking the tariff talks.
The STI closed up 1.1 per cent or 38.89 points at 3,759.22.
ST Engineering came in at the bottom of the table, shedding 1 per cent or seven cents to close at $7.06.
This varied market performance comes as US President Donald Trump’s gaze shifts to Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell.

title: China slashes US commodities purchases as trade war intensifies
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAmong the worst affected were purchases of liquefied natural gas and wheat, which both fell to zero in March.
– China sharply reduced imports of many US commodities in March – in some cases, to zero – as the trade war between the world’s two biggest economies intensified.
The US accounted for 17 per cent of China’s wheat imports in 2024, and 5 per cent of its LNG.
China’s purchases are likely to dwindle even further after the trade war kicked into higher gear in early April, when both sides launched blanket tariffs of more than 100 per cent on each other’s goods.
Corn imports fell to less than 800 tonnes, the lowest level since February 2020.

title: Asean, Australia and New Zealand’s upgraded free trade area deal enters into force
summary:
SINGAPORE – An upgraded agreement between Asean, Australia and New Zealand entered into force on April 21, enhancing business opportunities across a free trade area of over 703 million people, with a combined gross domestic product of more than US$5.6 trillion (S$7.3 trillion).
The deal to upgrade the Asean-Australia-New Zealand Free Trade Area (AANZFTA) was signed in Indonesia in August 2023 to promote opportunities in areas such as e-commerce, investment, services, sustainable development, consumer protection and government procurement.
It will also boost cooperation among governments to help businesses capture opportunities in the green economy.
The upgraded agreement also has a new chapter that promotes collaboration between governments to enhance the capabilities of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and improve the business environment for them.
In 2023, Asean’s total trade in goods with Australia and New Zealand amounted to US$138.4 billion.

title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares up as US eases proposed port fees on China-built vessels
summary:
The US has eased on its initial proposal of imposing port fees and curbs on China-built vessels.
SINGAPORE - Shares of mainboard-listed Yangzijiang Shipbuilding surged on April 21, after the US eased up on its initial proposal of imposing port fees and curbs on China-built vessels.
The company saw its share price sink in February, after the US Trade Representative Office (USTR) laid out proposed fees and other shipping restrictions on Chinese vessels.
US exporters and vessel owners using China-built vessels to service the Great Lakes, the Caribbean and US territories will also be exempt from port fees.
Chinese-built ships owned by non-Chinese firms will face a fee of US$18 per net ton, with annual increases of US$5.

title: Headstart On Record Podcast: Will working in the office 5 days a week return?
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxRecent high-profile office return mandates belie a broader availability of flexi-work options from more firms.
Those of us who are humming along at a comfortable rhythm with hybrid work might have watched with worry recent developments of major firms insisting on five days in office a week by default.
After all, it seemed like an equilibrium was reached in the years following the Covid-19 pandemic of working remotely for at least part of the week.
To piece together what to make of this mixed outlook, ST correspondent Tay Hong Yi speaks with his guest, a two-decade corporate veteran who now works with industry players to put in place progressive workplace practices.
5:11 Flexi-work arrangements are still more prevalent than before7:57 Is there a chance of a “domino effect” of firms issuing office return mandates, one after the other?

title: Keppel secures $2 billion in fresh capital commitments across flagship funds
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxKeppel aims to reach its $200 billion funds under management target by 2030.
SINGAPORE - Keppel secured fresh capital commitments of close to $2 billion for its three flagship funds, representing around $4.9 billion of funds under management (FUM).
The target funds are Keppel Data Centre Fund III (KDCF III), Keppel Education Asset Fund II (KEAF II) and Sustainable Urban Renewal (SUR) strategy.
The capital commitments that KEAF II secured came from a sovereign wealth fund which invested in Keppel Education Asset Fund I, alongside commitments from new limited partners from the insurance, pension and endowment sectors.
The newly secured funds bring the strategy’s cumulative FUM to around $4.3 billion to date and include latest commitments from one of Europe’s largest pension funds.

title: US dollar slides as Fed independence comes under threat from Trump
summary:
Mr Trump launched a series of public attacks against the Fed chief on April 17.
The dollar tumbled 1.3 per cent to a decade low of 0.8062 against the safe-haven Swiss franc.
Against the Singapore currency, the dollar fell 0.7 per cent to 1.3021 as at 4.21pm Singapore time.
Mr Win Thin, global head of markets strategy at Brown Brothers Harriman, wrote in a note: “We believe dollar weakness will continue.
The attack on Fed independence is intensifying.

title: South Korea uncovers ‘Made in Korea’ breaches intended to avoid US tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Korea Customs Service said it found 29.5 billion won (S$27 million) worth of country-of-origin violations in the first quarter.
SEOUL - South Korea has found increasing attempts to disguise foreign products, mostly from China, as Korean exports to avoid US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, said its customs agency on April 21.
That compared with a total of 34.8 billion won worth of violations for the whole of 2024, among which US-bound shipments accounted for 62 per cent.
Mr Trump slapped tariffs of 25 per cent on South Korea in April, which were later suspended for three months.
In March, 19.3 billion won worth of surveillance cameras were imported from China in parts and reassembled in South Korea to bypass US restrictions on Chinese communication devices.

title: Volvo to cut up to 800 US jobs as Trump’s tariffs bite
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxVolvo’s layoffs are the latest response from an industry reeling from the tariffs on auto parts.
NEW YORK - Volvo Group plans to lay off as many as 800 workers at three US facilities over the next three months due to market uncertainty and demand concerns in the face of US President Donald Trump’s tariffs, a spokesperson said.
Volvo Group North America said in a statement on April 18 that it has told employees it plans to lay off 550 to 800 people at its Mack Trucks site in Macungie, Pennsylvania, and two Volvo Group facilities in Dublin, Virginia, and Hagerstown, Maryland.
The company, part of Sweden’s AB Volvo, employs nearly 20,000 people in North America, according to its website.
“Heavy-duty truck orders continue to be negatively affected by market uncertainty about freight rates and demand, possible regulatory changes, and the impact of tariffs,” a spokesperson for Volvo Group North America said in an e-mailed statement.

title: Shrinking South Korea exports send global warning on Trump tariffs
summary:
- South Korea’s preliminary April trade data gave an early glimpse into how US President Donald Trump’s aggressive protectionist policies could dent shipments of export-reliant economies.
After hiking duties on imports of metals in March, Mr Trump imposed a 25 per cent tariff on auto imports and a 10 per cent tariff on all other shipments earlier in April .
The slowing momentum for exports underscores the risks to South Korea’s export-driven economy from Mr Trump’s protectionist policies.
Bloomberg Economics analyst Hyosung Kwon said: “Beyond the direct impact of tariffs, weaker demand for South Korean products as a result of a US slowdown will also hurt.
If the Trump administration decides to press ahead with plans to impose tariffs on semiconductor imports, it could further hurt the South Korean industry that has been a bedrock of the country’s export-led economy.

title: First shockwaves of Trump’s tariffs about to hit world economy
summary:
- Three weeks after US President Donald Trump effectively declared a trade war with the whole world, new economic forecasts and surveys will point to the initial fallout.
“Our new growth projections will include notable markdowns, but not recession,” IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva said on April 17.
In the four large crises we studied, the fund’s initial assessment of the immediate impact on global growth understated it by 0.5 percentage point.
Ms Georgieva is hoping that the coming days, which also feature a meeting of Group of 20 finance chiefs, might lower the temperature in global trade relations.
“We need a more resilient world economy, not a drift to division,” she said.

title: Fidelity, Goldman find tariff haven in Asia consumer stocks
summary:
A risk for consumer staples would be a flare-up in inflation, which could curb enthusiasm for the sector, said one analyst.
Strategists at Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley recommended Asian consumer staples in reports released after the April 2 tariff barrage, urging investors to turn defensive.
Fidelity International said it snapped up battered Chinese consumer stocks, betting the companies will benefit from government stimulus.
Asian consumer stocks have also fared better than their peers in the United States and Europe during the market turmoil, thanks to prompt vows of policy support.
In an April 6 report, Goldman strategists raised their recommendation for Asian consumer staples to overweight from market weight, saying they are tilting more “domestic and defensive”.

title: Headstart On Record Podcast: Will working in the office 5 days a week return?
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxRecent high-profile office return mandates belie a broader availability of flexi-work options from more firms.
Those of us who are humming along at a comfortable rhythm with hybrid work might have watched with worry recent developments of major firms insisting on five days in office a week by default.
After all, it seemed like an equilibrium was reached in the years following the Covid-19 pandemic of working remotely for at least part of the week.
To piece together what to make of this mixed outlook, ST correspondent Tay Hong Yi speaks with his guest, a two-decade corporate veteran who now works with industry players to put in place progressive workplace practices.
5:11 Flexi-work arrangements are still more prevalent than before7:57 Is there a chance of a “domino effect” of firms issuing office return mandates, one after the other?

title: Candy-maker YLF says it scrapped Singapore IPO as stock market sours on US tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxYLF Group Marketing had lodged its preliminary prospectus to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on March 27.
SINGAPORE - YLF Group Marketing – the maker of Pikin plum candies – said it withdrew its application for a Singapore initial public offering (IPO) due to tough market conditions created by US tariffs.
“Circumstances such as the US import duty tariffs have made the market unfavourable for IPO,” chief executive Lee Tee Wei told The Business Times.
YLF, which manufactures and distributes candy in Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand, lodged its preliminary prospectus to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on March 27.
YLF was started in 1975 by Mr Lee’s parents as food and beverage company Yew Lian Foodstuffs Trading, registering its first Pikin trademark in Singapore in 1987.

title: Digital bank Anext’s services a boon for small businesses
summary:
Mr Chua, 33, turned to Singapore-based digital wholesale bank Anext after the banks rejected his loan applications.
In less than three days, Anext Bank approved his loan of $10,000, repayable over five years.
He also holds an Anext business account, which does not charge transaction fees for local transfers and requires no minimum balance.
Anext Bank was named the Best Digital Bank in Singapore by The Asian Banker in TABInsights’ World’s Top 100 Digital Banks Ranking 2025, which ranked over 160 digital banks globally.
Green Link Digital Bank, the other Singapore-based digital wholesale bank, is similarly growing its operating income rapidly, although, like Anext, it was also loss-making in 2023.

title: Fund managers tapping MAS’ $5b boost for markets should step up to promote good corporate governance
summary:
Although data is difficult to come by, it appears that fund managers lag far behind their retail counterparts on institutional participation in corporate affairs.
All these criteria are quite logically what rational investors will use when deciding where to place their money.
Although data on institutional participation in corporate affairs, including attendance and voting at general meetings, is difficult to come by, it appears that the disappointing answer is that fund managers lag far behind their retail counterparts.
In a 2007 paper titled Improving the Implementation of Corporate Governance Practices in Singapore , well-known corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen noted: “In Singapore, institutional shareholder activism remains at a nascent stage of development, with very few institutional investors actively engaging with companies, participating in shareholder meetings, and voting their shares.
Other than these incidents, there have been no reported incidents of fund managers playing prominent roles in enforcing good governance, which is a shame, given the financial muscle these investors can exert.

title: S’pore stocks rise; OCBC jumps after chairman justifies $1.4b takeover offer for Great Eastern
summary:
OCBC jumps after chairman defends GE takeoverOCBC Bank was among the gainers on the index last week, rising 6.5 per cent to close the week at $15.98 .
OCBC, which has had a controlling stake in the insurer for almost three decades, now owns 93.7 per cent of GE.
That is what sets OCBC apart from its local peers DBS and UOB, which are pure-play banks, he said.
Correction note: An earlier version of the story said that OCBC will not raise its offer price for GE.
OCBC has clarified that it will not blink in its intentions for GE, not the price.

title: Volkswagen floats making Audis in US to swerve Trump tariffs
summary:
BERLIN - Volkswagen could relocate some production of its high-end Audi line to dodge US tariffs on automobiles ordered by US President Donald Trump, the German carmaker’s CEO said in an interview released on April 18.
“For Audi, production in the United States would be in line with our development strategy,” he said.
Mr Trump in March announced a 25 per cent tariff on autos imported to the United States, which is the number one destination for German car exports.
The Republican has claimed that imposing tariffs would make foreign companies relocate part of their production to the United States.
Mr Blume would not comment on the tariffs’ financial impact on Volkswagen, nor on whether it would raise its prices in the United States in response.

title: NTUC membership surpasses 1.4 million ahead of May Day
summary:
SINGAPORE - The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) now has more than 1.4 million members, its secretary-general, Mr Ng Chee Meng, said on April 20.
Mr Ng joined NTUC as deputy secretary-genera l in April 2018, before getting elected as secretary-general a month later.
To support older workers in accessing employment opportunities, NTUC had supported the Government in raising the statutory retirement and re-employment ages.
One of the older workers who benefited from training and job redesign is Mr Tan Kim San.
There are 58 unions and 27 NTUC e2i career and job services to support workers’ needs.

title: Malaysia growth misses forecasts even before US tariff hit
summary:
That is below the 4.8 per cent median forecast in a Bloomberg News survey, and marks a third straight quarter of slower growth.
The disappointing data comes as policymakers review the official 4.5 per cent to 5.5 per cent growth projection for 2025 on uncertainty over global trade.
Malaysia was hit with a 24 per cent US import tariff before US President Donald Trump temporarily pared it back to 10 per cent for 90 days while hiking tariffs on China.
“The downside risk to economic growth has become elevated, especially in the context of the US reciprocal tariff,” said Dr Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid, chief economist at Bank Muamalat Malaysia.
Malaysia is working to engage with the US to reduce tariff rates and expand the list of exemptions for its exports to mitigate the blow on the economy, Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said on April 14.

title: How China took over the world’s rare earths industry
summary:
Government forces acting under national security orders stormed the valley near Longnan in Jiangxi province, where much of the world’s heavy rare earth minerals were produced.
The mines were later nationalised and consolidated into a single state-run company, China Rare Earth Group.
Its manufacturers began holding enough rare earths in inventory to meet up to two years of their own needs.
Lynas mines and refines 60 per cent of Japan’s light rare earths, which are mixed with small quantities of heavy rare earths to make rare earth magnets.
The US rare earth magnet industry started with a subsidiary of General Motors in northern Indiana in the 1980s.

title: Japan’s core inflation accelerates, complicating BOJ’s rate path
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxCore inflation has now exceeded the Bank of Japan's 2 per cent target every month for three years in a row.
- Japan’s core inflation accelerated in March due to persistent rises in food costs, data showed on April 18, complicating the central bank’s task of weighing mounting price pressures against risks to the economy from higher US tariffs.
Core inflation has now exceeded the BOJ’s 2 per cent target every month for three years in a row, in a sign of mounting price pressure as companies continue to pass on rising raw material and labour costs.
Households faced price hikes for a wide range of goods including petrol, hotel bills and chocolates.
“Food prices will stay elevated for the time being due to global bad weather and higher imported food costs,” said Mr Takeshi Minami, chief economist at Norinchukin Research Institute.

title: US stocks mixed as Trump eyes trade deal, rips Powell
summary:
NEW YORK – Wall Street stocks finished mixed on April 17 as markets weighed more upbeat comments from US President Donald Trump on trade with his harsh criticism of Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell.
“There will be a trade deal, 100 per cent,” Mr Trump said during a working lunch with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.
But Mr Trump ripped into Mr Powell for not lowering interest rates, saying on social media that the Fed chair’s “termination... cannot come fast enough”.
Mr Hogan said a move by Mr Trump to fire Mr Powell would rattle markets and has not been priced in, but added that investors consider that outcome unlikely, and view Mr Trump’s comments as “bluster”.
Hertz, meanwhile, surged more than 42 per cent after investor Bill Ackman disclosed a stake in the car rental company.

title: Trump’s attack on elite colleges threatens safest US corporate bonds
summary:
NEW YORK – The Trump administration is ratcheting up its attack on Harvard University and higher education institutions, threatening the safest segment of the US corporate bond market.
While US colleges typically borrow in the tax-free municipal-bond market, the schools turned to the corporate space for quick and flexible cash as interest rates fell.
Other elite institutions like Rice University and Stanford University also tout the top grades.
Now, she said, there is more stigma given recent controversies, and that could be driving investors to sell the bonds.
To be sure, credit spreads had widened in the corporate-bond market even before the volatility surrounding President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

title: Trump insists he could fire independent US Fed chairman Powell
summary:
Speaking to reporters at the White House, Mr Trump said Mr Powell would “leave if I ask him to”.
The US President does not have direct authority to fire Federal Reserve governors, but Mr Trump could initiate a lengthy process to attempt to unseat Mr Powell by proving there was “cause” to do so.
Mr Trump has frequently criticised the Fed chairman, whom he originally nominated during his first term, accusing Mr Powell of playing politics.
ECB chief Christine Lagarde expressed her confidence in Mr Powell following Mr Trump’s remarks, saying she had “a lot of respect for my friend and esteemed colleague”.
Speaking on April 4, Mr Powell insisted he had no plans to step down as Fed chairman before his term ends in 2026.

title: ECB cuts interest rates again as Trump tariff fears threaten recovery
summary:
- The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered interest rates for the seventh time since June 2024 as trade tensions threaten to derail the region’s economic recovery.
But markets boosted bets on further cuts in borrowing costs as officials underscored the headwinds that Europe currently faces.
Despite some backtracking by Mr Trump, European Union products face 10 per cent tariffs for 90 days, with no firm indication on what happens beyond that.
In contrast, March data from the euro area confirmed frequent statements by ECB officials that disinflation is on track.
The volatile backdrop, however, has left Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank and Bank of America forecasting deeper reductions.

title: Insurance arm Great Eastern makes OCBC unique among its peers, bank’s chairman says
summary:
SINGAPORE - OCBC Bank chairman Andrew Lee has defended a takeover offer for Great Eastern (GE), saying the insurer gives the bank an added advantage over its peers.
“Today, we are an integrated financial services group consisting of OCBC, Bank of Singapore and GE.
With OCBC now owning 93.7 per cent of GE, the lion’s share of GE’s earnings directly benefits OCBC shareholders.
“We paid millions for that advice,” Mr Lee said, adding that the board has exercised its fiduciary duty in keeping strictly to the advice.
Whatever the outcome, “we’re doubling down on what we do best”, Mr Lee said, naming wealth management, GE’s insurance business, and regional growth in Indonesia as core priorities for growth.

title: Singapore shares rise on April 17 despite Wall St retreat; STI up 1.6%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe regional rally was out of step with Wall Street, where shares took another turn down.
SINGAPORE – Local shares again defied a downbeat Wall Street overnight and tracked regional bourses well into positive territory on April 17.
The buoyant mood sent the Straits Times Index (STI) up a solid 1.6 per cent, or 57.88 points, to 3,720.33.
Gainers easily outpaced losers 361 to 179 in the broader market on trade of 1.2 billion shares worth $1.4 billion.
The market swings are a by-product of trade uncertainties, said Mr Vishnu Varathan, head of macro research at Mizuho Securities.

title: TSMC upbeat on outlook as robust AI demand offsets tariff uncertainty
summary:
– Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) gave a bullish outlook for the year on robust demand for AI applications, adding that while there was uncertainty over US tariffs, the world’s largest contract chip manufacturer had yet to see any change in customer behaviour.
The Taiwanese company, a bellwether for the global chip industry, stood by its annual outlook for sales and capital spending on April 17 and forecast artificial intelligence (AI) chip revenue to double.
“We certainly are mindful of the potential impact from all the recent tariff announcements, especially the impact on end market demand,” TSMC chief executive C.C.
His comments follow media reports that TSMC could take a stake in a joint venture with floundering US chip company Intel.
Foreign investors have sold US$8.66 billion worth of TSMC shares so far in 2025 after buying US$2 billion in 2024 and US$10.4 billion in 2023, Goldman Sachs said in a report.

title: Gold hits fresh record as trade war, Fed chief Powell fire up haven demand
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGold has climbed almost 28 per cent in 2025 as the escalating trade war creates anxiety over a possible global recession.
Sydney - Gold hit another high on April 17 as warnings from Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell about the impact of the trade war fuelled volatility on Wall Street, leading to sharp declines in stocks and the US dollar.
The precious metal has climbed almost 28 per cent in 2025 – outpacing the 27 per cent gain it notched in 2024 – as the escalating trade war creates anxiety over a possible global recession.
Meanwhile, the Trump administration is preparing to pressure nations to curb trade with China in negotiations over US tariffs.
Gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$3,351.79 an ounce at 6.57am in Singapore.

title: CapitaLand Investment launches first retail Reit in China with assets worth $500 million
summary:
SINGAPORE - CapitaLand Investment (CLI) announced on April 17 that it intends to launch its first real estate investment trust (Reit) in China, to be named CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit (CLCR).
The listing would mark the first time an international company has sought listing of a retail Reit on the SSE and the first such retail Reit by a Singapore-based company, if approved.
CLI said the retail Reit will benefit from the Chinese government’s policies to stimulate domestic consumption.
Currently, both malls are owned within CapitaLand Group’s portfolio, with CapitaMall SKY+ jointly owned by CLI and the group’s privately held CapitaLand Development (CLD), while CapitaMall Yuhuating is owned by CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT).
CLI currently manages $18 billion worth of retail assets across 43 properties in China.

title: Singapore must prepare for new global order, seek new opportunities in tariff chaos: DPM Gan
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDeputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong delivering his opening remarks at a gathering of businessmen organised by DBS Bank on April 17.
SINGAPORE - Singapore needs to prepare for a new economic and geopolitical environment that is more protectionist, arbitrary and dangerous, besides managing the hit to economic growth this year, said Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong.
“These moves will open up new opportunities for businesses to explore new markets and strengthen their supply chains,” he said.
The US’ “reciprocal tariffs” have also upended the cornerstone of the rules-based trading order, which is especially important for Singapore.
On the other hand, we and our businesses risk being marginalised, left behind,” DPM Gan said.

title: Trump tariffs threaten to crush Vietnam’s factory boom towns
summary:
Nowhere is the perilous situation felt more deeply than in Vietnam’s southern industrial province Binh Duong.
“I’ve had so many video calls with my customers,” said Mr Yang, vice-president of Yang Cheng Wooden Industries International (Vietnam).
Mr Trump’s tariffs, though, may challenge the nation’s ambitious goal of boosting economic growth to at least 8 per cent in 2025 .
Some US buyers are requesting Vietnamese suppliers split the new 10 per cent tariff, Mr Tung said.
For now, Mr Yang has stopped buying materials for future production.

title: Singapore’s key exports may shrink in 2025 amid US tariffs, trade war: Economists
summary:
Its latest data showed growth in key exports slowed in March ahead of Mr Trump’s April 2 announcement of global tariffs that triggered an escalating trade war with China.
Non-electronics exports grew 3.8 per cent – half the pace of February’s revised 7.7 per cent increase.
Shipments to the US grew 5.7 per cent in March, a sharp drop from the 21.5 per cent growth in February.
Compared with a year earlier, total trade rose 3.4 per cent in March, following a 4.6 per cent expansion in February.
He noted that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) has already slashed its 2025 forecast for the volume of global trade in goods due to the sweeping tariffs, ensuing retaliation and uncertainty.

title: Nasdaq ends down 3.1% on Nvidia drop, economic angst
summary:
The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished at 16,307.16, down 3.1 per cent.
Mr Powell said that while the Fed’s employment and inflation goals were largely in balance at this point, policymakers could find themselves in the “challenging scenario” depending on how things evolve.
Mr Powell “took what was a moderately down day into a pretty dramatic slide,” Mr Ablin added.
The remarks come as Mr Trump’s wide-ranging trade agenda continues to dominate discussion in business and financial circles.
Nvidia ended down around 7 per cent after earlier slumping more than 10 per cent.

title: US looks to box in China by recruiting other trading partners, say sources
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe US wants to ensure that China does not find avenues around President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
The US also wants trading partners to refrain from absorbing excess goods from China, other people said.
The push amounts to an effort by Mr Trump’s team to harness longstanding partners to encircle China and raise pressure on Beijing to change its economic practices.
But Mr Trump and his team have sent conflicting signals about what their end goal is with China.
The President has long called Chinese President Xi Jinping a friend, and he has held out the possibility of brokering a tariff deal.

title: Stocking up on shares? Tread carefully as Trump’s tariff pause has yet to settle, experts warn
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMost countries, including Singapore, now face a 10 per cent tariff on their exports to the US, effective from April 5.
Most countries, including Singapore, now face a 10 per cent tariff on their exports to the US, effective April 5.
China, which retaliated against what it called threats and blackmail from Washington, is subject to a fresh 145 per cent tariff this year.
In retaliation, the world’s second-largest economy imposed a 125 per cent tariff on American goods entering China effective from April 12.
Even if Mr Trump’s tariffs are permanently rolled back, the economic damage has already been inflicted, said Mr Nigel Green, chief executive officer of global financial advisory deVere Group.

title: With earthworms and an oven, she built a better life for her family
summary:
Ms Lilis Suhartini, 36, pulls a tray from the large oven in her kitchen, carefully inspecting the batch of brown particles.
Initially, Ms Lilis produced small batches of earthworm powder, selling it to a local traditional herbal drink shop.
The increase in income from selling earthworm powder allowed Ms Lilis to pay for her sons’ education.
During the weekly repayment sessions, Amartha’s field agent taught Ms Lilis basic bookkeeping skills so she could track her cash flow.
Ms Lilis also hopes to inspire other women in her village to join the earthworm powder business.

title: Trump tariffs could put US Fed in a bind, its chief Jerome Powell warns
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUS Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said the tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation.
“Tariffs are highly likely to generate at least a temporary rise in inflation,” Fed chairman Jerome Powell told the Economic Club of Chicago, warning that the inflationary effects “could also be more persistent”.
Mr Powell said that while the Fed’s employment and inflation goals were largely in balance, policymakers could find themselves in the “challenging scenario in which our dual-mandate goals are in tension”.
“You’ll probably see continued volatility,” Mr Powell said on April 16.
Tariffs would be “likely to move us away from our goals”, Mr Powell said, referring to the Fed’s dual mandate.

title: DPM Gan and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer discuss US tariffs and their impact on trade
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDPM Gan Kim Yong raised concerns about the US tariffs in a call with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer.
SINGAPORE - Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong discussed America’s recent tariffs and their impact on trade in his first conversation with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer on April 15, which he described as a “frank exchange”.
“We discussed our relationship, we talked about the tariffs, our concerns about the tariffs.
We also discussed what we plan to do, going forward,” Mr Gan told reporters on April 16.
Mr Gan also touched on his call with Mr Greer in a LinkedIn post after the press conference, saying he shared Singapore’s concerns on how the tariffs would impact trade .

title: Mature workers, fresh grads may face challenges in jobs market in light of US tariffs: Tan See Leng
summary:
SINGAPORE – Mature workers and fresh graduates may face more challenges in the jobs market amid a global economy shake-up, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.
Dr Tan was speaking to the media during the first meeting of the Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce on April 16.
The task force was set up to help affected businesses and workers navigate the uncertainties sparked by US tariffs on Singapore goods.
Dr Tan, who co-leads this work stream, spoke about the vulnerability of mature workers and how companies may choose to downsize or let them go as the Singapore economy slows.
“Should there be a turn for the worse, we are prepared to provide even more substantial relief to workers and businesses.

title: Singapore’s new task force to address immediate tariff shock, and also plan for the future
summary:
DPM Gan said an economic slowdown will also impact jobs and wages, hence the task force will help Singapore companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, tackle their immediate challenges.
He said the task force will look into how existing schemes can help companies survive the immediate shock and retain their workforce.
The task force includes four other Cabinet ministers, along with representatives of Singapore’s economic and tripartite agencies.
Specifically, the task force will focus on three key areas: communications and “sensemaking” for businesses and workers, addressing their immediate challenges, and longer-term strategies for Singapore.
A cheaper currency may help Singapore exports by offsetting some of the price impact from the new tariff.

title: Singapore has the fiscal resources to get through tariff crisis, says Chee Hong Tat
summary:
Mr Chee said that the Government can bring forward the start date of some of the measures to help businesses and workers if necessary.
Mr Chee said these can help Singapore continue to generate the fiscal resources that it will need to strengthen its social safety nets and social compact.
For an open and small economy like Singapore, a 10 per cent tariff imposition will have larger ramifications.
That has already started to happen, with China slapping a 125 per cent tariff on US goods into the mainland in retaliation to the 145 per cent tariff the US has imposed on Chinese goods entering America.
We finish the final packaging... the impact would be significantly higher,” he said of the 10 per cent tariff the US has imposed on Singapore.

title: STI gains ground on April 16, bucking regional indexes
summary:
The STI ended 1 per cent or 37.73 points ahead at 3,662.45 although losers just outnumbered gainers 277 to 268 after 1.3 billion shares worth $1.5 billion changed hands.
SINGAPORE – Local shares managed to buck regional trends and a negative session on Wall Street overnight to record modest if welcome gains on April 16.
The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 1 per cent or 37.73 points ahead at 3,662.45, although losers just outnumbered gainers 277 to 268 after 1.3 billion shares worth $1.5 billion changed hands.
The Kospi in Seoul fell 1.2 per cent, Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 shed 1 per cent, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong dived 1.9 per cent and Malaysian shares fell 0.6 per cent.
The downbeat results followed lacklustre trading on Wall Street where the three indexes edged lower on lingering concerns over the Trump trade policies.

title: More workshops, regular updates to help S’pore firms cope with US tariffs: Josephine Teo
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore will organise more workshops and conferences, and have more media updates, to help firms here understand and navigate the changing business environment amid uncertainties triggered by the sweeping tariffs recently imposed by the US.
It is co-led by Minister for Digital Development and Information Josephine Teo and Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chairman Lim Ming Yan.
An example she raised is Enterprise Singapore’s frequently asked questions website section, which details how firms can handle the suspension of reciprocal tariffs.
Mr Lee said SBF held a closed-door forum on April 16, featuring insights from government, legal, logistics and financial experts.
Mrs Teo added that Singapore’s seniors, particularly those who remember past disruptions, understand the profound implications these changes could have for Singapore.

title: Five ministers to helm new economic resilience task force to help S’pore navigate US tariffs
summary:
The task force, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong, held its first meeting on April 16.
The second work stream, “addressing immediate challenges”, is co-led by Mr Ng, Mr Tan Hee Teck and Dr Tan See Leng.
It will focus on longer-term strategies to help businesses and workers seize new opportunities and build resilience in the evolving economic landscape.
The task force will begin engaging businesses and workers in the coming weeks and will provide regular progress updates.
The task force comes on the back of US President Donald Trump’s sweeping new tariffs on trading partners on April 2.

title: China’s economic growth in first quarter beats forecasts ahead of tariff impact
summary:
Things can deteriorate fairly quickly, with some high-frequency data showing tariff impact on US-bound shipments.”The impact of the trade war will likely manifest in economic activities starting from April.
The data released by the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) suggests the economy had a solid start in 2025 and growth accelerated in March.
With the positive data, the risk is that officials could decide to act only when they see concrete impact on growth from tariffs.
China could struggle to meet its official growth target of around 5 per cent in 2025 without more stimulus.
Economists at several international banks including UBS Group, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup and Societe Generale have all lowered their forecasts for China’s 2025 growth in recent weeks to around 4 per cent or lower.

title: World’s biggest trade fair in China confronts Trump tariff ‘disaster’
summary:
People at the China Import and Export Fair, commonly known as the Canton Fair, in Guangzhou on April 15.
- Executives at the world’s biggest trade fair in China found themselves staring into the abyss as the seams of global commerce came apart.
The American presence was very thin on the ground as the trade fair got started on April 15.
Canadian company Forno is also looking to move production of kitchen appliances such as fridges from China to get around the tariffs.
“The China-US ( relations are) beyond salvation – this change of gears is irreversible,” said Mr Dan Wang, China director of the Eurasia Group.

title: Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce to take three-pronged approach to help businesses, workers
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDPM Gan Kim Yong (left) and SBF vice-chairman Mark Lee at a press conference by the Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce on April 16.
These will be the three main work streams undertaken by the new Singapore Economic Resilience Taskforce, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong told the media during the first meeting of the task force on April 16.
The first work stream will focus on establishing regular three-way communication between the Government, businesses and workers, and will include updates about the latest developments and assessments of their impact.
The second work stream will be tasked with identifying the pain points and immediate challenges faced by businesses and workers.
Minister for National Development Desmond Lee, who co-leads the third work stream, noted that economic resilience is not only about withstanding adversity, but also transforming through it and thriving.

title: Japfa shareholders accept privatisation offer from founder’s family
summary:
SINGAPORE – Japfa shareholders have approved a bid by the family members of the mainboard-listed meat producer’s late founder to take the business private, paving the way for a delisting on or around June 3.
Japfa’s shareholders will receive 62 cents per share in cash on or around May 30, in line with the family members’ offer.
The family members of Japfa’s founder in January had offered to take the firm private, valuing the processor of chicken, pork and beef at US$877 million (S$1.16 billion).
The offer was made in January through a special purpose vehicle owned by Renaldo Santosa, Gabriella Santosa and their cousin Rachel Anastasia Kolonas.
The privatisation would also allow Japfa to save on expenses for maintaining its listing, and to focus its resources on its business operations.

title: LHN proposes spin-off, mainboard listing of co-living business Coliwoo
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxLHN expects to continue holding a majority stake in Coliwoo after its spin-off.
SINGAPORE - LHN Group intends to take its co-living business Coliwoo Group public on the Singapore Exchange.
The real estate management services group, dual-listed in Singapore and Hong Kong, has submitted applications in both places for the proposed spin-off and separate listing of the shares of Coliwoo on the mainboard of SGX.
The co-living business falls under the space optimisation business, independent of the other three business segments.
LHN expects to continue holding a majority shareholding in Coliwoo, which will continue to be consolidated with the group, assuming the proposed spin-off is successful.

title: A $2.3 billion plan to build Australia’s tallest tower falters
summary:
In one of the most prominent examples yet of Australia’s building crunch, the millennial developers’ ambition went stratospheric, it turns out, at the worst possible time.
Beulah’s Ms Teh is the daughter of Datuk Ir Teh Kean Ming, who was once CEO of IJM Corp, one of Malaysia’s biggest developers.
Ms Teh and Mr Chan both went to the University of Melbourne, where Ms Teh obtained a master’s in Architecture.
Mr Chan studied engineering and initially did not anticipate going into real estate, he said in a 2020 interview.
Even as Beulah was making plans for Australia’s tallest building, in 2021 it completed a 48-level apartment tower in Melbourne’s central business district called Paragon.

title: US stocks dip as markets monitor trade war fallout
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks finished lower on April 15 following news of solid bank earnings, as investors monitor developments in the US-China trade war after last week market gyrations.
A White House spokeswoman described the ball as being “in China’s court” in the trade war between Washington and Beijing.
Investors welcomed a calmer US Treasury market after last week’s spike in US Treasury bond yields.
“Will we have relief or progress with the trade tariff situation or is the situation going to get worse?“ Mr Sarhan said.
Netflix surged 4.8 per cent following a Wall Street Journal report that said the streaming company is targeting a doubling of revenue by 2030.

title: Nvidia hit with new US curbs on chip exports to China that will cost it $7.3 billion
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxNvidia's H20 graphics processing units will now require a licence to export to China “for the indefinite future”.
– Nvidia faces new US restrictions on the export of its H20 chip to China, a policy change that will cost the company billions of dollars and hamstring a product line that it explicitly designed to comply with previous curbs.
Advanced Micro Devices, which competes with Nvidia in the artificial intelligence chip market, slumped as well.
Trump officials have indicated that they want to strengthen and streamline that global framework.
They follow earlier sanctions on dozens of Chinese firms that Trump officials allege are aiding Beijing’s military tech efforts.

title: Minority shareholders question OCBC CEO Helen Wong’s re-election as director of Great Eastern
summary:
Minority shareholders pressed the board to confirm whether Ms Wong had disclosed these meetings and if the board had verified the accuracy of the Bloomberg report.
“It is not for the GE board to ask a director, who happens to be a CEO of a bank, concerning meetings that she might have conducted,” he said.
“From the board’s perspective, Ms Wong is well aware of her responsibilities as a director.
He added that GE’s AGM is not the right forum for “some shareholders to question other shareholders with regard to certain media reports”.
Ms Wong “also abstained from the board’s deliberations on the proposal for her re-election as a director”.

title: Home owners in HDB loan arrears to receive help servicing mortgage under new programme
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxHDB said about 1,200 households who are in HDB loan arrears could potentially benefit from the programme.
Under the Homeowner Job Support (HJS) pilot programme, the Housing Board will also suspend mortgage interest for home owners in mortgage arrears for one year.
HDB said about 1,200 households who are in HDB loan arrears could potentially benefit from the programme.
These include allowing them to pay their loan arrears by instalment until their financial situation improves.
HDB said the partnerships with WSG and e2i aim to support unemployed HDB home owners who have fallen behind in their mortgage payments, and help them secure stable employment to work towards repaying their mortgage arrears.

title: China’s economy will grow just 3.4 per cent in 2025 as US tariffs choke exports, says UBS
summary:
– UBS added to a series of growth downgrades for China with the most pessimistic forecast among major banks, predicting the economy will expand just 3.4 per cent this year as US tariffs choke exports.
The Swiss bank, which previously saw growth in 2025 at 4 per cent, maintained its estimate for 2026 at 3 per cent.
“The tariff shock poses unprecedented challenges to China’s exports and will set forth major adjustment in the domestic economy as well,” UBS economists including Tao Wang wrote in a note on April 15.
Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup are among global banks that cut their outlook for China in recent days, with most economists doubting Beijing can achieve the official target of around 5 per cent growth in 2025 .
China’s economy likely held up well in the first quarter before the biggest tariff hikes came into force.

title: Singapore shares in another day of rally, tracking regional indexes
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Straits Times Index closed up 2.1 per cent or 75.81 points at 3,624.72.
SINGAPORE - Singapore shares continued to rally on April 15, tracking regional indexes.
The Straits Times Index (STI) closed up 2.1 per cent, or 75.81 points, at 3,624.72.
The STI’s top gainer was Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, closing up 6.1 per cent, or five cents, at 87 cents.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index closed up 0.2 per cent, and the KLCI was up 0.4 per cent.

title: Singapore cyber-related trust marks expanded to cover cloud, AI and operations tech
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSME executives participating in a simulated cybersecurity exercise at the launch of the expanded Cyber Essentials and Cyber Trust marks on April 15.
“When we got (the Cyber Trust mark) in 2022, it really opened doors.
On April 15, the Cyber Trust mark and Cyber Essentials certification were enhanced to cover new areas in cloud, artificial intelligence (AI), and operational technology used largely in manufacturing.
More than 500 businesses have at least the Cyber Essentials mark today, out of over 300,000 companies in Singapore.
The enterprise also needs to secure their cloud usage, and they can take reference from the cloud security content in Cyber Essentials or Cyber Trust,” he said.

title: Made-in-China toy billionaire says tariffs will double US prices
summary:
– Toy billionaire Nick Mowbray said US President Donald Trump’s tariffs have “paralysed” his company and left it with little choice but to pump up retail prices in the US.
That has landed the firm at the sharp end of Mr Trump’s 145 per cent tariff on imports from China.
“At the tariff levels right now, in toys at least, those retail prices need to nearly double,” Mr Mowbray said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles.
“It’s not financially viable.”Zuru is negotiating with retailers, many of whom have paused orders, Mr Mowbray said.
“We’ve spent 22 years building this, and one or two people can upset it so much,” Mr Mowbray said.

title: US-China tariff war collapses trade in key petroleum product
summary:
The price of propane has plummeted in the US because selling to China is no longer viable because of tariffs.
US production has soared thanks to the shale revolution, and China has capitalised by ramping up its plastics-making capacity.
Chinese propane importers have been frantically trying to offload US cargoes they can no longer afford in exchange for other supplies.
The LPG trade from the US to China has grown rapidly in recent years to about US$1 billion (S$1.3 billion) a month.
Moreover, cargoes from the Middle East often mix propane with butane, which is a less suitable feedstock for Chinese plants, according to traders.

title: Italy’s secretive shipping tycoon emerges as lead player in Li Ka-Shing’s $25 billion ports deal
summary:
The deal has thrust 84-year-old Mr Aponte into an uncharacteristically high-profile position while underscoring his firm’s increasingly dominant role in worldwide shipping.
The low-key Mr Aponte, silver-haired and slight of build, rarely speaks in public or gives interviews.
Mr Gianluigi Aponte was born near the Bay of Naples, where the family traditionally ferried goods and passengers.
In the late 1980s Mr Aponte made the jump into the leisure segment, and MSC Cruises became the world’s third-largest cruise brand.
Like his European shipping peers, Mr Aponte pushed heavily into ports and logistics.

title: US dollar keeps falling as its ‘safe-haven’ status is questioned
summary:
Investors and many of Mr Trump’s advisers had expected the dollar to strengthen as tariffs were put in place.
The dollar would be destabilised further if Mr Trump sought to undermine the independence of the Fed, which sets interest rates free from political influence.
Mr Bessent said on April 14 that monetary policy was a “jewel box that’s got to be preserved”.
Mr Trump will have a chance to pick a new chair of the Fed after Mr Jerome Powell’s term expires in May 2026.
The administration will begin that process in the fall, Mr Bessent said.

title: South Korea unveils $30.6 billion support package for chips amid US tariff uncertainty
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSeoul will also ramp up a financial assistance programme for the chips industry to 20 trillion won.
- South Korea announced on April 15 an increase in its support package for the country’s vital semiconductor industry to 33 trillion won (S$30.6 billion), up about a quarter from a 26 trillion won package unveiled in 2024.
Seoul will also ramp up a financial assistance programme for the chips industry to 20 trillion won, versus the previous 17 trillion won, according to the joint statement from various ministries, including the Trade Ministry.
In 2024, South Korea’s exports of semiconductors stood at US$141.9 billion (S$187 billion), accounting for 21 per cent of the country’s total, government data showed.
Shipments to China and the US stood at US$46.6 billion and US$10.7 billion, respectively.

title: US stocks rise with Apple shares as investors assess tariff exemptions
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks ended higher on April 14, with Apple giving the S&P 500 its biggest boost as the White House exempted smartphones and computers from new tariffs.
Investors remain worried about how companies will manage supply chains as more changes are expected on the tariff front.
Global technology shares mostly rose on the news, especially for companies that rely on imports from China.
Investors, worried that a global trade war will push the economy into recession, have seen some of the biggest swings in the market in years as the Trump tariff news changes.
Technical analysts noted, though, that the S&P 500 is now in a “death cross” pattern, which marks a spot where a shorter-term correction could turn into a longer-term downtrend.

title: Job seekers can complete activities and earn points to qualify for payouts from April 15
summary:
To qualify for the payout, job seekers have to earn at least 10 points per month for the first three months, and five points per month for the next three months.
The payout will stop once job seekers secure a job.
Job seekers can track their progress, activity period and payouts on the Jobseeker Support scheme portal’s dashboard.
For instance, job seekers need to upload screenshots of their updated resumes, and provide details on who they have met for networking purposes.
The monthly payouts, however, are capped at a job seeker’s past average gross monthly income.

title: Candy maker YLF withdraws IPO, auto group Vin’s jumps on SGX debut
summary:
Candy maker YLF Group Marketing has halted its plans to go public on the SGX, less than three weeks after it lodged its prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO).
In contrast, Vin’s Holdings began trading on Catalist on April 15, making it the first company to go public on the SGX in 2025.
Its shares made their debut at 31.5 cents a share, and were trading at 36.5 cents at around 11am.
