The Singapore automotive group announced on April 14 that it has successfully completed a share placement for its IPO, raising $6 million in gross proceeds through the sale of 20 million shares at 30 cents apiece .
With the successful completion of the placement, Vin’s total issued share capital now comprises just over 131 million shares, giving the company a market capitalisation of $39.3 million upon listing.

title: Singapore shares close higher, in line with regional indexes
summary:
SINGAPORE - The Straits Times Index (STI) closed higher on April 14, mirroring most regional indexes.
The STI closed up 1 per cent or 36.38 points to 3,548.91.
The top gainer on the STI was SGX, which closed up 2.1 per cent or 26 cents to $12.95.
Across the region, major indexes closed higher, with the Kospi up 1 per cent and the Nikkei 225 up 1.2 cent.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index gained 2.4 per cent and the KLCI climbed 1.8 per cent.

title: GXS Bank acquires Validus Capital, leading digital lending platform for S’pore SMEs
summary:
Presently, GXS has a business banking solution, GXS Biz Account, but this is only for single ownership businesses, such as sole proprietorships.
Trust Bank, the third digital bank serving retail customers in Singapore, actually holds a full bank licence.
This allows it to offer retail and business banking services similar to those of legacy banks DBS, OCBC and UOB.
The joint venture between Standard Chartered Bank and the enterprise arm of NTUC also does not have business banking services for now.
The two digital wholesale banks in Singapore, Anext Bank and Green Link Digital Bank, are allowed only to take deposits and provide banking services to SMEs and other non-retail customer segments.

title: Companies getting ‘a bit tired’ of tariff chaos, DHL CEO says
summary:
SINGAPORE – Fatigue is setting in among companies and manufacturers trying to navigate US President Donald Trump’s whipsawing tariff moves, according to DHL Group chief executive Tobias Meyer.
Dr Meyer, head of one of the world’s biggest logistics companies, warned that companies and people are getting “a bit tired” of the constantly shifting announcements.
US officials have spoken of raising between US$300 billion (S$396 billion) to US$600 billion from the tariffs, while Mr Trump has pledged tax cuts.
Customers are opting to wait to make decisions until Mr Trump’s tariff decisions are decided.
Dr Meyer is visiting Singapore as the global logistics giant has opened a new €10 million (S$15 million) pharmaceutical hub in the city-state.

title: Ong Beng Seng to step down as managing director of Hotel Properties
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxOng Beng Seng is set to plead guilty in a court case linked to former transport minister S. Iswaran.
SINGAPORE - Property tycoon Ong Beng Seng, who is set to plead guilty in a court case linked to former transport minister S. Iswaran, will step down as managing director of Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) at the close of the company’s annual general meeting (AGM) on April 29.
HPL said in an exchange filing on April 14 that Ong, 79, “wishes to devote more time to manage his medical conditions”.
He had previously been scheduled to plead guilty on April 2 .
Its famous brands include Como Hotels & Resorts, Concorde Hotels, Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts, Hard Rock Hotels and Marriott International.

title: Olam to focus on food ingredients business, sell the rest
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxOlam Group will invest US$500 million in its food ingredients business and divest all remaining businesses and assets over time.
- Singapore-based food and agri-business conglomerate Olam Group said on April 14 it will invest US$500 million (S$657 million) in its food ingredients business and divest all remaining businesses and assets over time.
The equity investment in Olam Food Ingredients will allow the company to explore options including a potential concurrent listing in Europe and in Singapore, it said.
Mr Verghese said the timing of the listing is subject to the performance of Olam Food Ingredients and market conditions including the geopolitical situation.
In 2022, the company delayed a planned London listing for the food ingredients unit, citing market volatility amid the war in Ukraine.

title: China in bond sale deluge to help economy withstand surging US tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina's government accelerated bond offerings to help the economy offset the impact of surging US tariffs on Chinese goods.
- China’s credit expanded more than expected in March as the government accelerated bond offerings to help the economy offset the impact of surging US tariffs on Chinese goods.
That compares with a median forecast of 4.96 trillion yuan by economists in a Bloomberg survey, and an increase of 4.83 trillion yuan in the same month a year ago.
The median forecast was 3 trillion yuan.
However, US President Donald Trump’s policy flip-flop also underscores the massive uncertainty faced by the Chinese economy.

title: Singapore downgrades 2025 GDP forecast to 0%-2% as US-China tariff war weighs on global growth
summary:
On the same day, the Monetary Authority of Singapore further reduced the pace of the local currency’s trade-weighted appreciation, in response to easing inflation and rising risks to economic growth.
This is slower than the 5 per cent growth in the fourth quarter of 2024 and some market projections.
The tit-for-tat tariff moves could lead to a full-blown global trade war, which will upend global supply chains, raise costs and lead to a far sharper global economic slowdown.
She said this would bring her full-year 2025 growth forecast closer to 1.6 per cent – assuming that the 10 per cent tariff on Singapore remains intact.
MTI figures show the construction sector expanded by 4.6 per cent, extending the 4.4 per cent growth in the previous quarter.

title: Apple was on brink of crisis before Trump tariff reprieve
summary:
– Apple has managed to dodge its biggest crisis since the Covid-19 pandemic – for the moment, at least.
On the night of April 11, Mr Trump handed Apple a major victory, exempting many popular consumer electronics.
That, Apple executives believed, would be a near-term solution to avoid the eye-watering China tariff and stave off hefty price hikes.
Another concern: If Apple moves even more production from China at a rapid pace, how would the country retaliate?
A complete split with China – Apple’s manufacturing hub for decades – would be unlikely.

title: New condo launch One Marina Gardens sells 38% of units amid cautious buyer sentiment
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxOne Marina Gardens is the first residential development in Marina South.
Kingsford Group acquired the Marina Gardens plot for $1.03 billion in a state tender in June 2023.
According to the PropNex sales team, the bulk of the units sold were one- and two-bedroom units.
Indicative prices at One Marina Gardens started from $1.16 million for the one-bedroom units, $1.8 million for the two-bedroom units, $2.45 million for a three-bedder, and $4.45 million for the four-bedroom units.
BT understands agents were offered a higher commission for the project than for One Marina Gardens.

title: Singapore may see pickup in IPOs, corporate deals despite dimmer outlook: Experts
summary:
SINGAPORE – Despite rising market volatility triggered by US President Donald Trump’s protectionist trade policies, some experts reckon that corporate deal-making opportunities will persist in Singapore as companies reconfigure their strategies and supply chains.
Mr Ong noted that the uncertainties arising from the tariffs may also impact ongoing privatisation deals on the SGX.
Investors have also turned cautious in Malaysia, which has been the top IPO market in South-east Asia since 2024.
Only three IPOs were issued by Singapore companies in the first quarter – Uni-Fuels Holdings, FBS Global and Basel Medical – all of which were launched on Nasdaq, while none took place on the SGX.
Prof Charoenwong explained that capital market activities such as IPOs and other corporate deals are key to encouraging early-stage investment and entrepreneurship.

title: MAS eases Singapore dollar policy to help economy weather Trump’s tariff storm
summary:
“MAS will continue with the policy of a modest and gradual appreciation of the S$ Neer (Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate) policy band.
The Singapore dollar edged up 0.2 per cent to 1.3165 per US dollar as at 1pm, after the MAS announcement, following the US currency’s biggest plunge since 2022 last week.
The US bank has slashed its 2025 GDP growth forecast for Singapore to 1.4 per cent, and for 2026, to 1.2 per cent.
Still, the Singapore dollar has gained 1.1 per cent versus the British pound year to date, and is up 2 per cent against the Malaysian ringgit.
A more extreme measure would be to recentre downwards the policy band within which the currency moves – effectively allowing the Singapore dollar to depreciate.

title: Demand for S’pore goods, services set to fall as global growth weakens
summary:
But I have no doubt that our growth will be significantly impacted,” he said during a ministerial statement delivered on April 8.
China, which retaliated with an 84 per cent tariff on US goods on April 9, was excluded from the pause.
Its latest duties on US imports came into effect on April 10, the same day the White House clarified that Mr Trump’s previously announced 125 per cent tariff against China is actually 145 per cent, after including a 20 per cent tariff on fentanyl.
PM Wong warned that outward-oriented sectors in Singapore – like manufacturing, wholesale trade and transport – will bear the brunt of the tariff impact.
MTI, which had originally projected GDP growth of 1 per cent to 3 per cent for 2025, is reassessing “and will likely revise it downwards”, PM Wong said.

title: How TikTok’s parent, ByteDance, became an AI powerhouse
summary:
ByteDance is also using the data as the linchpin of a growing business in artificial intelligence (AI).
Concern over how ByteDance uses data has driven lawmakers in Washington to try to force a sale of TikTok’s US operations.
“ByteDance has all this data, all the time, from millions of users,” said Ms Wei Sun, a principal analyst in AI.
Its chatbot, Doubao, gained 60 million users within its first three months on the market in 2024 .
While many Chinese companies have started AI projects, a much smaller number have the resources to invest in the personnel and computing power needed to advance the technology.

title: Apple India produced $29 billion of iPhones in shift from China
summary:
– Apple Inc assembled US$22 billion (S$29 billion) worth of iPhones in India in the 12 months ended March, increasing production by nearly 60 per cent over the previous year in a sign of continued diversification away from China.
Of the total India production, Apple exported 1.5 trillion rupees (S$22.9 billion) worth of iPhones from the region in the fiscal year through March 2025, the nation’s Technology Minister said on April 8.
Apple’s average India production and exports surged all through the fiscal year to March.
Apple will increasingly prioritise iPhones from the India supply chain for its US customers, Bloomberg reported previously.
Barring the exceptions made, Mr Trump’s cumulative levies on China remain at 145 per cent, and will likely force companies such as Apple to intensify their supply chain shift.

title: US stocks finish higher after rollercoaster week
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks finished solidly higher on April 11, concluding a rollercoaster week on a positive note amid hopes that the market has absorbed the worst headlines about trade conflicts.
US equities shrugged off early weakness after China announced 125 per cent tariffs on US goods in the latest tit-for-tat move between the two superpowers.
The Dow Jones Industrial average gained 1.6 per cent to 40,212.71, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.1 per cent to 16,724,46.
US equities this week have gyrated as markets digest President Trump’s shifting announcements on tariffs and the evolving stance of other parties, including the European Union, which unveiled and then paused countermeasures earlier in the week.
JPMorgan Chase surged 4 per cent following better than expected results, while BlackRock gained 2.3 per cent and Morgan Stanley rose 1.4 per cent.

title: US Fed officials see higher inflation ahead as consumer confidence plunges
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxA widely-referenced consumer confidence survey from the University of Michigan noted a sharp drop in consumer confidence.
WASHINGTON - Policymakers at the US Federal Reserve on April 11 warned of higher inflation and slower growth ahead due to Mr Donald Trump’s tariff policy, which has sent shock waves through global markets.
Shortly after Ms Collins’ interview, a widely-referenced consumer confidence survey from the University of Michigan noted a sharp drop in consumer confidence, and flagged a worrying rise in both short-term and longer-term inflation expectations.
“I would be wary of assuming the impact of high tariffs on inflation would be only brief or limited,” he said.
“I expect increased tariffs to boost inflation this year to somewhere between 3.5 and 4 per cent,” he added.

title: Singapore shares settle lower on April 11; STI down 1.8%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxLosers just outstripped gainers 257 to 241 on trade of 1.5 billion shares worth $1.9 billion.
SINGAPORE – The giddy mood that supercharged markets on April 10 deflated on April 11 and pushed shares back into the red to end a traumatic week for investors here and elsewhere.
Across the broader market, losers just outstripped gainers 257 to 241 on trade of 1.5 billion shares worth $1.9 billion.
The Dow Industrials fell 2.5 per cent while the S&P 500 declined 3.5 per cent, and the Nasdaq slid 4.3 per cent.
The Kospi decreased 0.5 per cent, the Nikkei 225 shed 3 per cent and Malaysian shares declined 0.6 per cent, but Hong Kong’s Hang Seng added 1.1 per cent.

title: Singapore gets lion’s share of S-E Asia private equity in 2024, but tariff risks loom
summary:
The Republic secured US$7.6 billion (S$10 billion) of capital investment in companies that are not publicly traded, nearly half of the US$16 billion (S$21.1 billion) raised across South-east Asia, said global management consultancy Bain & Company in its South-east Asia Private Equity Report 2024.
“Our report shows that investors in South-east Asia are concerned about exit difficulties, fund-raising challenges and the availability of quality deals,” said Mr Usman Akhtar, head of Bain’s South-east Asia PE practice, who is based in Singapore.
The financial services sector, especially fintech, attracted more investor attention in 2024, with growth in South-east Asia outpacing the broader Asia-Pacific region.
Bain also highlighted that private education remains underdeveloped in South-east Asia, though structural trends point to significant growth potential.
Deloitte’s report, titled South-east Asia Edition Of The PE 2025 Almanac, also noted that Singapore is poised to maintain its dominance in South-east Asia’s mergers and acquisitions market.

title: Trump tariff nightmare continues to plague markets as US dollar plunges on trade war, recession fears
summary:
A midweek respite after US President Donald Trump announced a 90-day timeout on his tariff barrage failed to last.
Also, the pause does not address the elephant in the room – the US-China tit-for-tat trade war that now seems to be feeding on itself.
Both the US and China are key sources of trade and investments for Singapore and most Asian economies.
Around the world, markets were flashing red as steep sell-offs hit US assets – stocks, dollar and bonds – on recession fears.
At this level, the Singapore dollar has gained 3.1 per cent to date this year.

title: Google lays off hundreds of employees in Android, Pixel Group: Report
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe cuts follow the company’s January buyout offers to employees in the unit, the report said.
Bengaluru - Alphabet’s Google on April 10 laid off hundreds of employees in its platforms and devices unit, which works on the Android software, Pixel phones and the Chrome browser, The Information reported on April 11, citing a person with direct knowledge of the situation.
The cuts follow the company’s January buyout offers to employees in the unit, the report said.
Bloomberg in February reported that Google had cut employees in its cloud division , adding that the round of cuts impacted only a few teams.
In January 2023, Alphabet had announced plans to cut 12,000 jobs, or 6 per cent of its global workforce.

title: TikTok drives ByteDance’s 29% revenue growth while China business slows
summary:
– ByteDance’s revenue jumped 29 per cent to US$155 billion (S$208 billion) in 2024, after online video phenomenon TikTok drove a worldwide expansion that helped offset an economic downturn back home in China.
TikTok’s sizzling pace of growth has come into focus since Washington mandated that the social video platform find a buyer or exit its biggest market.
At home, its flagship video platform Douyin is grappling with belt-tightening across the world’s second-largest economy.
One of ByteDance’s biggest challenges in 2025 remains securing a US deal that appeases both Washington and Beijing.
Some of ByteDance’s biggest investors value the firm at over US$400 billion on their books, while the firm plans to buy back employee shares at a US$312 billion valuation.

title: Rich Indonesians wary of Prabowo’s policies send wealth overseas
summary:
– Wealthy Indonesians are shifting hundreds of millions of dollars offshore amid mounting concerns over President Prabowo Subianto’s fiscal discipline and the country’s economic stability.
The assets all offer ways for the country’s rich to skirt scrutiny in moving large sums of money around.
The shift began in October 2024 when Mr Prabowo came to power, but accelerated substantially after the rupiah plunged in March , the person said.
The outflows from South-east Asia’s biggest economy may have contributed to the steep decline in Indonesia’s currency.
While the rupiah and stock market sell-off may be an overreaction, “both foreign and local investors share growing concerns about Prabowo’s policies”, Mr Dinarto said.

title: Novartis pledges $30.5 billion US investment as pharmaceutical tariffs loom
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxNovartis says its spending on US operations over the next five years is expected to be nearly US$50 billion, a “clear demonstration” of its focus on America.
Spending on US operations over the next five years is expected to be nearly US$50 billion, the company said, a “clear demonstration” of its focus on America.
Eli Lilly said in February it will spend at least US$27 billion on four US plants within the next five years.
In March, Merck promised to invest US$8 billion domestically by 2028, while Johnson & Johnson pledged more than US$55 billion over the next four years.
In 2024, Novartis announced the construction of two new US manufacturing facilities for radioligand therapies for cancer, according to a company report.

title: Airwallex sees jump in Singapore revenue as more SMEs eye overseas expansion
summary:
The study was done between January and March, and involved 250 Singapore SMEs with 50 to 500 employees.
Now headquartered in Singapore, Airwallex provides SMEs with a single platform to manage their global financial operations, covering everything from multi-currency accounts and international transfers to corporate cards, expense management and online payments.
Mr Ershad said Airwallex can help businesses reduce cross-border transaction costs by offering access to interbank foreign exchange rates with low, transparent margins, among other things.
Airwallex reported a 153 per cent year-on-year jump in revenue in Singapore for 2024, fuelled by robust transaction volumes, which rose 159 per cent from a year ago.
Besides transfers, customers are also tapping the firm’s broader suite of products, which include spend management, treasury, and card issuance.

title: Gold surges past US$3,200 for first time as recession anxiety mounts
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBullion gained as much as 1.3 per cent in early Asian trading on April 11.
– Gold jumped to a fresh record above US$3,200 an ounce as concerns about the impact of US tariffs on the global economy pushed investors to the safe haven.
Spot gold jumped over 1 per cent to US$3,214.92 an ounce, as at 4.01pm in Singapore, after hitting a record high of US$3,219.84 earlier in the session.
“We remain quite positive for gold,” Mr Dominic Schnider, head of commodities and Asia-Pacific currencies at UBS Global Wealth Management, said on Bloomberg Television.
“The next step is going to be, at some point, the Fed coming in – and that gives the next leg-up for gold.” BLOOMBERG, REUTERS

title: Chinese tea chain Chagee launches US IPO amid market slump
summary:
– Chagee Holdings, a Chinese tea chain, is seeking to raise US$411 million (S$551 million) in an initial public offering (IPO) in the US, despite spiking stock volatility from US President Donald Trump’s tariff measures.
At the top of the price range, Chagee would have a market value of about US$3.3 billion based on the outstanding shares listed in the filing.
The launch comes as a number of firms have paused planned US listings amid the market turmoil, Bloomberg News has reported.
Along with Chagee, Airo Group Holdings also launched an IPO on April 10.
Chagee is proceeding with an IPO amid an escalating trade war between the US and China, with both sides imposing steep levies on each other’s goods.

title: US dollar sees biggest plunge since 2022 as stock markets skid on tariff war fears; STI down 2.1%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe US dollar extended losses after the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 1.5 per cent overnight, its biggest tumble since 2022.
TOKYO – Asian stock markets fell on April 11 as an escalating trade war between the world’s two biggest economies saw frantic sell-offs hit US assets on growing recession fears.
Singapore stocks were not spared with the Straits Times Index down 2.1 per cent at midday, after dropping 3.1 per cent soon after trading began.
The US dollar extended losses after the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 1.5 per cent overnight, its biggest plunge in three years.
The US dollar also weakened against the Singapore dollar, trading down 0.3 per cent to 1.3265 as at 12.13pm Singapore time.

title: US risky debt sees record outflows on investor fears for tariff-hit economy
summary:
– US leveraged loan funds had their biggest-ever weekly outflow as investors dumped corporate debt across the board on concern that the tariff-spurred market turmoil will hit the US economy.
Leveraged loans are ones that lenders extend to companies that already have considerable amounts of debt or a poor credit history.
Lenders consider leveraged loans as carrying a higher risk of default and, as a result, a leveraged loan is more costly to the borrower.
As a result, leveraged loans have become one of the worst-performing credit asset classes.
The exodus is exacerbated by the floating-rate nature of leveraged loans.

title: MAS expected to ease Singdollar policy on April 14 as Trump tariffs risk growth: Survey
summary:
While the US dollar gained against many Asian currencies in the wake of Mr Trump’s election victory in November 2024, the picture has become more nuanced in the past month.
Another option in the MAS’ toolkit is to re-centre its policy band downwards, effectively allowing the currency to depreciate.
Barclays is among those that see a small probability of the MAS reducing the slope as well as re-centring its policy band downwards.
That assessment preceded Mr Trump’s announcement of a 90-day pause on higher tariffs, while raising duties on China to 145 per cent.
MAS eased its Singdollar policy in January for the first time in five years, and the case to support the economy has become even stronger following Mr Trump’s tariffs and the ensuing global market ructions.

title: Big US companies went bankrupt at fastest pace since 2010, S&P says
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxCompanies that sought court protection in March include the owner of Forever 21’s US retail operator.
NEW YORK – Large US companies filed bankruptcy at the fastest rate in 15 years in the first three months of 2025, S&P Global Market Intelligence said on April 10.
A total of 188 bankruptcies were filed by large companies in the period to March, the most since 254 such filings were made over the first three months of 2010, S&P said in a report.
Companies that sought court protection in March include the owner of Forever 21’s US retail operator, Canada’s Mitel Networks and film producer Village Roadshow Entertainment Group.
The number of companies filing repeat bankruptcies in 2023 and 2024 was the most over a two-year span since 2020, Bloomberg News previously reported.

title: Making money out of a disaster: Fake news in Myanmar quake
summary:
“People just have to assume there’s a lot of false information that circulates.
They should be aware there are people making money off of false information,” said Mr Darrell West, a senior technology researcher at the Brookings Institution think-tank.
Misinformation and disinformation are common on social media following catastrophes, digital experts say, be it miscaptioned images, fake videos or false narratives about rescue efforts.
“In the current context in Myanmar, a vast volume of the disinformation you’re seeing circulate is financially motivated,” Ms Rio said.
And those people are particularly vulnerable to misinformation because they are desperately looking for information,” Ms Rio said.

title: Wall St ends sharply lower as tariff risks send investors fleeing
summary:
LONDON - Wall Street stocks tumbled on April 10 on mounting worries over the economic impact of US President Donald Trump’s multi-front tariff war.
After Mr Trump announced a 90-day tariff reprieve on April 9, the S&P 500 surged 9.5 per cent, the largest one-day percentage jump since October 2008.
The S&P 500 lost 188.85 points, or 3.46 per cent, at 5,268.05 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 737.66 points, or 4.31 per cent, to 16,387.31.
Among the 11 major sectors in the S&P 500, all but consumer staples ended in negative territory, with energy and tech suffering the largest percentage drops.
The S&P 500 posted no new 52-week highs and nine new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 13 new highs and 166 new lows.

title: US inflation unexpectedly cools ahead of tariffs impact
summary:
– Underlying US inflation cooled broadly in March, indicating some relief for consumers before widespread tariffs that risk contributing to price pressures.
Compared with March 2024 , the core CPI rose 2 per cent, remaining the tamest in nearly four years.
Some of the higher import costs will ultimately be passed on to consumers, and companies from Target to Volkswagen have warned that higher prices are in store for Americans.
The uncertainty is keeping Federal Reserve officials in wait-and-see mode as they look for more clarity on the impact the tariffs will have on inflation – and the economy more broadly.
Shelter prices rose at a moderate pace, reflecting the steepest drop in hotel stays in more than three years.

title: Singapore shares rebound on April 10, mirroring regional indexes; STI up 5.4%
summary:
News that the on-again, off-again tariffs are now in a 90-day holding pattern fired up relieved investors, who sent the Straits Times Index (STI) rocketing 5.4 per cent or 184.14 points to 3,577.83.
Across the broader market, gainers unsurprisingly thumped losers 474 to 153 on a bumper trade of 2.1 billion shares worth $3 billion.
As impressive as those gains were, the STI’s biggest winner was Jardine Matheson, up 8.7 per cent to US$39.87.
Mapletree PanAsia Commercial Trust was the only STI constituent that did not register gains, closing flat at $1.13.
Wall Street provided the fuel for the regional rebound, with the three key indexes recording stellar performances overnight.

title: TSMC sales beat estimates as AI demand soars ahead of US tariffs
summary:
– Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co’s (TSMC) quarterly revenue rose by larger than anticipated at 42 per cent, reflecting strengthening demand for AI servers and smartphones before US tariffs kicked in.
The main chipmaker for Apple and Nvidia reported revenue of NT$839.25 billion (S$34.2 billion) in the first three months of 2025.
Its results coincide with growing concerns about how tariffs may disrupt demand for electronics such as iPhones.
More broadly, there are signs that the pace of spending on data centres and artificial intelligence (AI) chips may be slowing somewhat.
Amazon.com alone is aiming to spend US$100 billion on AI in 2025.

title: Keppel considering sale of Singapore waste firm 800 Super, sources say
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxA deal could value the waste management firm at as much as $600 million, sources said.
SINGAPORE - Keppel is considering selling its stake in 800 Super Holdings in a transaction that could value the waste management firm at as much as $600 million, people familiar with the matter said.
Keppel bought 80 per cent of 800 Super through its infrastructure unit in 2022 in a deal valuing the then Catalist-listed company at about $380 million at the time.
A representative for 800 Super did not respond to a request for comment.
800 Super provides waste management, waste treatment, cleaning and landscaping services to the public and private sectors, its website shows.

title: G’day Australia, Hei Norway: Where to spend your Singdollar amid Trump’s tariff drama

SINGAPORE - US President Donald Trump’s tariff policies have sparked fears over trade disruptions, but for travel-hungry Singaporeans, there may be a silver lining.
Here is a look at where your Singdollar now stretches further, and where it, unfortunately, does not.
Some Singaporeans have already taken advantage of the favourable exchange rates ahead of the upcoming long weekends and June school holiday travel period, said Mr Kelvin Lam, chief operating officer of multi-currency mobile wallet YouTrip.
Japan is also less exposed to trade than Singapore, he added, so the yen may still trend upwards against the Singdollar.

title: US CEOs brace themselves for recession even after Trump tariff reprieve boosts stocks
summary:

But the chaos sown by his trade war means corporate America is planning for a recession.
Mr Jamie Dimon, the JPMorgan Chase & Co chief executive officer, said on April 9 that defaults will rise as the economy worsens.
Reminded that in March he had said he did not think the US was headed into a recession, Mr Bastian conceded to an interviewer on CNBC that things had changed.
The benchmark US gauge had been headed to a bear market, approaching a 20 per cent decline from its peak.

title: ST Engineering bags $1.4b contract for Taiwan’s Taichung MRT Blue line
summary:
SINGAPORE - ST Engineering announced on April 10 that its urban solutions business secured a $1.4 billion contract to provide turnkey rail services for Taiwan’s new Taichung mass rapid transit Blue line.
ST Engineering Urban Solutions will lead the overall project management and systems integration, and provide rail electronics including a communications system and automatic fare collection system, while overseeing the above-ground train depot development.
Its urban solutions subsidiary has been delivering rail electronics solutions for the Taichung MRT Green line and providing full turnkey rail services for projects in several other Taiwanese cities.
ST Engineering posted $11.3 billion in revenue and $702.3 million in net profit for the financial year 2024, with its order book coming in at $28.5 billion.
Shares of ST Engineering closed 5.1 per cent, or 32 cents, higher at $6.62 on April 10, among the biggest gainers in a Singapore market rebound.

title: Here are the biggest gainers among Singapore stocks after Trump’s tariff timeout
summary:
The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 8.2 per cent as soon as trading opened, taking its cue from the S&P 500, which closed up 9.5 per cent overnight in New York.
The Dow index ended 7.9 per cent higher, while the Nasdaq rose 12.2 per cent to notch its best day in 24 years.
Interest rate cuts reduce banks’ net interest margins and put pressure on their net interest income.
Baseline tariffs of 10 per cent on Singapore goods being imported to the US had kicked in on April 5.
Yangzijiang ShipbuildingThe China-based shipbuilder rose 8 per cent to $2.02, despite the escalating tit-for-tat tariff war between the US and China.

title: Singapore stock index up 5.5% at midday as Asia markets stage relief rally on Trump tariff pause
summary:
- Asian stock markets rebounded strongly on April 10 as investors picked up battered stocks after US President Donald Trump announced a 90-day pause on global tariffs announced last week for every country except China.
Overnight, the Trump pause sent US stocks soaring, with the S&P 500 closing up 9.5 per cent.
While Mr Trump’s announcement still left investors with uncertainty about his ultimate tariff policy, traders took the opportunity to shop for beaten-down stocks.
Since Mr Trump announced broad tariffs late on April 2, US stocks had fallen more than 12 per cent for their biggest four-day sell-off in five years.
Yet, the uncertainty for companies remains.”After Mr Trump’s reversal, Goldman Sachs said it was rescinding its recession forecast and reverting to its previous baseline estimate for the economy to grow in 2025.

title: Nike’s 30-year gamble on Vietnam rattled by Trump tariffs

The central bank has kept the benchmark rate at 3 per cent since May 2023 after a year-long tightening cycle.
Mr Abdul Rasheed said it expects continued ringgit volatility and that it is ready to curb any excessive fluctuation.

Investor concerns sent the Straits Times Index (STI) sliding 2.2 per cent, or 75.78 points, to 3,393.69 with losers outstripping gainers 414 to 203 on trade of two billion shares worth $2.9 billion.
DBS Bank slid 2.2 per cent to $37.16, OCBC Bank dived 2.6 per cent $14.42, while UOB plunged 3.6 per cent to $30.99.

title: NZ central bank cuts cash rate to spur growth, counter tariff risks
summary:

– New Zealand’s central bank cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 3.5 per cent on April 9, as policymakers sought to revive a struggling economy and counter risks from trade tariffs.
The decision is in line with a Reuters poll where all 31 economists surveyed forecast the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) would cut the cash rate for the fifth successive meeting.
This is a monetary policy review, and the central bank is not due to release updated economic forecasts until it meets in May.
“On balance, these developments create downside risks to the outlook for economic activity and inflation in New Zealand,” it said.

title: Boeing deliveries in March soar by 41% compared to year earlier
summary:

Through the first three months of the year, Boeing delivered 130 jets, including 104 of its best-selling 737 MAX.
That is up from just 83 jet deliveries, including 66 MAXs, during the first quarter of 2024.
Boeing’s production and deliveries have been hampered in the last year by a labour strike , regulatory scrutiny and supply chain bottlenecks.
Years of crises and production problems have left Boeing heavily saddled with debt, and it needs to increase deliveries to bring in more cash.

India is aiming to produce five million tonnes of green hydrogen per annum by 2030, a process that will require 125GW of renewable energy.

The company’s monthly contracted sales dropped 25.3 per cent from a year earlier to 3.2 billion yuan (S$590 million), Bloomberg calculations based on corporate filings show.

title: Singapore steps up efforts to become Asia’s restructuring hub
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe proposed changes to Singapore's insolvency law are aimed at enhancing its appeal as a hub for corporate restructuring in Asia.
Singapore – Singapore’s policymakers are wrapping up the public feedback process on proposed changes to its insolvency law, part of a broader effort to enhance its appeal as a hub for corporate restructuring in Asia.
A key change would broaden a provision in restructuring plans, known as cross-class cramdowns, to prevent shareholders from dissenting, according to a Ministry of Law report.
In 2016, Singapore went through a similar exercise to update its insolvency law, adopting a set of committee recommendations.
The structure for fees paid to judicial managers – who take over management of debtor companies during restructuring – also may change, as the report recommends adding “success fees”.

title: German exports up in February ahead of tariffs as industrial production falls
summary:
GDANSK/BERLIN – German exports rose more than expected in February as US demand increased in anticipation of tariffs by the Trump administration, but industrial production fell, showing the struggles of manufacturing in Europe’s biggest economy.
Most German exports went to the United States, up 8.5 per cent compared with January, as demand increased in anticipation of the tariffs.
German industrial production remains about 10 per cent below its pre-pandemic levels, some five years after the onset of Covid-19.
German industrial orders stagnated in February, data showed on April 4, showing that demand remains weak.
Higher defence and infrastructure spending are still months away, so it looks likely that German industrial production will contract again in the coming months, said Capital Economics senior Europe economist Franziska Palmas.

title: UOB and OCBC to cut interest rates on flagship savings accounts from May 1
summary:
SINGAPORE – Interest rates on more savings accounts are coming down in Singapore, with two of the three local banks – UOB and OCBC Bank – reducing rates on their flagship accounts, the UOB One and OCBC 360, from May 1.
A flagship savings account is a bank’s best savings product, which offers bonus interest rates that go up as customers transact more with the bank.
UOB is the only local bank to have previously cut its savings rates for its flagship account.
A spokesperson for UOB said the rate revisions reflect “longer-term interest rate expectations”.
Meanwhile, Maybank – which does not offer a flagship savings account – has kept the rates on its suite of savings products unchanged.

title: US automakers lobby to exclude low-cost parts from tariffs

Mr Trump on March 31 declined to say whether the administration is considering exempting some car parts from the tariffs.
He said he had already given automakers “a break” by pushing off tariffs for a month.
They contend that combined levies would send car prices soaring and depress demand from US consumers, who are already confronting average prices approaching US$50,000 (S$67,000).

“I think (traders) were taking advantage of an oversold situation,” CFRA’s Mr Sam Stovall told AFP.

title: Golden visa revamp tempts wealthy to eye New Zealand as haven
summary:
– New Zealand is seeing “red-hot” interest in its revamped golden visa programme from the US and Europe as rising geopolitical tensions prompt wealthy people to consider options abroad, Immigration Minister Erica Stanford said.
“I’m expecting that in the first month we’ll get a lot of applications,” Ms Stanford told Bloomberg News in a telephone interview.
“More than anything, it’s actually the geopolitical situation that has driven people to think we need somewhere else to live,” Ms Stanford said.
While formal application data will not be available for some months, Ms Stanford said immigration agents, lawyers and international advisers report soaring inquiries.
Ms Stanford acknowledged it is a key issue for would-be investors, and said talks about changing it are happening “at a leader-to-leader level” in the coalition government.

The loss attributable to shareholders stood at 32.8 billion yuan (S$6.1 billion), compared with a record 178 billion yuan loss in 2023, according to an exchange filing on March 31.
The annual reading indicated a 20 billion yuan loss in the second half of 2024, widening from the 12.8 billion yuan loss in the first half.

title: UOB, DBS and OCBC operations in Myanmar and Thailand see no major disruption from quake

A UOB spokesperson told The Straits Times that all its Thailand employees were accounted for when the earthquake happened.
Its spokesperson added that critical operations – including wholesale settlements, cheque clearing, foreign exchange transactions and regulatory reporting – were completed.
UOB’s contact centres also resumed operations on the morning of March 29, while both its primary and secondary data centres remained fully operational.
All of the group’s hospitality properties and malls, including One Bangkok, have resumed operations, the Frasers Property spokesperson had said.

title: Temasek, GIC said to be buying stake in clinical tester Novotech at $2.5 billion valuation
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTPG would remain the controlling shareholder of Novotech after the deal by Temasek and GIC.
– Singapore’s Temasek and sovereign wealth fund GIC will acquire a significant stake in Novotech to fuel growth and accelerate acquisitions for the clinical research and testing provider, valuing the company at more than A$3 billion (S$2.5 billion), people familiar with the matter said.
Existing backer TPG will also reinvest through its Asia VIII US$5.3 billion fund, Novotech said in a statement, confirming an earlier Bloomberg News report.
The deal will help TPG make a full exit from its previous investment in 2017 in Asia VI.
Spokespeople for TPG, Temasek and GIC declined to comment on the financial details of the transaction.

title: China manufacturing activity hits 12-month high ahead of escalating tariffs
summary:
