2 economy, which is also benefiting from foreign buyers front loading purchases in anticipation of further US trade curbs.
However, that relief is expected to be short-lived with US President Donald Trump set to announce new “reciprocal” tariffs on April 2 to tackle perceived trade imbalances, potentially adding more levies on Chinese goods.
“We doubt the rest of the year will be much better,” said Mr Evans-Pritchard of Capital Economics.
But US tariffs, which look set to escalate this week, will start to weigh on exports before long.” REUTERS

title: Asia stocks sink after Trump says reciprocal tariffs will hit ‘all countries’
summary:
“A range of Asian countries will face the challenge of reciprocal tariffs, with Vietnam and Thailand among the most vulnerable,” said DBS Bank senior economist Ma Tieying.
South Korea was most vulnerable to automobile tariffs, Ms Ma said, adding that Malaysia and Singapore were susceptible to semiconductor and pharmaceutical tariffs respectively.
Money managers around the world are derisking their portfolios or refraining from taking big positions as they remain wary about the announcement of the so-called reciprocal tariffs and the impact on the economy.
Most South-east Asian currencies crept higher against the US dollar as a safety flight to US Treasuries pressured the greenback.
“We expect an overall depreciation of Asian currencies against the dollar in Q2,” analysts at MUFG wrote.

title: Asia braces itself for historic test of export model from Trump’s reciprocal tariffs
summary:
Reciprocal tariffs, in addition to those already announced in 2025, could shave as much as 1.3 percentage points off economic growth in countries across Asia, according to Goldman Sachs economists.
Along with Mexico, Canada and the European Union, Asia has been squarely in the sights of Mr Trump’s protectionist push since his Jan 20 return to the White House.
Beijing’s recent pro-business pivot and optimism over advances in artificial intelligence have spurred a rally in Chinese stocks even as Mr Trump’s trade threats have magnified.
‘Squeeze, not choke’There are tentative signs that Mr Trump’s pressure may spur a deepening of commercial links within Asia.
Japan and China held their first economic dialogue in six years in Tokyo on March 22, although prospects for a coordinated response to Mr Trump’s tariffs remain a long way off.

title: US employers cool hiring in March as tariff fallout threatens economy: Poll
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWith consumer spending and confidence sliding, any notable weakening in job growth will raise additional concerns about the US economy’s prospects.
– US employers probably tempered their hiring in March, just as consumers grew increasingly cautious and the economic outlook dimmed on concerns about the fallout from higher tariffs.
This would leave average job growth over the past three months at the slowest pace since October 2024.
The latest report card on the labour market follows data that indicates a notable first-quarter slowing in the economy.
Other Fed governors, including Dr Adriana Kugler, Dr Philip Jefferson, Dr Lisa Cook and Mr Michael Barr, are also due to speak in the coming week.

title: Gold crosses US$3,100 for first time as expected US tariff barrage boosts safe havens
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe gold rally has been fuelled by central bank buying and demand for safe havens amid rising geopolitical and macro uncertainties.
Canberra – Gold started the week with a fresh record high, ahead of US President Donald Trump’s expected latest tariff barrage that has heightened concerns of a global trade war.
He has already imposed tariffs on aluminum, steel and autos, along with increased tariffs on all goods from China.
The rally has been fuelled by central bank buying and haven demand amid rising geopolitical and macro uncertainties.
The lender cited higher-than-expected central bank demand and strong inflows into bullion-backed exchange traded funds.

title: Temasek’s 65 Equity makes Europe foray with Swiss pharma merger
summary:
– Asset manager 65 Equity Partners is backing Swiss pharmaceutical ingredient maker Healthcare Advanced Synthesis’ (HAS) acquisition of Cerbios-Pharma, marking its first deal in Europe.
The deal values the combined company at about US$380 million (S$510 million), according to people familiar with the matter.
Partners Group Holding bought a stake in British pharmaceutical manufacturing services provider Sterling Pharma Solutions in 2023.
65 Equity plans on integrating HAS and Cerbios before pursuing other acquisitions in the broader CDMO space, Mr Heberling said.
It manages about US$3.3 billion and typically writes cheques of US$50 million to US$150 million to back family-owned and founder-led companies.

title: askST Jobs: Dealing with loss from leaving well-loved colleagues
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxIt is natural to grieve over leaving a team you are bonded with.
How can I deal with the sense of loss I feel from leaving a team I am fond of?
A: It is natural to grieve over leaving a team you are bonded with, says organisational psychologist Brandon Koh.
Workers can also remind themselves of the personal and professional goals and values that motivated the change despite feeling bonded with the team they are leaving.
“Just because we do not meet daily in a work context does not mean we cannot hang out outside of work,” Ms Petrov notes.

title: S’pore takes lead in training maritime professionals to handle greener but hazardous fuels
summary:
It will also reduce the administrative burden on maritime companies and make training easily accessible by enabling group enrolments and streamlining payments.
Ms Vishakha Lall, lead research engineer of the Centre of Excellence in Maritime Safety, said the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in maritime training can help reduce the challenges faced by trainers in evaluating candidates.
“We have worked and implemented solutions for at least two bunkering and shipping companies for two years,” she said.
Under the enhanced Tripartite Maritime Training Award, the training duration for mid-career individuals will be reduced from 31 to 22 months through a more streamlined curriculum that strengthens core maritime competencies, said MPA in a statement on March 28.
Internal mobility increased by 21 per cent in 2024 in Singapore, and by 18 per cent for the local maritime industry.

title: DFI Retail shares pop on news of Giant, Cold Storage sale; stock helps drive STI to record high
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDFI Retail Group will sell Giant and Cold Storage in Singapore to Malaysian retail group Macrovalue.
SINGAPORE – Shares in DFI Retail Group rose after it announced on March 24 that Giant and Cold Storage in Singapore would be sold to Malaysian retail group Macrovalue .
Shares in DFI, which is a component stock on Singapore’s Straits Times Index (STI), closed the week at US$2.39, up by more than 6 per cent.
STI surpasses 4,000 markDFI’s jump helped the benchmark STI hit a record high during the week.
The treasury shares were originally repurchased under a $200 million share buyback programme at an average cost of 34 cents per share.

title: askST Jobs: Dealing with loss from leaving well-loved colleagues
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxIt is natural to grieve over leaving a team you are bonded with.
How can I deal with the sense of loss I feel from leaving a team I am fond of?
A: It is natural to grieve over leaving a team you are bonded with, says organisational psychologist Brandon Koh.
Workers can also remind themselves of the personal and professional goals and values that motivated the change despite feeling bonded with the team they are leaving.
“Just because we do not meet daily in a work context does not mean we cannot hang out outside of work,” Ms Petrov notes.

title: Singapore firms in Myanmar and Thailand confirm staff are safe, little or no damage to facilities
summary:
When contacted, Singapore Exchange-listed Yoma Strategic Holdings and Fraser & Neave (F&N) told The Straits Times that all staff are safe, and their facilities and businesses in Myanmar and Thailand had little or no damage.
Some properties related to our core business operations also sustained minor damage,” a spokesperson for Yoma Strategic said.
A spokesperson for F&N said the company has been in contact with its teams and that all its staff in Myanmar and Thailand are safe.
“Our plant in Myanmar has sustained little or no damage, while our facilities in Thailand remain unaffected,” the spokesperson added.
In Myanmar, F&N distributes its 100Plus sports drinks and bottles Chang Beer.

title: Sembcorp Industries’ Mandalay power plant loses power after March 28 earthquake
summary:
SINGAPORE – A power plant in Myanmar built and operated by Singapore’s Sembcorp Industries has experienced a power trip because of grid failure following an earthquake that hit the country on March 28.
When contacted, a Sembcorp spokesperson told The Straits Times that despite losing power, the US$300 million (S$402.7 million) gas-fired power plant in Mandalay has not been damaged.
“As a result of the earthquake that struck central Myanmar, Sembcorp Myingyan Independent Power Plant experienced a trip due to a grid failure,” the spokesperson said.
The 225MW power plant was completed and began supplying power to the Myanmar government in 2018.
Under the agreement, Sembcorp Myingyan Power Company will build and operate the power plant for 22 years, after which the facility will be transferred to the Myanmar government.

title: Frasers Property ‘closely monitoring’ aftermath of Myanmar quake
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxFrasers Property said all the group’s hospitality properties and malls, including One Bangkok, have resumed operations.
In response to queries from The Business Times, a spokesperson for Frasers Property said all the group’s hospitality properties and malls, including One Bangkok, have resumed operations.
Frasers said it had confirmed that all Frasers Property employees in Bangkok are safe.
The group’s Frasers Hospitality arm manages three serviced residences in Bangkok – Fraser Suites Sukhumvit, Modena by Fraser Bangkok and North Park Place.
In addition, it has an effective interest of 59.6 per cent in Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company Limited, which develops and manages a diversified portfolio of assets.

title: Musk’s xAI start-up swallows up X social network in surprise deal
summary:
The deal streamlines Mr Elon Musk's businesses and solidifies the relationship between the former Twitter and xAI.
“The combination values xAI at US$80 billion and X at US$33 billion,” the billionaire wrote on March 28 in a post on X.
For Mr Musk, the deal streamlines his businesses and solidifies the relationship between the former Twitter and xAI, which has used information from the social network to hone its chatbot.
The start-up is competing with AI companies such as OpenAI, which Mr Musk co-founded before an acrimonious split.
Mr Musk has a long history of blending his various operations by sharing investors, technology and employees.

title: Companies practising steward leadership called to step forward
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSPH Media Trust director Patrick Daniel speaking at the dinner unveiling the Steward Leadership 25 list at Pan Pacific Hotel on Oct 23, 2024.
Steward Leadership 25 (SL25), which is in its fourth edition in 2025, is open to for-profit entities across all sectors.
The award will be given to 25 of the best projects of steward leadership excellence.
Steward leadership – characterised by a deep-seated commitment to fostering a collective better future for stakeholders, society, future generations and the environment – is not merely a noble pursuit but a strategic business imperative, said SAC.
“It seeks to establish an optimal approach to growth and achieving prosperity that benefits employees, shareholders and society,” the centre added.

title: Me & My Money: Former govt scholar invests in healthcare business to provide better patient service
summary:
Mr Chim, 38, is driven by his experiences when he was growing up.
Mr Chim was just 25 then and doing his national service.
Entrepreneur Andrew Chim started the I-Health clinics because he was looking for a high level of healthcare that focuses on service quality and good communications.
“I’m very afraid of being broke, because I know what that feels like – that’s the feeling that drives me,” said Mr Chim.
It was the same after I entered the working world – I don’t spend money even when I have it.

title: US stocks plunge on tariff fears, inflation data
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 28, in New York City.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled 1.7 per cent to 41,583.90, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index lost 2 per cent at 5,580.94.
“That could lead to a global recession or a global economic slowdown, and that could hurt profits,” he said.
The stock market stumble also came as investors digested inflation data released earlier on March 28.
From a year ago, the PCE price index, a preferred inflation gauge of the Federal Reserve, was up 2.8 per cent.

title: Singapore fintech firms developing AI-powered solutions see rise in funding
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Singapore FinTech Association said most fintech firms across various sectors integrate AI into their systems.
AI-powered fintech investments in Singapore jumped to US$160 million in the second half of 2024, from US$24 million in the first half, data from professional services firm KPMG on Feb 26 showed.
KPMG data also showed that Singapore’s fintech funding has been on a downward trend since 2023, amid a global downturn in fintech investments as investors focus on companies with a clear and achievable path to profitability.
The Singapore FinTech Association (SFA), which facilitates collaboration between market participants and stakeholders in the fintech ecosystem, said most fintech firms across various sectors integrate AI into their systems.
But Mr Ruddenklau said that while there is a lot of interest in AI, generative AI, agentic AI and automation, there is a lot of caution, too.

title: Piyush Gupta steps down as CEO of DBS at his final AGM with the bank
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox(From left) Former DBS CEO Piyush Gupta, chairman Peter Seah, and new CEO Tan Su Shan.
SINGAPORE - Mr Piyush Gupta has officially stepped down as DBS Bank chief executive and passed the baton to Ms Tan Su Shan.
Ms Tan, who is the first female CEO in DBS’ history and was previously the bank’s deputy CEO, is expected to continue DBS’ focus on high return on equity businesses and global growth.
Mr Gupta, who is 65 and a Singapore citizen, is stepping down from a high point in the bank’s history.
Mr Gupta noted that higher fee income helped to offset the decline in interest income as interest rates fell during the year.

title: Port operator PSA reports 25% drop in 2024 net profit despite moving more containers
summary:
SINGAPORE – Earnings at PSA International plunged in 2024 despite the firm moving record numbers of containers at its ports in Singapore and overseas.
PSA reported in January that it handled 100.2 million twenty-foot containers, or twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs), at its port terminals in 2024, up 5.6 per cent on 2023.
It was the first time PSA had moved more than 100 million TEUs in a single year.
The facility will complement the new Tuas Port, which will be the world’s largest automated terminal when fully complete in the 2040s.
PSA announced in February that Tuas Port has handled 10 million TEUs since operations began in September 2022.

title: Li Ka-shing’s CK Hutchison will not sign deal to sell strategic Panama ports next week: SCMP
summary:
HONG KONG - Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing’s CK Hutchison will not sign a deal next week to sell its two port operations near the Panama Canal to a BlackRock-led group amid growing pressure from Beijing, the South China Morning Post reported on March 28, citing a source close to the company.
The deal was expected to be signed on April 2, according to the sale announcement made on March 4.
It is understood the situation does not mean the deal has been called off, the South China Morning Post added, citing the source.
A CK Hutchison unit operates two of the five ports adjacent to the Panama Canal, which manages about 3 per cent of the global sea-borne trade.
The telecoms-to-retail conglomerate has been caught in China’s crosshairs in the highly politicised deal with a BlackRock consortium, which includes selling assets near the strategically important Panama Canal.

title: Singapore’s STI crosses 4,000 mark for the first time before closing 0.2% down
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe STI hit 4,005.18 shortly after the session opened, surpassing the record high of 3,991 points clocked the day before.
SINGAPORE – It was a red-letter day – at least initially – for local shares on March 28 when the Straits Times Index (STI) crossed the 4,000-point mark for the first time.
The STI hit 4,005.18 shortly after the session opened, surpassing the record high of 3,991 points clocked the day before, but then the heat went out of the market.
The index closed at 3,972.43, down 9.14 points or 0.2 per cent from the day before.
The STI heroics followed another lacklustre session on Wall Street overnight after the White House announced new tariffs on auto firms.

title: Singapore real estate firm RealVantage jointly acquires Arthouse Hotel in Scotland for over $20m
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe 59-room Arthouse Hotel in Scotland's Glasgow city is undergoing renovation.
SINGAPORE – Singapore real estate firm RealVantage has joined forces with a London firm to buy the Arthouse Hotel in the Scottish city of Glasgow for £12 million (S$20.8 million).
RealVantage owns 85 per cent of the 59-room hotel, with its British partner Oberland, a London-based real estate investor and asset manager, accounting for the rest.
Potential purchasers include real estate investment trusts, family offices, hospitality-focused funds, high-net-worth individuals and hotel owner-operators.
The firm has two broad strategies – lending to developers and collecting interest payments, or funding or part-funding property investments, such as the Arthouse Hotel deal.

title: World’s top-performing defence stock soars 3,100% in five years
summary:
Hanwha Aerospace shares have risen more than 3,100 per cent in the last five years, making it the best-performing defence stock on Bloomberg’s World index.
Both are little known outside South Korea but play a key role in preparing the country’s troops for possible battle with its heavily militarised neighbour, North Korea.
The company aims to generate 70 trillion won in revenue by 2035, with 10 trillion won annual profit, when it completes building production facilities in Europe, Middle East, Australia and the United States.
“Why did we buy South Korean weapons?
“We think South Korean partners would be able to supply high-quality weapons within a few months.” BLOOMBERG

title: SingPost shares jump 5% after it completes $845m sale of Australian logistics business
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore Post (SingPost) has completed the divestment of its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings (FMH), for A$1 billion (S$845 million).
Shares in SingPost jumped on the news, with the stock closing up 5.1 per cent to 61.5 cents on March 28, with 41.2 million shares traded.
Sale proceeds will be used to reduce debt, including the repayment of a A$362.1 million debt.
In a press statement, SingPost said the sale necessitates a strategy reset for the group – earnings in the interim are now dependent on its postal and e-commerce logistics business in Singapore, its international e-commerce logistics business, and two major non-core assets that have been performing well.
“The successful divestment of the Australia business, along with potential future divestitures, will create a significant cash pool,” it added.

title: UOB rejects allegations of improper conduct made by ex-CEO of former client Yang Kee Logistics
summary:
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said separately that it is looking into the allegations made by Mr Koh Kien Chon, who is also known as Mr Ken Koh.
He used to be the chief executive of Yang Kee Logistics, a client of UOB.
The bank said in a media statement later in the day that it has issued a warning letter to Mr Koh.
Yang Kee Logistics was founded in 1990 by Mr Koh’s father Koh Yang Kee.
The company and its major shareholder Koh Yang Kee – the holding company for the Koh family – were placed under receivership in May 2022.

title: Shipowners already adjusting contracts for proposed US tax on Chinese vessels
summary:
New clauses state that companies hiring Chinese ships will bear the cost of any taxes, in part or in full, sources said.
SINGAPORE – Shipowners and charterers are altering leasing contracts to cope with the multimillion-dollar port fees expected to be imposed on Chinese-built vessels by the Trump administration, according to people familiar with the matter.
Among the questions plaguing shipowners is how exactly a Chinese vessel will be defined in the final instance.
The USTR is currently recommending different fees, starting with a levy of as much as US$1 million (S$1.3 million) per ship per port visit.
More than a third of the tonnage from ships currently trading were built by China, Clarksons data shows.

title: Straits Times Index crosses 4,000 mark for the first time
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe STI hit 4,005.18 points shortly after the market opened, data from the Singapore Exchange showed.
SINGAPORE - The Straits Times Index (STI) set an intraday record on March 28 as it crossed the 4,000 mark for the first time in early trading.
The index hit 4,005.18 points shortly after the market opened, data from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) showed.
Mr Howie highlighted that the benchmark index maintains one of the highest dividend yields regionally.
ST Engineering closed up 0.9 per cent at $6.79, while Sembcorp declined 0.5 per cent to $6.34.

title: Growing Singapore demand boosts Malaysian cross-border bus firm’s IPO
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxHI Mobility operates 155 Causeway Link buses on the Singapore-Johor route, which is around a quarter of its overall fleet.
- HI Mobility is betting on increased traffic with Singapore to drive growth as the Malaysian operator of Causeway Link buses started trading on March 28 after a rare listing by one of the country’s transport providers.
It operates 155 Causeway Link buses on the Singapore-Johor route – around a quarter of its overall fleet.
The company’s stock market debut is a rare success story in Malaysia’s public transport landscape, which is mostly dominated by closely held state-linked firms.
Malaysia’s stock market was also the region’s top IPO destination, hosting over US$1.8 billion worth of IPOs.

title: Delta Thailand becomes Asia’s worst stock after $40 billion rout
summary:
The plunge in the shares of Delta Electronics (Thailand) is an extreme example of how the AI craze has created excessive valuations.
BANGKOK - Just four months ago, shares of Delta Electronics (Thailand) were outpacing global peers, prompting a series of moves from Thai market authorities to halt the rally.
The 2025 tumble wiped out about US$30 billion (S$40 billion) of Delta’s market value and made the stock the biggest laggard on the MSCI Asia Pacific Index.
The unit of Taiwan’s Delta Electronics makes components for automobiles and data centre chargers, among other products.
The stock is now trading at about 45 times forward earnings, below its five-year average of 55, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

title: Teaching and tech professionals in high demand in 2024 as Singapore’s job market remains tight
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s labour market remained tight in 2024, with new roles making up nearly half of all job vacancies, said the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in its annual Job Vacancies Report.
In 2014, professional, managerial, executive and technician (PMET) roles made up only 43.4 per cent of job vacancies.
Manpower Minister Tan See Leng delivering a press briefing on the Jobs Vacancies Report 2024 at the KPMG Singapore office on March 28.
Software, web and multimedia developers came in second, after topping the list of top PMET vacancies in the previous two years.
With increased focus on skills-based hiring, more employers are looking beyond academic credentials when recruiting, even for PMET roles, said MOM.

title: Top US Fed official warns tariff-driven inflation boost is ‘inevitable’
summary:
While tariff-driven inflation could prove short-lived, Ms Collins said it is possible that price pressures could prove more persistent.
“It looks inevitable that tariffs are going to increase inflation in the near term,” Ms Collins said on March 27 during a fireside conversation in Boston .
Policymakers have said borrowing costs are well positioned to wait for greater clarity on the economic impact of US President Donald Trump’s policy changes , including trade and immigration .
St Louis Fed president Alberto Musalem, however, said on March 26 that policymakers should be wary of assuming that such inflation would be entirely temporary.
Ms Collins highlighted two channels to watch for the impact of tariffs on inflation.

title: Indonesia’s Widjaja family moves to delist Sinarmas Land from SGX; more large-cap exits on horizon
summary:
SINGAPORE - An entity controlled by Indonesia’s billionaire Widjaja family has made a voluntary unconditional cash offer for all the shares in Sinarmas Land that it does not already own at 31 cents apiece.
The offeror, Lyon Investments – which counts executive chairman Franky Oesman Widjaja, chief executive officer Muktar Widjaja and Ms Margaretha Natalia Widjaja among its directors – currently holds about 70.3 per cent of the total number of issued shares in Sinarmas Land.
Shares of Sinarmas Land jumped on the news, rising as much as 23.6 per cent to 34 cents on March 28, before closing at 32 cents, up 16.4 per cent.
It added that it was making the offer to delist the company from SGX’s mainboard.
Ms Foo expects delistings to continue to outpace listings in 2025 , in line with the broader market consensus.

title: US stocks extend losses on auto tariff shock
summary:
“I think there’s a lot of confusion right now,” said Mr Tom Cahill, of Ventura Wealth Management.
Investors have been expecting more details surrounding Mr Trump’s promised tariffs on April 2, with markets previously lifted by hopes that they would be more targeted than anticipated.
But Mr Trump’s announced 25 per cent auto tariffs, to take effect next week, came unexpectedly to investors, Mr Cahill added.
On March 27, shares in major automaker Ford declined 3.9 per cent, while General Motors plunged 7.4 per cent.
While markets have tried to rally, this effort “lacks conviction,” said Mr Cahill, as it is risky getting ahead of Trump’s April 2 announcement.

title: Early adopter advantage: Get ahead of the curve with prime Marina South waterfront living
summary:
One Marina Gardens offers homes on Singapore’s developing southern coast, with direct access to the city centre and green spacesAn artist's impression of One Marina Gardens, which will be located in the waterfront district of Marina South.
Rising in the heart of Marina South, One Marina Gardens is poised to redefine urban living in one of Singapore’s most anticipated districts.
One Marina Gardens boasts an enviable location in Marina South, Singapore’s newest prime district.
Exercise with panoramic views of Marina Bay at One Marina Garden’s elevated wellness facilities.
PHOTO: ONE MARINA GARDENSThe development’s proximity to Marina Bay Sands, Marina Bay Link Mall, Suntec City, Raffles City, Satay by the Bay and an array of retail and dining options ensures that everything from world-class entertainment to everyday essentials is within easy reach.

title: Retail investors may be able to tap private market assets under proposed framework
summary:
SINGAPORE - Retail investors in Singapore could soon be able to put money into private market investment funds under a new framework that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is looking to introduce.
There is also more interest from experienced industry players in offering such products to retail investors.
Retail investors can also invest in retail bonds backed by private equity, which are currently available in the market.
Retail investors also have different needs from institutional and accredited investors when it comes to private market investments.
“Retail investors might lack the experience and knowledge needed to evaluate and manage private market investments effectively,” he added.

title: Singapore fund inflows surge 167% to $7.6 billion for 2024: Morningstar
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxFixed income funds have emerged as the most popular asset class in 2024.
SINGAPORE - Total net inflows into Singapore-registered funds hit $7.6 billion for 2024, a surge of 167 per cent from $2.85 billion in 2023, according to a report by financial-services firm Morningstar on March 27.
The funds logged $1.7 billion in net inflows in the fourth quarter, down from a record $3.1 billion in the quarter before.
The asset class registered $158.8 million of net inflows in the fourth quarter of 2024, down from $1.5 billion in the quarter before.
On fixed income, Morningstar pointed out that investors can consider longer-term bonds which are likely to appreciate in price when interest rates decline.

title: STI hits new high with gains across most sectors; closes up 0.5%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGainers outstripped losers 274 to 218 on trade of one billion securities worth $1.4 billion.
SINGAPORE – Local shares hit a new high in trading on March 27 before closing in the black, thanks to solid gains across most sectors.
The positive mood evident all week remained intact to send the Straits Times Index (STI) to as high as 3,991 points in the morning before closing at 3,981.57, up 0.5 per cent or 17.86 points for the day.
Gainers outstripped losers 274 to 218 across the broader market on trade of one billion securities worth $1.4 billion.
The banks rose: DBS added 0.4 per cent to $46.58, OCBC was up 0.8 per cent to $17.38, and UOB advanced 1.1 per cent to $38.26.

title: Daryl Ng to step down as Yeo’s chairman; banking veteran Na Wu Beng to succeed him
summary:
Mr Daryl Ng, 46, has served as board chairman for around five years, and will concurrently step down from his role as non-independent, non-executive director after the AGM.
He will be succeeded by banking veteran Na Wu Beng, who has served as deputy chairman and independent director since 2023.
Mr Daryl Ng is the son of Mr Philip Ng’s brother Robert Ng, who is the chairman of Hong Kong-listed Sino Group, FEO’s sister company.
Mr Daryl Ng was first appointed director in 2018 and helmed the board from 2020.
The company also recorded an assets/investments impairment of $7.7 million, which it attributed to the “challenging operating environment, particularly in China and Singapore”.

title: Musk’s Tesla a rare winner as Trump’s auto tariffs spread the pain
summary:
Most carmakers stand to lose as US President Donald Trump imposes new levies on auto imports and key components from next week.
“There are very few winners,” Mr Sam Fiorani, vice-president of global vehicle forecasting for AutoForecast Solutions, said in a phone interview.
“Consumers will be losers because they will have reduced choice and higher prices.”One notable winner in the tariff chaos is Mr Elon Musk.
His Tesla has large factories in California and Texas that churn out all the electric vehicles it sells in the US.
Foreign brands heavily reliant on imported vehicles will face the most pressure.

title: Paragon Reit offer is fair and reasonable, says independent financial adviser
summary:
SINGAPORE - A $2.78 billion offer to privatise the real estate investment trust (Reit) that holds the Paragon mall in Orchard Road has been deemed “fair and reasonable” by an independent assessor.
Documents lodged on the Singapore Exchange on March 27 revealed that PrimePartners, the independent financial adviser appointed by Paragon Reit , has concluded after considering the financial terms involved that the offer is fair and reasonable.
The offer to take Paragon Reit private by major shareholder Cuscaden Peak Investments comprises paying unit holders 98 cents per unit in cash.
Cuscaden Peak and its subsidiaries, which hold 61.5 per cent of Paragon Reit, will abstain from voting.
Units of Paragon Reit were trading flat at 97 cents on March 27.

title: China pauses new deals with Li Ka-shing family over Panama ports plan
summary:
– China has told state-owned firms to hold off on any new collaboration with businesses linked to Mr Li Ka-shing and his family, according to people familiar with the matter, after the Hong Kong billionaire irked Beijing with his plan to sell two Panama ports to a global consortium.
The order to pause new dealings does not necessarily mean Beijing will bar state firms from working with businesses linked to Mr Li.
The impact on CK Hutchison from a halt on new business with state-owned companies may be limited.
The bulk of its operations spans Europe, North America and Australia, in sectors covering retail, telecommunications, ports and utilities , with little exposure to Chinese state-owned firms .
Its insurance arm, FWD Group Holdings, has stated its ambition to expand into mainland China , in previous financial documents, which would likely require partnerships with Chinese companies .

title: UOB to issue $2.68 billion in US dollar-denominated bonds
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe US dollar-denominated multi-tranche bonds are due in 2028 and 2030.
SINGAPORE - UOB said on March 27 that it intends to issue US$2 billion (S$2.68 billion) in US dollar-denominated multi-tranche bonds due in 2028 and 2030.
The issue comprises US$800 million senior notes due in 2028 priced at 4.401 per cent, US$900 million senior floating rate notes due in 2028, and US$300 million senior floating rate notes due in 2030.
The bank said in a statement that it had taken advantage of recent constructive markets and a stable window, ahead of US President Donald Trump’s proposed tariffs on April 2.
The Singapore lender did not reveal how it intends to utilise the proceeds.

title: OpenAI expects revenue to triple to $17 billion in 2025
summary:
- OpenAI expects to more than triple its revenue in 2025 to US$12.7 billion (S$17 billion), fuelled by the strength of its paid artificial intelligence (AI) software, according to a person familiar with the matter.
The San Francisco-based company generated US$3.7 billion in annual revenue in 2024 , said the person, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal communications.
OpenAI expects revenue will continue growing at a fast clip, more than doubling in 2026 to US$29.4 billion, the person said.
The New York Times reported in September 2024 that OpenAI was eyeing revenue of US$11.6 billion for 2025.
OpenAI does not expect to be cash-flow positive until 2029, the person said, a year when it projects revenue will top US$125 billion.

title: Hong Kong lures investment firms Ardian, Arga as they eye regional expansion
summary:
The investment manager, which advises US$177 billion (S$237 billion) of assets, will add Hong Kong as its fifth Asia office after Seoul, Tokyo, Beijing and Singapore.
The company has at least 14 staff working in the existing Asia offices, according to its website.
Ardian is applying for licences with the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission, one of the sources said.
Separately, Arga Investment Management, a Stamford, Connecticut-based firm, is planning to open an office in Hong Kong, according to a source familiar with the matter.
The firm manages US$19 billion of assets, according to its LinkedIn page, which also includes a hiring advertisement for Hong Kong.

title: Tesla has a problem – and it’s not just Elon Musk’s politics
summary:
WASHINGTON – Tesla Inc’s sales started slowing even before chief executive Elon Musk really threw his weight around in US politics.
Mr Musk himself says he is having “great difficulty” running his businesses while also tending to his work in Washington.
What’s the state of Tesla’s sales?
Mr Trump came to Mr Musk’s defence with a photo opportunity at the White House on March 11 where he perused several Tesla vehicles and pledged to buy a Model S .
Mr Musk also hopes to begin delivering a humanoid robot called Optimus to other companies starting in 2026 .

title: Cathay cinema at Jem closes as landlord seeks $4.3 million in rental arrears
summary:
There were no more movie listings for the Jem outlet on Cathay Cineplexes’ website as of the morning of March 27.
Lease terminationBut Lendlease Reit decided to terminate its lease with the cinema chain as it seeks to recoup, among other things, some $4.3 million in rental arrears, mm2 added.
“Cathay Cineplexes remains committed to realigning and rightsizing its cinema business in anticipation of the market and audience shift post-Covid.
In response to ST’s queries, Lendlease Reit said a new tenant will be taking over the approximately 47,000 sq ft space.
But with fewer and smaller Cathay cineplexes, there will be fewer movie timings after the first week or two of release.

title: US stocks slip as auto tariffs approach
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks veered off course on March 26 after the White House said President Donald Trump would announce fresh tariffs on the auto sector after markets close.
The tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 2 per cent to 17,899.01, while the CBOE Volatility Index – Wall Street’s so-called “fear gauge” – jumped 7 per cent, reflecting market jitters.
The turn in market sentiment followed White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt’s remarks earlier on March 26 that Mr Trump would unveil the “auto industry” tariffs at 4pm (4am on March 27, Singapore time).
“It’s the continuation of worries regarding the tariffs and the impact on the economy,” Mr Peter Cardillo from Spartan Capital Securities told AFP.
“Everyone is (also) waiting to see what the reciprocal tariffs are going to be on April 2,” he added.

title: Singapore stocks track Wall St gains on strong sentiment; STI up 0.2%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.2 per cent or 9.18 points to end at 3,963.71.
SINGAPORE – Gains among regional bourses after a modestly positive session on Wall Street overnight helped nudge local shares higher on March 26.
The indexes swung between gains and losses all day before the S&P 500 closed 0.2 per cent ahead, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1 per cent and the Nasdaq advanced 0.5 per cent.
The Australian market rose for a fifth day running, adding 0.7 per cent, in part due to federal government budget support for hard-pressed consumers.
DBS was up 0.7 per cent at $46.39 and OCBC gained 0.4 per cent to $17.25, but UOB fell 0.1 per cent to $37.85.

title: 1.3% dip in Singapore factory output in February despite high growth expectations
summary:
Total output decreased by 1.3 per cent year on year, after a revised 8 per cent increase in January and a 5.9 per cent rise last December.
Excluding the more volatile biomedical industry, output increased by 0.3 per cent, according to data from the Economic Development Board on March 26.
On a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, total manufacturing output decreased by 7.5 per cent.
Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output decreased by 7.9 per cent.
The chemicals cluster output decreased by 0.1 per cent in February year on year.

title: Grab seeks up to $2.7 billion loan for potential takeover of Gojek parent GoTo: Sources
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox– Singapore ride and delivery firm Grab Holdings is in talks to raise a loan of as much as US$2 billion (S$2.7 billion) to back its potential takeover of Indonesia-based rival and Gojek parent GoTo Group, according to people familiar with the matter.
The so-called bridge loan could have a tenor of about 12 months, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private matters.
A GoTo spokesperson declined to comment while Grab didn’t respond to e-mails and messages requesting comment.
Grab is also considering a bond or equity take-out after the firm secures the bridge loan, said one of the people.
Still, the deal is dependent on the successful acquisition of GoTo, the people added.

title: Pop Mart’s profit more than doubles on Labubu craze
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxStrong overseas sales of its Labubu collectible toys have turned Pop Mart into one of the hottest stocks, with shares up 360 per cent in the past year.
Hong Kong - Pop Mart International Group said it will continue to expand its global footprint with a focus on North America and Europe, after reporting that its profit more than doubled in 2024, driven by the popularity of its patented Labubu collectible toys.
Pop Mart will also look at strengthening cooperation with artists and brands to promote the “cross-boundary integration of pop culture”, it said.
Net income for the Beijing-based toys company soared 188 per cent to 3.1 billion yuan (S$572 million) in 2024 compared with 1.1 billion yuan a year earlier, beating the 2.71 billion yuan estimated by analysts.
Thirteen of its intellectual property products generated sales of over 100 million yuan.

title: $400m forestry fund to focus on S-E Asia as climate, conservation focus grows
summary:
Sydney-based New Forests will manage the fund and help Oji Holdings identify the forestry assets, which can be existing plantations or sites to develop new ones.
Mr Seeto said that although the fund was global in focus, more than half the investment would be in South-east Asia.
“This fund is to help Oji meet their 2030 net-zero requirement,” Mr Seeto said.
Other investors could join and become shareholders in the venture , which could help fund larger regional investments in forestry and conservation.
Forests are increasingly in focus ahead of the COP30 United Nations climate talks at the end of the year.

title: Trust Bank launches money-lock anti-scam feature
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTrust Bank customers can lock their money in up to five Savings Pots, or sub-accounts.
SINGAPORE - Trust Bank announced the roll-out of its money-lock feature, Trust Lock, for customers on March 26.
This allows Trust customers to lock Savings Pot – a sub-account – to prevent withdrawals.
UOB allows customers to lock specific amounts of money in existing savings accounts or a separate LockAway Account.
The money-lock feature has been activated for more than 181,000 customers, locking $15.8 billion in savings as at end-October 2024.

title: OCBC chief Helen Wong’s 2024 pay up 5.8% to $12.8 million
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE - OCBC Bank group chief executive Helen Wong’s total pay rose in 2024 as the bank’s full-year earnings reached a new high, according to disclosures in its annual report released on March 26.
Ms Wong’s annual pay for the year came in at $12.8 million, a 5.8 per cent increase from the $12.1 million she earned in 2023.
Ms Wong’s annual remuneration included a base salary of $1.2 million, lower than the $1.44 million she earned in 2023.
Deferred shares amounted to $4.5 million, which also increased from the $4.2 million in 2023.
UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong came in second, earning $15.05 million in 2024.

title: Consumer confidence on where US economy is headed plunges to 12-year low
summary:
- Americans are increasingly anxious about their jobs and finances as the Trump administration’s trade policies and government cutbacks stoke concern about the economy.
Economists have warned that Mr Trump’s plans for sweeping tariffs on the US’ biggest trading partners could reignite inflation.
Whiplash from shifting trade policies, and investors’ concern about a potential slowdown in the US economy, fuelled a stock market sell-off earlier in March .
(Over the most recent 12 months, the inflation rate was 2.8 per cent, according to the consumer price index for February.)
Mr Stephen Miran, chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, played down the drop in consumer confidence in an interview with CNBC on March 25.

title: DNA testing firm 23andMe says ‘delays’ resolved after users rushed to delete data
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox– DNA testing company 23andMe said on March 25 it experienced website delays, after a wave of customers sought to delete their genetic data before the firm can be sold through a planned bankruptcy auction.
Those problems have since been resolved, the spokesperson said, advising users to contact customer support if they continue to encounter trouble deleting data.
But Ms Miller is concerned that 23andMe users do not know who could end up buying users’ genetic information, or if a purchaser could use the information for nefarious purposes.
For example, she said, could health information contained in her or her husband’s genetic data be used by an insurance company to increase their coverage costs?
Any auction will be overseen by a federal judge and be monitored by the Justice Department and state attorneys-general, some of whom have issued consumer alerts instructing 23andMe users how to delete their data.

title: US stocks gain on lingering hopes over Trump tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, during morning trading, on March 25.
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks mostly closed higher on March 25, building on earlier gains amid hopes that US President Donald Trump might take a narrower approach to upcoming tariffs than originally expected.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat at 42,587.50, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index advanced 0.2 per cent to 5,776.65.
“The absence of bad news is good news for stocks,” said Mr Adam Sarhan from 50 Park Investments.
For now, markets are waiting for further hints about Mr Trump’s upcoming tariff roll-out, with the President having promised “reciprocal tariffs” tailored to each trading partner on April 2.

title: China floods the world with AI models after DeepSeek’s success
summary:
It fired up a long-dormant Chinese tech industry – and now, Western names from OpenAI to Nvidia may pay the price.
Chinese companies have in the past two weeks rolled out no fewer than 10 major product updates or releases – and that is just the big names.
The rapidly accelerating array of enhancements and tune-ups is more than Chinese companies jumping on the DeepSeek bandwagon.
Collectively, the AI models – nearly all of them open-sourced – represent the developers’ efforts to set world standards and benchmarks, and grab a bigger slice of the global market.
With China’s strength in hardware, the cheaper and more accessible the AI models, the more the demand for devices powered by AI, said Mr Balaji Srinivasan, tech investor and former general partner at Andreessen Horowitz.

title: Haidilao operator Super Hi slips back into the red with $15.5 million loss in Q4
summary:
In a statement on March 25, Super Hi attributed the decline to a US$40.4 million net foreign exchange loss, arising from the depreciation of local currencies against the US dollar.
Super Hi finds itself in the red again after posting a US$37.7 million profit in the preceding quarter – which had been a turnaround from its US$1.4 million net loss in the third quarter of 2023.
Meanwhile, revenue rose 13.4 per cent to US$778.3 million and operating income was up 23.7 per cent at US$53.3 million.
Super Hi chief executive and executive director Yang Lijuan said the group will continue expanding its Haidilao restaurant network and optimising store layout.
As at Dec 31, Super Hi operated 122 Haidilao outlets outside of China, after opening two restaurants and closing one in the fourth quarter.

title: New Cold Storage, Giant owners say $125m price tag fully reflects value of the business
summary:
SINGAPORE - Although DFI Retail Group has decided to offload its Singapore supermarket business to focus on other more lucrative businesses, the new owners of Cold Storage and Giant see new opportunities to expand their supermarket empire.
“I don’t often come to Cold Storage as the products are pricey, so I hope prices will drop with the acquisition,” she said.
Consumers can also expect to see Cold Storage outlets opening in emerging districts such as those near Lentor Modern.
Macrovalue owns two Cold Storage and 38 Giant outlets in Malaysia, as well as 11 upscale Mercato supermarket outlets.
“Besides price and range, Singapore customers wish for better service, like staff who can recognise them by name,” Mr Lim said.

title: Singapore stocks track regional gains; STI up 0.5%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5 per cent or 18.2 points to 3,954.53.
SINGAPORE - Singapore stocks ended higher on March 25, tracking gains in the region.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5 per cent or 18.2 points to 3,954.53.
The Nikkei 225 was up 0.5 per cent, the Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gained 0.7 per cent, while the IDX Composite advanced 1.2 per cent.
On the STI, Singapore Exchange was the top gainer, rising 1.9 per cent to $13.33.

title: MAS-led measures to revive SGX a good start, but rebuilding confidence key to sustaining momentum
summary:
Temasek chief executive Dilhan Pillay described the measures as the most significant for the local stock market in over 30 years.
Better recourse and corporate governanceThe ongoing dispute between some shareholders of Great Eastern (GE) and OCBC is one example of the lack of avenues for some minority shareholders to negotiate better terms for themselves.
However, some minority shareholders continued to oppose the offer and refused to sell.
So, if fraudulent disclosures occur, minority shareholders may struggle to seek redress.
Ultimately, the stock market operates in a cycle.

title: Tesla sales in Europe plunge 40% in February as market share drops
summary:
– Tesla’s electric vehicle sales have fallen in 10 of the last 12 months in Europe, with the carmaker struggling mightily at the beginning of 2025.
Tesla’s sales plunged 43 per cent in the first two months of the year, deviating from the 31 per cent rise in industry-wide EV registrations.
Tesla commanded 1.8 per cent of the total market and 10.3 per cent of the battery-electric market in February, down from 2.8 per cent and 21.6 per cent a year ago respectively.
Changing over to the new Model Y required pausing production at factories around the world early in 2025, including at the company’s assembly plant outside Berlin.
Those disruptions cost the company weeks of output and either lost or deferred sales.

title: Trading firm tied to China’s fallen copper king sells Singapore office at 20 Collyer Quay
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAwin Resources International sold the office at 20 Collyer Quay to a subsidiary of developer GuocoLand earlier this month.
Awin Resources International, a trading affiliate of Mr Wang’s Amer International Group, sold the office at 20 Collyer Quay to a subsidiary of developer GuocoLand earlier in March, according to official records seen by Bloomberg.
Mr Wang – nicknamed “copper king” in his heyday, when his sprawling group was said to handle a 10th of China’s copper imports – has stumbled in recent years, suspending regular metals trading and closing factories.
Bloomberg News reported in October that Mr Wang himself faced legal claims seeking US$1.6 billion (S$2.1 billion) in unpaid debts.
At its zenith, the Amer office in the upper reaches of a tower just across the harbour from Marina Bay Sands was packed with rosewood furniture and photographs of Mr Wang with senior government officials.

title: Indonesian rupiah tumbles to lowest since Asian financial crisis
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe rupiah has also slumped against the Singapore currency, down about 6 per cent so far in 2025.
– The Indonesian rupiah pared losses after the country’s central bank intervened to prop up the currency from its weakest level since the Asian financial crisis.
The rupiah has also slumped against the Singapore currency and is down about 6 per cent to date in 2025.
Since then, it has been forced to intervene almost daily to stabilise the currency as global market volatility increased amid concern over US trade policy.
“Jittery equities market, ongoing concern on deficit trajectory and the holidays ahead might exacerbate near-term rupiah volatility,” said senior Apac market strategist Wee Khoon Chong at BNY.

title: Samsung Electronics says co-CEO Han Jong-hee has died of cardiac arrest
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSamsung Electronics co-CEO Han Jong-hee passed away at a hospital on March 25 while being treated for cardiac arrest.
Mr Han, 63, became CEO of South Korea’s biggest company in 2022 and was also in charge of its consumer electronics and mobile devices division.
Mr Han, who was also a board member, died at a hospital on March 25 while being treated for cardiac arrest, a company spokesperson said, adding that a successor had not yet been decided.
Mr Han joined Samsung nearly 40 years ago and built his career in its television business.
Over the past year, our company failed to adequately respond to the rapidly evolving AI semiconductor market,” Mr Han had said at the meeting.

title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to buy rest of Northpoint City for $1.17 billion
summary:
SINGAPORE – The manager of Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) announced on March 25 it will buy the rest of Northpoint City in Yishun for $1.17 billion.
FCT inked agreements with FCL Amber and Bright Bloom Capital to acquire the south wing of Northpoint City for $1.17 billion.
It will be done via the purchase of North Gem Trust (NG Trust), a private trust that holds the interests in the target property.
Following the acquisition, FCT will have full ownership of Northpoint City, said Mr Richard Ng, chief executive of the manager of FCT.
The acquisition cost of $1.17 billion comprises $375.2 million for the acquisition price and about $785 million of bank loans owed by NG Trust.

title: HSBC weighs outsourcing some trading operations to lift returns
summary:
- HSBC Holdings is considering outsourcing part of its sprawling trading business as executives struggle to justify making technology investments needed to keep up with larger rivals.
The moves would allow HSBC to save millions of dollars in information technology costs associated with running trading desks around the globe, two of the sources said.
HSBC is open to a deal with firms including Citadel Securities and Jane Street Group, the sources said.
Spokespeople for HSBC, Citadel Securities and Jane Street declined to comment.
Jane Street has also discussed offering a similar service with some banks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump Media taps Singapore-based Crypto.com for Made-in-America ETFs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUS President Donald Trump’s administration has been easing restrictions on the digital asset industry.
- Trump Media & Technology Group plans to work with Crypto.com on a line-up of “Made-in-America” investments – an arrangement that puts the US President’s social media company in business with a Singapore-based firm that was locked in a legal battle with US regulators in 2024.
Mr Donald Trump is Trump Media’s largest shareholder, with a US$2.4 billion (S$3.2 billion) stake that is held in a trust controlled by his son Donald Trump Jr.
Trump Media also revealed that its digital currency ETFs will include Cronos, a virtual currency affiliated with Crypto.com.
Crypto.com chief executive Kris Marszalek also met with Mr Trump at Mar-a-Lago to discuss political appointments related to the industry.

title: New DBS CEO Tan Su Shan keen on ‘bolt-on’ acquisitions rather than large-scale M&As
summary:
Ms Tan said DBS would like to stay focused on its existing operational footprint and not spread itself “too thin”.
SINGAPORE - DBS Group’s incoming chief executive Tan Su Shan is open to “bolt-on” acquisitions and will focus on boosting the Singaporean lender’s high-return businesses such as wealth and transaction banking.
Ms Tan, 57 and currently deputy CEO, will become DBS’ first female CEO and also the first to be appointed from within the ranks of the bank on March 28.
Besides its presence in Asian financial hubs Singapore and Hong Kong, DBS’ main markets in the region include India, China, Taiwan and Indonesia.
Ms Tan said that DBS would like to stay focused on its existing operational footprint and not spread itself “too thin”.

title: 23andMe’s bankruptcy puts 15 million users’ DNA info on auction block
summary:
23andMe has proposed a May 14 auction for the sale of its assets, which include the genetic data of more than 15 million customers.
Those concerns were fuelled in part by a 2023 data breach that compromised the information of roughly seven million 23andMe customers.
“Our users’ privacy and data are important considerations in any transaction, and we remain committed to our users’ privacy and to being transparent with our customers about how their data is managed,” the company said.
California and Connecticut’s top law enforcement officers issued consumer alerts on March 24, providing instructions on how 23andMe customers can delete their genetic information.
Although the scale of 23andMe’s genetic data is likely unique, customer data is regularly sold in bankruptcy.

title: China’s Xiaomi raises $7.4 billion in upsized share sale for EV expansion
summary:
The company sold 800 million shares at HK$53.25 each, the company said in its statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
The offering, which comes weeks after EV giant BYD’s US$5.6 billion fund-raising, builds on wha is shaping up to be a bumper year for share sales in Hong Kong.
As to Xiaomi, the company is investing aggressively in its nascent EV business to drive growth.
It recently increased its 2025 EV delivery target after posting the fastest revenue growth since 2021.
Xiaomi shares have more than tripled from their low in August, making them the best performers on the Hang Seng and one of China’s most expensive tech stocks.

title: Hyundai, Trump announce $28 billion US investment, new steel plant
summary:
- South Korea’s Hyundai Motor Group announced a US$21 billion (S$28 billion) investment in the United States with President Donald Trump at the White House on March 24.
The investment includes a new US$5.8 billion Hyundai Steel plant in Louisiana that will produce over 2.7 million tonnes of steel annually, creating more than 1,400 jobs.
The steel plant is expected to supply steel to auto plants in Alabama and Georgia.
We want to keep it that way,” Mr Trump said.
Mr Trump has already introduced tariffs to boost protection for US steel and aluminium producers.

title: US stocks close sharply higher, Nvidia and Tesla rally
summary:
The S&P 500 has recovered about 4 per cent from its recent low on March 13, and it remains down around 6 per cent from its Feb 19 record high close.
The S&P 500 climbed 1.76 per cent to end the session at 5,767.57 points.
Crypto stocks rallied with a 4 per cent rise in bitcoin prices, with MicroStrategy surging 10 per cent and Coinbase adding 7 per cent.
Advancing issues outnumbered falling ones within the S&P 500 by a 5.4-to-one ratio.
The S&P 500 posted 5 new highs and 1 new lows; the Nasdaq recorded 46 new highs and 97 new lows.

title: Cold Storage, Giant customers can expect cheaper products, more variety after takeover, buyer says
summary:
DFI Retail Group, which owns Cold Storage and Giant in Singapore, on March 24 announced that it will sell all 48 Cold Storage and 41 Giant outlets, as well as two distribution centres, to Macrovalue for $125 million.
The brands under Cold Storage include CS Fresh, CS Gold and Jason’s Deli.
In Singapore, Giant and Cold Storage compete with FairPrice, which has 164 stores, and Sheng Siong with 77 outlets.
DFI, then known as Dairy Farm, bought Singapore’s Cold Storage with a network of 142 stores in 1993.
In 2003, it bought 35 Shop N Save supermarkets, which were later converted to Giant supermarkets in 2013.

title: Singapore shares rise on Monday; STI up 0.3%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe top gainer on the STI was DFI Retail Group, which rose 4 per cent or nine US cents to US$2.34.
SINGAPORE - Singapore shares ended higher on March 24, bucking a regional trend.
The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3 per cent or 9.88 points to 3,936.33.
DBS was up 0.4 per cent or 18 cents at $45.49, OCBC gained 0.5 per cent or eight cents to end at $17.06, while UOB lost 0.3 per cent or 11 cents to finish at $37.84.
The Kospi lost 0.4 per cent, the Nikkei 225 slipped 0.2 per cent and the KLCI dipped 0.1 per cent.

title: Singapore core inflation falls further to 0.6% in February, lowest since June 2021
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s core inflation declined for the fifth straight month in February after falling sharply in January as most spending categories saw smaller year-on-year price increases.
For February, core inflation, which excludes private transport and accommodation costs to better reflect the expenses of households here, eased to 0.6 per cent year on year.
In January, core inflation slid to 0.8 per cent from 1.7 per cent in December 2024.
Overall – or headline – inflation cooled to 0.9 per cent year on year in February from 1.2 per cent in January as private transport inflation moderated, in addition to the fall in core inflation.
UOB’s Mr Koh said the bank has lowered further its 2025 average core inflation forecast to 1 per cent, from 1.3 per cent previously, but maintained its overall inflation forecast at 1.3 per cent.

title: All Cold Storage, Giant outlets in Singapore to be sold to Malaysian group for $125m
summary:
SINGAPORE – All Cold Storage and Giant supermarket outlets in Singapore will be sold to Malaysian retail group Macrovalue for an initial price of $125 million.
Besides Singapore, DFI has a presence in other markets such as Thailand, Hong Kong and the Philippines.
Some supermarket outlets, including Giant at IMM in Jurong East and at Simei MRT station, and Cold Storage in Tampines 1, have been renovated and upgraded.
The latest store to close – on March 10 – is Cold Storage at Leisure Park Kallang.
It runs 164 supermarkets islandwide under the FairPrice, FairPrice Finest and FairPrice Xtra formats.

title: DNA testing firm 23andMe files for bankruptcy to sell itself; CEO leaves after failed bids
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBengaluru – Genetic testing firm 23andMe filed for for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US to help the US$50 million (S$66.8 million) company sell itself, as co-founder and chief executive Anne Wojcicki resigned after multiple failed takeover bids.
She intends to make another bid during the bankruptcy process, she said in a post on X, without giving details.
“After a thorough evaluation of strategic alternatives, we have determined that a court-supervised sale process is the best path forward to maximise the value of the business,” 23andMe chairman Mark Jensen said in a statement.
23andMe said it secured a debtor-in-possession financing commitment for about US$35 million and expects to continue operating during the sale process.
It listed both assets and estimated liabilities of US$100 million to US$500 million.

title: Gold rush: Customers in Asia race to cash in their old jewellery and coins
summary:
MUMBAI – As gold prices jump to successive highs, jewellers across Asia and the Middle East are grappling with displays losing their sparkle as customers race to cash in their old jewellery and coins.
Consumers are shifting towards buying cheaper jewellery or opting to sell their existing gold or using it as loan collateral instead of making new purchases.
Other major Asian markets have also seen a slump in demand for gold jewellery, with more sellers than buyers.
Jewellery hubs in the Middle East are seeing a similar dip in demand, according to a Dubai-based bullion dealer.
Looking ahead, analysts say the outlook for jewellery demand remains gloomy, although investment demand for bullion is likely to remain strong.

title: Li Ka-shing’s son invited to Beijing amid controversial Panama port deal
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMr Li Ka-shing’s CK Hutchison group agreed to sell its Panama port operations to US investors, a move that is said to have angered Beijing.
– Shares in Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing’s CK Hutchison Holdings rallied after one of his sons was invited to mix with senior Chinese officials and global executives at a high-profile meeting in Beijing over the weekend amid the company’s controversial sale of its ports in Panama .
The flagship conglomerate of Mr Li Ka-shing’s global business empire, CK Hutchison has been caught in the crosshairs of increasing tensions between the US and China.
CK Hutchison is expected to sign the agreement involving the sale of its two Panama ports by April 2.
Several prominent Hong Kong politicians have also weighed in on the deal, with the city’s leader John Lee vowing to handle the deal “in accordance with the law and regulations”.

title: AI boom turns Asian data centres into magnets for loan deals
summary:
– Artificial intelligence (AI) advances are fuelling a funding frenzy for data centres in Asia, spawning a series of record-breaking loans and filling the pipeline with even more potential deals.
In the span of a week, two major Asian data centre operators secured their biggest-ever loans, partly earmarked for the expansion of their operations in Malaysia, which is becoming a hub for these facilities.
The deals underscore the industry’s appeal in attracting a range of investors – from banks to real estate players – as the AI boom drives demand.
The state has about 30 data centre projects completed or under construction, plus 20 more awaiting approvals.
“Consequently, investors may demand higher risk premiums or choose to divest from projects tied to Chinese entities, potentially stalling growth in the South-east Asian data centre market.” BLOOMBERG

title: China promotes business potential to Apple, Pfizer and other US companies
summary:

title: Diverging US economic data begs the question: Is a slowdown coming?
summary:
– US economic data are diverging wildly, fuelling a debate over whether rising anxiety from President Donald Trump’s trade policies will push a moderating economy into a serious downturn.
Surveys of sentiment among households and businesses, known as “soft data”, are warning of a marked slowdown ahead as Mr Trump pushes forward with tariffs and steep cuts to federal spending.
But “hard data” from government statistics, like employment and manufacturing, suggests those fears – potentially including stagflation or even recession – are overblown.
Then there is the hard data, which indicates the economy is cooling off but hardly dropping off.
“If that’s going to affect the hard data, we should know it very quickly.

title: Tesla’s retail fans buy the stock at a pace never seen before
summary:
Sales of Tesla cars have sunk in key European markets, such as France and Germany, as well as in China and Australia.
Even its most avid Wall Street bulls are turning cautious.
But one group is buying the electric vehicle maker’s shares like never before: chief executive Elon Musk’s fans.
The company has long had an ardent fan base of individual investors who hang on Mr Musk’s every word on X, the social media platform he owns.
They analyse Tesla in great detail in online forums and largely function as a hype crew for the stock.

title: US stocks shrug off economic jitters to close higher
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in New York City, on March 21.
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks closed higher on March 21 after fluctuations, shaking off ongoing economic uncertainty including those triggered by US President Donald Trump’s tariff plans – following his comments that these will contain some flexibility.
“There is certainly some hesitation, as we still have a lot of the trade uncertainties ahead of us with the April 2nd reciprocal tariff announcements,” said Mr Angelo Kourkafas, of Edward Jones.
On April 2, Mr Trump has promised reciprocal levies tailored to each US trading partner, to remedy practices deemed unfair by Washington.
Athletic footwear and apparel giant Nike saw its shares fall by 5.5 per cent after earlier reporting a decline in quarterly revenues.

title: Singapore’s competition watchdog gives green light to SIA-ANA cooperation for Singapore-Tokyo route
summary:
Singapore's competition regulator notes that the main competitors on the routes between the two cities are SIA and ANA.
SINGAPORE - Singapore’s competition watchdog on March 21 said it has conditionally approved a proposed commercial cooperation between Singapore Airlines and All Nippon Airways (ANA) after accepting their commitments to not infringe competition laws.
The carriers said their proposed cooperation would lead to several benefits.
“Most stakeholders did not raise concerns with the proposed commitments,” it said, adding that two stakeholders provided suggestions for “refinement”.
“After evaluating the feedback provided, CCCS considered the proposed commitments to be sufficient to mitigate the competition concerns arising from the proposed cooperation,” the watchdog said.

title: UOB chief Wee Ee Cheong’s pay down 5.5% to $15.05 million in 2024
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMr Wee Ee Cheong's annual remuneration comprises a base salary of $1.44 million, up from the $1.2 million in 2023, and a bonus of $13.56 million.
SINGAPORE – UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong was paid less in 2024 compared with his earnings in 2023, although his base salary increased.
Mr Wee’s $15.05 million pay package was 5.5 per cent lower than the $15.9 million he received in 2023, but still higher than the $14.2 million he racked up in 2022, according to the bank’s annual report, out on March 21.
His annual remuneration comprises a base salary of $1.44 million, up from the $1.2 million in 2023, and a bonus of $13.56 million, down from $14.7 million in 2023.
DBS Bank said in its annual report earlier in March that outgoing CEO Piyush Gupta received $17.58 million in total pay for 2024.

title: Singapore shares end down as trade war fears escalate; STI down 0.1%

Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxInvestors opted for a defensive stance and nudged the Straits Times Index down 0.1 per cent or 4.04 points to 3,926.45.
SINGAPORE – The four-day winning streak for local shares ended with barely a whimper on March 21 amid renewed fears of a trade war escalating.
The falls in recent weeks have left the once-high-flying Nasdaq down 8.3 per cent so far in 2025.
ST Engineering was the STI’s biggest decliner, sliding 4.2 per cent to $6.62 after hitting successive highs in recent weeks and outstripping other leading blue chips .

title: Temasek, Warburg Pincus-backed insurance group SRG embarks on aggressive regional expansion plan

title: Chocolate Finance says all withdrawals paid out; future requests to take three to six business days
summary:
SINGAPORE – Financial services platform Chocolate Finance has paid out all withdrawal requests made between March 10 and March 18, the firm announced on March 21.
Previously, withdrawals of up to $20,000 – or multiple withdrawals totalling that amount in a single day – were paid out instantly.
The firm told The Straits Times that it is unable to commit to a timeline for the resumption of instant withdrawals.
The MAS said on March 10 that it is querying ChocFin about its representations of its instant withdrawals programme.
Chocolate Finance declined to comment on the amount of withdrawals it has processed since March 10.

title: India’s $30.71 billion plan to rival China factories to lapse after it disappoints
summary:
As at October 2024, India issued less than 8 per cent of funds allocated for manufacturing incentives under the programme.
– Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government has decided to let lapse a US$23 billion (S$30.7 billion) programme to incentivise domestic manufacturing, just four years after it launched the effort to woo firms away from China, according to four government officials.
India had issued just US$1.73 billion in incentives – or under 8 per cent of the allocated funds, the document said.
Since the plan’s introduction, manufacturing’s share of the economy has decreased from 15.4 per cent to 14.3 per cent.
The incentives programme was “possibly the last chance we had to revive our manufacturing sector”, he added.

title: Prabowo faces investor revolt over Indonesia’s economic path
summary:
Indonesia President Prabowo Subianto has been causing unease with his populist spending measures and plans to dilute the central bank’s independence.
Singapore – For months, President Prabowo Subianto’s moves to chip away at Indonesia’s long-established economic guardrails have stoked anxiety in markets.
Mr Prabowo, 73, is now threatening to upend that trajectory.
“People in the markets are concerned about economic policymaking,” said Mr Achmad Sukarsono, lead analyst for Indonesia at Control Risks.
None of that bodes well for Mr Prabowo’s biggest pledge of all: boosting economic growth to 8 per cent.

title: Nike’s comeback bid threatened by inventory reset, tariffs
summary:
NEW YORK – Nike’s turnaround effort is hitting snags as the company tries to clear out old inventory while feeling the effects of a growing trade war.
Inventory fell 2 per cent in the period but chief financial officer Matt Friend said those levels remain “elevated across all categories”.
China also remained a weak spot, with sales missing analyst expectations amid a prolonged consumer slump in the market.
A company website shows Nike has 117 manufacturing locations in China and eight in Mexico.

title: FedEx cuts profit outlook again on mounting economic woes
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe parcel company is considered an economic bellwether because of its exposure to a broad swath of the global economy.
NEW YORK – FedEx lowered its full-year guidance for a third consecutive quarter as inflation and uncertain demand for shipments squeeze the parcel company’s bottom line.
Higher-than-expected inflation in the current quarter is putting pressure on costs, FedEx chief executive Raj Subramaniam said during a conference call with analysts.
The parcel company, considered an economic bellwether because of its exposure to a broad swath of the global economy, said its latest outlook assumes the global economic and political and trade environment do not worsen any further.

title: US stocks edge lower as Fed rally falters
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 20.
WASHINGTON – US stocks closed lower on March 20, as a Federal Reserve-related rally lost steam, and traders looked ahead to the prospect of additional tariffs in April.
The broad-based S&P 500 fell 0.2 per cent to 5,662.89, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.3 per cent to close at 17,691.63.
Among individual stocks, professional firm Accenture’s shares slumped 6.7 per cent after announcing that the Trump administration’s efficiency drive had begun affecting its business.
The business consulting firm said the cost-cutting drive, led by billionaire Trump ally Elon Musk, had hit its federal services business.

title: Perplexity AI in talks to raise funds at $24b valuation: Source
summary:
NEW YORK – Perplexity AI is in talks to raise funds at an US$18 billion (S$24.03 billion) valuation, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on March 20, as the Nvidia-backed start-up looks to grow and capture soaring demand for its search tools.
The jump in valuation doubles the previous US$9 billion figure, reported by Reuters in November.
The company has discussed raising between US$500 million and US$1 billion in the round, the source added.
The AI start-up has been upgrading features on its platform to better compete with Google’s Gemini and Microsoft-backed OpenAI’s ChatGPT.
Perplexity is among the leading firms attempting to challenge incumbents in the search engine market such as Alphabet’s Google.

title: Qoo10 Singapore creditors file $198M claims, only $34,650 recovered
summary:
SINGAPORE – More than $198 million in claims have been submitted by creditors to the liquidator of beleaguered online marketplace Qoo10, but only $34,650 has been recovered, according to minutes of the latest creditors’ meeting seen by The Straits Times.
According to the Jan 17 creditors’ meeting minutes, the liquidator received 322 claims totalling $250,441 from three preferential creditors and $197.9 million in unsecured claims.
The remaining 319 unsecured creditors’ claims comprised trade and customer payables, and intercompany payables or loans owed by Qoo10 to its related companies.
Qoo10’s liquidation follows mounting claims from its unpaid vendors, which triggered investigations by the authorities in both Singapore and South Korea.
Due to cash flow issues faced by Tmon and WeMakePrice, which accounted for a third of Qoo10’s sales, Qoo10 could not collect receivables.
