Feb 25, 2025: Mr Kwek Leng Beng files court papers to address an “attempted coup” by Mr Sherman Kwek and parties in concert.

title: Singapore shares fall as company earnings disappoint; STI down 0.2%
summary:
SINGAPORE – Disappointing corporate results from two index heavyweights prompted investors to send the local market down a notch on Feb 26 .
The fallout left the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.2 per cent or 7.82 points to 3,908.05, but on the broader market, gainers beat losers 330 to 236 after 1.5 billion securities worth $1.7 billion changed hands.
City Developments (CDL) was also in the doghouse after reporting a second-half earnings decline of 54.7 per cent to $113.5 million.
Trading in CDL shares was halted on Feb 26 after its board disagreed on its composition and constitution.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index rose 3.3 per cent, the Kospi in South Korea gained 0.4 per cent and Malaysian shares added 1.3 per cent.

title: Singapore factory output grows 9.1% in January
summary:
Excluding the more volatile biomedical industry, output increased 7.3 per cent, according to data from the Economic Development Board on Feb 26.
On a seasonally adjusted month-on-month basis, manufacturing output increased 4.5 per cent.
Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output increased 4.2 per cent.
Conversely, the output of the medical technology segment declined 3.5 per cent owing to lower export demand for medical devices.
The chemicals segment’s output declined 2.4 per cent in January compared with a year ago.

title: BP cuts renewable investment and boosts oil and gas in strategy shift
summary:
– BP slashed planned investment in renewable energy and said on Feb 26 that it would increase annual oil and gas spending to US$10 billion (S$13.4 billion), in a major strategy shift aimed at boosting earnings and investor confidence.
BP cut planned annual investment in renewable energy businesses by more than US$5 billion, from its previous forecast, to between US$1.5 billion and US$2 billion a year.
It now aims to grow oil and gas production to between 2.3 million and 2.5 million barrels of oil equivalent per day (boepd) in 2030.
Under Mr Auchincloss’ predecessor Bernard Looney, BP pledged in 2020 to cut oil and gas output by 40 per cent while rapidly growing renewables by 2030.
Mr Auchincloss said the transition to renewable energy has been slower than BP initially expected following the war in Ukraine, the Covid-19 pandemic, volatile energy markets and changing attitudes towards renewable energy in some countries.

title: Grand Venture posts 2024 profit jump on rising AI adoption, semiconductor demand
summary:
SINGAPORE – The growing adoption of advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI) helped drive up full-year earnings at precision engineering firm Grand Venture Technology (GVT).
Semiconductor revenue alone surged 64.9 per cent to $87.8 million in 2024 and was GVT’s largest contributor at 55 per cent of total turnover.
GVT said semiconductor revenue growth was also fuelled by strong demand from chip packaging firms, including customers making high bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, which boost data processing and storage.
“Our expanded involvement in advanced semiconductor manufacturing technologies will be key drivers for our future growth,” GVT said.
In Sept 2024, the company confirmed that it is in discussions for a secondary listing on the main market of Bursa Malaysia.

title: HSBC names Asia country, banking heads in CEO’s major revamp
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxHSBC's CEO is enacting sweeping changes at the Asia-focused lender to reduce costs, complexity and job duplication.
– HSBC Holdings gave country heads in some smaller Asian markets additional responsibilities as the lender streamlines and removes management layers.
Some commercial and global banking staff applied for roles and lost out, according to people familiar with the matter.
HSBC CEO Georges Elhedery, who took over in 2024, is enacting sweeping changes at the Asia-focused lender to reduce costs, complexity and job duplication.
In the “priority markets” of China, India and Singapore, HSBC named Mr Tang Zhenyi, Mr Ajay Sharma and Mr Gilbert Ng as heads of banking, it said.

title: Japan Post planning $5.4 billion sale of shares in Japan Post Bank, sources say
summary:
- Japan Post Holdings is planning to sell shares in Japan Post Bank which could total some 600 billion yen (S$5.4 billion), two sources familiar with the matter said, in the latest loosening of ties between the businesses.
That would give Japan Post Bank more freedom to do business, as restrictions intended to protect private companies would be relaxed.
Japan Post and Japan Post Bank said they are considering various options from a capital policy perspective, but no decisions have been made.
Japan Post, Japan Post Bank and Japan Post Insurance listed in 2015 in what was Japan’s largest privatisation in about three decades.
Japan Post cut its exposure to Japan Post Bank in 2023 and currently owns 61.5 per cent.

title: CDL’s Sherman Kwek disappointed over father’s ‘extreme actions’ on filing lawsuit over alleged coup
summary:
Mr Sherman Kwek stated that this legal action was taken despite it not being authorised by the majority of the board.
Mr Kwek Eik Sheng, who is in his early 40s, is the nephew of Mr Kwek Leng Beng.
(From left) CDL’s group CEO Sherman Kwek, executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and group chief operating officer Kwek Eik Sheng at the company’s results briefing in 2023.
“The undercurrent, if any, between Kwek Leng Beng and his son is not visible.
PHOTO: HONG LEONG GROUPMr Kwek Leng Peck is the cousin of Mr Kwek Leng Beng and the uncle of Mr Sherman Kwek.

title: Europe’s banks warn of hidden credit risk in sudden ESG retreat
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBanks in Europe have been waiting for years for their clients to start providing hundreds of data points under new ESG reporting rules.
Banks in Europe have been waiting for years for their clients to start providing hundreds of data points under new ESG reporting rules.
“Now, they’re not getting that.”Banks will, of course, continue to ask for sustainability data, Ms Cabanac said.
The US has also voiced displeasure at the design of Europe’s ESG rules, which force non-EU companies targeting the EU to comply.
Ms Wojnar said the EBA is now hoping that the basic data points that banks need “will remain available”, despite the expected rollback.

title: CDL’s Kwek Leng Beng seeks to fire son Sherman as CEO over ‘attempted coup’
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxCDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (left) has filed court papers against his son and group CEO Sherman Kwek.
Mr Lee stated “urgent concerns” as justification for the rushed appointments but failed to provide specifics, Mr Kwek Leng Beng claimed.
(From left) Mr Kwek Leng Beng with his younger son Kingston, wife Cecilia and elder son Sherman in 2008.
(From left) CDL’s group CEO Sherman Kwek, executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and group chief operating officer Kwek Eik Sheng at the company’s results briefing in 2023.
In 1971, Mr Kwek Leng Beng, his brother Kwek Leng Joo and their father Kwek Hong Png bought control of a loss-making CDL.

title: SingPost to hold EGM seeking approval for sale of its Australia logistics business
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore Post will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) seeking shareholders’ approval to sell its Australian logistics business.
However, given that FMH is a major contributor to SingPost’s overall profits, a sale would also raise questions about the company’s long-term growth potential.
SingPost expects to receive gross proceeds of approximately A$775.9 million and a profit of around S$289.5 million from the proposed sale of FMH.
The company intends to use the proceeds to repay A$362.1 million in debt taken to finance the acquisition of FMH.
A special dividend is also being considered, subject to the completion of the sale, SingPost said.

title: ANZ Bank trading probe among most complex ever, ASIC chief says
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxANZ is under scrutiny for its role in the execution of a 10-year Treasury bond sale in 2023.
– Australia’s corporate watchdog is on track to conclude its investigation into bond trading activities at ANZ Group Holdings by the middle of 2025, a probe the watchdog’s chief said was among the toughest in its history.
“It’s probably one of the most complex markets investigations we have ever undertaken,” Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) chairman Joe Longo said on Feb 26.
He expects the probe to end by the middle of 2025, reiterating a previously stated timeline.
ANZ is under scrutiny for its role in the execution of a 10-year Treasury bond sale in 2023.

title: CDL calls for trading halt, cancels results briefing
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxIn documents filed with SGX, CDL posted full-year results that showed a fall in both revenue and net profits.
SINGAPORE - Listed property developer City Developments Limited (CDL) called for a trading halt before the market opened on Feb 26.
Following the release of its request for trading halt announcement, the company also cancelled a briefing for its 2024 results, which had been scheduled for 10am on Feb 26, pending the release of further announcements.
In documents filed with the Singapore Exchange, CDL also posted full-year results that showed a substantial fall in both revenue and net profits.
CDL also posted more than $600 million in global asset divestments as part of its capital recycling initiative.

title: Americans are expecting higher prices - that could unnerve the Fed
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxOn Feb 25, a survey showed that consumer confidence fell sharply in February and inflation expectations rose.
- Fresh off the worst inflation shock in decades, Americans are once again bracing themselves for higher prices.
If those worries persist, it could be a political problem for Mr Trump, whose promise to control prices was a central part of his message during 2024’s campaign.
“We don’t want inflation expectations moving up so much that it makes the Fed’s job harder to get inflation back to 2 per cent.”Most economists see keeping inflation expectations in check as crucial to controlling inflation itself.
Officials at the central bank have so far downplayed concerns about inflation expectations.

title: Musk’s net worth drops almost $30 billion as Doge drives market unease
summary:
– Mr Elon Musk’s net worth fell by US$22.2 billion (S$29.7 billion) on Feb 25 – his fourth-largest one-day loss – as stock markets faltered on scepticism about potential tariffs and ongoing federal cost-cutting efforts.
Tesla, which makes up more than half of Mr Musk’s fortune, was particularly hard hit after reports that its sales in Europe – where Mr Musk’s favourability has tumbled as he inserted himself into domestic politics – plunged by almost half in January.
Mr Musk has spearheaded the effort to cut government spending through the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge).
Even with Feb 25’s decline to a net worth of US$358 billion, Mr Musk is still about US$100 billion richer than he was before Mr Trump won the election in November 2024, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
Thanks to record-high funding rounds for his private companies and a blistering Tesla rally that saw it reach a record before its recent sell-off, Mr Musk’s net worth reached an all-time high of US$486.4 billion on Dec 17.

title: Gold retreats from record high with Fed
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBullion slipped by as much as 2.1 per cent, and is trading about US$60 away from Feb 24’s fresh all-time high of US$2,956.19 an ounce.
– Gold retreated as investors took profits after another record-breaking session, with prices still supported by growing optimism over the timing of the next US Federal Reserve rate cut and increasing haven demand.
Bullion slipped by as much as 2.1 per cent, and is trading about US$60 away from Feb 24’s fresh all-time high of US$2,956.19 an ounce.
Swap markets now price in a quarter-point cut by the Fed in July.
Haven demand driven by ongoing uncertainty over Mr Trump’s trade and geopolitical agendas is also supportive of bullion prices.

title: US to probe need for tariffs on copper imports
summary:
- US President Donald Trump ordered an investigation on Feb 25 into possible levies on US copper imports, with officials citing a need to rebuild domestic production and safeguard national security – the latest salvo of the President’s tariff threats.
The world’s biggest economy has been increasingly reliant on copper imports to meet domestic consumption needs.
The imposition of tariffs or other trade barriers, however, could hit some of the US’ biggest suppliers, including Chile and Canada.
“To build back our copper industry, I will investigate the imposition of possible tariffs,” Mr Lutnick added.
Such probes focus on the harm that certain imports – in this case copper and derivatives – could have on US national security.

title: Coupang profit beats estimates, even as sales growth slows
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe online retailer’s net revenue rose 21 per cent to US$7.97 billion (S$10.65 billion) in the quarter ended Dec 31.
– Coupang, the largest e-commerce company focused on South Korea, handily beat profit estimates for the fourth quarter of 2024, even as sales grew more slowly than expected during the period.
The online retailer’s net revenue rose 21 per cent to US$7.97 billion (S$10.65 billion) in the quarter ended Dec 31 , compared with an average analyst projection of US$8.08 billion.
With initial backing from SoftBank Group Corp, Coupang has invested heavily to popularise overnight delivery in South Korea.
Alibaba in December 2024 agreed to team up with E-Mart’s e-commerce platform to better compete in the country’s fast-paced online retail sector.

title: Weak consumer confidence data hits US stocks as Tesla tumbles
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders working on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in New York City, on Feb 25.
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks mostly fell on Feb 25 following weak US consumer confidence data, while Tesla shares dove on a big drop in European auto sales.
US consumer confidence in February saw its largest monthly decline since August 2021, according to a Conference Board survey that comes on the heels of other lacklustre US reports.
The broad-based S&P 500 shed 0.5 per cent to 5,955.25, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.4 per cent to 43,621.16.
“If confidence sags and consumers retrench, GDP growth will go down.”Upcoming data releases will give additional color on the US economy, with investors especially keen for Feb 28 inflation data.

title: OCBC to return $2.5b capital via special dividends and share buybacks, Q4 profit misses estimates
summary:
The total payout will amount to $3.82 billion, which is in line with the group’s target payout ratio of 50 per cent, said OCBC.
It also proposes a special dividend of 16 cents per share, bringing total dividend to $1.01 per share, which represents a total payout ratio of 60 per cent for 2024.
Wealth management income grew 13 per cent year on year to $4.89 billion.
It accounted for 34 per cent of total income, up from 32 per cent a year earlier.
This is driven by an increase of 14 per cent in banking wealth management assets under management (AUM) to $299 billion.

title: Treasury’s Bessent vows to re-privatise a US economy that is ‘brittle underneath’
summary:
In the wide-ranging speech, Mr Bessent blamed “prolific overspending” under former president Joe Biden and regulations that have hindered supply-side growth as the main drivers of “sticky inflation”.
“The private sector has been in recession,” Mr Bessent said.
Mr Bessent said Mr Trump’s planned tariffs were an essential part of this plan, with three main goals.
In deciding on reciprocal tariff rates, Mr Trump’s administration, including the Treasury, will examine a wide range of factors, including other countries’ tariff rates, non-tariff barriers and currency practices, Mr Bessent said.
Asked about how Australia, which has a free-trade agreement with the US, was doing in this regard, Mr Bessent said, “so far, so good, but I’m not USTR”, referring to the Office of the US Trade Representative.

title: US consumer confidence posts biggest drop in over 3 years
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAmericans appear to be growing anxious about the potential negative impact on the economy of US President Donald Trump’s policies.
- US consumer confidence deteriorated at its sharpest pace in 3½ years in February, while 12-month inflation expectations surged, offering further signs that Americans were growing anxious about the potential negative impact on the economy of President Donald Trump’s policies.
It comes on the heels of surveys last week showing steep declines in business and consumer sentiment in February.
“The economy could well grind to a halt in the first quarter of the year as consumers stay home.”The Conference Board’s consumer confidence index dropped seven points – the biggest decline since August 2021 - to 98.3 this month.
The US central bank paused cutting interest rates in January while policymakers monitored the economic impact of the Trump administration’s policies.

title: Tesla shares slump 9% on disappointing Europe sales
summary:
- Shares of the US electric vehicle pioneer Tesla slumped 9 per cent on Feb 25, as investors digested disappointing European sales and chief executive Elon Musk’s aggressive foray into politics.
The auto giant sold less than 10,000 units in Europe in January, down 45 per cent from a year earlier.
The fall in Tesla’s share price dragged its market capitalisation back below US$1 trillion (S$1.3 trillion) for the first time since November 2024.
Mr Musk has taken on a controversial advisory role in US President Donald Trump’s administration, charged with slashing government spending.
Alongside its European struggles, Tesla also faces stiff competition from automakers like BYD in China – a key market for electric vehicles.

title: CDL’s Sherman Kwek says source of discord lies with Kwek Leng Beng’s adviser, Catherine Wu
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMr Sherman Kwek (right), son of billionaire Kwek Leng Beng (left), revealed that the underlying reason that led to the public fallout at the company was his father’s adviser, Dr Catherine Wu.
Dr Wu served as a director at M&C, the hotel subsidiary of Mr Kwek Leng Beng’s business empire, until her service was terminated in January 2024.
The older Mr Kwek added that lapses of corporate governance at CDL and its subsidiaries have been halted.
In response, the senior Mr Kwek filed court papers to “restore corporate integrity”, and intends to replace his son as CEO.
CDL said Mr Sherman Kwek will remain as CEO until a formal board resolution is passed to change the company’s leadership.

title: Sherman Kwek, alleged ‘attempted coup’ camp appoint lawyers in court battle for CDL board control
summary:
SINGAPORE - City Developments Limited (CDL) group chief executive Sherman Kwek and six board directors, called out by CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng for an “attempted coup” to take control of the board, have appointed lawyers to represent them in court.
On one side is Mr Kwek Leng Beng, supported by board directors Philip Yeo, Colin Ong and Chong Yoon Chou.
On Feb 25, Mr Kwek Leng Beng’s camp filed High Court papers to “set things right”.
“This is necessary to address the attempted coup and restore corporate integrity,” said Mr Kwek Leng Beng, who turns 84 in 2025.
The irregularly constituted nominating and remuneration committee has also been suspended from further actions, the older Mr Kwek said.

title: Singapore stocks rise 0.3% despite Yangzijiang Shipbuilding dive
summary:
SINGAPORE – Positive corporate earnings and a general lift in sentiment on Wall Street overnight put local investors in the mood to step up trading on Feb 27.
Gains on the STI were led by CapitaLand Investment, which added 4.8 per cent to $2.62 after announcing a bumper payout to shareholders.
Sentiment also improved on Wall Street with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq shaking off a four-day decline, although tariff concerns resurfaced.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.43 per cent, while the S&P 500 was flat and the Nasdaq rose 0.26 per cent.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng lost 0.3 per cent, South Korea’s Kospi fell 0.7 per cent and Malaysian stocks ticked down 0.1 per cent but the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo rose 0.3 per cent.

title: CapitaLand Investment back in the black in H2, proposes special dividend
summary:
The group swung to a net profit of $148 million for the six months to December, from a net loss of $170 million in the year-ago period.
Excluding gains or losses from divestments, revaluations and impairments, operating net profit fell 4 per cent to $214 million.
For the full year, net profit surged 165 per cent to $479 million, from $181 million in 2023.
This brings the total dividend for 2024 to about 18 cents, with a total payout of about $904 million.
Maybank is maintaining its buy recommendation as the stock “remains below book and on the higher payout positive surprise”.

title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding loses $3b in market value this week after shares sink for 4th day
summary:
SINGAPORE – Shares of mainboard-listed Yangzijiang Shipbuilding plunged for a fourth straight day as a US proposal to impose fees on Chinese-built vessels entering American ports continued to batter the stock.
The sell-off has wiped about $3 billion off the Chinese shipbuilder’s market value, with its shares falling 24 per cent in four days.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding is one of the largest non-state-owned shipbuilding companies in China.
On Feb 26, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 50.5 per cent year-on-year jump in net profit to 3.6 billion yuan (S$665.2 million) for the second half ended Dec 31, 2024.
For the full year, it reported a net profit of 6.6 billion yuan, up 61.7 per cent from 4.1 billion yuan a year prior.

title: Tariffs on China risk hurting US economy more than data suggests
summary:
Since returning to the White House in January, US President Donald Trump has imposed a new 10 per cent tariff on Chinese goods.
– New research suggests US President Donald Trump’s latest tariffs on imports from China could hit the American economy more than official US trade data indicates.
US data shows that imports from China declined to 13.4 per cent of total imports in 2024 from 21.6 per cent in 2018.
De minimis exemptionThe hit will be amplified if Mr Trump does away with an exemption threshold for direct-to-consumer imports.
Since returning to the White House in January, Mr Trump has imposed a new 10 per cent tariff on Chinese goods.

title: 7-Eleven owner’s shares plunge as family buyout fails
summary:
– Seven & i Holdings’ shares plunged after a proposed nine trillion yen (S$80.7 billion) management buyout led by the convenience store chain’s founding family collapsed.
The stock closed down 11 per cent on Feb 27, the largest fall on an intraday basis on record, slicing the 7-Eleven owner’s market value to around US$33 billion (S$44.3 billion).
If the buyout plan falls over, Seven & i chief executive Ryuichi Isaka may have little choice but to enter negotiations with Couche-Tard.
In its statement on Feb 27, Seven & i said it “remains committed to exploring all opportunities to unlock value for shareholders” and continues to assess Couche-Tard’s proposal.
Couche-Tard signalled its interest more than six months ago, then increased its proposed price in September 2024.

title: Maybank teams up with SME association to help firms expand in Johor-Singapore economic zone
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSINGAPORE – Maybank Singapore signed an agreement on Feb 27 that aims to help smaller firms expand in the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ).
The bank, South-east Asia’s fourth-largest by assets, will also offer green lane financing in Malaysia for loans of up to RM20 million ($6.04 million).
Maybank Singapore said the number of inquiries and referrals from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) about doing business in Johor jumped 250 per cent in 2024 compared with 2023.
Maybank Singapore country chief executive Alvin Lee told The Straits Times that the biggest pain point that firms here face is the high cost of doing business.
By working with Maybank, we can create these pathways.”ASME represents around 6,500 large, small and medium-sized companies across a range of industries.

title: Nissan prepares to replace CEO after Honda deal falls apart
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxNissan is drawing up plans to replace CEO Makoto Uchida following another dismal set of earnings and the collapse of talks to combine with Honda, sources say.
Nissan directors are gauging interest in potential candidates to succeed Mr Makoto Uchida, the 22-year company veteran who has been CEO since late 2019, one of the people said.
Mr Uchida looked to Honda for help late in 2024, striking a tentative agreement to combine under a joint holding company.
Mr Uchida was clear-eyed during a Feb 13 press conference about how pivotal tie-ups will be to Nissan’s future.
Mr Uchida announced plans in November 2024 to trim 9,000 jobs and a fifth of the company’s production capacity.

title: Sembcorp full-year profit up 7% to $1b; final dividend more than doubles to 17 cents
summary:
Its board of directors proposed a final dividend of 17 cents per share, more than double the eight cents declared a year ago.
Together with the interim dividend of six cents per share paid in August 2024, the total dividend for 2024 will be 23 cents per share.
The renewables segment also saw net profit fall by 9 per cent to $183 million in 2024.
It was hit by curtailment in China during the year, and lower wind speeds in India in the second half of 2024, Sembcorp said.
For the second half-year, net profit rose 14 per cent to $471 million from $412 million in the year-ago period.

title: Nvidia sales grow 78%, showing AI boom not dead even as breakneck pace of growth slows
summary:
DeepSeek, a Chinese start-up, said it had made its AI systems with a small fraction of the AI chips used by other companies, and at a small fraction of the cost.
On Feb 26, Nvidia showed those fears were overblown, even as the breakneck pace of its growth slows.
Nvidia’s business has been buoyed by the biggest tech companies’ non-stop spending on AI data centres.
It is rolling out a new, more powerful series of AI chips known as Blackwell and charges US$60,000 to US$70,000 for a signature chip.
How long the building of data centres will last has been a question since the start of the AI boom.

title: Google axes employees in cloud division
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThroughout 2024, Google made cuts that slowly rippled across the company as it went through a process of reorganisation unit by unit.
– Alphabet’s Google on Feb 26 cut staff in its cloud division, according to people familiar with the matter.
Throughout 2024, Google made cuts that slowly rippled across the company as it went through a process of reorganisation unit by unit.
The cloud layoffs come as the tech industry’s culling of its corporate workforces has become all but standard in a new year.
Google Cloud, which is regarded as one of the company’s best bets for growth as the search business matures, remains a key area of investment.

title: Nasdaq rises while Dow falls on latest Trump tariff talk
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in New York City.
NEW YORK - Gains in Nvidia ahead of earnings helped lift the Nasdaq on Feb 26, while the Dow retreated on White House talk of more tariffs, this time on the European Union.
Stocks have been under pressure in recent days due to lacklustre US economic data and worries about Mr Donald Trump’s policies.
During a Cabinet meeting, the US president said he expects 25 per cent tariffs on the European Union.
The broad-based S&P 500 was flat at 5,956.06, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3 per cent to 19,075.26.

title: Qatar Airways wins approval for 25% stake in Virgin Australia
summary:
– Canberra will let Qatar Airways buy a 25 per cent stake in troubled airline Virgin Australia, a senior government minister said on Feb 27, injecting foreign competition into the nation’s Qantas-dominated aviation sector.
Qatar will pay an undisclosed sum to acquire a minority stake in Virgin Australia after the deal was blessed by Australia’s competition watchdog.
Virgin Australia started bankruptcy proceedings in 2020, laying off hundreds of staff as the Covid-19 outbreak grounded international flights.
Three Australian women lodged legal action against Qatar Airways following the ordeal, although the case was eventually dismissed.
Qatar Airways chief executive Badr Mohammed Al-Meer said in 2024 that the proposed Qatar-Virgin tie-up would be good for Australians.

title: New CDL directors won’t exercise powers until court’s further notice: Kwek Leng Beng
summary:
SINGAPORE – The two new directors at City Developments Limited (CDL), who are at the centre of a disagreement between executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his son, group chief executive Sherman Kwek, have undertaken not to exercise any powers in their role until further notice by the Singapore court, Mr Kwek Leng Beng said.
The CDL board approved their appointments as independent non-executive directors on Feb 7, a move that was questioned by Mr Kwek Leng Beng.
CDL’s group CEO Sherman Kwek and his father, executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng, at a media briefing on Feb 28, 2024.
PHOTO: CDL“The two new directors, irregularly and hastily appointed on Feb 7 by means of directors’ resolutions in writing, have undertaken not to exercise any powers as directors until further notice of the court,” Mr Kwek Leng Beng said in the statement , giving an update on the High Court hearing .
“The board committees and the management of the relevant subsidiaries are now safe from further attempts to destabilise , dismantle and reconstitute them,” Mr Kwek Leng Beng said.

title: What to know about CDL’s father-and-son duo and other family members in the business
summary:
Here are some things to know about Mr Kwek Leng Beng and his family:1.
Trained as a lawyer in London, Mr Kwek Leng Beng got into the family business in the 1960s and focused on running CDL’s operations in Singapore.
Mr Kwek Hong Png (centre) and his two sons, Mr Kwek Leng Joo (left) and Mr Kwek Leng Beng.
(From left) CDL’s group CEO Sherman Kwek, executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and group chief operating officer Kwek Eik Sheng at the company’s results briefing in 2023.
Mr Kwek Leng Peck, CDL’s former non-executive and non-independent director, quit in 2020Mr Kwek Leng Peck, 69, is Mr Kwek Leng Beng’s cousin and Mr Sherman Kwek’s uncle.

title: 13,000 DBS staff to learn AI, data skills amid bank’s plans to cut 4,000 workers over 3 years
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDBS said they expect the reduction in workforce will come from natural attrition.
SINGAPORE - DBS Bank has identified about 13,000 staff for upskilling or reskilling and over 10,000 of them have started training for artificial intelligence (AI) and data-related skills, the bank said on Feb 25.
“We will continue to invest in upskilling and reskilling our employees to enable them to be future-ready,” a DBS spokesperson said.
DBS said they expect the reduction in workforce will come from natural attrition as these temporary and contract roles are completed over the next few years.
Outgoing chief executive Piyush Gupta said there are 8,000 to 9,000 of such contract and temporary staff, according to the Bloomberg report .

title: Singapore shares in the red as regional indexes fall; STI retreats 0.3%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.3 per cent or 11.88 points to 3,915.87.
SINGAPORE - Equities in Singapore closed Feb 25 in the red, tracking regional losses.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3 per cent or 11.88 points to 3,915.87.
In Singapore, the top gainer on the STI was Mapletree Logistics Trust, which added 1.6 per cent or two cents to $1.24.
DBS Bank added 0.4 per cent or 20 cents to $46.55, while UOB lost 0.4 per cent or 15 cents to $38.20.

title: Tesla sales fall 45% in Europe amid political blowback to Elon Musk
summary:
- Tesla’s sales in January plunged 45 per cent across Europe, where rival carmakers saw a surge in electric vehicle (EV) demand.
After emerging as a leading donor to Mr Donald Trump during 2024’s US election cycle, Mr Musk set his sights on Europe, backing far-right parties and attacking incumbents.
Mr Musk also called for the imprisonment of British Prime Minister Keir Starmer in January while advocating for the release of jailed far-right activists.
Changing over assembly lines for the Model Y also may have had an effect on its January registrations.
The company builds the Model Y at four plants globally, including at its factory outside Berlin.

title: Alibaba shares plunge as Trump order stirs China trade angst
summary:
– Alibaba Group Holding shares tumbled as US President Donald Trump’s latest executive order stirred fears about deepening trade tensions between the United States and China.
Alibaba shares in Hong Kong on Feb 25 slumped 3.8 per cent, as a gauge of Chinese shares tumbled 2.8 per cent.
The company’s American depositary receipts fell 10 per cent overnight on Feb 24, the biggest decline since October 2022.
Alibaba had gained about 70 per cent in 2025 through Feb 21’s close, while the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index rose 18 per cent.
Over the weekend, Mr Trump directed the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US to limit Chinese spending on technology and other strategic US sectors.

title: Trump team seeks to toughen Biden’s chip controls over China
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Trump administration is eyeing more Nvidia curbs and Chinese company sanctions.
Trump officials recently met with their Japanese and Dutch counterparts about restricting Tokyo Electron and ASML Holding Engineers from maintaining semiconductor gear in China, according to people familiar with the matter.
Some Trump officials also aim to further restrict the quantity and type of Nvidia chips that can be exported to China without a licence, said some of the people.
It could take months before the talks produce any new US regulations, as Mr Trump makes staffing decisions at key federal agencies.
Some Trump officials want to reduce that threshold, people familiar with the matter said, which would expand the scope of the licence requirement.

title: S’pore-listed Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares tumble after US proposes port fees for Chinese-built vessels
summary:
SINGAPORE - Shares of mainboard-listed Yangzijiang Shipbuilding tumbled for a second straight day after the United States Trade Representative’s (USTR) office proposed imposing a fee on Chinese-built vessels entering US ports.
The USTR in a notice published on Feb 21 laid out its proposed fees and other shipping restrictions on Chinese vessels.
The fee drops to US$750,000 for fleets with 25 per cent to 50 per cent Chinese-built vessels, and US$500,000 for fleets with less than 25 per cent.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding is one of the largest non-state-owned shipbuilding companies in China.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding is expected to report its full-year earnings by Feb 28.

title: Great Eastern Q4 profit falls 14% to $134.8 million
summary:
SINGAPORE - Great Eastern on Feb 25 reported a net profit of $134.8 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, down 14 per cent from $157.2 million in the previous corresponding period.
Excluding this impact, NBEV in the fourth quarter would have been $197.4 million, down 13 per cent year on year.
Barring unforeseen circumstances, Great Eastern said it “aims to maintain each dividend amount to be no lower than the preceding one”.
However, it did result in Great Eastern breaching the minimum free float requirement and its shares were suspended from trading.
SGX had no objection to granting the extension and Great Eastern has until May 25 to explore options.

title: China’s defence of currency takes toll on big banks, bond funds
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina’s strategy of defending its currency by choking local liquidity is sending ripples throughout the financial system, squeezing banks and fuelling losses at bond funds.
– China’s strategy of defending its currency by choking local liquidity is sending ripples throughout the financial system, squeezing banks and fuelling losses at bond funds.
The latest sign of a cash crunch at Chinese banks is a sharp drop in their lending through repurchase contracts, or repo.
“This may exacerbate the selling pressure in the bond market and pose a risk of negative feedback loop,” he added.
The ripple effects for banks and bond funds in the country show how China’s determination to defend its currency is increasingly becoming a problem for investors.

title: Nasdaq closes down as AI caution weighs on tech, Nvidia results in focus

“The dominance of the AI tech trade has run its course, not that these companies aren’t great stocks.
Berkshire Hathaway shares and hit record highs in early trading, after Mr Warren Buffett’s conglomerate reported a record annual profit.

title: Starbucks cuts 1,100 corporate jobs to speed up turnaround
summary:
Starbucks is eliminating 1,100 corporate jobs in a move aimed at increasing efficiency and quickly enacting changes to revitalise the company.
Starbucks doesn’t disclose how many corporate workers it has, and the bulk of its employees around the world work in its cafes.
Workers who are losing their jobs will be notified by Feb 25, according to an announcement.
Southwest Airlines said earlier this month that it planned to cut 15 per cent of corporate jobs in its first-ever round of layoffs.
Starbucks has said that Mr Niccol will spend most of his time in Seattle or visiting stores.

title: Apple plans $669 billion in US investment, 20,000 research jobs in next four years
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxApple will add about 20,000 research and development jobs across the US in four years.
Apple said on Feb 24 it would spend US$500 billion (S$669 billion) in US investments in the next four years that will include a giant factory in Texas for artificial intelligence servers and add about 20,000 research and development jobs across the country in that time.
That US$500 billion in expected spending includes everything from purchases from US suppliers to US filming of television shows and movies for its Apple TV+ service.
Davidson, noting that the US$500 billion likely includes all of Apple’s spending in the US, including general and administrative costs.
Mr Trump, in a Truth Social post, thanked Apple and Mr Cook, saying the move reflected the company’s faith in his administration.

title: SoftBank, Temasek among eFishery investors facing near wipeout
summary:
The fallen start-up, whose financial backers include SoftBank Group and Singapore’s Temasek Holdings, had been a star of Indonesia’s start-up scene.
eFishery was valued at US$1.4 billion in 2023 after it raised US$200 million from Abu Dhabi’s 42XFund and some of its earlier investors.
In all, global investors plowed around US$315 million into eFishery’s preferred shares over five funding rounds, according to the presentation.
SoftBank didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment outside regular business hours, while a Temasek spokesperson declined to comment.
The company had claimed to have more than 400,000 fish feeders deployed, and investigators initially estimated the number was closer to 24,000.

title: Singapore shares slide after MAS unveils stock market measures; STI down 0.1%
summary:
SINGAPORE - Equities in Singapore were marginally lower at the end of the first trading session after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) unveiled plans to boost the stock market.
Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 298 to 286, after 1.4 billion securities worth $1.7 billion changed hands.
The STI’s top counter was property developer UOL, which rose 5.9 per cent or 30 cents to $5.39.
It is being developed by a joint venture between UOL, Singapore Land and CapitaLand Development.
It rose 3.9 per cent or 50 cents to $13.30, buoyed by investors’ positive sentiment towards MAS’ initiatives.

title: DBS expects to shrink contract and temp jobs by 4,000 over next 3 years as AI replaces roles
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxReductions will come from natural attrition, DBS said, and permanent staff will not be affected.
SINGAPORE – DBS Group Holdings expects to reduce its contract and temporary staff by around 4,000 over the next three years as artificial intelligence (AI) increasingly takes on roles carried out by humans, outgoing chief executive officer Piyush Gupta said.
DBS has 8,000 to 9,000 of such workers, according to Mr Gupta, who said permanent staff will not be affected.
Still, many firms have stressed that the shift will result in roles being changed by technology, rather than replaced altogether.
Ms Teresa Heitsenrether, who oversees JPMorgan Chase’s AI efforts, said in November 2024 that the bank’s adoption of generative AI was so far augmenting jobs.

title: S’pore core inflation falls sharply in January to 0.8% as price rises ease, CPI is rebased
summary:
This is the lowest since June 2021, when core inflation was 0.6 per cent, and also beat a Bloomberg analysts’ forecast of 1.5 per cent.
On a month-on-month basis, which shows the momentum in prices, core inflation and overall inflation fell to minus 0.2 per cent and minus 0.7 per cent, respectively.
It kept its forecast for overall inflation forecast unchanged at 1.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent on an anticipated pickup in private transport inflation.
Maybank economist Chua Hak Bin said the sharp month-on-month fall in core inflation was a surprise, and that the decline was not because January 2024 had a higher inflation base.
Services inflation dipped to 1 per cent in January from 1.6 per cent in December.

title: Fund managers welcome MAS’ $5b boost for stock market; SGX shares up nearly 4%
summary:
MAS surprised the market when it launched a $5 billion programme where the funds will be channelled to selected Singapore fund managers to invest in Singapore stocks.
These were among the first set of measures recommended by the review group set up in August 2024 to strengthen the local stock market.
“If the fund managers really go out to hunt for stocks, this will improve liquidity.
AGT Partners chief executive Gregory See agreed that the $5 billion programme is a good starting point, although the amount may be modest compared with the overall market capitalisation of the stock market.
“We have a lot of global fund managers based in Singapore who have Asia programmes that could redeploy and boost,” he said.

title: Elon Musk’s Starlink races with Chinese rivals to dominate satellite internet
summary:
The billionaire’s Starlink communications network is facing increasingly stiff challenges to its dominance of high-speed satellite internet, including from a Chinese state-backed rival and another service financed by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos.
Starlink has since 2020 launched more satellites into low-earth orbit (LEO) – an altitude of less than 2,000km – than all its competitors combined.
China launched a record 263 LEO satellites in 2024, according to data from astrophysicist Jonathan McDowell analysed by tech consultancy Analysys Mason.
It has announced plans to deploy 648 LEO satellites in 2025 and as many as 15,000 by 2030.
Starlink currently has about 7,000 satellites, according to Dr McDowell, and has set itself a target of operating 42,000 by the end of the decade.

title: Raffles Medical shares jump 6.7% on new dividend policy, share buyback plan
summary:
SINGAPORE - Private healthcare provider Raffles Medical Group has revised its dividend policy to pay out at least 50 per cent of its sustainable earnings annually.
Shares of Raffles Medical jumped when trading opened, with the counter up five cents, or 6.1 per cent, at 87.5 cents at the midday trading break.
Its healthcare services division registered revenue growth of 4.1 per cent from $283.4 million to $295.1 million.
Looking ahead, Raffles Medical said it is “optimistic” that the company will remain profitable in 2025.
Raffles Medical said the company’s three general hospitals in Beijing, Shanghai and Chongqing demonstrated strong potential for growth and a positive outlook ahead .

title: China developers buy land at 20% premium in bet on market bottom
summary:
Seven out of the 10 transactions in 2025 involved state buyers, including China Resources Land, China Overseas Land & Investment, Poly Developments and Holdings Group, and mixed-ownership firm Greentown China Holdings.
Most of the land parcels sold are small, according to China Real Estate Information.
That has prompted more developers to compete for quality land parcels, especially in economic hubs such as Shanghai and nearby Hangzhou.
Changsha, the capital of central Hunan province, stipulated that developers’ profits should not exceed single digits relative to the land cost.
State giant China Overseas Land & Investment splurged 11 billion yuan on it.

title: Alibaba to invest $70 billion in AI over next 3 years in major pivot
summary:
- Alibaba Group Holding pledged on Feb 24 to invest more than 380 billion yuan (S$70 billion) in artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure such as data centres over the next three years, a major commitment that underscores the e-commerce pioneer’s ambitions of becoming a leader in the field.
The Chinese company is righting a business knocked off-kilter by a government clampdown that began in 2020, refocusing its ambitions on e-commerce and AI.
Alibaba’s three-year timeline lags behind its US peers: Microsoft for one expects to spend US$80 billion (S$107 billion) this fiscal year on AI data centres, while Meta has earmarked some US$65 billion for 2025.
Alibaba has gained more than US$100 billion of market value in 2025, though it is still far from its pre-crackdown peak.
Apple is incorporating Alibaba’s AI technology into Chinese iPhones, a vote of confidence in its prowess.

title: WiseTech board quits as founder triumphs in power struggle; shares of Aussie firm plummet
summary:
The resignations follow “intractable differences in the board and differing views” around Mr White’s position at WiseTech.
The bombshell announcement, almost unheard of in corporate Australia, cements Mr White’s influence at the freight software company he founded and led for three decades.
Four months on, the board has disintegrated, and Mr White is back at the top of the business.
Mr White is so closely associated with WiseTech’s value that cutting him loose would have risked a stock market rout.
Two fresh confidential complaints about Mr White, made by an employee and a supplier, compounded the pressure on WiseTech’s directors to take more substantive action.

title: S’pore-listed Olam to make $2.46 billion gain from sale of stake in agribusiness unit; shares surge
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Saudi buyer has three years to exercise a call option on the rest of Olam Agri that Olam Group owns.
The Saudi firm has three years to exercise a call option on the remaining 19.99 per cent stake in Olam Agri that Olam Group owns.
Olam Agri, which sells grains and seeds and makes everything from edible oils to pasta, was created in a rejig of Olam’s structure in 2020.
The most recent deal now values Olam Agri at US$4 billion, 23 per cent higher than its current market capitalisation, according to Olam Group.
On completion of the 44.6 per cent stake sale, Olam Group will realise an estimated gain on disposal of US$1.84 billion (S$2.46 billion), it said.

title: New wave of workforce moves need to provide targeted help for workers, employers: Industry players
summary:
It expands on the SkillsFuture Mid-Career Training Allowance for mid-career workers undergoing full-time training previously unveiled in Budget 2024.
Moreover, workers who still need to pay for all or part of the course fees themselves may be in greater need of help, compared with those funded by employers.
For these courses, the WSS will take after the mid-career training allowance under the SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme, albeit with a lower age limit of 30 rather than 40.
Other than helping workers already in the workforce, the latest measures have the potential to draw more people into the workforce too, some observers say.
These workers may face difficulties as the full-time mid-career training allowance does not apply to individuals who have been unemployed for more than a year.

title: UOB peaks above $39 while Seatrium slips; MAS surprises with $5b plan to invest in S’pore stocks
summary:
SINGAPORE – UOB shares hit an all-time high of $39.20 last week, buoyed by record net profits in 2024 and treats for shareholders in the form of dividends.
A $2 billion share buyback plan, where UOB shares will be purchased by the bank and subsequently cancelled, was also announced.
He acquired 200,000 UOB shares on Feb 19 at an average price of $38.65 per share.

title: How firms can tap information to drive digital transformation
summary:

title: Shein's annual profit down by more than a third, FT reports
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxShein's net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion (S$1.34 billion) in 2024.
- Online fast-fashion retailer Shein’s profit dropped by more than a third in 2024, adding to its challenges ahead of a planned listing on the London Stock Exchange, the Financial Times reported on Feb 23.
Net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion (S$1.34 billion) in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.
Shein’s sales for the full year rose by 19 per cent to US$38 billion, the report said, adding that the figures were from internal projections ahead of finalised accounts.
Bloomberg reported last week that Shein was under pressure to cut its valuation as low as US$30 billion.

title: European tech sector sees unexpected rebound on AI windfall
summary:
European technology giants are exceeding expectations this quarter, joining financial and healthcare companies as one of the reporting season’s best-performing segments.
The MSCI Europe Index’s 1.1 per cent per-share earnings growth is also ahead of expectations of a 1.3 per cent decline.
Along with healthcare and financial companies, technology is one of three sub-indexes that have surprised most positively so far this season.
The company is set to benefit from surging demand for chipmaking machines as companies are spending heavily on AI.
SAP raised its revenue outlook for 2025 and reported 29 per cent growth in its cloud backlog, as clients increasingly take up its AI business services offering.

title: Universal’s theme parks, long in Disney’s shadow, expand at dizzying pace
summary:
“How high is up?”When Mr Mark Woodbury became Universal’s theme park chief in 2022, he pressed his lieutenants to answer that question.
Universal’s parks had already become a surprise growth engine for NBCUniversal, but Mr Woodbury saw an even bigger opportunity to lift the business firmly out of Disney’s shadow.
As businesses, theme parks come with numerous risks.
Epic Universe will open in May with rides themed to the How To Train Your Dragon franchise.
“When I saw it, my first reaction was, ‘This is a theme park waiting to happen’,” he said.

title: How Gen Zs and millennials can build their retirement nest eggs
summary:
This could comprise liquid assets such as cash, Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings and income from other sources such as payout from retirement income insurance, dividends from equities or rental income.
