The 2025 expectations show that Whirlpool’s efforts to raise prices and lower costs are not yet paying off.
In 2025 , the company said it expects to save about US$200 million in costs.
In the quarter, sales for this segment rose from the year prior, but trailed expectations.

title: Britain braces itself for another dismal year of declining car production
summary:
LONDON – Automakers produced fewer cars in Britain in 2024, and output is poised to fall again in 2025 – potentially to the lowest in more than 70 years.
Production is expected to drop to around 775,000 in 2025 , which would be in line with the number of cars manufactured in 2022.
“The level of demand isn’t there,” Mr Mike Hawes, chief executive of SMMT, told reporters on Jan 29.
The government phased out a plug-in car grant for private car purchasers in 2022.
“It can’t keep shaking it, to expect that it will just continue to effectively subsidize demand.”The outlook for car production in 2025 is tempered by Jaguar Land Rover – Britain’s No.

title: BOJ to slice almost $672 billion off balance sheet to decrease liquidity in economy
summary:
The BOJ decided on Jan 24 to offer no new lending from July under its fund-provisioning programme to stimulate bank lending.
That is another 6.5 trillion yen that will disappear from the balance sheet by January 2028.
Still, the Fed’s experience points to potential risks ahead for the BOJ as it tries to reduce its balance sheet without spooking markets.
All outstanding loans from the lending programme are expected to be wiped off the BOJ’s books by March 2028.
The central bank’s balance sheet stood at ¥740 trillion, according to the latest data.

title: IBM beats profit estimates as AI shift boosts software performance, shares surge
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe software segment recorded its biggest revenue jump in five years.
BENGALURU – IBM surpassed fourth-quarter profit estimates on Jan 29, driven by robust demand in its software unit as businesses ramped up IT spending, sending the company’s shares soaring about 10 per cent in extended trading.
The software segment recorded its biggest revenue jump in five years, as customers prioritised spending on cloud infrastructure amid a rush to adopt the data-intensive generative artificial intelligence technology.
Consulting weaknessIBM’s AI book is dominated by its consulting business, which accounts for about 80 per cent of it.
But revenue from the consulting segment fell about 2 per cent to US$5.2 billion in the quarter.

title: Las Vegas Sands misses profit estimates on weakness in Macau business
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Nevada-based company had previously flagged that it was seeing slowing growth in its integrated resorts and casino business at Macau properties.
BENGALURU – Casino operator Las Vegas Sands missed analysts’ estimates for fourth-quarter profit on Jan 29, hurt by tepid performance of its Macau business.
The Las Vegas, Nevada-based company had previously flagged that it was seeing slowing growth in its integrated resorts and casino business at Macau properties, including the Venetian Macau, which contribute a major part to the company’s net revenue.
Las Vegas Sands posted an adjusted profit of 54 US cents per share for the quarter ended Dec 31.
Revenue from Macau operations fell about 5 per cent to US$1.86 billion (S$2.51 billion).

title: Theft leaves British retailers with a record $3.7 billion in losses
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe cost of retail theft rose 21 per cent in the year to Aug 31, 2024, from the year before.
LONDON – Customer theft cost British retailers a record £2.2 billion (S$3.7 billion) in 2024 as they grappled with a persistent and worsening crime wave, a trade group said.
The cost of retail theft rose 21 per cent in the year to Aug 31, 2024, from the year before, the British Retail Consortium (BRC) said in its latest crime survey, published Jan 30.
“Retail crime is spiralling out of control,” said Ms Helen Dickinson, chief executive of the BRC.
The cost of prevention measures such as CCTV rose 52 per cent from £1.2 billion to about £1.8 billion in 2024, the BRC found.

title: Microsoft shares fall as cloud forecast disappoints Wall Street
summary:
Azure results for the fiscal second quarter also fell below Wall Street expectations.
Microsoft’s capital expenditures hit US$22.6 billion (S$30.52 billion), above analysts’ consensus estimate of US$20.95 billion, according to data from Visible Alpha.
Microsoft said earlier on Jan 29 it had added DeepSeek, the breakout Chinese AI model, to its offerings on Azure.
Microsoft said AI contributed 13 percentage points of Azure’s growth in its fiscal second quarter, up from 12 percentage points the previous quarter.
At the company’s Intelligent Cloud unit, which includes the Azure platform, revenue rose to US$25.54 billion, missing expectations of US$25.76 billion.

title: Sony makes change at top amid entertainment push
summary:
Mr Yoshida, 65, will stay on in his position as chair.
Before it lost its lead in recent decades, Sony was the first name in consumer electronics, churning out handfuls of iconic inventions like the Sony Walkman, which it introduced in 1979.
Mr Yoshida inherited from his predecessor, Mr Kazuo Hirai, a company that was no longer bleeding red ink.
During Mr Yoshida’s seven years leading Sony, the Japanese company spent billions of dollars building its vast empire of games, music and movies.
Mr Yoshida “solidly guided Sony’s turnaround”, said Ms Mika Nishimura, a senior analyst at Okasan Securities in Tokyo.

title: Nissan plans job, output cuts at US vehicle assembly plants
summary:
DETROIT – Nissan Motor is eliminating a work shift at two US vehicle assembly plants and trimming its hourly staff via buyouts, a downsizing to align its output with lower sales volumes as it mulls over a possible sale to Honda Motor.
He declined to say how many fewer cars Nissan expects to produce or the amount of the estimated cost-savings from the reductions.
Nissan has pledged to cut 9,000 jobs globally and reduce production capacity by 20 per cent.
The company notified hourly workers at the plants on Jan 29 and plans to communicate the cuts to suppliers within the next 24 hours.
Nissan expects to resume two-shift production at both factories when new models are introduced in 2027 and 2028.

title: Coffee’s 94% rally finally hits the last holdouts for demand
summary:
SAO PAULO – Coffee’s dizzying rally, which saw prices surge more than 90 per cent in 2024, has already hurt demand in most major markets.
With feeble demand growth in the US and Europe’s high-income countries, the industry has become increasingly reliant on consumers in emerging economies.
In Vietnam, industry groups are reporting that high prices are making some buyers hesitant to place large orders.
Consumers will likely become “more restrained”, said Mr Pavel Cardoso, president of Brazil’s coffee industry association Abic.
China’s “culture of coffee consumption is just at the beginning”, Mr Von Luehrte said.

title: Tesla’s profit fell sharply to $3.1 billion for last quarter of 2024
summary:
The company, which is led by billionaire Elon Musk, said it made a profit of US$2.3 billion (S$3.1 billion) during the last three months of 2024.
That was a decline compared with US$7.9 billion a year earlier, but 2023’s profit included a one-time tax benefit of US$5.9 billion.
Tesla’s operating profit, which excludes that special gain, fell 23 per cent in the final three months of the year.
Sales rose 2 per cent to US$25.7 billion in the fourth quarter, from US$25.2 billion in the same period in 2023.
For the full year , profit was US$7.1 billion, Tesla said, down from US$15 billion a year earlier.

title: Sustainability remains critical despite pullbacks from US banks: DBS
summary:
But Mr Muenkel said the alliance serves as a valuable platform for collective action towards achieving net-zero emissions, particularly in an Asian context.
Mr Muenkel added: “The time horizon is quite important.
DBS is also hiring people with expertise in sustainability, as it intends to integrate sustainability across the organisation, Mr Muenkel said.
Mr Muenkel noted that there might have been a little too much hype around sustainability a couple of years ago, but things are evolving.
In Asia, however, it is a different environment where there is still a lot of support from policymakers and regulators and positive momentum, Mr Muenkel noted.

title: TikTok bidder to offer ‘significantly’ more than $27 billion
summary:
NEW YORK – A group of American investors vying to buy TikTok with support from top YouTuber MrBeast has secured more than US$20 billion (S$27 billion) for their offer, according to Mr Jesse Tinsley, the tech entrepreneur organising the bid.
It remains unclear if Mr Tinsley and his investor group will be serious contenders for what are shaping up to be competitive and fast-evolving negotiations.
“We have not heard back directly,” Mr Tinsley told Bloomberg.
It is unknown whether ByteDance and the Chinese government consider offers from Mr Tinsley and Mr McCourt as palatable paths forward.
Mr Tinsley’s group “could stabilise TikTok and put it in a good place for users and data integrity across the United States population”, Mr Tinsley said.

title: Australian BNPL firm Zip plummets as second-quarter earnings disappoint
summary:
BENGALURU – Shares of Zip Co slipped to their worst intraday session in more than 2½ years on Jan 30, after the Australian buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) company’s second-quarter earnings failed to meet market expectations.
The growth of BNPL companies is being challenged by multiple factors, including higher funding costs, greater regulatory scrutiny, and intense competition from major banks and payment organisations.
Zip’s pre-tax, depreciation, and amortisation cash earnings increased by 50.2 per cent year on year, reaching A$35.3 million (S$29.7 million), but fell short of analysts’ expectations.
Zip, Australia’s largest independent BNPL company, did not provide an outlook for the reported quarter.
Zip also floated plans to increase marketing expenditure in the second half of the year, a move that RBC warned could impact short-term profitability.

title: Gold holds decline after Fed chair Jerome Powell flags pause in Fed easing cycle
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBullion traded near US$2,760 an ounce, within about US$30 of its all-time high.
MELBOURNE – Gold held a slight decline after US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell said officials will not rush to lower US interest rates, adding that the central bank is pausing easing to see further progress on inflation.
Bullion traded near US$2,760 an ounce, within about US$30 of its all-time high.
On Jan 29 it eased 0.2 per cent, as the Federal Open Market Committee kept interest rates unchanged.
Higher rates tend to pose a headwind for gold, as it does not pay interest.

title: Meta to pay $33.7 million to settle Trump’s 2021 lawsuit over suspended accounts
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDiscussions about the lawsuit started again after Meta chief executive Mark Zuckerberg visited Mr Donald Trump’s Florida Mar-a-Lago club for a dinner with him in November 2024.
MEXICO CITY – Meta Platforms on Jan 29 said it has agreed to pay about US$25 million (S$33.7 million) to settle a lawsuit by President Donald Trump over the company’s suspension of his accounts after the Jan 6, 2021, attack at the US Capitol.
Mr Trump’s Facebook and Instagram accounts were suspended after his supporters launched an assault on the US Capitol following a speech by him repeating false claims that his election defeat was the result of widespread fraud.
Out of the settlement amount, US$22 million will go towards a fund for Mr Trump’s presidential library, and the rest to legal fees and other plaintiffs in the case.
In a departure from its past practice, Meta in December announced a US$1 million contribution to Mr Trump’s inaugural fund.

title: Even most affordable US childcare costs surged 50%: Survey
summary:
Fees at childcare centres based in people’s homes soared by almost 50 per cent in 2024 to US$344 (S$464) a week.
NEW YORK – The cost of what was once one of the most affordable options for childcare soared in 2024, putting it out of reach of many working families, according to a new survey.
Fees at childcare centres based in people’s homes – long embraced by some parents as a more affordable option than formal daycare centres – soared by almost 50 per cent in 2024 to US$344 (S$464) a week, the survey by online caregiving marketplace Care.com found.
Some 90 per cent of parents lost sleep over caregiving stress, while 80 per cent reported crying, the survey found.
“Everybody knows how broken it is,” Mr Wilson said of the childcare industry.

title: Microsoft has kind words for DeepSeek AI, offers it to customers
summary:
– Microsoft chief executive Satya Nadella had some kind words for DeepSeek, the Chinese artificial intelligence start-up that roiled his company’s shares earlier this week.
The upstart stunned the US tech industry with an open-source AI model called R1 that it claims rivals or outperforms the abilities of western technology but at a fraction of the cost.
“DeepSeek has had some real innovations,” Mr Nadella said during an investor call after Microsoft reported quarterly results on Jan 29.
Could Microsoft and partner OpenAI train its AI models and handle user queries – a process known as inferencing – more cheaply?
Microsoft has used its software to wring better performance and cost savings from each new generation of AI models and AI hardware, Mr Nadella said.

title: SoftBank in talks to invest up to $33.7 billion into OpenAI, FT reports
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSoftBank could invest US$15 billion (S$20.2 billion) to US$25 billion directly into Microsoft-backed OpenAI.
BENGALURU – Japan’s SoftBank is in talks to invest as much as US$25 billion (S$33.7 billion) into ChatGPT maker OpenAI, the Financial Times reported on Jan 29.
SoftBank could invest US$15 billion to US$25 billion directly into Microsoft-backed OpenAI on top of its commitment of more than US$15 billion to Stargate, the report said, citing multiple people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.
Stargate is a joint venture by Oracle, OpenAI and Softbank that plans to invest US$500 billion to help the United States stay ahead of China and other rivals in the global AI race.
“The talks are ongoing and the amount that SoftBank could invest in primary equity into OpenAI is a moving target,” a source told the FT.OpenAI and SoftBank did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: US stocks retreat as Fed holds steady on interest rates
summary:
NEW YORK – Wall Street stocks finished lower ahead of a deluge of earnings from tech heavyweights as markets digested a Federal Reserve decision to keep interest rates unmoved.
Stocks did not move significantly after the decision or during a news conference with Fed chairman Jerome Powell.
The broad-based S&P 500 declined 0.5 per cent to 6,039.31, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.5 per cent to 19,632.32.
“The market knows tariffs are coming,” Mr Sarhan said.
Trump Media & Technology Group gained 7.3 per cent as it announced a venture with Charles Schwab, establishing a programme to promote “American First investment vehicles”.

title: US Fed pauses rate cuts, resisting Trump pressure
summary:
WASHINGTON – The US Federal Reserve left its key lending rate unchanged on Jan 29, resisting pressure from President Donald Trump to continue with cuts in the first rate decision since his return to office.
Policymakers voted unanimously to keep the Fed’s benchmark lending rate at between 4.25 per cent and 4.5 per cent, the Fed announced in a statement.
The decision marked a pause following three consecutive rate reductions which lowered the Fed’s key lending rate by a full percentage point.
It does so primarily by raising or lowering its key short-term lending rate, which influences borrowing costs for consumers and businesses.
Moody’s Mr Zandi said he also expects two rate cuts later in the year.

title: LVMH’s subdued sales temper hopes for a rapid luxury rebound
summary:
LVMH’s sales of fashion and leather goods declined in the fourth quarter, casting doubt on the prospects of a quick recovery in luxury demand.
“What I expect is to see a gradual recovery,” LVMH chief executive Bernard Arnault said of China during a presentation on Jan 28.
Mr Arnault struck an upbeat tone at the presentation.
A sale of the Moet Hennessy drinks unit is not on the agenda, Mr Arnault added.
The division gets a new management team starting next week, led by Mr Guiony and Mr Arnault’s son Alexandre.

title: Nasdaq leads Wall St higher, tech shares recover from Jan 27 sell-off
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks ended higher on Jan 28, with Nvidia and other artificial intelligence-linked technology shares recovering from sharp losses the previous day as investors snapped up bargains.
Apple shares rose 3.7 per cent.
US President Donald Trump said late on Jan 27 he plans to impose tariffs on imported computer chips, pharmaceuticals and steel.
On the Nasdaq, 2,188 stocks rose and 2,216 fell as declining issues outnumbered advancers by a 1.01-to-1 ratio.
Volume on US exchanges was 13.87 billion shares, compared with the roughly 15.5 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.

title: HSBC to shutter some investment banking units in Europe, US
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxHSBC is set to withdraw from providing equity capital markets and advisory services outside of its core operations.
HONG KONG – HSBC Holdings will wind down some of its investment banking operations in Europe, Britain and the Americas as part of chief executive Georges Elhedery’s ongoing restructuring.
The lender told its staff that it would begin speaking to clients over the coming days about the closing of its investment banking businesses in the West, and that it would complete any live deals and mandates, according to the memo.
He has already announced the merger of commercial and investment banking outside of Hong Kong and Britain, and eliminated layers of senior management.
While HSBC is one of the largest lenders in the West, it is not often corporate clients’ first port of call for their investment banking needs.

title: Global markets sink as DeepSeek triggers AI rethink, with tech stocks hardest hit
summary:
“By developing cutting-edge AI models with less advanced and more cost-efficient hardware, DeepSeek challenges the heavy investments US tech companies are pouring into high-cost AI infrastructure,” he said.
China has now leapfrogged from 18 months to six months behind state-of-the-art AI models developed in the US, one person said.
Software maker Snowflake decided on Jan 27 to add DeepSeek models to its AI model marketplace after receiving a flurry of customer inquiries.
The acclaim garnered by DeepSeek’s models underscores the viability of open-source AI technology as an alternative to costly and tightly controlled technology such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT, industry watchers said.
Besides a rallying cry, DeepSeek also offers a warning to US tech companies, said Mr Venky Ganesan, a partner at Menlo Ventures.

title: Singapore shares rise before Chinese New Year break; STI up 0.1%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe half-day of trading left the Straits Times Index up a modest 0.1 per cent or 4.36 points at 3,801.07.
SINGAPORE – The tech-stock meltdown that hammered Wall Street overnight had little effect here as investors wound down for the Chinese New Year break on a positive note, albeit a muted one.
The half-day of trading left the Straits Times Index (STI) up a modest 0.1 per cent, or 4.36 points, at 3,801.07.
In the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 249 to 186 on thin trade of 622.7 million securities worth $904.1 million.
Australian tech shares were also smashed alongside their Wall Street peers but the overall market was trading flat, thanks to strength in retailers, communication services and banks.

title: ANZ’s Singapore-based credit trading team poached by Standard Chartered, report says
summary:
SINGAPORE – The entire Singapore-based credit trading team of Australian bank ANZ has been poached by rival Standard Chartered Bank, according to the Australian media on Jan 28.
The Australian newspaper quoted sources saying staff at ANZ’s credit trading arm revealed plans to leave the bank on Jan 27, reportedly jumping ship to StanChart.
ANZ credit trader Ming Wo said in a LinkedIn post that he was leaving the bank “with a heavy heart” after nearly 20 years there.
The report said credit traders Adam Hall and Timothy Teh were also among those set to leave the bank .
Many employees in the ANZ credit division were furious that the scandal had affected the broader markets business, according to sources cited by The Australian.

title: DPM Heng seeks deeper Singapore, Germany ties to promote free trade, innovation
summary:
SINGAPORE - Singapore and Germany should work together to sustain globalisation, drive innovation, and find new partners that believe in the value of free trade and investment, said Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
DPM Heng proposed a two-pronged approach that advanced economies like Germany and small open economies like Singapore can pursue together.
“Asean is a market of 677 million people with a rising middle class and a combined gross domestic product of around €3.6 trillion (S$5.08 trillion),” DPM Heng said.
German firms can use Singapore as an Asian innovation node, DPM Heng said.
Concluding his speech, DPM Heng said: “To continue growing, Singapore and Germany must continue to tap on global opportunities, while pursuing structural reforms.” He also wished the gathering a happy Chinese New Year.

title: Rare China support shows Vanke may be too big to fail
summary:
– China Vanke has been thrown a lifeline by the state authorities, a rare show of support that signals the developer may be too big to fail even after dozens of property firms defaulted amid China’s punishing housing slump.
An official from Shenzhen Metro Group, its largest state shareholder, will take over as chairman.
“I expect Shenzhen Metro to eventually become Vanke’s majority shareholder.”The unusual support shows that Vanke holds a special place within China’s moribund property sector.
The government has sought to assuage concerns that Shenzhen Metro’s balance sheet may not be big enough to support Vanke.
The assets “will support Shenzhen Metro to use as many market-based measures as possible to push forward Vanke’s prudent development”.

title: Singapore’s data centre Reits fall on DeepSeek threat; analysts warn of fallout
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxData centre-related Reits in Singapore already fell on Jan 27 on the DeepSeek fallout.
Nvidia on Jan 27 suffered a wipeout of US$589 billion (S$796 billion) in its market value – the most for any stock ever on Wall Street.
Data centre-related real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore fell on Jan 27 on the back of the saga surrounding DeepSeek.
On Jan 27, Keppel DC Reit dropped about 8 per cent to $2.09, and Digicore Reit fell around 6 per cent to US$0.545.
This development has also had an impact on all data centre-related Singapore Reits such as Keppel DC Reit, Digital Core Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust, he added.

title: London rents rise at slowest pace since 2021; fall outside of city for first time since 2019
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBritain is seeing a cooling of what has been a ferociously hot rental market over the last year.
That is up 2.4 per cent from a year earlier, the slowest pace of increase since 2021.
Outside of London, rents fell for the first time since 2019, the report showed.
London rents are almost a third higher than before the Covid-19 pandemic, the equivalent of £630 per month, Rightmove said.
There are about 10 tenant applications per rental property, almost double the pre-Covid-19 norm.

title: DeepSeek’s AI model tests limits of US curbs on Nvidia chips
summary:
DeepSeek says it used less-advanced Nvidia H800 chips to build a model that appears on a par with the best offerings from OpenAI.
The US imposed sweeping controls on the sale of the most advanced Nvidia chips to China in October 2022, and has ratcheted up the measures each year since.
But Nvidia has responded by designing new semiconductors for the Chinese market – including those DeepSeek likely used to build R1.
He also lauded its R1 model as a “positive development” that could allow for less expensive AI advancements across the board.
The fact that DeepSeek managed to build R1 illustrates “lagging impact of the failure of the October 2022 export controls”, Mr Allen said.

title: Singapore-listed US office Reits seen to benefit from Trump’s return-to-office mandate
summary:
It is one of three Singapore-listed Reits seen benefitting from the Trump move.
SINGAPORE - Singapore-listed office real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) will benefit from US President Donald Trump’s executive order mandating federal employees return to in-person work, analysts said.
As at Jan 24’s close, the trio of US office Reits recorded a strong weekly gain of more than 10 per cent.
UOB Kay Hian is positive on Singapore-listed US office Reits, on the back of corporate giants’ return-to-office mandate.
UOB Kay Hian reiterated its “overweight” call and said that “overwhelmingly attractive valuations beckon” for SGX-listed US office Reits.

title: World’s richest people led by Nvidia co-founder Jensen Huang lose $145b after DeepSeek sell-off
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox– The world’s 500 richest people, led by Nvidia co-founder Jensen Huang, lost a combined US$108 billion (S$145 billion) on Jan 27 as a tech-led sell-off tied to Chinese AI developer DeepSeek sent major indexes plunging.
Dell’s Michael Dell lost US$13 billion, and Binance Holdings co-founder Zhao “CZ” Changpeng shaved US$12.1 billion.
Tech-sector titans as a group saw US$94 billion of wealth evaporate – roughly 85 per cent of the Bloomberg index’s total decline.
Mr Zuckerberg’s fortune soared 385 per cent to US$229 billion over the same period and Amazon.com’s Jeff Bezos gained 133 per cent to US$254 billion.
While Mr Huang and Mr Ellison suffered losses, other major tech billionaires’ fortunes escaped unscathed.

title: What is China’s DeepSeek and why is it freaking out the AI world?
summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI start-up that is just over a year old, has stirred awe and consternation in Silicon Valley after demonstrating breakthrough artificial intelligence (AI) models that offer comparable performance to the world’s best chatbots at seemingly a fraction of the cost.
The company develops AI models that are open source, meaning the developer community at large can inspect and improve the software.
But DeepSeek’s progress suggests Chinese AI engineers have worked their way around the restrictions, focusing on greater efficiency with limited resources.
It gave the world a glimpse of its DeepSeek R1 model, designed to mimic human thinking.
Like all other Chinese AI models, DeepSeek self-censors on topics deemed sensitive in China.

title: Nvidia sheds $792 billion of market value in DeepSeek rout, biggest one-day loss in US history
summary:
Nvidia’s shares tumbled 17 per cent on Jan 27, erasing US$589 billion (S$792 billion) from the company’s market capitalisation.
That eclipsed the previous record – a 9 per cent drop in September that wiped out about US$279 billion in value – and was the biggest in US stock-market history.
The latest AI model of DeepSeek, released last week, is widely seen as competitive with those of ChatGPT’s OpenAI and Facebook’s Meta Platforms.
In a bid to stall China’s progress in AI, the US has banned the export of advanced semiconductor technologies to the country and is limiting sales of advanced Nvidia AI chips to others.
But DeepSeek’s progress suggests Chinese AI engineers have found a way to work around the export bans, focusing on greater efficiency with limited resources.

title: Nasdaq, S&P 500 fall as China's DeepSeek AI model hits tech shares
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSurging popularity of a low-cost Chinese AI model raised investor worries about the outlooks for AI leaders in the US.
Nvidia’s shares sank, while an index of semiconductor stocks had its biggest single-day percentage fall since March 2020.
DeepSeek’s AI Assistant by Jan 27 had overtaken US rival ChatGPT in downloads from Apple’s App Store.
According to preliminary data, the S&P 500 lost 87.85 points, or 1.44 per cent, to end at 6,013.39 points, while the Nasdaq Composite lost 607.47 points, or 3.04 per cent, to 19,346.83.
Among other big tech-related companies, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet also were down, while AI server maker Dell Technologies fell sharply.

title: Tesla, BMW sue EU after China-made EVs hit by tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe EU has only seen limited progress so far in negotiations with China over a comprehensive deal to replace the EV tariffs.
Elon Musk’s Tesla and BMW have sued the European Union’s executive, adding to a flurry of cases by Chinese carmakers attacking tariffs peaking at 45 per cent on imports of electric vehicles into the bloc.
The EU has only seen limited progress so far in negotiations with China over a comprehensive deal to replace the EV tariffs, Bloomberg has reported.
The EU imposed anti-subsidy tariffs of 7.8 per cent on Tesla on top of the 10 per cent levy.
The firm was hit because its electric Mini Cooper and the 100 per cent electric Mini Aceman are made in China, according to car website Autogear.

title: Singapore shares track regional declines; STI down 0.2%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index declined 0.2 per cent or 7.55 points to 3,796.71.
SINGAPORE - Shares in Singapore ended lower on Jan 27, tracking declines in the region.
The benchmark Straits Times Index declined 0.2 per cent or 7.55 points to 3,796.71.
Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 277 to 242, after one billion securities worth $1.1 billion changed hands.
On the STI, Venture Corporation was the biggest decliner, falling 3.8 per cent or $0.50 to $12.58.

title: UK firms see biggest hit to output and profit since Covid-19 pandemic
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxOne in five UK-listed companies issued a profit warning in 2024, the worst ration since the pandemic.
- Business activity has slumped at British firms and profit warnings have risen, according to two reports that say each trend is the worst it’s been since the pandemic.
Finance Minister Rachel Reeves needs output to pick up in order to drive higher tax revenues.
InsolvenciesThere were 274 profit warnings in total among listed companies in Britain, according to the EY-Parthenon report.
“This cycle has been different,” said Ms Jo Robinson, a partner at EY-Parthenon, where she leads the UK and Ireland turnaround and restructuring strategy.

title: Chinese AI assistant DeepSeek tops iPhone downloads, spurs Asia stocks
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxDeepSeek AI assistant rocketed to the top of Apple’s iPhone download charts, stirring doubts about the strength of America’s AI lead.
- Chinese start-up DeepSeek’s eponymous artificial intelligence assistant rocketed to the top of Apple’s iPhone download charts, stirring doubts in Silicon Valley about the strength of America’s lead in AI.
The app’s underlying AI model is widely seen as competitive with the latest from ChatGPT owner OpenAI and Facebook parent Meta Platforms.
US stock index futures also tumbled amid concerns that DeepSeek’s AI models may disrupt US technological leadership.
Lauded by investor Marc Andreessen as “one of the most amazing and impressive breakthroughs”, DeepSeek’s assistant shows its work and reasoning as it addresses a user’s written query or prompt.

title: Fewer S’pore retrenchments in 2024 than in 2023; resident employment grew: MOM
summary:
For the full year, the number of residents – Singaporeans and permanent residents – in employment grew, unlike in 2023 when there was a decline in resident employment.
MOM will release further details on the breakdown of employment growth in a regular report due in mid-March.
In the fourth quarter, while Singapore’s total employment continued to grow, resident employment growth slowed to 8,700, down from 22,300 in the preceding quarter but higher than the growth of 3,900 in the fourth quarter of 2023.
Looking ahead, employment growth is expected to be slower in 2025 due to global uncertainties and market volatility, noted the ministry.
“With an already high resident labour force participation rate by international standards and low resident unemployment, there is limited headroom for resident employment to keep expanding.

title: China manufacturing activity unexpectedly shrinks for first time in four months
summary:
- China’s manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in January for the first time in four months, official data showed on Jan 27, as Beijing struggles to sustain the recovery of the world’s second-largest economy.
The PMI stood at 50.1 in December, its third straight month in positive territory after ending a six-month decline in October.
China’s trade surplus reached almost US$1 trillion (S$1.35 trillion) in 2024, as producers looked to shift stocks overseas to counter weak domestic demand.
Beijing has pledged to prioritise revitalising domestic demand, but has revealed little apart from a recently expanded trade-in programme that subsidises purchases of cars, appliances and other goods.
Chinese leaders are also hoping policy support measures in late 2024 will increase demand in the struggling property sector and ease developers’ financial difficulties, which significantly impacts domestic demand and local government finances.

title: New World debt turmoil rocks one of Hong Kong’s richest families
summary:
– For decades, Hong Kong’s “big four” property dynasties have been viewed as cash-rich bastions of stability.
For now, New World appears to be an isolated case among Hong Kong’s big four real estate families.
It is the largest amount to be pledged by any of Hong Kong’s top billionaire families for such a refinancing, according to Bloomberg-compiled data.
It is not helping that Hong Kong’s residential prices are still hovering at an eight-year low, while office towers are reeling from overcapacity.
“New World had the assumption at the time that China and Hong Kong’s economies could have high growth perpetually,” said Mr Wong.

title: CDL Hospitality Trusts posts 11.9% fall in second-half DPS
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe stapled group's managers attribute the lower second-half distribution to a fall in net property income.
SINGAPORE - The managers of CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) on Jan 27 posted a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 2.81 cents for the second half ended December 2024, down 11.9 per cent from 3.1 cents in the previous corresponding period.
The lower distribution and DPS came as net property income contribution from a residential property in Manchester was insufficient to cover interest costs during the gestation period, said CDLHT’s managers.
Excluding the one-off liquidation proceeds, total distribution and DPS would have declined by 8.9 per cent and 9.9 per cent, respectively, year on year.
The stapled group’s portfolio consists of property in eight countries, including Japan, Britain, Australia and the Maldives.

title: Hong Kong’s property distress catching up with city’s banks
summary:
– Distressed property sales in Hong Kong are beginning to bite banks that used to be well protected against loan losses.
The city’s commercial real estate sector is going through one of its worst slumps in history, with no end in sight.
Some of the city’s banks had been recovering from the hit they took from the downturn in mainland China’s real estate market.
The vast majority of the commercial real estate debt is performing, but the risks are elevated, analysts Francis Chan and Patrick Wong said in the report.
“We believe worries about the Hong Kong banking sector are overblown,” they said.

title: Instil hope, not fear of tariffs, in global population to raise consumption and growth: BlackRock CEO
summary:
SINGAPORE - Growing the global economy will not be achieved by fixating on tariffs, national debt or deficits, but by inspiring hope in people, said the boss of the world’s largest asset manager.
Mr Fink cited China, which has “the highest savings rates of any major economy in the world”, as an example.
Mr Fink pointed out that Europe lags behind the US and China in innovation, entrepreneurialism and adaptability.
Mr Fink warned that wages could nevertheless rise, leading to higher inflation in the longer term.
Mr Fink was not the only US finance chief in Davos who appeared sanguine about Mr Trump’s proposed tariffs.

title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust posts 7% fall in second-half DPS but core DPS rises 3%
summary:
After adjusting for non-periodic items, core DPS stood at 5.49 cents, up 1 per cent from 5.44 cents recorded in the same period the year before.
Clas’ total distribution for the second half was down 4 per cent to $134.8 million from $140.8 million in the same period the previous year.
Revenue for the half-year period stood at $423.2 million, up 6 per cent from $397.6 million recorded in the same period the year before.
For the full year , total distribution fell 2 per cent on year to $231.2 million from $237 million.
Meanwhile, revenue for the full year rose 9 per cent on year to $809.5 million from $744.6 million.

title: US Fed prepares to pause this week in first rate decision since Trump’s inauguration
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Fed’s challenge this week is how to pause and communicate a data-dependent approach to future rate cuts without drawing the ire of President Trump.
- The US Federal Reserve is expected to announce a pause in rate cuts on Jan 29, as policymakers look to continue tackling inflation under close and vocal scrutiny from President Donald Trump.
“The Fed will not front-run any policies by the new administration,” Ms Swonk from KPMG said of the bank’s upcoming rate decision.
In December, Fed policymakers dialled back the number of rate cuts they expect in 2025 to a median of just two, with some incorporating assumptions about Trump’s likely economic policies into their forecasts, according to minutes of the meeting.
Many economists see his tariffs and immigration proposals as inflationary, potentially keeping the Fed on pause for longer if they come into effect.

title: More e-hongbao gifted in 2024; trend expected to continue this year
summary:
Fellow fintech player YouTrip has seen a rise in users sending digital hongbao since it launched the initiative in 2021.
The number of e-hongbao sent surged tenfold in 2024 compared with in 2023, said Mr Kelvin Lam, chief operating officer of YouTrip.
He said users sent an average of seven e-hongbao in 2024, with the largest single e-hongbao amounting to $1,000.
Wise customers Ivan Tolic and Desmond Chew still prefer to hand out physical red packets when they can.
Mr Tolic, a 36-year-old business development manager in Singapore, first started sending digital hongbao to his family based in Malaysia during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: US stocks are jumping on earnings wins by the most since 2018
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe robust results are a much-needed driver for US stocks after the S&P 500 traded sideways through much of January.
Only those that account for about one-fifth of the S&P 500’s market capitalisation have so far reported.
But if the trend holds, it would mark the best post-earnings reaction since 2018, the BI data shows.
While it is not unusual to see analysts ratcheting down earnings forecasts at the start of earnings season, it could be an early sign of changing sentiment.
The slew of positive earnings – combined with less aggressive tariff talk during Mr Trump’s first week than had been feared – helped send the S&P 500 to its second straight weekly gain.

title: Two more SGX delistings expected as SLB Development, Japfa receive privatisation offers
summary:
SINGAPORE – Two more companies, property developer SLB Development and agri-food business Japfa, may be delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after receiving privatisation offers from their major shareholders.
The moves potentially extend a slew of SGX delistings that took place in 2024, which included Silverlake Axis, Best World International and Isetan Singapore.
SLB was listed on the Catalist board of the SGX on April 20, 2018.
Lian Beng currently holds about 708.5 million shares in SLB, representing about 77.6 per cent of the total number of issued shares.
Japfa, which runs chicken and pig farms in Indonesia and Vietnam, closed at 53 cents on Jan 24.

title: Tech’s $20 trillion rally hinges on high-stakes earnings stretch
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxShares of Alphabet, Meta and other technology giants have rallied to start the year.
NEW YORK – Investors are heading into yet another pivotal Big Tech earnings cycle with the companies’ shares near record highs and valuations stretched.
A key distinction this time: The group’s profit growth is projected to come in at the slowest pace in almost two years.
Apple follows on Jan 30, while Alphabet and Amazon.com announce next week, and then chipmaker Nvidia Corp on Feb 26.
The sector’s superior earnings growth and exuberance around AI have been key drivers for US stocks during the bull market that began more than two years ago.

title: CNN plots major overhaul as it enters a new Trump era
summary:
And if CNN does not follow that advice for the digital age, Mr Thompson says, the company may no longer exist.
“This is a moment where the digital story feels like an existential question,” Mr Thompson said in an interview.
CNN also previewed a new streaming service, similar to its TV product, that it will charge for.
Mr Thompson and Ms MacCallum have also appealed to Mr David Zaslav, the CEO of Warner Bros Discovery, for additional investment in CNN’s digital priorities.
“You can use your thumb to flick from a CNN news story to a CNN anchor to a reporter,” Mr Thompson said.

title: Chinese port hit by congestion ahead of major holiday, potential US tariffs
summary:
– Exporters are jostling to load and ship cargo from Shenzhen’s Yantian Port, one of the world’s largest container ports, before an eight-day Chinese New Year holiday starting on Jan 28 and ahead of a potential wave of US tariffs on Chinese goods.
China has vowed to defend its “interests” against Mr Trump’s tariff threats.
As the congestion at Yantian Port worsened last week , trucking fees rose, denting exporters’ bottom line.
Trucking fees from Shenzhen’s Fuyong, a logistics hub, to Yantian Port rose to more than 2,500 yuan from 1,000 yuan prior.
Mr Li said Mr Trump’s tariff threat was to be blamed for the congestion.

title: Starbucks CEO awarded $129.2 million in first four months on the job
summary:
– Starbucks Corp granted its new chief executive Brian Niccol about US$96 million (S$129.2 million) after four months of work in 2024 , one of the biggest compensation packages in corporate America.
Mr Niccol, who joined Starbucks in early September, also received a US$5 million sign-on bonus after his one-month anniversary with the company.
Starbucks ousted its previous CEO in 2024 after a string of sales declines.
Mr Niccol was recruited from Chipotle Mexican Grill to turn the business around.
In the filing, Starbucks said Mr Niccol was a “highly sought-after, effective leader with a proven track record”, with the experience to drive the chain’s growth.

title: US stocks retreat, cutting into weekly gains
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks concluded a winning week on a tepid note on Jan 24, retreating following mixed earnings in a move attributed to profit taking.
After a flattish open, all three major indices moved into negative territory - a trend that held the rest of the session.
“This is normal consolidation or profit taking after a big 2-week rally,” said Mr Adam Sarhan, of 50 Park Investment.
Stocks have gained in recent sessions following benign US inflation data, strong earnings from banks and the new presidency of Mr Donald Trump in Washington.
Others with big earnings-related moves included American Express, down 1.4 per cent; CSX, down 5.8 per cent; and Texas Instruments, down 13.1 per cent.

title: Global growth driven by strong US economy expected in 2025: WEF panel
summary:
However, much of that growth will be mostly driven by the US, International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Kristalina Georgieva told a World Economic Forum (WEF) panel in Davos, Switzerland, on Jan 24.
Global growth is projected by the IMF to be 3.3 per cent in 2025, with an upward revision in the US offsetting downward revisions elsewhere.
It expects the US to achieve 2.7 per cent growth in 2025, representing a sharp upward revision from 2.2 per cent in previous forecasts.
This is because of stronger economic policy coordination between countries and central banks after the 2008 global financial crisis.
“The evidence still supports the proposition that global interdependence and specialisation by each country is good for everyone.

title: Self-storage firms in 20 areas can operate until leases expire
summary:
SINGAPORE - Self-storage companies located in 20 areas around the island can stay put until their leases expire, following a review by industrial landlord JTC.
It is understood that JTC will allow self-storage facilities to be set up only in areas earmarked for light and clean industries that are not located in “core” areas.
This announcement comes as JTC lifted a moratorium on the sector after a review to accommodate the increasing demand from the self-storage industry.
In a statement on Jan 24, self-storage companies will be allowed to go on operating at all their existing facilities until their leases expire.
Meanwhile, JTC said: “Following consultations with self-storage players (SSPs) on the future of the self-storage industry, JTC will be lifting its current moratorium on requests for self-storage use on JTC industrial land.” It was imposed in late 2021.

title: Chinese firms boost shareholder returns via dividends and buybacks
summary:
- Chinese firms are attracting investors with increased dividends and buybacks, spurred by a policy push for corporate governance reforms in a bleak and uncertain economic environment.
According to LSEG data, the dividend yield of Chinese companies stood at 2.8 per cent at the end of 2024, the highest in eight years.
According to LSEG Lipper data, Chinese dividend funds have seen inflows of about US$8 billion (S$10.78 billion) since 2020, compared with inflows of just US$273 million in the previous five years.
Valuations for Chinese stocks remain below their historical average, which means investors need to be careful about picking the right stocks that generate returns, besides being cheap.
Compared with other major markets, Chinese stocks trade at roughly 13 times forward earnings while Japan’s Nikkei trades at 15 times and the S&P 500, at nearly 25 times.

title: Singapore stocks fall 0.1% despite record session on Wall Street overnight
summary:
SINGAPORE – A record session on Wall Street overnight failed to inspire local investors, who were more focused on the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) easing policy settings here and US President Donald Trump calling for lower interest rates.
The mixed signals left the Straits Times Index (STI) in the doldrums, eventually dipping 0.1 per cent, or 2.31 points, to 3,804.26 on Jan 24.
It was a far cry from Wall Street, where a robust earnings season and President Trump’s backing for tax cuts and deregulation helped send the S&P 500 up 0.5 per cent and its first record of 2025.
The losers were in Tokyo, where shares fell 0.1 per cent, and in Malaysia, where counters dropped 0.2 per cent.
The local chatter centred on MAS moves to favour a more gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar.

title: Singapore digital bank Anext announces new CEO
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAnext focuses on offering services such as digital banking and lending to local and regional SMEs.
SINGAPORE – Digital wholesale bank Anext has appointed a new boss to replace outgoing chief executive Toh Su Mei.
Ms Toh led Anext to become one of the key regional players in offering finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) via digital platforms.
Anext began operations in 2022 after receiving a digital wholesale banking licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
It focuses on offering services such as digital banking and lending to local and regional SMEs.

title: OCBC CEO meets key Great Eastern deal holdouts in $1.4 billion takeover bid
summary:
The bank held almost 94 per cent of Great Eastern after the takeover offer closed in July.
OCBC’s cash offer of $25.60 a share was well above where Great Eastern was trading in the months before 2024’s takeover bid was announced.
Earlier in January, London-based shareholder Palliser Capital called the Great Eastern takeover bid “gravely unfair” to shareholders.
The Wong brothers’ grandfather, Mr Wong Siew Qui, was chairman of Great Eastern Life Assurance from 1951 to 1969.
Great Eastern was founded in 1908, and is one of the largest insurers in Singapore and Malaysia.

title: Disney hikes CEO Bob Iger’s pay by 30% to $55.4 million, reflecting profit turnaround
summary:
NEW YORK – Walt Disney boosted chief executive Bob Iger’s total pay by 30 per cent in fiscal 2024, underscoring his turnaround of the media and entertainment company.
Disney’s CEO earned US$41.1 million (S$55.4 million) in the year that ended in September, up from $31.6 million in fiscal 2023, according to a filing on Jan 23.
Mr Iger is in his second stint as CEO, having returned in 2022 after a previous 15-year run.
The company’s profitable streaming services, including Disney+, Hulu and ESPN+, are helping the company reduce its dependence on cable TV.
Disney signed a deal earlier in January to merge its Hulu + Live TV platform with sports-focused streaming service FuboTV.

title: Singapore factory output grows 10.6% in December, beating forecasts
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWithin the electrical cluster, semiconductor production grew 11.4 per cent.
Within the cluster, the “other chemicals segment” rose 18.6 per cent due to a higher output of fragrances.
Biomedical manufacturing output grew 9.4 per cent year on year.
Output in the pharmaceuticals segment rose 13.7 per cent on account of a different mix of active pharmaceutical ingredients being produced.
General manufacturing output rose 3.7 per cent in December.

title: China’s frugal tourists avoid far-flung trips over Chinese New Year holiday
summary:
– China’s straitened economic circumstances are being reflected in Chinese New Year travel plans, with many choosing cheaper domestic trips or nearby destinations in Asia.
The holiday snapshots reflect a home-bias shift among Chinese tourists, who for years were the globe’s biggest spenders.
“Chinese are being more selective about their travel,” said Mr Subramania Bhatt, chief executive of China Trading Desk.
But over the past two years, her salary has flat-lined while her bonuses have been slashed in half.
Furthermore, nearly three out of four travellers are booking trips less than a month in advance as people hold out for last-minute offers, Mr Bhatt said.

title: Boeing warns of $5.4 billion quarterly loss, nearly triple market expectations
summary:
The loss would be nearly triple the size expected by Wall Street.
Boeing shares fell 3.5 per cent in after-hours trading on Jan 23 as the company projected quarterly revenue of US$15.2 billion, below expectations of US$16.27 billion.
The Covid-19 pandemic further squeezed the company, and 2024 began with a mid-air panel blowout on a nearly new 737 Max, sending Boeing into another crisis.
Based on the Jan 23 quarterly results forecast, the company’s annual loss for 2025 could rival 2020, when it lost nearly US$12 billion, the most in its history.
Boeing Commercial Airplanes expects fourth-quarter revenue of US$4.8 billion and an operating margin loss of 43.9 per cent, the company said.

title: MAS eases Singdollar policy for first time since 2020 as it lowers key inflation forecast
summary:
MAS refers to this value as the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$Neer), or the trade-weighted exchange rate.
As a result, MAS cut its forecast for 2025 core inflation to 1 per cent to 2 per cent, from 1.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent.
Commenting on the outlook for economic growth, MAS said global economic policy uncertainty has risen since the last monetary policy review in October 2024, mainly reflecting expectations of increasing trade policy frictions.
MAS uses S$Neer as its main monetary policy tool to contain imported inflation because Singapore imports almost everything it consumes.
The S$Neer is allowed to move up and down within an undisclosed policy band set by MAS.

title: British supermarket chain Sainsbury’s cuts 3,000 jobs as tax hike looms
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe job cuts at Sainsbury's add to a slew of evidence underscoring the British budget’s impact on retailers.
LONDON – J Sainsbury will cut 3,000 staff and close its remaining cafes, as Britain’s second-largest supermarket chain steps up a cost-saving drive after the government announced higher taxes on businesses.
Overall, the cuts will affect about 2 per cent of the grocer’s 148,000 staff.
On Jan 23, Associated British Foods cut guidance for sales growth at its Primark discount fashion retailer, citing a downturn in spending.
The supermarket said it will also close its remaining patisserie, hot foot and pizza counters, replacing them with popular aisle items including fresh food.

title: JPMorgan boosts Jamie Dimon’s pay to $52.8 million after record profit
summary:
NEW YORK – JPMorgan Chase & Co lifted chief executive Jamie Dimon’s pay to US$39 million (S$52.8 million) for 2024, a year in which the biggest US bank beat its own record for the highest annual profit in the history of American banking.
The board granted Mr Dimon a US$1.5 million salary and US$37.5 million of performance-based incentive compensation, according to a regulatory filing.
The question of when Mr Dimon will retire, and who might succeed him, has hung over JPMorgan for years.
Mr Dimon recently abandoned a long-time joke that retirement was five years away, no matter when asked.
JPMorgan is the second major bank to announce CEO pay for 2024.

title: Crypto’s richest man, out of prison, turns Binance Labs into giant family office
summary:
Binance Labs, which oversees about US$10 billion of crypto-related assets, will be renamed YZi Labs, according to a statement on Jan 23.
YZi Labs will also manage the wealth of Binance co-founder Yi He, with whom Mr Zhao has three children.
There is no immediate need for Mr Zhao to inject more money into YZi Labs, Ms Zhang said.
Before its rebranding, Binance Labs invested in hundreds of projects, including the likes of Sky Mavis, Aptos Labs, LayerZero, Polygon and The Sandbox.
Before her first stint at Binance, Ms Zhang spent about five years as an investment principal at Kleiner Perkins.

title: US stocks gain as Trump touts plan for tax cuts
summary:
NEW YORK – Wall Street stocks finished higher on Jan 23, shrugging off early weakness as investors digested President Donald Trump’s remarks to the World Economic Forum in Davos.
Mr Trump’s much-anticipated video appearance included a call for lower interest rates, a renewed threat of tariffs on companies that plan to import items and a pledge to cut corporate taxes further.
Investors cheered the message on tax cuts, which Mr Trump held out as a “carrot” to attract investment as compared with the “stick” of tariffs, said Mr Jack Ablin, of Cresset Capital.
“Certainly, everyone understands the tariff message and now we’re hearing more about the tax incentives,” said Mr Ablin.
Mr Ablin noted that Mr Trump has not advanced a campaign trail proposal to hike tariffs on Chinese goods by 60 per cent, evidence of some “moderation” in the returning president’s tone.

title: Does the ‘no buy’ challenge help you save?
summary:
In a “no buy” (or “no spend”) challenge, participants aim to go an extended period without making purchases beyond the essentials.
At this point, I should disclose that I tried a “no buy” challenge in 2019.
Taking on the “no buy” challenge made me realise that it’s important to identify the emotional trigger behind a purchase.
Engaging in meaningful social interactions without opening one’s wallet is one of the biggest hurdles of a “no buy” challenge.
Those who want to try a “no buy” challenge should first commit to analysing their spending and their impulses to spend.

title: T-bills remain an option for low-risk portion of an investment portfolio as yields hold around 3%
summary:
It has been much the same for one-year T-bills, with yields hitting a three-decade high of 3.87 per cent on Jan 26, 2023.
Mr Chen, the private investor, said that besides T-bills, there are other low-risk options for parking cash, such as fixed deposits and money market funds.
The 2.95 per cent yield exceeded his expectations.
A money market fund is a type of unit trust that invests in low-risk instruments with maturities of less than a year.
Some money market funds here include the Fullerton SGD Cash Fund, the Phillip Money Market Fund, the LionGlobal SGD Money Market Fund and the Lion-MariBank SavePlus fund.

title: Changi Airport to focus on e-commerce, pharmaceutical shipments as cargo capacity tightens
summary:
SINGAPORE – Cargo volumes at Changi Airport surged in 2024 on the back of strong global demand for shipments through Singapore, and a shift from ocean to airfreight due to disruptions in the Red Sea.
“E-commerce has emerged as a key growth driver of the global air cargo industry.
These initiatives are expected to help CAG maximise space until fresh cargo handling capacity comes on stream from the mid-2030s onwards.
The moves also come amid expectations that air cargo demand will continue to outpace capacity in 2025.
Analysts at freight data platform Xeneta projected on Jan 9 that global air cargo demand would grow by 4 per cent to 6 per cent year on year in 2025, outpacing global cargo capacity supply growth of 3 per cent to 4 per cent.

title: Overcoming challenges, pandemic: How home-grown fashion brand finds success abroad
summary:
The founders of In Good Company are four friends who used to work together as colleagues on another local label.
Despite the challenges posed by Covid-19, In Good Company emerged stronger from the crisis, thanks to its familiarity and headstart with the e-commerce business model.
Lesser known, however, is how local bank UOB supported and continues to support the brand through its ups and downs.
Beyond the UOB SME app, UOB’s SME customers can also leverage UOB BizSmart, a comprehensive suite of digital business management solutions.
Terms and Conditions governing UOB Business World Debit Card and UOB Business World Debit Card Bonus Cash Rebate Promotion apply, visit uob.com.sg/bizdebit for more information.

title: Sportswear giants Adidas and Puma weighing job cuts
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGerman sportswear giants Adidas and Puma have both said they are seeking to reduce costs through possible job cuts.
– German sportswear giants Adidas and Puma have both said they are seeking to reduce costs, including through possible job cuts, as they aim to bolster profits.
Adidas said it wanted to ensure “long-term success” and had “begun examining how we can adapt our business’ structures to the reality of our work”.
German news outlet Manager Magazin said the plans could affect up to 500 employees and reflected chief executive Bjorn Gulden’s desire to simplify Adidas.
Puma, Adidas’ smaller rival, said on Jan 22 that it was also aiming to cut costs, including through “personnel expenses” – suggesting job cuts could be on the table – as it released disappointing results.

title: Singapore stocks close higher on Jan 23 as inflation eases; STI up 0.7%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxInvestors here cheered news that full-year inflation came in at 2.4 per cent in 2024.
SINGAPORE – A tech rally on Wall Street overnight and encouraging inflation figures in Singapore helped local shares close the day’s trading in positive territory on Jan 23.
In the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 262 to 237 on trade of 933.4 million securities worth $1 billion.
The most active counters included Yangzijiang Financial, which rose 3.5 per cent to 44.5 cents after 28.8 million shares changed hands .
DBS rose 1.1 per cent to $43.81, UOB was up 0.9 per cent to $37.35 and OCBC gained 0.4 per cent to $17.09.

title: Singapore Retailers Association calls for relaxed foreign worker quotas, levies in Budget 2025
summary:
SINGAPORE – An increase in the dependency ratio ceiling (DRC) and reduced foreign worker levies are among the measures that Budget 2025 could adopt to help Singapore retailers manage rising costs and a tight labour market, the Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) said.
In its Budget 2025 recommendations released on Jan 23, it proposed easing the DRC to “facilitate the employment of more foreign workers” to fill front-line retail roles.
The current DRC of 35 per cent for the services sector creates “significant challenges” for manpower resourcing, SRA noted.
“This would help to upskill the retail workforce for the next leap of growth in the retail sector as we continue to digitalise and transform the sector,” it added.
For the retail sector, SRA proposed widening the list of source countries to include those with a “service-oriented culture” , such as the Philippines or Vietnam .

title: Govt to continue green budgeting, set aside money for climate action: Ministry of Finance
summary:
SINGAPORE – The Government will continue to take a green budgeting approach and ensure that it sets aside finances for climate mitigation and adaptation, said the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Jan 23.
The building of more cycling paths is also expected to cost about $1 billion, MOF said in its paper.
The Government can also borrow money through green bonds to finance nationally significant green infrastructure projects.
First published in 2022, the framework lays out the requirements around sovereign green bonds issued to finance green public sector projects.
These issuances will also help to attract green capital and investors, and anchor Singapore as a green finance hub in Asia, MOF said.

title: Cafe chain Oriental Kopi’s shares double on IPO debut in Malaysia
summary:
The cafe chain operator, which listed on Bursa Malaysia’s Ace Market for growth companies, opened at 81 Malaysian sen compared with its IPO price of 44 sen.
It was the most actively traded stock on Bursa Malaysia for the day, with more than 828.7 million shares traded.
Oriental Kopi raised gross proceeds of around RM184 million.
Oriental Kopi partners with Singapore’s Paradise Group, which owns eateries such as Canton Paradise, Paradise Dynasty and Beauty in The Pot, for its operations in the Republic .
The company intends to open two more Oriental Kopi cafes in Singapore in 2025, according to its prospectus.

title: PSA International rebrands, expands corporate venture capital arm to tap emerging trends
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxPSA Singapore is one of the world's largest centres for container movement, handling about 40 million containers in 2024.
SINGAPORE – Port operator PSA International has revamped its corporate venture capital arm to tap emerging trends in the shipping industry.
The unit – now called PSA Ventures – will commercialise intellectual property developed with partner organisations and research institutions, while also pursuing traditional venture capital investments.
PSA International group chief executive Ong Kim Pong said: “As the management of international maritime hubs, transportation infrastructure and networks grows increasingly complex, PSA Ventures will enable us to venture-build with key partners and capitalise on emerging trends.
PSA Singapore is one of the world’s largest centres for container movement, handling about 40 million containers in 2024.

title: EnterpriseSG to boost support for Singapore firms; revenue up $14.5b among 2,300 helped in 2024
summary:
This is better than the 9,300 figure in 2019, but falls below the average of 18,200 firms it helped annually between 2020 and 2023.
EnterpriseSG chairman Lee Chuan Teck on Jan 23 highlighted the national agency’s need for tailored aid.
The revenue of firms EnterpriseSG helped to take on innovation projects grew by an average of $10.2 million, nearly double the $5.2 million in 2023.
For instance, the agency will enhance the Scale-Up programme, which started in 2019 to help local companies grow and expand globally.
Singapore firm Rapsodo signed global baseball star Shohei Ohtani to be its ambassador in 2024 after a strategy review spurred by EnterpriseSG.

title: Singapore core inflation drops further to 1.8% in December
summary:
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s core inflation extended its decline in December 2024 as the cost of services moderated, though the gauge came in above analysts’ expectations.
Core inflation, which strips out private transport and accommodation costs to better reflect household expenses, eased to 1.8 per cent year on year, from 1.9 per cent in November 2024.
It is still the lowest since November 2021 when core inflation was 1.6 per cent.
On a month-on-month basis, which shows the momentum in prices, core inflation increased by 0.5 per cent, while headline inflation rose by 0.3 per cent.
“We expect core inflation to stay below 2 per cent in 2025, and have also recently revised our average forecast to 1.5 per cent for 2025,” said Mr Chua.

title: Ascott bags 16 new signings under Oakwood portfolio to tap growing ‘bleisure’ market
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAscott's Oakwood brand has almost 100 properties across 50 cities, including Ha Long in Vietnam (above).
SINGAPORE – Ascott, the wholly owned lodging business unit of CapitaLand Investment, has secured 16 new signings under the Oakwood brand in 2024, up 30 per cent from the previous year.
With the new signings, Ascott’s Oakwood portfolio now comprises nearly 100 properties that are both operational and in the pipeline.
This comes as all new properties under the refreshed Oakwood brand will feature on-site dining options.
As at Jan 23, more than half of Oakwood properties offer dining on-property services, which feature various culinary options, Ascott said.

title: OpenAI, SoftBank to commit $26 billion each to Trump’s Stargate AI project, says report
summary:
– SoftBank Group and OpenAI each plan to commit US$19 billion (S$26 billion) of capital to Stargate, the mega US artificial intelligence (AI) endeavour President Donald Trump unveiled this week, the Information reported.
Stargate will initially deploy US$100 billion, and the rest of the funding is expected over the next four years.
The project to construct data centres and other infrastructure is being led by SoftBank and OpenAI.
Mr Altman told colleagues that Stargate was like a venture fund, with OpenAI and SoftBank as its general partners, the Information said.
Mr Trump has made it clear that US leadership in AI is a priority for his administration.

title: American firms in China fearful of US-China trade turmoil at 5-year high, shows survey
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe annual survey by AmCham in China showed 51 per cent of respondents were concerned about a future deterioration in the US-China relationship.
The annual survey by the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in China showed 51 per cent of respondents were concerned about a future deterioration in the US-China relationship.
Geopolitical tensions, policy uncertainties and trade disputes are the major concerns of US businesses in China, AmCham China said.
The survey of 368 AmCham China member companies was completed between October and November 2024, partly after Mr Trump won the presidential election on Nov 5.
Almost half of the respondents still rank China as a top-three global investment priority, around the same level as 2024.

title: Japan’s exports rise as world awaits Trump tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxExports likely received a lift from last-minute demand anticipating fresh tariffs under US President Donald Trump.
– Japan’s exports rose for a third straight month in December on the back of a weaker yen, as businesses waited for further clarity on likely US trade policy in President Donald Trump’s second term.
The yen averaged 152.48 per US dollar in December, 3.8 per cent weaker than a year earlier, the report said.
A weaker yen tends to help exporters become more competitive, while it makes imports of energy and food more expensive.
Before the report was released, analysts at SMBC Nikko Securities wrote in a note that exports probably got a lift from last-minute demand anticipating fresh tariffs under Mr Trump.

title: South Korea’s economy barely grows in Q4 as political crisis jolts 2025 outlook
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxBank of Korea and economists expect the political crisis to remain a dampener on growth in 2025 too.
– South Korea’s economy barely grew in the fourth quarter of 2024, as the country’s worst political crisis in decades hurts already weakened domestic demand and threatens to further sap growth in a year of rising external risks under a second Trump presidency.
Worryingly, the BOK and economists expect the political crisis to remain a dampener on growth in 2025 too.
In the October to December quarter, GDP grew 1.2 per cent on an annual basis, the slowest pace since the second quarter of 2023.
Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok, serving as acting president, said earlier this week the government was willing to discuss it with Parliament.

title: Hit Netflix show Culinary Class Wars heats up Seoul restaurant scene
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox– In September, Seoul’s fine dining scene received a big boost with the premiere of hit Netflix cooking competition Culinary Class Wars.
His restaurant Choi Dot, in the affluent Cheongdam-dong neighbourhood, has always been popular, but Culinary Class Wars has brought a whole new level of fame.
According to the chef, Trid has also been fully booked since the release of Culinary Class Wars.
The buoyed interest in Culinary Class Wars-linked dining rooms comes as Seoul is seeing a strong rebound in tourism, nearly on a par with pre-pandemic levels.
Culinary Class Wars is one of the latest shows to benefit.

title: Chipmaker SK Hynix posts record quarterly profit surpassing Samsung on AI boom
summary:
– South Korea’s SK Hynix has forecast that sales of its high-end semiconductors used in generative artificial intelligence (AI) chipsets would double in 2025 after reporting a record quarterly profit that surpassed its bigger rival Samsung.
The world’s second-biggest memory chipmaker posted an operating profit of 8.1 trillion won (S$7.64 billion) in the October-December quarter, exceeding Samsung’s forecast fourth-quarter operating profit of 6.5 trillion won.
This is the first time that SK Hynix’s quarterly operating profit beat Samsung’s, analysts said, as its rival lags in supplying high-end HBM chips to Nvidia.
The company said its HBM chips accounted for 40 per cent of its total Dram revenue in the fourth quarter.
SK Hynix said it began supply of 12-layer HBM3E chips, the most advanced HBM model currently in mass production, to a customer in the fourth quarter.

title: Microsoft poised to benefit from Trump’s $677 billion AI project with zero money
summary:
– When US President Donald Trump joined tech executives on Jan 21 to tout a US$500 billion (S$677 billion) artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure project led in part by OpenAI, one question sprang to mind: where’s Microsoft?
In 2023, Microsoft was close to a deal to invest tens of billions of additional dollars in OpenAI, according to people familiar with the situation.
The revised deal between OpenAI and Microsoft indicates that the two companies continue to work together closely, the person added.
The Stargate joint venture and rejigged partnership with OpenAI also lets Microsoft offload some AI spending onto rivals.
When asked by CNBC to comment on the Stargate joint venture, Mr Nadella said: “Look, all I know is I’m good for my US$80 billion.” BLOOMBERG

title: S&P 500 hits record high with boost from Netflix results, AI investment plan
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, during morning trading on Jan 22 in New York City.
NEW YORK - Wall Street’s indexes rose on Jan 22, with the benchmark S&P 500 hitting a record high during the session, as investors cheered streaming video provider Netflix’s quarterly report and technology shares rallied a day after US President Donald Trump announced a private-sector artificial intelligence infrastructure plan.
The technology sector was the biggest gainer among the S&P 500‘s 11 major industry indexes with hefty boosts from AI chip leader Nvidia and Microsoft.
Netflix rallied sharply after the company reported a record number of subscribers for the holiday quarter, enabling it to increase prices for most service plans.
“This is just the excitement about the technology investments,” said Ms Irene Tunkel, chief US equity strategist at BCA Research, noting the market’s narrow breadth on Jan 22.

title: Easing of Houthi sanctions on Red Sea ships could free up capacity but lead to congestion at ports
summary:
More than 134 ships have been attacked in the Red Sea in 12 months, according to a UN Security Council Panel of Experts report on Yemen published in October 2024.
It took many months and extreme disruption to achieve this stability, so carriers will be wary of heading back to the Red Sea too soon.
Mr Sand warned that there will be severe disruption in the immediate period following a return of ships to the Red Sea.
Many vessels initially arrived together or unscheduled at the Singapore port owing to less predictable shipping schedules.
Should the Red Sea fully reopen, however, the main economic impact would be a sudden availability of ships and capacity, which could drive down freight rates for shippers and consumers.

title: Volvo opens Singapore facility to support its electric vehicle ambitions
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Volvo tech hub consists of a research and development lab and office space for engineers.
SINGAPORE – Auto giant Volvo has set up a facility here to support its ambitions to become a fully electric carmaker and a technology leader.
The Volvo tech hub, officially opened on Jan 22, spans 9,423 sq ft and consists of a research and development lab and office space for engineers.
Its site in Krakow, Poland, focuses on software engineering development, while the one in India tackles functions such as IT support.
The Singapore hub will be key to deep tech and advanced engineering development for Volvo, said Dr Tan.

title: STI ends 0.4% lower amid mixed Asian trading and Trump’s tariff remarks
summary:
SINGAPORE – Wall Street’s rally overnight failed to inspire local investors, who sent shares down a notch on Jan 22, following newly inaugurated US President Donald Trump’s trade tariff remarks, while regional bourses were mainly higher.
New York markets were buoyant on the prospect of Mr T rump’s return to Washington, but t he benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.4 per cent , or 14.16 points, to 3,781.21.
On the broader market, losers outpaced gainers 280 to 205 on trade of 1.3 billion securities worth $1.2 billion.
Chinese stocks were in the red amid Mr Trump’s tariff threats.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 gained 1.6 per cent, South Korea’s Kospi rose 1.2 per cent and Malaysian shares were up 0.5 per cent.

title: TikTok owner ByteDance plans to spend $16b on AI chips in 2025
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe move comes amid pressure from Washington to sell TikTok in the United States.
BENGALURU – ByteDance is placing a big bet on artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure as the TikTok parent plans to spend more than US$12 billion (S$16.3 billion) on AI in 2025, the Financial Times reported on J an 21 , citing sources.
This move comes as the Chinese company faces pressure from Washington to sell its popular video-sharing app in the United States.
ByteDance plans to spend 40 billion yuan (S$7.5 billion) to acquire AI chips in China in 2025, the report said.
Beijing has given its tech companies informal guidance to buy at least 30 per cent of their chips from the country’s own suppliers, the report said.

title: Major overhaul to supercharge Singapore’s trade associations and chambers
summary:
SINGAPORE – A major overhaul is looming for Singapore’s trade associations and chambers (TACs) that will sharpen their skills, boost efficiency and expand their ability to drive economic growth.
They fall into four main areas: sector value proposition, human capital development, operational excellence and governance.
The plan was unveiled at the inaugural TAC Summit by Ms Low Yen Ling, Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry, as well as Culture, Community and Youth.
The road map aims to help TACs improve how they collaborate with one another, acquire necessary skills and embrace innovation.
Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling launching SBF’s Sector Transformation Map at the inaugural TAC Summit on Jan 22.

title: China’s luxury sales see biggest drop in a decade amid economic slowdown
summary:
