title: Australian casino giant Star on brink of collapse as cash runs out
summary:
SYDNEY – Australia’s biggest listed casino operator, Star Entertainment Group, once had it all.
Now Star is bleeding cash, desperate for funding and – by some analyst estimates – has a 50-50 chance of collapsing.
Almost A$4 billion (S$3.4 billion) has been wiped from Star’s market capitalisation since late 2021, leaving the company valued at just A$387 million.
Earnings are under pressure from a cost-of-living crisis and analysts expect Star to lose money for a fourth straight year.
At the same time, daily gambling cash limits at the flagship Sydney casino are due to drop to A$1,000 by August as the authorities attempt to limit personal losses and eliminate money-laundering opportunities.

title: Marco Polo Marine responds to Sias over wage and bonus rise despite revenue drop
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMarco Polo Marine said that although revenue declined in FY2024, gross profit and adjusted net profit increased.
SINGAPORE – Marine logistics company Marco Polo Marine said the increase in its wages, salaries and bonuses in financial year 2024 is “in line with the expansion plans” that the group took in recent years.
Marco Polo Marine also confirmed that construction of the CSOV has remained within the initial budget of US$60 million (S$82 million).
Sias queried how the company would compete against Chinese shipyards, given that their reopening has lowered demand for ship repair.
Marco Polo Marine said there was an overstatement of the group’s non-controlling interest balance against its foreign currency translation reserves in its FY2024 results announced on Nov 28, 2024.

title: Citigroup axes more staff as part of cost-cutting plan
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxCitigroup set out an aim in 2024 to reduce jobs by 20,000 by end 2026.
NEW YORK – Citigroup eliminated more jobs this week after going through an overhaul last year, as part of a sweeping reorganisation under chief executive officer Jane Fraser to curb costs.
Managing directors in the wealth business and technology unit are leaving, according to people familiar with the matter.
“Leadership changes, retirements and targeted staff changes are all normal course when running a business,” Citigroup said in an e-mailed statement.
Headcount was 229,000 as of the end of the fourth quarter, down by 10,000 from a year earlier.

title: Record $27 billion pulled from US environmental, social and governance funds
summary:
– US fund managers trying to sell environmental, social and governance (ESG) strategies just had their worst year ever.
According to data provided by Morningstar, US sustainable funds suffered almost US$20 billion (S$27 billion) of net redemptions in 2024, up from roughly US$13 billion in 2023.
Withdrawals from ESG funds contrasted with inflows to conventional funds, which attracted about US$740 billion of net new money, according to Morningstar.
Since then, an energy crisis, soaring inflation and higher interest rates have pummelled green returns, opening the door for sceptics to make their case.
“Under the new Trump administration, we may see litigation pressures exacerbate ‘greenhushing’ where companies downplay their sustainability efforts,” Ms Bioy said.

title: Singapore’s December exports beat forecasts with 9% rise, but uncertainty ahead as Trump tariffs loom
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxFor the whole of 2024, Singapore's key exports grew 0.9 per cent, analysts estimate.
SINGAPORE – Singapore’s key exports beat market forecasts in December 2024 in its second straight month of growth, but analysts said the road ahead is uncertain as the threat of Trump tariffs looms.
Year on year, electronics exports expanded 18.6 per cent in December, after a 23.1 per cent rise in the previous month.
Singapore’s exports to the US grew by 30.7 per cent in December, after it fell 19.4 per cent in the month before.
Exports to Malaysia grew by 24.2 per cent in December, due to chips, other computer peripherals and non-monetary gold.

title: China’s new home prices stabilise with stimulus push
summary:
On an annual basis, new home prices fell 5.3 per cent following a 5.7 per cent drop in the preceding month.
Home sales have slumped in China since the property market was hit by a crisis in 2021.
However, he cautioned that the overall property market has not bottomed out yet.
That view was supported by the steady month-on-month prices and price increases in first-tier cities in December.
Property investment in 2024 fell 10.6 per cent from the previous year, marking the largest annual decline on record, according to separate official data.

title: BP to cut 4,700 jobs and 3,000 contractor roles to reduce costs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe company has stopped or paused 30 projects since last June.
– BP is eliminating 4,700 positions, about 5 per cent of its workforce, and more than 3,000 contractor jobs, chief executive Murray Auchincloss told staff on Jan 16 as the London-based energy giant seeks to reduce costs.
The company has stopped or paused 30 projects since last June to focus on those that make the most money.
BP has fallen further behind its fellow oil majors during Mr Auchincloss’ tenure as CEO and is now worth less than half as much as Shell.
The company aims to cut costs by US$2 billion (S$2.7 billion) by end-2026.

title: Mining giants Rio Tinto, Glencore said to weigh $216 billion mega merger
summary:
LONDON - Rio Tinto Group and Glencore have been discussing combining their businesses, which if successful would rank as the largest-ever mining deal and create a US$158 billion ($216 billion) behemoth to rival longstanding leader BHP Group.
Rio Tinto is the world’s second-biggest miner, with a market value of about US$103 billion ($140.8 billion) at the close of trading in London on Jan 16, while Glencore was valued at about US$55 billion.
Both Glencore and Rio own some of the best copper mines in the world.
It has exited coal mining completely and instead sought to grow its copper and lithium businesses.
A combination with Rio would raise questions about Glencore’s coal mining assets, which is a business that Rio exited several years ago.

title: CDL divests over $600 million of assets in 2024, including Suzhou project
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe divestment of the retail and office components of Hong Leong City Centre in Suzhou is slated for completion this quarter.
The completed divestments include a Ransome’s Wharf site in London and freehold eight-storey industrial building Cideco Industrial Complex in Singapore.
Strata units in Citilink Warehouse Complex, Cititech Industrial Building, Fortune Centre and Sunshine Plaza in Singapore were also divested.
It said the divestment of the retail and office components of Hong Leong City Centre (HLCC) , a mixed-use development in Suzhou, is slated for completion this quarter.
Completed in 2018, HLCC, which is located in Suzhou Industrial Park, includes residential towers, a Grade A office tower, a retail mall and a hotel flagged as M Social Suzhou .

title: China begins probe into US chip grants, alleged dumping
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina will investigate allegations that the US dumps lower-end chips and unfairly subsidies its own chipmakers.
- China will investigate allegations that the US dumps lower-end chips and unfairly subsidises its own chipmakers, in potentially one of Beijing’s strongest retaliatory moves against American technology sanctions.
“The US Chips and Science Act violates the fundamental principles of a market economy and caused profound and significant impact on the global semiconductor supply chain,” the China Semiconductor Industry Association said in a WeChat statement .
Micron Technology warned in 2023 that about half of its sales tied to China-headquartered clients may be hit by the country’s cyber-security probe.
Just this week, the Biden administration unfurled regulations intended to curb the supply of artificial intelligence accelerators to China.

title: US stocks end lower, unable to extend rally
summary:
NEW YORK - Wall Street stocks finished lower on Jan 16 following a meandering session, as the market gave back some of the gains from the previous session.
Major indices spent part of the day in positive territory but were unable to extend a Jan 15 rally following consumer pricing data that reassured investors about the inflation outlook.
“It’s been a lacklustre day for stocks after surging yesterday,” said a note from Briefing.com.
US retail sales grew 0.4 per cent from November to December, a slower pace than in November but still a solid increase.
Financial heavyweights Bank of America and Morgan Stanley added to the trove of solid bank earnings.

title: Trump Treasury pick Bessent backs US Fed independence, dollar, sanctions on Russian oil
summary:
“If we do not renew and extend, then we will be facing an economic calamity,” Mr Bessent said.
Increased US oil production would allow for tougher sanctions on Russian oil majors, he said.
Mr Bessent coolly fielded questions ranging from US competition with China, to child tax credits, and did not stray from answers consistent with previous Republican Treasury nominees.
“I think on monetary policy decisions, the FOMC should be independent,” Mr Bessent said, referring to the Fed’s rate-setting panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
“Treasury - along with the whole of government and Congress - has used its borrowing capacity to save the union, save the world, and save the American people,” Mr Bessent said.

title: UOB inks MOU with chambers of commerce to boost collaboration, investments in Johor-S’pore SEZ
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUOB inked the MOU with the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry and the Associated Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia.
SINGAPORE – UOB has signed an agreement to boost collaboration and investment opportunities in the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ).
The bank inked the memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI) and the Associated Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia (ACCCIM) on Jan 16.
UOB and the Chinese chambers will also jointly organise activities such as visits, conferences and networking events, as well as propose new initiatives aimed at connecting businesses with opportunities.
However, more details are needed in order to know if the MOU will indeed help Singapore’s transport companies, Mr Lim said.

title: PSA International reports handling a record 100.2 million containers in 2024
summary:
SINGAPORE – PSA International (PSA) handled a record number of containers worldwide in 2024 despite escalating geopolitical tensions and greater maritime uncertainty.
It is also the first time PSA has reported a container throughput of more than 100 million TEUs in a single year, it said.
Container throughput refers to the total number of containers handled by a port or terminal over a specific period.
PSA’s terminal in Singapore achieved a throughput of 40.9 million TEUs in 2024, up 5.5 per cent from 2023.
Its terminals outside the country handled 59.2 million TEUs, an increase of 5.7 per cent.

title: SBF-PwC Budget wishlist includes help for S’pore SMEs with M&A and simpler listing rules
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inbox(From left) SBF chief policy officer Musa Fazal, SBF CEO Kok Ping Soon, PwC Singapore executive chairman Marcus Lam and PwC Singapore tax leader Lennon Lee.
SBF and PwC Singapore have come up with a Budget wish list.
SINGAPORE – Initiatives to help firms deal with rising business costs and expand via mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are centre stage in a Budget wish list put forward by PwC Singapore and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF).
Another significant recommendation for Feb 18’s Budget suggests deepening local capital markets and encouraging more SMEs to list on the Singapore Exchange.
Another recommendation looks at combining two existing financing schemes into a new Enterprise and Workforce Transformation Grant to encourage businesses to improve both their operations and their workforce simultaneously.

title: British activist investor Palliser seeks to disrupt ‘unfair’ Great Eastern takeover
summary:
SINGAPORE - Any privatisation deal must be fair and reasonable, said the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or Sias, after British activist investor Palliser Capital protested against insurer Great Eastern’s proposed takeover by OCBC Bank.
The investor is looking to disrupt the takeover of Great Eastern (GE), the Financial Times (FT) reported on Jan 15.
Palliser also reportedly complained to MAS about the insurer’s refusal to meet the activist investor over the issue, FT added.
OCBC made a $1.4 billion bid on May 10, 2024, to take GE private following shareholder unhappiness over falling returns.
“Sias also highlighted that GE would not be allowed to delist given that the offer was ‘not fair’,” he said.

title: US inflation data, Wall St rally lift Singapore shares; STI adds 0.8%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUS markets set the theme for the day after new inflation numbers revived expectations of interest rate cuts.
SINGAPORE – Better inflation data in the US and the Wall Street surge that followed set the tone for a positive day across regional markets on Jan 16.
The optimistic sentiment here lifted the Straits Times Index (STI) 0.8 per cent or 28.55 points to 3,801.13.
US markets set the theme for the day after new inflation numbers revived expectations of interest rate cuts.
The Dow rose 1.65 per cent, the S&P 500 advanced 1.83 per cent and the Nasdaq ended 2.45 per cent higher.

title: Singapore chip gear maker GVT says AI boom far from over
summary:
That is a boon for up-and-coming equipment suppliers such as GVT, as chipmakers need to invest in their production systems.
“We are riding on the AI wave,” Mr Ng said in an interview.
Those saying AI is a bubble are wrong because many industries have yet to adopt the technology, he added.
While still a niche player in the chip ecosystem, GVT has tripled its annual revenue – and stock price – since its 2019 stock market debut in Singapore.
Last week, Micron announced a US$7 billion (S$9.6 billion) plan to make HBM chips in Singapore.

title: TSMC drives record investment into US, Japan in China decoupling
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWashinton is offering companies like TSMC grants and loans to start production in the US in tech rivalry with China.
- Taiwanese companies invested a record amount of money in the US and Japan in 2024 while the figure for China stagnated – highlighting supply chain shifts resulting from tech rivalries and worsening cross-strait ties.
In contrast, new investments into China rose only slightly to US$3.65 billion in 2024 .
Also, relations between China and Taiwan have worsened since May 2024 , when President Lai Ching-te took charge of the democracy of 23 million people.
TSMC, however, faces headwinds from US government technology restrictions on China and uncertainty about potential Trump tariffs.

title: SIA, Scoot carried record number of passengers in December
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSIA carried 2.4 million passengers in December, up 9.6 per cent from a year ago, while Scoot’s passengers stood at 1.1 million, up 2.3 per cent.
SINGAPORE – National carrier Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its low-cost arm Scoot carried a total of 3.6 million passengers in December 2024, a monthly record for the SIA group.
In particular, SIA carried 2.4 million passengers in December 2024, up 9.6 per cent from 2.2 million in the year-ago period.
For the whole of 2024, the group ferried 39 million passengers, 12.7 per cent more than the 34.6 million in 2023.
SIA served 80 destinations, and Scoot served 72.

title: Hong Kong weighs raising taxes on top earners for second year
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxEven after the increase in 2024, Hong Kong’s income tax rates are attractive compared with many other financial centres.
– Hong Kong’s government is exploring options to raise taxes on the city’s highest earners for a second straight year to plug shortfalls in its budget, according to people familiar with the matter.
Even after the increase, Hong Kong’s income tax rates are attractive compared with many other financial centres including New York and London.
The latest considerations came amid a nascent recovery in Hong Kong’s financial labour market after a bruising talent exodus in the pandemic years.
That pushed the total licensees to a record as banks and asset managers bet on Hong Kong’s push to become the world’s biggest wealth management hub.

title: Temasek said to be interested in Blackstone’s $4b sale of Bob Dylan, Adele song rights
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSingapore’s Temasek, Apollo Global Management and Warburg Pincus have reportedly expressed interest in the sale, which includes music from Bob Dylan and Adele.
Blackstone, one of the world’s biggest asset managers, is testing what has been a frothy market for so-called performance rights.
Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music company, went public in 2021 and is currently valued at about US$46 billion.
They have pumped money into catalogues, distribution, service providers and performance rights organisations.
A year earlier, private equity firm New Mountain Capital paid a reported US$1.7 billion for BMI, one of the largest performance rights groups.

title: British activist investor Palliser takes protest against Great Eastern takeover to MAS, SGX
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxAccording to FT, Palliser Capital said Great Eastern’s board was “highly complacent” in recommending the offer.
SINGAPORE - London-based activist investor Palliser Capital is looking to disrupt the takeover of insurer Great Eastern by majority shareholder OCBC Bank, the Financial Times reported on Jan 15.
According to FT, Palliser – which has a stake in Great Eastern – accused OCBC of treating minority shareholders unfairly in its attempted full takeover of the company.
The offer did, however, result in Great Eastern breaching the minimum free float requirement and its shares being suspended from trading.
SGX has given Great Eastern until Jan 24 to explore options to comply with the free float requirements.

title: Job searching, hiring in S’pore got tougher in 2024 amid rapidly changing skill needs: LinkedIn
summary:
This outstrips a global average of 50 per cent in Singapore and 16 other markets.
Conversely, half of the 500 hiring professionals LinkedIn polled separately said it has become more challenging to find qualified talent over the past year.
ST PHOTO: MARK CHEONGOver the same period, skill needs are estimated to change by 64 per cent in India and 66 per cent in Australia.
From 2024 to 2030, the change in required skills in Singapore is over 30 per cent.
This means members could get recommended better job matches, with more nuanced matching that goes beyond just keywords.

title: US stocks pop on inflation data, strong earnings
summary:
NEW YORK - US stocks jumped on Jan 15, reversing a recent decline as traders responded enthusiastically to strong bank earnings and data indicating a slowdown in underlying inflation.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 1.7 per cent at 43,221.55, while the broad-based S&P 500 jumped 1.8 per cent to 5,949.91.
And fresh data showed headline inflation rose in the 12 months to December, but actually eased once volatile food and energy prices were stripped out, fueling optimism in the markets.
“There’s a lot of relief from the (inflation) data this morning,” Mr Angelo Kourkafas, of Edward Jones, told AFP, noting there had been a positive reaction in the markets to the decline in the so-called “core” inflation measure.
Among individual firms, Tesla’s shares soared by 8 per cent, as did those of Bank of New York Mellon after it reported strong quarterly earnings results.

title: Hindenburg founder to close short seller behind $136 billion Adani stocks sell-off
summary:
“That day is today.”In 2023, another famous short seller decided to shut down his firm.
One of Hindenburg’s reports was a bet against Indian conglomerate Adani Group in 2023 that led to more than US$100 billion (S$136 billion) in value wiped off the group’s shares.
The short seller accused Adani Group of using offshore tax havens improperly, which the company denied.
The short seller said Nikola deceived investors about its technological developments.
“I now view Hindenburg as a chapter in my life, not a central thing that defines me,” Mr Anderson wrote.

title: Waterfront living 15 mins from S'pore: Tropicana-Banyan Group launch JB luxury serviced apartments
summary:
This reality awaits at Skypark Kepler, where the 2026 completion of the RTS Link will transform cross-border luxury living from vision to reality.
As part of the Lido Waterfront Boulevard Township, Skypark Kepler brings resort-style amenities to urban living.
The development’s shared spaces include fitness centres, gardens, recreational areas and access to the Banyan Sanctuary Club and Banyan Living.
In terms of pricing, Skypark Kepler stands out: There are units available for under RM1 million (approximately S$303,000).
It offers a glimpse of what the future of urban living might look like amid a rapidly changing landscape.

title: Indonesian central bank announces surprise rate cut
summary:
- Indonesia’s central bank unexpectedly announced a cut in its key interest rate on Jan 15 in a bid to boost economic growth and a weakening rupiah.
Bank Indonesia lowered the benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 5.75 per cent, citing a shift in policy to bolster stability and growth.
Its two other main rates were also cut by 25 basis points.
It marks the first rate cut since September.
Mr Warjiyo said Bank Indonesia projected that economic growth would be slower in 2025 compared with 2024.

title: US consumer prices rose for third straight month to 2.9% in December
summary:
The consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.4 per cent in December after climbing 0.3 per cent in November, the Labour Department’s Bureau of Labour Statistics said on Jan 15.
In the 12 months through December, the CPI was up 2.9 per cent after rising 2.7 per cent in November.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast the CPI gaining 0.3 per cent and rising 2.9 per cent year on year.
Goldman Sachs expects two rate cuts in 2025 , in June and December, revised down from three.
The last reduction was in December, when policymakers also projected two rate cuts in 2025 instead of the four they had forecast in September 2024.

title: Singapore shares decline on weak sentiment; STI falls 0.4%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe STI index was led by integrated resort operator Genting Singapore, which added 2 per cent to close at 75 cents.
The wary sentiment left the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4 per cent or 16.19 points to 3,772.58, with gainers outnumbering losers 241 to 217 on trade of 875.2 million securities worth $1.1 billion.
The STI index was led by integrated resort operator Genting Singapore, which added 2 per cent to close at 75 cents.
DBS Group Research said the gradual lease up of Clint’s gross power within its data centres will be “a shot in the arm for Clint to realise its value”.
“We see brighter prospects of a partial stake sale of data centres to partners... which will significantly unlock value for the Reit and right-size its overall capex commitments towards completing these data centres.”

title: Cabbies, platform workers can be legally represented by 3 associations: NTUC
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxNTUC has been advocating for platform workers, starting with taxi drivers through the NTA in 2010.
SINGAPORE – Cabbies, ride-hailing drivers and freelance delivery workers now have better legal protection under the Platform Workers Act.
This means they now have legal powers to potentially represent the 67,600 or so workers in Singapore and negotiate with platform operators for better conditions.
The National Trades Union Congress has been advocating for platform workers, starting with taxi drivers through the NTA in 2010.
The three platform work associations have already set up the NTUC Care Fund (Work Injury Relief), which hands out $250 worth of grocery vouchers if workers are injured on the job.

title: Roxy Square owners aim to cut asking price by 11% to $1.12 billion in another en-bloc bid
summary:
SINGAPORE – Freehold Roxy Square will be relaunched for collective sale again, but this time, plans are under way to lower the reserve price by 10.8 per cent to $1.12 billion, sole marketing agent JLL said on Jan 15.
They are now collecting signatures to get an 80 per cent mandate to cut the reserve price from $1.25 billion.
Based on the proposed reserve price of $1.12 billion, the unit land rate will be reduced to $1,852 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), from $2,094 psf ppr previously.
Built in three phases from the early 1980s to 2000, Roxy Square comprises Roxy Square Shopping Centre and the 576-room Grand Mercure Singapore Roxy hotel.
“The proposed reduction in reserve price, if supported by the majority owners, enhances the site’s appeal, especially considering the area’s consistent demand for quality residences.”

title: Crypto crime value likely hit a high of $56 billion in 2024, says report
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe total value of cryptocurrencies sent to illicit addresses in 2024 is expected to hit a high of US$51 billion over time.
SINGAPORE - The value of cryptocurrency that was sent to illegal digital addresses in 2024 is likely to surpass 2023 numbers, a Chainalysis report said.
The American blockchain analytics firm said in its 2025 crypto crime report released on Jan 15 that US$40.9 billion (S$56 billion) in cryptocurrencies was received by illicit addresses in 2024 based on its findings, lower than the US$46.1 billion in 2023.
But, as it continues to find more data throughout 2025, the firm estimates that the total value in 2024 could hit a high of US$51 billion .
In general, the total value in crypto crime excludes revenue from non-crypto-native crime, such as traditional drug trafficking, and other crimes in which crypto may be used as a means of payment or laundering.

title: Oil shipping rates extend rally after US imposes wider sanctions against Russia
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxTraders are expected to seek more tankers to load crude from Saudi Arabia in February, which could drive freight rates higher.
SINGAPORE – Oil shipping rates extended their rally on expectations of a tightening in global tanker supply from wider US sanctions on Russia’s fleet and traders’ demand for ships to load Middle East oil for Asia, industry sources said on Jan 15.
For comparison, China’s Unipec earlier booked two VLCCs for late January loading from the Middle East at WS51-52.25.
Traders are expected to seek more tankers to load crude from Saudi Arabia in February, which could drive freight rates higher, the shipbroker added.
Surging freight costs and spot premiums for Middle East crude are squeezing Asian refiners’ margins.

title: German specialty chemicals firm Munzing opens regional office in Singapore
summary:
SINGAPORE – A German company that makes chemicals used in areas like construction and food processing has opened an office here to exploit opportunities in the region.
Munzing’s facility at the German Centre in Jurong’s International Business Park is its first in Singapore and will serve as the company’s Asia-Pacific headquarters.
The company has also set up a 500 sq m warehouse near the office to help move its products, which include construction chemicals and food processing additives, across regional markets.
Munzing chief executive Michael Munzing speaking at the opening ceremony of the company’s first office in Singapore.
PHOTO: MUNZINGMr Dino Tan, head of Europe at the Economic Development Board (EDB), noted that Munzing’s presence will contribute to the growth and innovation capabilities of Singapore’s chemicals sector.

title: CapitaLand India Trust inks deal with global hyperscaler amid fast-growing data centre demand
summary:
SINGAPORE – CapitaLand India Trust’s (Clint) manager announced on Jan 15 that it has signed a long-term agreement with a leading global hyperscaler for one of its data centres under development.
It is also developing four facilities in the key data centre corridors of India, which are Mumbai, Chennai, Hyderabad and Bengaluru.
“With the support of our sponsor, CapitaLand Investment (CLI), we are well poised to meet the fast-growing demand for data centre capacity in India,” said Mr Nagabhushanam.
India – a core market for CLI – demonstrates “strong growth potential” across asset classes Clint is active in, including data centres.
CLI has 27 data centres globally and offers more than 800 MW of gross power on a “completed basis”.

title: Ho Bee Land joins race to acquire Australian property developer AVJennings
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxHo Bee Land currently indirectly holds a 5.49 per cent stake in AVJennings.
SINGAPORE – Real estate group Ho Bee Land has launched a non-binding indicative offer to acquire all shares it does not indirectly own in AVJennings for A$0.70 apiece.
Ho Bee Land said on Jan 15 the total consideration of the deal would amount to about A$390.7 million (S$330.5 million).
“The proposed transaction represents a good opportunity for the group to enhance its scale and capabilities in Australia,” noted Ho Bee Land.
Ho Bee Land noted that the proposed transaction is not expected to have a material impact on the company’s consolidated net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2025.

title: South Korea’s jobless rate jumps as political turmoil hits economy
summary:
SEOUL – South Korea’s unemployment rate rose to the highest level in more than three years as the number of jobs dropped, offering further evidence of an economy shaken by a martial-law row and a deadly airline crash .
South Korea lost 52,000 jobs compared with a year earlier, in the first contraction since February 2021.
The deterioration in the job market comes as consumer and business confidence slumps by the most since the outbreak of Covid-19.
Pessimism over the economy grew further when a Jeju Air plane crashed at a south-western airport in late December, killing 179 people onboard.
The BOK is set to meet on Jan 16 for the first decision of the year.

title: Only 25% of companies in Asia-Pacific consider nature-related issues important to operations
summary:
Singapore also came out tops in the number of companies that integrated nature-related issues into their overall risk management, according to the study.
NTU Associate Professor Kelvin Law, who teaches accounting, noted that nature disclosures are broader than climate-related ones.
In this way, the biggest challenge for companies is in how to measure their nature-related impact, the experts said.
Some Singapore companies that have taken the lead in producing nature-related disclosures include property developer City Developments, UOB and Olam Group’s Olam Agri and Olam Food Ingredients.
Prof Law said: “Although climate-related disclosures have become increasingly mandatory globally, nature-related disclosures remain voluntary.

title: Chinese developer Country Garden reveals $33 billion loss for 2023 in delayed report
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe property giant pledged to clinch a deal with creditors on a debt restructuring plan by June.
– Country Garden Holdings suffered another record loss in 2023 as the Chinese property giant pledged to clinch a deal with creditors on a debt restructuring plan by June.
The embattled firm reported a loss attributable to shareholders of 178.4 billion yuan (S$33.3 billion) for the year, compared with a loss of six billion yuan in 2022, according to an exchange filing on Jan 14.
Its loss narrowed in the first half of 2024 to 12.8 billion yuan, from 48.9 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.
Creditors tend to pursue such actions to speed up the debt restructuring by expediting talks on a repayment plan.

title: Cordlife’s licences for cord blood banking, human tissue banking services renewed for a year
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxPreviously, Cordlife was allowed to resume its cord blood banking services on a limited basis.
SINGAPORE – Cordlife announced its cord blood banking service and human tissue banking service licences have been renewed by the Ministry of Health (MOH) for one year, with effect from Jan 14.
This was after follow-up audits by MOH showed that Cordlife met the requirements to resume its provision of cord blood banking services.
Cryopreserved cord blood units in seven of its 22 storage tanks were exposed to suboptimal storage temperatures.
The result was that about 7,500 cord blood units were considered non-viable and unlikely to be suitable for stem cell transplants.

title: S’pore must continue to attract investors to build regional HQs, grow wealth here: Chee Hong Tat
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSecond Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat at a fireside chat with Ms Patricia Quek, head of UBS Wealth Management Singapore, during the UBS Asia Wealth Forum 2025 on Jan 14.
The wealth management sector continues to flourish, with the number of single-family offices growing to more than 2,000 by the end of 2024, said Mr Chee.
Singapore has been working with such Chinese firms to build their regional hubs here, Mr Chee said.
He added that the financial sector has seen good progress in the past few years, and noted that wealth management and financial services remain key growth areas.
Wealth management assets in Singapore have grown by an average of about 10 per cent per year over the past five years.

title: More options for S’pore bond investors with US Treasury yields closing in on 5%
summary:
Germany’s 10-year bond yields, which are the benchmark for the euro area, rose to a seven- month high.
Singapore’s 10-year government bond yields have also risen, climbing from around 2.7 per cent to 2.8 per cent in December 2024, to over 3 per cent this month.
Returns on shorter-term six-month Treasury bills in Singapore have risen in tandem with the increase in longer-dated bond yields here.
T-bills became popular with retail investors here when yields climbed along with interest rate hikes in the US in 2022 and 2023.
DBS Bank added that investors should opt for high-quality, investment-grade bonds, as opposed to riskier high-yield bonds, or junk bonds.

title: Singapore shares bleed red ink; STI falls 0.1%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe benchmark Straits Times Index declined 0.1 per cent or 2.93 points to 3,788.77.
SINGAPORE - Shares in Singapore were in the red on Jan 14, amid a mixed regional showing.
Across the broader market, advancers beat decliners 278 to 226, with 938.1 million securities worth $994.3 million traded.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index rose 1.8 per cent, while South Korea’s Kospi Composite Index gained 0.3 per cent.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 fell 1.8 per cent, while the Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index declined 0.6 per cent.

title: Digital asset banking group Sygnum turns unicorn after raising $80m
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxCrypto banking group Sygnum will use the funds to expand its product portfolio with a focus on Bitcoin technology.
SINGAPORE – Digital asset banking group Sygnum, which is based in Singapore and Switzerland, has raised US$58 million (S$80 million) to bring its valuation to more than US$1 billion, a unicorn company in start-up parlance.
He said the investment in Sygnum “coincides with a potential inflection point for Bitcoin’s institutional adoption and regulatory clarity”.
In a statement on Jan 14, the group said it has more than US$5 billion in total client assets.
In July 2024, Sygnum launched a round-the-clock multi-asset settlement network that counts members such as digital asset exchange AsiaNext and prime broker Hidden Road.

title: Singapore could end up as ‘collateral damage’ under Trump 2.0 tariffs: Chan Heng Chee
summary:
Professor Chan Heng Chee, ambassador-at-large at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Singapore , said: “What the US does or does not do matters to the whole world.
Prof Chan added that free trade agreements (FTAs) with the US are not foolproof.
Unlike in his first presidency, Trump is more confident and prepared for his second term, said Prof Chan.
On China, Prof Chan has a positive view and believes it is only a matter of time before the world’s second-largest economy recovers.
Prof Chan also delivered Professor Tommy Koh’s keynote address at the forum as he was feeling unwell.

title: China to roll out broad stimulus to offset impact of US tariffs, says Goldman
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxUS President-elect Donald Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Chinese imports at rates as high as 60 per cent.
– China will use a broad range of stimulus measures to offset the effects of expected US tariffs and a persisting housing downturn, according to Goldman Sachs Group.
Mr Hatzius added that tariffs on Chinese shipments and auto imports from Europe are “going to have an impact” on US inflation and growth, though “not a huge impact”.
US President-elect Donald Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Chinese imports at rates as high as 60 per cent, levies that would decimate trade between the two countries.
Goldman earlier predicted a 20 per cent tariff on Chinese goods as its base case, although how Trump may roll out the levies remains uncertain.

title: DBS’ Piyush Gupta sees US as global growth engine in 2025 but warns of headwinds
summary:
SINGAPORE – Outgoing DBS Bank chief executive officer Piyush Gupta expects the US to remain as a global growth engine but warns of three potential headwinds that could lead to a market correction.
Mr Gupta delivered his last opening address on Jan 13 at the DBS Private Bank Market Outlook for the first quarter of 2025.
If so, it makes sense for investors to buy US equities even though they are expensive, as earnings are coming through, Mr Gupta added.
“So I think the US should do generally well, but I still see a lot of choppiness, a lot of volatility,” Mr Gupta said.
Indonesia’s outlook is uncertain, though long-term growth is projected at around 5 per cent, Mr Gupta said.

title: Global electric vehicle sales up 25% in 2024
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxIncentives and emission targets pushed EV sales in China and aided Britain in overtaking Germany as Europe’s biggest battery-electric market in 2024.
Incentives and emission targets pushed electric vehicle (EV) sales in China and aided Britain in overtaking Germany as Europe’s biggest battery-electric market in 2024, research firm Rho Motion said.
Sales in China jumped 36.5 per cent to 1.3 million vehicles in December and totalled 11 million for the whole of 2024.
In the US and Canada, EV sales rose 8.8 per cent to 190,000 in December, while Europe reported sales of 310,000 , up 0.7 per cent from the same month of 2023.
In the rest of the world, December sales rose by 26.4 per cent.

title: Rolling US tariffs would be ‘problematic’ for Fed, says UBS
summary:
Money market are pricing just one Fed rate reduction in 2025 with progress towards lower US inflation essentially stalled.
– A decision by US President-elect Donald Trump to ramp up tariffs gradually once he takes office would be “problematic” for the Federal Reserve as it battles the last-mile of inflation, according to Dr Arend Kapteyn at UBS.
Dr Kapteyn said he did not believe that the risk of higher US tariffs was priced in by financial markets.
That will potentially support a go-slow approach by the Fed after it cut rates three times in 2024 .
Mr Hatzius said US tariffs are unlikely to have a “huge impact” on inflation and growth.

title: Starbucks limits use of cafes, bathrooms to paying customers
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxStarbucks’ new rules represent a pivot from a policy set in 2018 that allowed anyone to linger in its cafes.
– Starbucks reversed a policy allowing anyone, even those who had not purchased anything, to use its cafes, patios and restrooms.
Baristas will be trained on how to enforce the guidelines and can ask those who violate the rules to leave, Starbucks said.
Customers may use the restroom or connect to the Wi-Fi before approaching the counter to make a purchase, according to the company.
Starbucks’ new rules represent a pivot from a policy set in 2018 that allowed anyone to linger in its cafes.

title: Crypto firm Tether and its founders moving to El Salvador
summary:
– Cryptocurrency firm Tether plans to move its headquarters to El Salvador, its chief executive said, as the founders of the world’s biggest stablecoin look to capitalise on the Central American country’s bid to become a hub for crypto trading.
Mr Ardoino, his fellow managers and co-founders of Tether will also move their residences to El Salvador, he said.
“This move to El Salvador will be the first time we’re going to also have a physical headquarters,” he said.
“So we have some liquidity in other banks, but the vast, vast majority of the T-bills (Treasury bills) are in Cantor,” Mr Ardoino said.
In a separate post on Jan 13, Mr Bukele asked Rumble chief executive Chris Pavlovski to consider moving the headquarters of the video-sharing platform to El Salvador.

title: Siloam expresses intent to acquire First Reit’s Indonesia hospital portfolio
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSiloam is the existing operator and tenant of First Reit's hospital assets in Indonesia, including Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta.
SINGAPORE – The manager of First Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) said on Jan 13 that it received a preliminary non-binding letter of intent (LOI) from Siloam International Hospitals to acquire the Reit’s portfolio of hospital assets in Indonesia.
The board of First Reit’s manager will conduct a strategic review to assess the LOI and explore all strategic options for the trust, the manager said in a bourse filing.
First Reit has 15 properties in Indonesia, comprising 11 hospitals, two integrated hospitals and malls, one integrated hospital and hotel and one hotel and country club.
Its Indonesian healthcare properties are operated by Siloam, a private healthcare player listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange.

title: GIC investment chief to step down from Singapore sovereign wealth fund, say sources
summary:
SINGAPORE – GIC’s chief investment officer (CIO) Jeffrey Jaensubhakij plans to step down after almost three decades at one of the world’s biggest sovereign wealth funds, according to people familiar with the matter.
“GIC considers key appointments very carefully and will announce changes in a timely manner,” a GIC spokesperson said in an e-mail statement .
While it does not reveal its assets under management, GIC is estimated to oversee US$800.8 billion (S$1.1 trillion), making it the seventh-largest sovereign wealth fund, according to the Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute (SWFI).
He also spoke at major events such as the World Economic Forum in Davos as one of the sovereign wealth fund’s primary representatives.
Mr Yeo will have spent exactly one year as deputy group CIO when he takes over from Dr Jaensubhakij.

title: Trump team studying gradual tariff hikes of 2% to 5% per month: Sources
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxPresident-elect Donald Trump's tariff threats are already driving up longer-term borrowing costs around the world.
- Members of US President-elect Donald Trump’s incoming economic team are discussing slowly ramping up tariffs month by month, a gradual approach aimed at boosting negotiating leverage while helping avoid a spike in inflation, according to people familiar with the matter.
A spokesman for Trump’s transition team referred to the President-elect’s previous public comments and social media posts about tariffs.
That has left a complicated picture for the Federal Reserve because Trump’s tariff threats are seen as a risk to the growth outlook while potentially stoking inflation if nations retaliate.
International Monetary Fund managing director Kristalina Georgieva said tariff threats are already driving up longer-term borrowing costs around the world.

title: Nasdaq closes lower, S&P 500 up slightly as US yields stay elevated
summary:
Comments from Fed officials have pushed bond yields higher.
The S&P 500 had weekly losses in four of the last five weeks.
“The inflation issue is out there and higher yields in general aren’t great for either the bond market or really the stock market.
CVS Health and Humana also jumped as the S&P 500 health care sector rose.
Moderna plummeted as the biggest decliner on the S&P 500 after slashing its 2025 sales forecast by US$1 billion (S$1.37 billion).

title: HR professionals prepare for changes due to workplace fairness Bill
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Workplace Fairness Bill makes it unlawful for firms to employ workers based on their age, race and other criteria.
SINGAPORE - Human resources (HR) groups have given their thumbs-up for the landmark Bill tackling workplace discrimination that was passed in Parliament on Jan 8 , giving workers greater protection against biases on grounds like age, race and nationality.
The legislation will prohibit retaliation – such as dismissals, salary deductions or harassment – against staff who report workplace discrimination.
For instance, its workplace mental well-being playbook is designed to give actionable guidance, in the form of case studies, experts’ insights and illustrations, to help organisations support employees’ mental well-being at the workplace.
HR groups and professionals The Straits Times spoke with said they are preparing for changes internally, which include plans to conduct training for HR teams.

title: Tax breaks and special zones for foreign firms: How Tokyo is transforming into a global green finance hub
summary:
This year, FinCity hosted Tokyo Sustainable Finance Week for the first time as part of Japan Weeks, highlighting the importance the government is placing on sustainable finance.
“Sustainable finance plays a vital role in advancing our sustainability initiatives.
LINESFrom slow starter to global leaderMr Takada recalls that when he joined the OECD Green Finance Team in 2015, sustainable finance was still an emerging concept in Japan.
“At that time, relatively few people in Japan even knew the concept of sustainable finance and Japan was a slow starter.
“Foreign companies looking to relocate to Japan stand to gain unparalleled access to a thriving ecosystem of innovation in sustainable finance,” says Mr Takada.

title: Asset managers upbeat on Asian markets, see opportunities for digital, private assets in S’pore: Survey
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMost Singapore fund managers say they are upbeat on the global economic outlook.
SINGAPORE - Fund managers here are generally positive about the long-term outlook of Asian economies and financial markets despite an increasingly fragmented global order shaped by geopolitical tensions and China’s tepid economy.
In Singapore, some see growth opportunities in digital and private assets in 2025.
Additionally, 48 per cent pointed to private assets, while 17 per cent highlighted environmental, social and governance (ESG) investments as key drivers.
Imas chief executive Carmen Wee told ST on Jan 13 that investment managers in the Republic are adapting to shifts in investor preferences as demographics evolve and millennial investors seek innovative and alternative products.

title: Singapore stocks fall amid regional rout; STI down 0.3%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Straits Times Index fell 0.3 per cent or 9.86 points to 3,791.70.
SINGAPORE – Stocks in Singapore fell on Jan 13 as investors digested stronger-than-expected US employment numbers, which dimmed expectations of interest rate cuts.
The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3 per cent or 9.86 points to 3,791.7 points.
Both the South Korean Kospi and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index shed 1 per cent, and the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) fell 1.1 per cent.
Thai Beverage led the index’s losses, falling 2.7 per cent or 1.5 cent to 53.5 cents.

title: PropertyGuru names Lewis Ng as new CEO as Hari Krishnan steps down
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxMr Lewis Ng (left) will return to the company and succeed Mr Hari Krishnan as CEO from March 2025.
SINGAPORE – PropertyGuru’s chief executive officer and managing director Hari Krishnan is stepping down as CEO of the group after a decade in this role.
In a statement on Jan 13, Mr Krishnan said that “the time is right to pursue new interests and for the company to transition to new leadership”.
Mr Lewis Ng will return to the company and succeed Mr Krishnan as CEO from March.
Mr Krishnan will then transition to the role of senior adviser to the board.

title: British PM vows AI will usher in ‘golden age’
summary:
“I am determined to harness it to usher in a golden age of public service reform,” Mr Starmer wrote in the Financial Times ahead of a speech.
‘Economic mismanagement’The government plans include the creation of “dedicated AI growth zones” designed to speed up planning proposals for data centres and other AI infrastructure.
However, the Conservative opposition pointed out that Mr Starmer previously axed a supercomputer project in Edinburgh planned by the previous government.
Mr Starmer’s administration estimated that AI could be worth £47 billion (S$78.3 billion) to the UK each year over a decade.
Mr Starmer has put firing up Britain’s economy at the heart of his agenda since taking office in July 2024.

title: SingPost’s fired CEO Vincent Phang resigns from board
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSingPost had asked Vincent Phang, its former CEO, to resign as a director of SingPost and all its related companies.
SINGAPORE - The former group chief executive of Singapore Post (SingPost), Vincent Phang, has resigned from his role as a non-executive, non-independent director with effect from Jan 12, the mainboard-listed group announced on Monday.
This comes after Mr Phang, former group chief financial officer Vincent Yik, and former chief executive of SingPost’s international business unit Li Yu were fired by SingPost on Dec 21.
The company had also asked Mr Phang to resign as a director of SingPost and all its related companies.
In a joint statement after their employment was terminated, Mr Phang and Mr Yik said they “categorically reject any suggestion that we were grossly negligent, had behaved inappropriately or had sought to misrepresent facts at any point”.

title: iPhone loses global market share with Apple AI absent in China
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe iPhone slipped a point to 18 per cent market share in 2024.
– Apple sold fewer iPhones and lost ground to Chinese rivals in 2024, reflecting the absence of Apple Intelligence in its largest market outside the US.
The iPhone slipped a point to 18 per cent market share in 2024, according to Counterpoint Research data.
Arch-rival Samsung Electronics also gave up share to faster-growing Android device makers from China, led by Xiaomi and Vivo.
“Apple’s iPhone 16 series was met with a mixed response, partly due to a lack of availability of Apple Intelligence at launch,” Counterpoint director Tarun Pathak said.

title: NUS tokenises green bond data in pilot with Northern Trust and UOB
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe green bond reporting token is part of a broader strategy to explore how blockchain technology can enhance green finance practices.
Under the pilot, Nasdaq-listed Northern Trust will mint and hold a green bond reporting token using its digital assets platform.
The digital token will hold the environmental impact reporting data from NUS’ third green bond that was issued in 2023.
The pilot will focus on ensuring data integrity to provide investors with confidence that the environmental impact reporting data is secure, immutable and reliable , NUS said.
The green bond reporting token is the first step in NUS’ broader strategy to explore how blockchain technology can enhance green finance practices through a three-year agreement signed with Northern Trust in November 2024.

title: China exports hit record in 2024 with front-loading ahead of looming Trump tariffs
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe value of Chinese shipments rose almost every month in 2024, pushing it above the highs of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Exports rose 10.7 per cent to US$336 billion (S$462 billion) in December 2024, according to a statement from the Customs Administration on Jan 13.
Imports rose 1 per cent in December 2024 , leaving an unprecedented trade surplus of US$992 billion for 2024.
The value of shipments rose almost every month in 2024 , pushing it above the highs of the Covid-19 pandemic.
But this may be one of the last high points for Chinese trade, at least directly with the US, with Trump promising to impose even higher tariffs on Chinese goods when he takes office next week.

title: US tech giant Apple fails to block S. Korean firm from registering ‘Wapples’ trademark in S’pore
summary:
SINGAPORE – US technology giant Apple has failed in its bid to block a South Korean security systems company from registering “Wapples” as a trademark in Singapore.
On Dec 3, 2021, South Korean information technology (IT) security company Penta Security filed an application in Singapore to register the trademark “Wapples”.
Products under the “Wapples” trademark were developed to protect web applications and application programming interfaces, or APIs, from unauthorised access and cyber attacks.
“When a common word in the English language is incorporated into an invented word, what is the impact on public perception?
She added: “(Wapples) is an invented word, and is, on its own merit, distinctive and dominant as a whole.

title: Oil jumps as new US sanctions set to curb Russian supply to China, India
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe new US sanctions included producers Gazprom Neft and Surgutneftegas, as well as 183 vessels that have shipped Russian oil.
Brent and WTI have risen by more than 6 per cent since Jan 8, and both contracts surged after the US Treasury imposed wider sanctions on Russian oil on Jan 10.
The new sanctions included producers Gazprom Neft and Surgutneftegas, as well as 183 vessels that have shipped Russian oil, targeting the revenue Moscow has used to fund its war with Ukraine.
Many of the tankers named in the latest sanctions have been used to ship oil to India and China as previous Western sanctions and a price cap imposed by the Group of Seven countries in 2022 shifted trade in Russian oil from Europe to Asia.
Some of the ships have also moved oil from Iran, which is also under sanctions.

title: Global air finance summit to take stock of jet shortages, tariff threat
summary:
– Financiers and lessors who make the global air travel industry tick gathered for an annual meeting in Dublin on Jan 13, buoyed by strong lease rates and relatively stable oil prices but facing uncertainty over jet shortages and trade tensions.
For now, that means good profits for lessors and many airlines, since shortages push up demand and fares.
But there are concerns over access to efficient new aircraft as supply chains lack parts and labour.
Trump has promised to impose sweeping tariffs, which some analysts think could affect the supply chains of the aerospace and other industries while dampening air cargo demand.
In India, the world’s fastest-growing air travel market, the rupee hit a record low on Jan 10.

title: Grand Venture Technology, A*Star to develop manufacturing platform for advanced ceramics
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGrand Venture Technology said the tie-up with A*Star will help it snag opportunities in high-growth industries.
SINGAPORE – Grand Venture Technology (GVT) and A*Star will be working together to develop a customised manufacturing platform for advanced ceramics.
In December 2024, GVT was selected as a preferred supplier for advanced semiconductor packaging equipment by a global semiconductor assembly and packaging equipment manufacturer.
It is used in advanced semiconductor chips that support applications, such as those in data centres and artificial intelligence.
The company is also positive on the growth of the advanced packaging market.

title: Global bond tantrum is a wrenching and worrisome start to 2025
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxGlobal bond yields have soared even after the Federal Reserve embarked on rate cuts — a jarring disconnect that has few precedents in recent history.
– For those unsettled by the relentless rise in government bond yields in the US and across much of the world lately, the message from markets is getting clearer by the day: Get used to it.
Just days into 2025, yields on US government debt are surging as the risks to supposedly super-safe assets mount.
A number of Wall Street banks on Jan 10 trimmed their forecasts for 2025 cuts in the wake of strong jobs data.
The continued pricing out of Fed rate cuts in 2025 only compounds the poor performance of US government bonds compared with riskier assets such as stocks.

title: Apple’s board recommends shareholders vote against proposal to eliminate diversity programmes
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxApple said the shareholder proposal was an inappropriate attempt to micromanage its business strategy.
Apple’s board of directors recommended investors vote against a shareholder proposal to abolish the company’s diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) programmes, according to a proxy filing from the company.
The National Centre for Public Policy Research, a conservative think-tank, submitted a proposal that the company consider abolishing its “inclusion and diversity programme, policies, department and goals”.
It added that the shareholder proposal was an inappropriate attempt to micromanage Apple’s business strategy.
Several major companies, including Meta and Amazon, are winding down diversity programmes ahead of Republican Donald Trump’s return to the US presidency as conservative opposition to such initiatives grows louder.

title: How Trump came around to crypto – and what crypto wants in return
summary:
In December 2024, Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek met Trump at Mar-a-Lago to discuss crypto industry appointments and regulations.
Trump was once sceptical of digital assets, saying Bitcoin “seems like a scam” and that crypto’s value was “based on thin air”.
What does the crypto industry want from Trump?
The crypto industry is also looking for specific legal language on what exactly crypto is and how the industry should operate legally, which could reduce worries of lawsuits from government agencies.
Advocates would also welcome having crypto assets classified as commodities rather than securities, which would then make them fall under the remit of the CFTC.

title: US stocks plunge on solid jobs report
summary:
WASHINGTON - Wall Street stocks plummeted on Jan 10, on the back of a strong employment report that fueled expectations the central bank might make fewer interest rate cuts this year.
The slide across major indexes came after a Department of Labour report showed the world’s biggest economy adding 256,000 jobs in December.
Following the report, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note shot up, before moderating its gains.
Investors took the better-than-expected labor market figures “as a sign” that the Federal Reserve would be slower in reducing interest rates, said Mr Sam Stovall, of CFRA.
“January will continue to be a volatile month,” Mr Stovall said, citing interest rate worries and traders’ focus on earnings reports.

title: Securities turnover value on SGX up 5% in December despite lower market volume
summary:
December’s total market volume, however, fell 15 per cent to 19.4 billion shares, from 22.7 billion shares clocked for the corresponding month in 2023, the bourse operator’s monthly market statistics report showed.
December’s securities daily average value stood flat year on year at $954 million, although the securities daily average volume was down by 19 per cent at 922 million shares.
The STI’s standout showing comes after years of a stagnant Singapore market with low liquidity.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore has set up an equities market review group in a bid to revive the local market.
The FTSE Taiwan Index Futures’ volume rose 11 per cent for 2024 to 18.6 million contracts, as investments in artificial intelligence boosted Taiwan’s equities market, which is heavily dependent on technology and semiconductor industries.

title: Adani Wilmar to become subsidiary of Wilmar International after share sale
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxSingapore Exchange-listed Wilmar International could own as much as 75 per cent of Adani Wilmar after the share sale.
The move will see Adani Wilmar, one of India’s largest retailers of cooking oil, rice and pulses, become a subsidiary of Singapore Exchange-listed Wilmar International.
Adani Wilmar, a joint venture between Adani Group and Wilmar International, is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange and National Stock Exchange of India.
The Singapore company could own as much as 75 per cent of Adani Wilmar after the share sale, compared with 44 per cent now, making Adani Wilmar its subsidiary.
Based on his valuation forecasts, Wilmar International shares could be worth as much as $3.54 in the next 12 months.

title: Singapore banks reverse midweek gains; STI down 1.6% ahead of US jobs data
summary:
SINGAPORE – Local investors were scrambling for leads on Jan 10 after Wall Street was closed overnight to mark former US president Jimmy Carter’s memorial.
The closure came a day ahead of crucial US jobs figures that will determine the trend of interest rates, so the air of drift and uncertainty was especially acute.
The outcome here left the Straits Times Index (STI) down a chunky 1.6 per cent or 61.04 points to 3,801.56, with the banks taking a major hit.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding lost 3.5 per cent to $3, after falling 5 per cent by the midday break.
Australian shares lost 0.4 per cent with banks again the biggest losers on cautious trade ahead of those US employment numbers.

title: Banks are poised to get a boost from Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone: Observers
summary:
SINGAPORE – Banks in Singapore and Malaysia will reap significant benefits from the new Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), noted Maybank executive Thilan Wickramasinghe.
He noted on Jan 7 that Singapore banks have been integrating their wholesale and retail banking operations on a regional scale over the past five years or so.
Malaysia will set up an infrastructure development fund, while Singapore will design funding support to help local companies expand into the JS-SEZ.
The economic zone could also offer opportunities for businesses in Singapore to establish complementary operations in Johor, all of which will generate more business for banks, Mr Wickramasinghe said.
HSBC has also named banks in both countries as key beneficiaries of the JS-SEZ.

title: China halts bond buying to defend yuan as economic gloom worsens
summary:
The central bank will pick a time to resume buying depending on market conditions, it added.
Benchmark bond yields had slumped to an all-time low, driven by bets on aggressive policy easing to reignite a sluggish economy and demand for haven assets.
The move reflects “the authorities’ discomfort with plummeting government bond yields and increasing yuan depreciation pressure”, said Mr Ken Cheung, chief Asian foreign-exchange strategist at Mizuho Bank.
“This marks another move by the PBOC to support the yuan exchange rate,” said Ms Serena Zhou, an economist with Mizuho Securities Asia.
China government bond yields rose across the curve following the statement, with the five-year rate climbing eight basis points and 10-year rate gaining four basis points to 1.675 per cent.

title: Fu Yu’s largest shareholder requisitions EGM to oust directors amid poor performance
summary:
Mr Lim, who owns some 29.45 per cent of Fu Yu shares, called for the meeting as he believes a “strategic reset” and reorganisation of the board are needed amid the company’s “poor performance”.
Fu Yu manufactures precision plastic and metal components.
“Since the election of Huang and Tan to the board, substantial shareholder value has been erased,” said Mr Lim in his letter on Jan 9.
If the three resolutions are approved, the trio will be designated as independent non-executive directors of the company, said Mr Lim.
In response to his letter, Fu Yu said the board will convene an EGM in due course and provide further updates to shareholders when there are material developments.

title: Simplicity needed to untangle insurer Income’s Gordian knot
summary:
This axiom can be applied to the Gordian knot that seems to bind home-grown Income Insurance.
The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) set up its first cooperatives in 1970 – the insurer NTUC Income and NTUC Comfort, a taxi cooperative.
Former NTUC Income chief Tan Kin Lian, whose tenure lasted 30 years from 1977 to 2007, said NTUC Income was “financially weak” when he took over.
Despite this, the agents were happy as sales were brisk because premiums of Income’s products were 10 per cent cheaper than its competitors’.
DBS sold its insurance business, Insurance Corporation of Singapore (ICS), in 2001.

title: Wall Street bonuses to jump by double digits at biggest banks
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxWall Street banks are expected to pay their traders bigger bonuses this year.
At Morgan Stanley and larger rival JPMorgan Chase & Co, bonuses will rise more than 10 per cent for traders, people familiar with their deliberations said.
And for JPMorgan’s investment bankers, bonuses will rise roughly 15 per cent.
The raises follow two years of industrywide restraint as investment banks struggled to maintain the flurry of trading and dealmaking they handled at the height of the coronavirus pandemic.
When times are good, individual windfalls can stretch into millions of dollars – multiples of what bankers and traders might reap from salaries.

title: US Fed officials signal interest rates likely on hold for a while
summary:
– Several Federal Reserve officials confirmed the US central bank will likely hold interest rates at current levels for an extended period, only cutting again when inflation meaningfully cools.
Boston Fed president Susan Collins said on Jan 9 that a slower approach to adjusting interest rates is merited now as officials confront “considerable uncertainty” over the US economic outlook.
Kansas City Fed president Jeff Schmid said interest rates may already be close to a level that neither stimulates nor slows the economy.
She said her outlook for interest rates was consistent with the median projection officials released after the Fed’s December meeting, which pointed to two quarter-point reductions in 2025 .
“I still see us on a downward policy rate path.

title: Transformers toymaker Bloks jumps 82% in HK after frenzy over IPO
summary:
HONG KONG – Shares of Bloks Group, the popular Chinese maker of Ultraman and Transformers figurines, surged 82 per cent in their Hong Kong trading debut after the company’s US$215 million (S$294 million) initial public offering (IPO) drew overwhelming demand from individual investors.
Shanghai-based Bloks opened at HK$109.60 a share, compared with its IPO price of HK$60.35.
The frenzy over Bloks – demand from mom-and-pop investors was thousands of times higher than the number of shares reserved for them – builds on the popularity of Chinese toy companies lately.
The share price of Pop Mart International Group, which counts Blackpink’s Lisa as a fan of its Pucky Roly Poly Kitty toys, quadrupled last year.
“There is certainly a positive halo around the games and general entertainment space,” Mr Benjamin Harburg, managing partner at Magic Stone Alternative Investment, said of the demand for Bloks shares.

title: Retailers fall, hit by rising investor concerns about UK economy
summary:
Other retailers also slumped with sausage roll-seller Greggs down as much as 11 per cent after highlighting concerns about weak consumer confidence.
J Sainsbury, which will report its Christmas sales figures on Jan 10, fell about 4.5 per cent.
Concerns over the strength of the UK economy and fiscal plans by UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves are growing, with the UK among the hardest hit by a rout in global bond markets this week, driven by investor concerns over levels of public debt.
Retailers have been particularly hard hit by Reeves’ budget as they face a big increase in staff salaries.
Not even solid performances from Tesco, which hit its highest market share since 2016, and M&S, whose food arm had its biggest one-day sales record this Christmas, could offset wider market concerns.

title: Sats and WFS clinch 14 new cargo and ground handling contracts from Air India
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Sats group landed these contracts in a global tendering process, which also saw Air India renew 11 existing contracts with Sats and WFS.
The Sats group landed these contracts in a global tendering process, which also saw Air India renew 11 existing contracts with Sats and WFS.
The new cargo handling and ground handling stations are in North America, the UK, Europe and Asia, “significantly” expanding Air India’s partnership with Sats and WFS, the group noted.
Mr Ramesh Mamidala, head of cargo at Air India, said streamlining Air India’s logistics processes and enhancing service levels across passengers and cargo were key to the airline’s ongoing transformation.
“By strengthening our partnership with Sats and WFS, we look forward to delivering a world-class operation for our customers around the world.”

title: Uniqlo owner reports strong growth in all markets but China
summary:
Cooler winter weather in Japan boosted clothing sales and stronger brand recognition pushed up overseas sales, Fast Retailing said.
The results show the company is on track to establish strong footholds for sales growth in new markets , in addition to Japan and China where it currently makes the majority of its revenue .
For China, where sales and profit declines extended into the latest quarter, the company is closing under-performing stores and revamping bigger and better-located outlets to drive sales.
The stock jumped 54 per cent in 2024 while the benchmark Topix index rose 18 per cent.
The main challenges are China sales and the company’s limited ability to reduce discounts and address stock shortages across all regions, said Ms Chelsey Tam, an equities analyst at Morningstar Inc. BLOOMBERG

title: Deft at blending AI with design practices? This Singapore-based venture capitalist firm wants you
summary:
The newly launched Design AI and Tech Awards (Daita) has a fresh backer – multi-asset investment firm Granite Asia, which is offering all finalists a golden ticket to its network and consultation hours with its senior managing partner Jenny Lee.
Said BT’s Ms Chen: “Granite Asia’s dedication to supporting innovation aligns with the award’s mission to celebrate outstanding design and technology solutions that address real-world challenges.
“We are confident that its support will empower shortlisted companies, unlocking new opportunities and driving further innovation.”There are three award categories: product design, system design and spatial design.
The nine finalists will gain access to venture capital (VC) firm Granite Asia’s events, masterclasses and networking opportunities, and the final three will land additional consultation hours.
With assets under management totalling US$5 billion, the firm has investments in 48 companies with valuations exceeding US$1 billion.

title: China’s consumer prices weaken further, adding to deflation worries
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxChina in December made boosting consumption and domestic demand the top priority in 2025, for only the second time in at least a decade.
The consumer price index (CPI) edged up 0.1 per cent in that month from a year earlier, in line with the median forecast of economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
“Improvement in domestic demand is a necessary condition for reflation,” Citigroup economists Ji Xinyu and Yu Xiangrong said in a note.
For the full year, consumer prices inched up only 0.2 per cent from 2023, well short of the 1.1 per cent gain economists had predicted at the beginning of 2024.
Officials led by President Xi Jinping in December made boosting consumption and domestic demand the top priority in 2025, for only the second time in at least a decade.

title: Singapore shares fall on signs of Fed’s tight reins on rate cuts; STI down 0.6%
summary:
Sign up now: Get ST's newsletters delivered to your inboxThe Straits Times Index slipped 0.6 per cent or 24.38 points to 3,862.6.
SINGAPORE – Signals that the US Federal Reserve will be keeping a tight rein on rate cuts in 2025 had a dampening effect on shares here and across the region on Jan 9.
The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.6 per cent, or 24.38 points, to 3,862.6, with losers beating gainers 281 to 222 on modest trade of 982.3 million shares worth $913.1 million.
The ASX 200 in Sydney snapped a five-day winning streak to drop 0.2 per cent despite data showing Aussies splashed out over the Black Friday sales.
UOB senior economist Alvin Liew said he expects a pause in interest rate cuts in the January meeting as the Fed “takes stock of the inflation and growth outlook under the new Trump administration”.
